plants.soil: Warm, fertile, and well drained.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors 6 weeks before last spring frost, or buy seedlings in late spring. Transplant to larger pots if needed. Plant out in late spring, when the weather is settled and warm.
plants.frostTolerant: A semi-tropical plant; cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: From midsummer onward, drench with a liquid feed every two weeks.
plants.notes: Stake plants to keep them from falling over when they become heavy with fruit. Mulch to keep soil lightly moist.
plants.harvesting: Use secateurs to cut fruits from the stem. Perfect fruits have shiny skins and only a few immature seeds inside.
plants.companions: Beans, Pepper, Catnip, Marigold and Tarragon.
plants.troubleshooting: Use cloches to keep plants warm. Remove covers when plants begin blooming so the starry purple flowers can be pollinated by bees.

plants.soil: Rich soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil in early summer or under cover in pots.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Plants raised in a greenhouse or under cover will have softer leaves. Pinch off flower buds as they appear to keep the plant productive.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves a few at a time to keep the plant cropping.
plants.companions: Tomato, Pepper, Purslane and Lettuce.

plants.soil: Good, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil in rows. Early sowings should be protected by cloches or raised under cover in modules.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Support plants in windy places. Dig in roots when finished cropping as these return nitrogen to the soil.
plants.harvesting: Harvest before the pods become tough. Often get a second crop.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Brussels Sprouts, Broccoli, Calabrese, Cauliflower, Celery, Carrot, Sweetcorn, Potatoes, Nasturtium and Lovage.

plants.soil: Rich soil, well-drained but with plenty of organic matter to retain moisture.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in mid spring or direct into ground from late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Rarely required.
plants.notes: Strong supports needed for climbing varieties. Supply plenty of water to the roots from flowering through to harvest.
plants.harvesting: Pick pods young before they get stringy.
plants.companions: Sweetcorn, Sunflower, Squash, Rosemary and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Rich soil, well-drained with plenty of organic matter to retain moisture.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover or cloches in early-mid spring or direct into soil if later.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Rarely required.
plants.notes: Strong supports needed for climbing varieties. Supply plenty of water to the roots from flowering through to harvest.
plants.harvesting: Pick young beans regularly and the plants will continue to crop.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Beetroot, Strawberry and Potatoes.

plants.soil: Rich soil. Well-drained light but deep soil preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid-spring, at about the time apple trees bloom. Sow autumn crops in mid to late summer. Thin seedlings to at least 10cm (4 in) apart to grow large roots.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Rarely required.
plants.notes: Each seed is actually a small cluster of seeds, so space well and may require thinning. Be careful not to damage the beet when weeding. Young leaves are also a colourful addition to salads. Liable to bolt (run to seed) if sown too early, though some varieties are resistant to this.
plants.harvesting: Harvest young leaves for salad greens as you thin young plants. Pull roots when they become plump. To keep through winter, harvest plants, cut off the tops, and keep in a cool cellar or refrigerator.
plants.companions: Beans, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, Calabrese, Cabbage, Lettuce, Onion and Onions.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow mid to late spring, either direct into soil or in pots to plant out later if clubroot disease is a problem in your soil. Firm down well when planting out. For green summer broccoli, see 'Calabrese'.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. May need supportive canes during the winter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest the next winter/spring by cutting off the large central head first before it starts to flower. Smaller side shoots should then be produced for harvesting a few weeks later.
plants.companions: Oregano, Cauliflower, Calabrese and Cabbage.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow early spring under cover. Plant out early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed in mid to late summer.
plants.notes: Unless using a self-blanching type, will need to be planted in trenches, then tubes wrapped round in mid summer and/or earthed up with soil. Keep moist during dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Can cut frequently if required. In any case harvest before the first frost in autumn.
plants.companions: Chives, Garlic, Nasturtium, Cauliflower, Calabrese, Cabbage, Tomato and Lovage.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best but will grow in most locations.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil from early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Cut leaves as required.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best but will grow in most locations.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil from early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water well in dry periods.
plants.harvesting: Roots can be lifted throughout winter.
plants.companions: Chives.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow early or mid spring in pots or protected seed bed. Plant out when thumb height.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, improves with frost.
plants.feeding: Mix a high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. May need supportive canes during the winter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from the bottom of the plant upward, twisting off sprouts that are larger than a marble. Removing nearby leaves helps to make room for growing sprouts.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Buckwheat, Calendula, Carrot, Chamomile, Dill, Mint, Nasturtium, Onion, Onions, Rosemary, Sage, Potatoes and Agastache.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid spring either direct into soil or in pots to plant out later if clubroot disease is a problem in your soil.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: When heads begin to form, feed with a liquid plant food.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from mid summer onwards by cutting off the large central head first before it starts to flower. Smaller side shoots should then be produced for harvesting a few weeks later.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Mint, Sage, Cauliflower, Calabrese, Cabbage, Agastache, Thyme and Dill.

plants.soil: Light, deep, well-drained soil which has not had compost or manure added recently (to avoid forked roots forming.)
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil under cloches from late winter or without protection from mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Light frost tolerant.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Slugs love young carrot seedlings so protect early started plants. Thin out when the seedlings are large enough to handle if they are too close (best done in damp evenings to prevent carrot fly). Cover with mesh or fleece to deter carrot fly. Weed carefully during early stages.
plants.harvesting: Can be harvested over a long period, although if left in ground over winter they may split attracting slugs.
plants.companions: Chives, Potatoes, Leek, Lettuce, Rosemary, Sage, Tomato, Onion, Onions, Salsify, Cabbage, Peas and Mangetout.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow mid to late spring, either direct into soil or in pots to plant out later if clubroot disease is a problem in your soil. Firm down well when planting out.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mix composted manure or another high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting. When heads begin to form, feed with a liquid plant food.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. Bend over a few leaves if required so that the cauliflower head is kept shaded while it is forming.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the head has fully developed, but before the curd becomes loose, with a "ricey" appearance.
plants.companions: Oregano, Tomato, Celery, Dill, Sage and Mint.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots in mid spring. Plant out after last frosts.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fornightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: One or two plants is plenty - they will produce lots of cougettes over a season.
plants.harvesting: Harvest before the cougettes get too big and turn into marrows. This encourages more cougettes to grow.
plants.companions: Nasturtium and Zinnia.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots in mid spring. Plant out after last frosts.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fornightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: Support plants well so they can climb upwards, even when the cucumbers get large. This also protects the cucumbers from slugs. Occasionally a plant can produce very bitter cucumbers so always test a bit before serving to others!
plants.harvesting: Cut the cucumbers off the plant when they are still quite young, otherwise the skin becomes hard and will need peeling. More cucumbers will then be produced.
plants.companions: Dill, Tansy, Nasturtium, Oregano, Radish, Lettuce, Sunflower, Borage and Beans.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be frost tolerant, depending on species.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with rich compost in spring or autumn. Additional feeding requirements varies depending on species.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Some flowers can be added to salads, make good herbal teas, or can be harvested for use in cut or dried flower arrangements.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: Best grown from cloves, planted direct into holes, pointed end up in late autumn or late winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Many varieties require a cooler period with temperatures under 10 degrees celcius for the first one or two months.
plants.harvesting: Dig up bulbs in summer when leaves start to turn yellow. Clean them and let them dry out over a few days before storing.
plants.companions: Tomato, Apple, Apricot, Plum, Cherry, Pear, Peach, Raspberry, Redcurrant and Gooseberry.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for winter weeds. Plants left in the ground too long often have loose bulbs that do not store well.

plants.soil: Most herbs can be grown in otherwise poor soil but it should be well drained and free of weeds.
plants.position: Sunny to shady, dependent on herb.
plants.sowPlant: Usually sow direct into soil in late spring. Perennial herbs need lifting and dividing in autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Some types are partially frost tollerant but most are not.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Just a small area will usually provide more than enough, unless growing for decorative reasons or using them to attract beneficial insects to the garden. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required, a few leaves at a time. Can be dried by hanging a bunch in a dry place although some flavour is lost when dried.

plants.soil: Good soil, firm, preferably with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in spring. Plant out when thumb sized.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. May need supportive canes during the winter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves gradually from the centre of each plant while they are still tender. New leaves will grow and harvesting can extend from late autumn/fall right through to the next spring.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Chamomile, Catnip, Tansy, Thyme, Buckwheat, Nasturtium, Marigold, Cabbage, Brussels Sprouts, Broccoli, Calabrese, Cauliflower and Agastache.

plants.soil: Requires rich, loamy soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in early to mid spring. Plant out when the soil is warm. Alternatively, sow directly into weed-free ground in late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: In late summer while the weather is still warm, drench plants thoroughly with a water-soluble plant food.
plants.notes: When leeks are almost the size you prefer, blanch them for 2 to 3 weeks by putting a mound of soil, mulch, or a cardboard tube around the base of each stem. Grows best in areas where nights remain cool through summer.
plants.harvesting: Can be left in the ground until required and harvested right through autumn, winter and early spring.
plants.companions: Carrot, Celery and Strawberry.

plants.soil: Most soil types but best if it's moisture retentive with some dug in compost.
plants.position: Semi-shade, a cool sunny spot or inter-planted between other crops.
plants.sowPlant: Early planting can be done under cover in modules or under cloches outside. Continue sowing outside every few weeks for a continous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Early sowings are easily attacked by slugs and snails, so may be best in containers. Thin out to give plenty of room for each plant to grow. In hot summer conditions lettuce can bolt (produce flower heads) and becomes tough and a little bitter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves as required over a number of weeks.
plants.companions: Garlic, Beetroot, Dill, Chives, Basil, Carrot, Strawberry, Radish, Spinach, Lettuce, Cabbage, Spring Onion, Onion, Onions and Poached Egg Plant.
plants.troubleshooting: Shallow lettuce roots need constant moisture. Do not allow the soil to dry out.

plants.soil: Most soil types but best if it's moisture retentive with some dug in compost.
plants.position: Semi-shade, a cool sunny spot or inter-planted between other crops.
plants.sowPlant: Early planting can be done under cover in modules or under cloches outside. Continue sowing outside every few weeks for a continous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Early sowings are easily attacked by slugs and snails, so may be best in containers. Thin out to give plenty of room for each plant to grow. In hot summer conditions lettuce can bolt (produce flower heads) and becomes tough and a little bitter.
plants.harvesting: When the heart of the lettuce feels firm pull the whole plant up and cut off the roots. Harvest in the morning when the leaves are cool and full of moisture.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Dill, Chives, Basil, Carrot, Strawberry, Radish, Spinach, Cabbage, Spring Onion, Onion, Onions and Poached Egg Plant.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of added compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in mid spring and plant out in early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed from mid summer onwards.
plants.notes: Tie upright types to canes with string to support the weight of the fruit. Remove side shoots which grow in the angle between the leaf stems and the main stem of the plant.
plants.harvesting: Pick regularly as soon as the fruits are ripe. This encourages production of more tomatoes.
plants.companions: Marigold, Basil, Garlic, Borage, Mint, Chives, Monarda, Nasturtium, Asparagus, Carrot, Celery, Cucumber, Onion, Onions, Parsley, Pepper, Poached Egg Plant and Calendula.
plants.troubleshooting: Blossom end rot patches on the bottom of fruits are a nutritional disorder best prevented by growing tomatoes in well-prepared soil with constant light moisture. Yellow leaves indicate lack of magnesium, so apply liquid feed.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Easiest to sow onion sets (tiny bulbs) which are planted direct into the soil from autumn onwards. Can also be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late winter before planting out mid-late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required, though overwintered sets can be given a liquid feed in spring.
plants.notes: Japanese variety onion sets can be used to give an early harvest. Onion sets are also the better choice for heavier or wetter soils.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Chamomile, Carrot, Lettuce, Strawberry, Tomato, Garlic, Spring Onion and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.notes: Other plants requiring up to 10cm (4in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

Other plants requiring up to 25cm (10in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

Other plants requiring up to 50cm (20in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

plants.soil: Light, deep, well-drained soil which has not had compost or manure added recently (to avoid forked roots forming.)
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil when it has warmed up from mid spring onwards. Takes a couple of weeks to germinate.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Thin out when the seedlings are large enough to handle if they are too close. Weed carefully during early stages. Cover with mesh or fleece if carrot fly has been a problem in the past, although parsnips are less susceptible to this.
plants.harvesting: Use a garden fork to loosen soil along outside of the planting before pulling roots. Can be left in the soil through winter in many areas.
plants.companions: Onion, Onions, Radish, Spring Onion and Potatoes.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start peas off under cover in early spring in a length of old guttering as this makes it easy to tip them into their final planting site. Or sow directly into the soil once it has warmed up in late spring. Sow in batches for a continuous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required, although a mulch of compost, grass clippings or other organic matter can help on poor soils.
plants.notes: Support plants with a strong row or wigwam structure over which netting can be tied for them to climb up. Alternatively, use twiggy sticks pushed into the ground near each plant.
plants.harvesting: Best picked just before eating, often sweet enough to enjoy raw.
plants.companions: Chives, Mint, Alyssum, Carrot, Sweetcorn, Cucumber, Radish, Turnip and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Mature plants usually stop producing and die back in hot summer weather.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.position: Sheltered sunny position or under cover.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in early spring. Transfer to bigger pots as required. If planting out then do so from mid spring when soil has warmed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed once the plant is a reasonable size.
plants.notes: Sometimes require supports if the peppers are large.
plants.harvesting: Harvest peppers green when they have grown to a good size or wait for them to ripen to yellow or red if preferred.
plants.companions: Basil, Oregano, Carrot, Tomato and Marjoram.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil with plenty of compost dug in is best but will grow in most positions.
plants.sowPlant: Grow from seed potatoes. Chit them by leaving on cardboard or eggboxes in a light position until they have produced short green sprouts. Plant out in early to mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: As shoots appear, draw soil over them if there is still a possibility of frost. Once the shoots are hand height, earth them up by drawing more soil around them leaving the top of the shoots still showing to keep the actual potatoes covered. If any potatoes get exposed to light and turn green they should not be eaten. Make sure potatoes are kept watered in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: The earliest potatoes can be harvested when the plants begin to flower. Once the foliage has wilted harvest the main crop within a couple of weeks, digging in from the side to avoid damaging the tubers.
plants.companions: Basil, Marigold, Peas, Squash, Aubergine, Sage, Beans, Coriander and Horseradish.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil with plenty of compost dug in is best but will grow in most positions.
plants.sowPlant: Grow from seed potatoes. Plant out in early to mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: As shoots appear, draw soil over them if there is still a possibility of frost. Once the shoots are hand height, earth them up by drawing more soil around them leaving the top of the shoots still showing to keep the actual potatoes covered. If any potatoes get exposed to light and turn green they should not be eaten. Make sure potatoes are kept watered in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Once the foliage has wilted harvest the main crop within a couple of weeks, digging in from the side to avoid damaging the tubers.
plants.companions: Basil, Horseradish, Marigold, Peas, Squash, Beans, Aubergine and Coriander.

plants.soil: Almost any soil with good drainage.
plants.position: Sunny for spring and autumn sowings, light-shade for summer sowings.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the ground, protecting with a cloche if cold weather is expected.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: A really good crop for growing inbetween others, especially as it grows to maturity so quickly.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as the root has developped to a usable size, while taste and texture are still good.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Lettuce, Peas and Mangetout.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Grown from a crown (root) which can be split from a healthy plant and planted out, usually in mid winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but leaves and shoots die back.
plants.feeding: Mulch with extra compost each year after the leaves have died down.
plants.notes: Early sweet stems can be produced by forcing and blanching the rhubarb: in mid winter to early spring add dry material such as leaves or straw and cover with a deep container or bucket to exlude light for about one month.
plants.harvesting: Do not harvest during the first year of growth. After this, pull a few of the thicker sticks when long enough. Stop harvesting in early summer and allow plants to grow freely for the rest of the season.
plants.companions: Strawberry.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Sun or partial shade. A cooler, shady position in summer.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards or under cover for an earlier sowing in mid-late winter. Can also sow in early autumn for a winter crop.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop that doubles as a cooked green. Flower buds are also edible. Hot weather causes leaves to become very strongly flavored.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in small batches as required. Once it flowers the leaves become tougher and hotter in taste.
plants.companions: Beans, Dill, Lettuce, Mint, Nasturtium and Thyme.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles sometimes make small holes in leaves.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture retentive soil which has had compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in late winter, planting out in early spring, or direct into the soil from then on using cloches for protection if required.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, survives winter with mulch in milder areas.
plants.feeding: Not needed for spring crops grown in rich soil, but older plants benefit from feeding with a liquid feed in spring, when they show vigorous new growth.
plants.notes: Keep well watered. Hot or dry conditions can make it bolt (run to seed) which reduces production of usable leaves considerably. Sow another crop in late summer/early autumn.
plants.harvesting: Pick a few leaves at a time to allow the plant to continue producing more.
plants.companions: Celery, Cauliflower, Aubergine, Strawberry and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Slow growth and yellowing leaves indicate nutritional stress. Drench with a water soluble plant food.

plants.latinName: Cucurbita pepo,  C. moschata, C. maxima
plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots in mid spring. Transfer to larger pots if necessary. Plant out in late spring when no danger of frost.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fortnightly liquid feed from mid summer onwards.
plants.notes: Towards the end of the summer raise the squash off the ground by putting a piece of wood or similar under them to prevent rotting. Water roots generously in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: When the plant starts to die cut off the squash leaving part of the stalk attached. Allow the skin to harden in the sun for a few days if wanting to store them in a frost-free place.
plants.companions: Sweetcorn, Marigold, Beans, Nasturtium and Lemon Balm.

plants.soil: Well-drained rich soil with compost dug in, slightly acidic preferred.
plants.position: Sunny for best ripening, although will grow in partial shade.
plants.sowPlant: Can be raised from seed but most people use new plants, or produce their own from runners which existing plants put out during summer. Usually need to be planted by autumn for a crop the following year, although good bought-in plants can be planted in spring and still produce a crop.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardy, though plants go dormant from late fall to early spring.
plants.feeding: In autumn and again in early spring, topdress established plants with rich compost or an organic fertiliser. Allow plants to rest in midsummer.
plants.notes: Can be used as a ground cover beneath grapes or apple trees, or managed as a perpetual bed. In late summer, remove weeds and withered leaves, and thin runners to no more than 3 per plant. Lift and transplant extra runners.
plants.harvesting: Gather ripe fruits in the morning, when they are cool, and refrigerate immediately. Wash in cool water just before eating.
plants.companions: Borage, Lettuce, Thyme, Onion, Onions, Garlic, Beans and Nigella.
plants.troubleshooting: Slugs can be deterred with straw mulch or traps. Use jamjars or netting to protect ripening berries from birds.

plants.soil: Will grow in most good soils.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil in late spring or early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Cold weather can improve flavour and texture.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water well in dry periods.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in autumn when the swede is well developed. In milder areas can be left in the ground until mid winter, otherwise lift and store them in boxes of sand.
plants.companions: Onion, Onions, Peas and Mangetout.

plants.soil: Rich soil best but will grow in most places.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the ground in mid spring onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Keep well watered in dry seasons.
plants.harvesting: Pull a few leaves from the outside of the plant regularly from mid summer onwards.
plants.companions: Beans, Cabbage, Broccoli, Calabrese, Cauliflower, Brussels Sprouts, Onion and Onions.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of added compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in mid spring and plant out in early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed from mid summer onwards.
plants.notes: Tie upright types to canes with string to support the weight of the fruit. Remove side shoots which grow in the angle between the leaf stems and the main stem of the plant.
plants.harvesting: Pick regularly as soon as the fruits are ripe. This encourages production of more tomatoes.
plants.companions: Basil, Garlic, Nasturtium, Asparagus, Carrot, Celery, Cucumber, Onion, Parsnip, Pepper, Borage, Chives, Monarda, Onions and Calendula.
plants.troubleshooting: Blossom end rot patches on the bottom of fruits are a nutritional disorder best prevented by growing tomatoes in well-prepared soil with constant light moisture. Yellow leaves indicate lack of magnesium, so apply liquid feed.

plants.soil: Any reasonably fertile well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Early sowings can be under cover in late winter and planted out under cloches in early spring. Otherwise sow direct into soil from mid spring to mid summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, survives mild frosts, can protect with straw.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Keep watered in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Can be harvested from late summer onwards. Lift main crop in mid autumn and store to prevent them becoming woody in texture.
plants.companions: Peas, Lettuce and Winter Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Spring crops bolt to seed quickly, so pull them when the roots are perfect.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best but will grow in most locations.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil from early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water well in dry periods.
plants.harvesting: Roots can be lifted throughout winter.
plants.companions: Salsify.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in late winter to plant out in early spring. Or sow direct into ground from mid spring onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from early spring to early summer.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Thyme, Chamomile, Catnip, Rosemary, Sage, Tomato, Celery, Nasturtium, Tansy and Agastache.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid-late summer and transplant to final positions in early to mid autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Wait until a few light frosts have passed to harvest, because cool weather enhances the sweet flavour of cabbage.
plants.companions: Marigold, Nasturtium, Mint, Sage, Thyme, Onions and Garlic.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots in mid spring. Plant out after last frosts.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fornightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: Basically the same as cougettes but left longer to produce fewer larger fruit. Seeds are removed before eating.
plants.harvesting: Harvest before the cougettes get too big and turn into marrows. This encourages more cougettes to grow.
plants.companions: Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Start mangetout off under cover in early spring in a length of old guttering as this makes it easy to tip them into their final planting site. Or sow directly into the soil once it has warmed up in late spring. Sow in batches for a continuous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Support plants with a strong row or wigwam structure over which netting can be tied for them to climb up. Alternatively, use twiggy sticks pushed into the ground near each plant.
plants.harvesting: Pick whole pods regularly while still young and not stringy.
plants.companions: Chives, Mint, Sweetcorn, Cucumber, Radish, Turnip, Alyssum and Beans.

plants.latinName: Cucurbita pepo,  C. moschata, C. maxima
plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots in mid spring. Transfer to larger pots if necessary. Plant out in late spring when no danger of frost.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fortnightly liquid feed from mid summer onwards.
plants.notes: Towards the end of the summer raise the pumpkins off the ground by putting a piece of wood or similar under them to prevent rotting. Water roots generously in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: When the plant starts to die cut off the pumpkins leaving part of the stalk attached. Allow the skin to harden in the sun for a few days if wanting to store them in a frost-free place.
plants.companions: Sweetcorn, Melon, Squash, Beans, Monarda, Oregano and Lemon Balm.

plants.soil: Warmed, well-drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in mid spring and plant out in early summer. Alternatively sow direct under cloches in late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Plant in blocks of at least 9 plants, all the same variety, to encourage pollination by the wind. Often planted with squash as they like similar conditions. Keep well watered in dry spells.
plants.harvesting: Harvest just before eating to get the sweetest taste, when the tassles at the top of the cobs turn brown to black. You can peel back the leaves and check the corn: if they ooze milky sap when pressed with a fingernail then they are ready.
plants.companions: Dill, Marigold, Sunflower, Beans, Cucumber, Melon, Peas, Squash and Pumpkin.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, use raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Easiest to sow as sets (tiny bulbs) which are planted direct into the soil from early winter onwards. Can also be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late winter before planting out mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Used instead of onions for an earlier crop and concentrated flavour.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from mid summer as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Chamomile, Carrot, Strawberry, Tomato, Lettuce and Cabbage.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Chives, Garlic, Onions and Lavender.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Chives, Garlic, Onions, Parsnip and Lavender.

plants.soil: Rich, well drained, with plenty of compost added.
plants.position: Full sun or partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Best raised from buying or splitting off shoots which arise from the roots of mature plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, survives mild frosts, can protect with straw or fleece.
plants.feeding: Can apply weekly liquid feed in summer if necessary.
plants.notes: Need plenty of water so they benefit from having a layer of mulch such as well rotted compost around them to retain moisture.
plants.harvesting: Use a sharp knife to cut the heads (flower buds) with 2 inches of stem attached while they are still closed or justly slightly opening.
plants.companions: Peas, Mangetout and Hairy Vetch.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained, and free of persistent weeds.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Set out dormant 1-year old roots, called crowns, in late winter or early spring. A few varieties can be grown from seed.
plants.frostTolerant: Long-lived hardy perennial. Beds can produce for decades.
plants.feeding: Mulch with 5cm (2 in) of rich compost or rotted manure every winter.
plants.notes: After the stems die back in early winter, cut them off at ground level and compost them. Remove weeds, apply compost and mulch, and your yearly maintenance is done.
plants.harvesting: Begin gathering spears the second year after planting, cutting all spears that appear for a month in early spring. In subsequent years, harvest for 6 weeks each spring.
plants.companions: Calendula, Tomato, Marigold and Petunia.
plants.troubleshooting: Cutting new shoots just below the surface often helps control problems with asparagus beetles, which often lay their eggs on tender shoots near the soil line.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. Prefers a pH of 6.
plants.sowPlant: Buy plants or use offshoots from an existing plant and cut them to 15cm (6 in) after planting.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required but if leaves start to yellow then add a liquid feed.
plants.notes: Need supporting on wires or tied against a fence. Train the briars onto wire supports from 1m (3ft) high and above. Each autumn add some compost.
plants.harvesting: Pick over a long season as ripe.
plants.companions: Pear, Cherry and Almond.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be frost tolerant, depending on species.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with rich compost in spring or autumn. Additional feeding requirements varies depending on species.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Some flowers can be added to salads, make good herbal teas, or can be harvested for use in cut or dried flower arrangements.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be frost tolerant, depending on species.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with rich compost in spring or autumn. Additional feeding requirements varies depending on species.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Some flowers can be added to salads, make good herbal teas, or can be harvested for use in cut or dried flower arrangements.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be frost tolerant, depending on species.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with rich compost in spring or autumn. Additional feeding requirements varies depending on species.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Some flowers can be added to salads, make good herbal teas, or can be harvested for use in cut or dried flower arrangements.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: In spring mulch around the root area with compost and then grass clippings or other organic mulch.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. You can add a variety of this tree to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potasium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges. In spring mulch around the root area with compost and then grass clippings or other organic mulch.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe.
plants.troubleshooting: May need to protect fruit from birds with netting, or just allow for losing some fruit.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: After harvesting cut the canes down to ground level, leaving any new shoots.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe. Can protect with netting if birds are eating them but make sure that the plant doesn't grow through the netting making it difficult to remove.
plants.companions: Garlic and Rye.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Can be started off early under cover in modules which are then planted out but usually sown direct into position.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water in dry conditions and keep weed free.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required when they reach a usable size.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Carrot, Strawberry, Tomato, Swiss Chard and Cabbage.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Large trees are usually already well established.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches.

plants.soil: Any reasonably fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Set out tubers in spring, planting them 10cm (4 in) deep. Plants grow quite tall, and can be used to shade heat-sensitive neighbors.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes. Plants die back to the roots in winter.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Can be invasive, so use flowers indoors as cut flowers to reduce reseeding.
plants.harvesting: Harvest tubers from late autumn as required. Make sure all tubers are removed from soil by end of season.
plants.companions: Beans, Cucumber and Rhubarb.
plants.troubleshooting: Powdery mildew often affects plants in late summer, but does not impact yields.

plants.soil: Average, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds 5cm (2 in) deep and 8cm (3 in) apart in late spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm. Make additional sowings until midsummer.
plants.frostTolerant: Warm-season annuals, cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Can mix compost or an organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: The pods of many dry beans can be eaten as runner beans when very young.
plants.harvesting: Gather pods when they dry to tan. Allow the harvested beans to dry indoors for one to two weeks before storing in a cool, dry place. Most varieties produce all at once.
plants.companions: Celery, Sweetcorn, Cucumber, Potatoes, Rosemary and Strawberry.
plants.troubleshooting: Pods that come into contact with soil are prone to rot. Mulch to prevent this problem.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow late summer to move to final positions in autumn to be over-wintered and ready for spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf colour and type. Most early-maturing cabbage varieties produce smallish heads.
plants.harvesting: Harvest early plants or leave to mature to a firm 'heart' until early summer.  Small secondary heads often grow from the base of early cabbage plants after the primary head is cut.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Thyme, Chamomile, Catnip, Rosemary, Sage, Celery, Nasturtium, Tansy and Agastache.
plants.troubleshooting: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid-late summer and transplant to final positions in early to mid autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed plants with a liquid plant food when they begin to form heads.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Keep soil moist in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from early spring to early summer.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Nasturtium, Sage, Lettuce, Kale, Mustard, Mizuna, Tatsoi and Endive.
plants.troubleshooting: Slugs can be a problem.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow early spring under cover. Plant out early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed monthly with a liquid organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Keep moist during dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from late autumn through to spring - can be left in the soil over winter if required.
plants.companions: Spinach, Lettuce, Peas and Mangetout.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil in early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Can be forced and blanched by replanting in a deep soil-filled box in a warm place during winter.
plants.harvesting: Can run to seed if sown too early.
plants.companions: Endive, Mizuna, Tatsoi and Mustard.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.position: Sun or partial shade. A cooler, shady position in summer.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards or under cover for an earlier sowing in mid-late winter. Can also sow in early autumn/fall for a winter crop.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in small batches as required.
plants.companions: Carrot, Turnip, Leek, Cabbage and Viola.

plants.soil: Almost any soil type.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards or indoors during winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required while seedlings are still small.
plants.companions: Chives and Mint.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.position: Sun preferred but tolerant of some shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil in late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Can blanch a few plants at a time when they are grown by excluding light from them for a few days. This can make them less bitter.
plants.harvesting: Havest as required by cutting off at base. Will sometimes resprout.
plants.companions: Chicory, Mizuna, Tatsoi and Mustard.

plants.soil: Rich, well draining, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors, or sow in shallow furrows filled with potting soil. Thin seedlings to 30cm (12 in) apart when they are 3 weeks old. Chop the pulled seedlings into salads.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings are frost tender, but mature plants tolerate light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed every 3 weeks with a liquid organic fertiliser, and use a rich, biodegradable mulch such as grass clippings.
plants.notes: When the bulb is the size of an egg, surround it with 6 inches of loose mulch to help it plump up and slightly blanch it.
plants.harvesting: Snip tender young leaves as needed in the kitchen. When the bulbs reach 8cm (3 in) in diameter, pull them and store in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Mint.

plants.soil: Rich soil, light textured with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in early spring either direct into soil or in pots to plant out later.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil but can still benefit from organic compost mixing in before planting.
plants.notes: Not as affected by cabbage root fly as other members of the brassica family. May require fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves but usually matures quickly enough for this not to be a problem.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from mid summer onwards when roots are up to tennis ball size to prevent the texture becoming 'woody'.
plants.companions: Beans, Beetroot, Celery, Cucumber, Lettuce, Potatoes and Onion.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards or under cover for an earlier sowing in mid-late winter. Can also sow in early autumn/fall for a winter crop.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates extreme cold when well rooted.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in small batches as required.
plants.companions: Carrot, Turnip, Leek, Cabbage and Viola.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds that threaten to overtake the small plants.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best but will grow in most locations.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil from early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Cut leaves as required.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots in mid spring then plant out once all danger of frosts is past.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Keep moist by watering regularly. Pinch out the growing tip once the plant has made three leaves and do the same to side shoots as they appear.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit as soon as it feels slightly soft when the ends are pressed.
plants.companions: Sweetcorn, Pumpkin, Radish, Squash, Marigold, Nasturtium, Oregano and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds early and then mulch to avoid trampling the vines after fruits have set.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil from early to late summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: May need to protect under mesh or fleece to prevent problems with flea beetle. Keep soil moist in dry weather to prevent bolting (running to seed.)
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Mustard, Kale, Endive, Tatsoi, Dill, Mint and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Rich, well draining, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Soak seeds in water overnight before planting them 2cm (1 in) deep and 15cm (6 in) apart in warm soil after last frosts. Thin to proper spacing after two weeks.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Requires warm temperatures to give a good yield. Wear gloves if handling the plants when wet gives you an allergic reaction.
plants.harvesting: Pick pods young while they are still small.
plants.companions: Sunflower.
plants.troubleshooting: Ants sometimes damage okra blossoms.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid-late summer and transplant to final positions in early to mid autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Keep soil moist in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from early spring to early summer.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Nasturtium, Sage, Lettuce, Mustard, Kale, Endive, Tatsoi and Mizuna.

plants.soil: Well-drained, reasonably good soil, though will tolerate a variety of sites.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in late spring, planting out when all risk of frost past or direct into the soil from then onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Requires very little attention. Soak seeds in water overnight before planting to improve germination.
plants.harvesting: Pull a few leaves from the outside of the plant regularly from mid summer onwards to produce more growth.
plants.companions: Strawberry, Peas and Beans.

plants.soil: Rich soil best but will grow in most places.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the ground in mid spring onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Keep well watered in dry seasons.
plants.harvesting: Pull a few leaves from the outside of the plant regularly from mid summer onwards.
plants.companions: Asparagus.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots in mid spring. Plant out after last frosts.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fornightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: One or two plants is plenty - they will usually produce several squash over a season.
plants.harvesting: Harvest regularly when the squash are not too large; this encourages more to grow.
plants.companions: Sweetcorn, Cucumber, Melon, Pumpkin, Marigold, Oregano, Nasturtium, Borage and Lemon Balm.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best, but can adapt to any fertile, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant 'slips' that grow from sprouting tubers in late spring or early summer, after the soil is very warm.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Mix a good organic compost into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Sweet potatoes form a dense green ground cover, thriving in hot summer conditions. Tubers are often found 12 inches or more from the plant's primary crown, so dig carefully.
plants.harvesting: Dig in autumn when the soil is still warm. Cure in a warm, airy place for two weeks before storing at cool room temperatures.
plants.companions: Beans, Parsnip and Beetroot.
plants.troubleshooting: Deer are fond of sweet potato vines.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.position: Sunny position preferred, tolerant of some shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, will freeze well.
plants.companions: Marigold.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. Acidic pH of 5 to 5.5 required.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe.
plants.companions: Cranberry.

plants.soil: Will grow on relatively poor soil as long as it is well drained and compost is dug in. pH of 6.5 to 7 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well rotted compost annually.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to three buds. Vines can gradually be trained up a support system.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, thinning a few out beforehand to allow others to swell.
plants.companions: Chives and Agastache.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in to retain moisture. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, or a little before if heavy crop produced.
plants.companions: Marigold, Tansy and Tomato.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in to retain moisture. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, will freeze well.
plants.companions: Marigold.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, will freeze well.
plants.companions: Marigold.

plants.soil: Moist soil preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Usually sow direct into soil in late spring. Alternatively, divide plants in autumn or early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Lift the clumps every three years and divide them.
plants.harvesting: Cut back as required - this encourages new growth.
plants.companions: Carrot, Apple, Garlic, Onion, Onions, Grape Vine and Beetroot.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil amended with compost.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in individual containers, or sow seeds outdoors 1cm (half an inch) deep and 5cm (2 in) apart. Gradually thin seedlings to proper spacing, and eat your thinnings. Older seedlings are difficult to transplant successfully.
plants.frostTolerant: Can tolerate mild frost.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.harvesting: Can harvest leaves, or leave to flower and produce seeds which can be ground.
plants.companions: Potatoes, Basil, Mint and Tansy.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil amended with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in individual containers, or sow seeds outdoors 1cm (half an inch) deep and 5cm (2 in) apart. Gradually thin seedlings to proper spacing, and eat your thinnings. Older seedlings are difficult to transplant successfully.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings may need protection from light frosts.
plants.feeding: Drench with a liquid organic fertiliser when plants are 10cm (4 in) tall.
plants.notes: Dill flowers and seeds are used in making breads and pickles.
plants.harvesting: Gather and dry leaves when plants are 25cm (10 in) tall. Use a paper bag to harvest seeds when they change from green to tan and fall freely from their umbels.
plants.companions: Cucumber, Sweetcorn, Lettuce and Zinnia.
plants.troubleshooting: Large plants may be blown over by gusty storms. Stake if necessary.

plants.soil: Well-drained but moist soil preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Usually sow direct into soil in mid spring or raise in pots to plant out.
plants.frostTolerant: Some types are partially frost tolerant but most are not.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Pick leaves as required from mid summer.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required, a few leaves at a time. Can be dried by hanging a bunch in a dry place although some flavour is lost when dried.
plants.companions: Oregano, Thyme and Pepper.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil where mint's wandering tendencies can be kept in check.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Mint is also easy to root from stem tip cuttings stuck into moist potting soil. Some strains are propagated only from cuttings rather than seeds.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy even in cold areas. If desired, small plants can be potted up in autumn and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Spearmint or peppermint are the most versatile strain for cooking.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Rocket, Cabbage, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, Calabrese, Broccoli, Coriander, Lavender, Marjoram and Agastache.
plants.troubleshooting: Often becomes invasive. If possible, grow near paths, driveways, or other hard surfaces, or in containers buried halfway in the ground.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil in an easily accessible site.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Some strains are propagated only from cuttings. Authentic Greek oregano can be grown from seeds or plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy in cold areas provided plant is well-rooted and mulched. If desired, small plants can be potted up in autumn and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Some strains are grown for their pretty pink flowers. Oregano often spreads in hospitable spots. Moderately invasive.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Tomato, Pepper, Marjoram and Squash.
plants.troubleshooting: Control oregano's spread by cutting back flowering stems when their colours fade.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds in early spring, and keep moist. Parsley germinates slowly. Or, start with young purchased plants. Take care not to disturb the roots when transplanting parsley.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food monthly.
plants.notes: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food monthly.
plants.harvesting: Try both curled and flat-leafed or Italian parsley, which has stronger flavour. Plants that survive winter will bloom first thing in spring.
plants.companions: Asparagus, Sweetcorn and Tomato.

plants.soil: Well drained soil with compost dug in.
plants.position: Sun preferred but will grow in most positions.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, keeping in mind that growth habit varies with variety. Trailing rosemary for walls, or dwarf varieties for containers, are propagated by rooting stem cuttings rather than from seeds. Wild Mediterranean rosemary can be grown from seeds or plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Where winters are mild, rosemary can grow into huge, shrub-like plants.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Trailing rosemary is great cascading over a wall.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying from spring to late summer.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Carrot, Sage and Beans.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors in early spring. Plants started from seed may not bloom their first year.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy through mild frosts. In colder areas, small plants can be potted up in fall and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: One-year-old plants nursed through winter produce beautiful blue flowers. Sage grown in containers can be kept in a cold garage through winter.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying from spring to autumn.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Cucumber, Tomato and Rosemary.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants are often short-lived, so root a few stem cuttings each spring to always have vigorous young plants.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased plants, or start seeds indoors in early spring. Good culinary thyme can be grown from seed, but some creeping forms are propagated only from rooted cuttings or divisions.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardy. Becomes dormant from fall to spring.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: Creeping forms make sturdy ground covers. Bees are attracted to pink thyme flowers.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in summer, before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Rocket, Brussels Sprouts, Cabbage, Cauliflower, Kale, Sage, Strawberry, Ageratum, Dianthus, Portulaca and Dahlia.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants are often short-lived, so root a few stem cuttings each spring to always have vigorous young plants.

plants.soil: Rich, well drained, with plenty of compost added.
plants.position: Full sun or partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors 8 weeks before last spring frost, or buy rooted divisions in spring. Set out at about the time of the last frost.
plants.frostTolerant: Short-lived perennial where winters are mild, but often grown as an annual in climates with warm days and cool nights.
plants.feeding: Keep well fed with liquid feed through midsummer. Feed less when plants begin to produce buds.
plants.notes: Need plenty of water, so mulch generously to keep the soil cool and moist.
plants.harvesting: Use a sharp knife to cut the heads (flower buds) with 2 inches of stem attached while they are still closed or justly slightly opening.
plants.companions: Peas and Hairy Vetch.
plants.troubleshooting: Artichokes grow best in cool, maritime climates, but a few plants are worth trying in any garden.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly in the soil in early spring, or start indoors and set out seedlings. Arugula also makes a fine fall crop, and plants often survive winter with a protective mulch.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates light frosts and moderate freezes.
plants.feeding: Not generally required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop that doubles as a cooked green. Flower buds are also edible. Hot weather causes leaves to become very strongly flavored.
plants.harvesting: Harvest young leaves as you need them for cooking. The flower buds and flower petals also are edible.
plants.companions: Beans, Dill, Lettuce, Mint, Nasturtium and Thyme.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles sometimes make small holes in leaves.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained, and free of persistent weeds.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Set out dormant 1-year old roots, called crowns, in late winter or early spring. A few varieties can be grown from seed.
plants.frostTolerant: Long-lived hardy perennial. Beds can produce for decades.
plants.feeding: Mulch with 2 inches of rich compost or rotted manure every winter.
plants.notes: After the stems die back in early winter, cut them off at ground level and compost them. Remove weeds, apply compost and mulch, and your yearly maintenance is done.
plants.harvesting: Begin gathering spears the second year after planting, cutting all spears that appear for a month in early spring. In subsequent years, harvest for 6 weeks each spring.
plants.companions: Tomato, Marigold, Calendula and Petunia.
plants.troubleshooting: Cutting new shoots just below the surface often helps control problems with asparagus beetles, which often lay their eggs on tender shoots near the soil line.

plants.soil: Rich soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot that is convenient for quick picking.
plants.sowPlant: Make a late spring planting of seedlings started indoors or purchased. In summer, after the soil is warm, sow more basil wherever you want it to grow.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Cover transplants with flowerpots to shade them from strong sun for 2 days or so. To keep new leafy branches coming on, pinch off the upright flower spikes as they appear.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves a few at a time as you need them in the kitchen. In midsummer, cut plants back by half to stimulate new growth, and make big batches of pesto with the trimmings.
plants.companions: Tomato, Pepper and Lettuce.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants that slowly wilt to death and show a dark ring on their stems near the soil line are infected with fusarium wilt.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to very light shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds 2 inches deep and 6 inches apart in late spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm. Make additional sowings until midsummer.
plants.frostTolerant: Warm-season annuals, cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Mix an organic fertilizer into the soil before planting, using rates given on the label. Supplemental fertilizer seldom required.
plants.notes: Bush beans are among the easiest vegetables to grow; highly recommended for first-time gardeners. Also can be used as a warm-weather cover crop to boost soil nitrogen levels.
plants.harvesting: Gather pods before they fill with seeds. When picked often, many varieties continue to produce for up to a month.
plants.companions: Beet, Marigold, Carrot, Celery, Swiss Chard, Corn, Cucumber, Peas, Potatoes, Strawberry, Radish and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Japanese beetles and Mexican bean beetles sometimes damage leaves and pods. Gather them in broad containers of soapy water in the cool of the morning.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to very light shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds 2 inches deep and 6 inches apart in late spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm. Install a sturdy trellis before you plant your pole beans.
plants.frostTolerant: Warm-season annuals, cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Mix an organic fertilizer into the soil before planting, using rates given on the label. Supplemental fertilizer seldom required.
plants.notes: Mulch to keep the soil cool and moist, and to reduce problems with weeds.
plants.harvesting: Gather pods before they fill with seeds. When picked often, pole beans continue to produce all summer.
plants.companions: Sunflower, Corn and Rosemary.
plants.troubleshooting: Japanese beetles and Mexican bean beetles sometimes damage leaves and pods. Gather them in broad containers of soapy water in the cool of the morning. During very hot weather, pole beans may temporarily stop producing new flowers and pods.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds 2 inches deep and 4 inches apart two weeks or more after the last frost has passed. Grow pole varieties in warm climates, but stick with faster-maturing bush varieties where summers are short.
plants.frostTolerant: Warm-season annuals, cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Mix an organic fertilizer into the soil before planting, using rates given on the label. Supplemental fertilizer seldom required.
plants.notes: Lima beans need plenty of hot weather. They are most productive in warm climates.
plants.harvesting: For fresh eating, gather pods when they feel well-filled with seeds, and are slightly leathery. Limas for dry storage can be left on the plants until they change from green to tan.
plants.companions: Corn.
plants.troubleshooting: Slow growth due to cool temperatures is common, but pest problems are rare. Lima beans are easy to grow in warm climates.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds 2 inches deep and 3 inches apart in late spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm. Make additional sowings until midsummer.
plants.frostTolerant: Warm-season annuals, cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Mix an organic fertilizer into the soil before planting, using rates given on the label. Supplemental fertilizer seldom required.
plants.notes: The pods of many dry beans can be eaten as snap beans when very young.
plants.harvesting: Gather pods when they dry to tan. Allow the harvested beans to dry indoors for one to two weeks before storing in a cool, dry place. Most varieties produce all at once.
plants.companions: Celery, Corn, Cucumber, Potatoes, Strawberry, Catnip, Rosemary and Lettuce.
plants.troubleshooting: Pods that come into contact with soil are prone to rot. Mulch to prevent this problem.

plants.soil: Good, well-drained soil.
