plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil in rows. Use blankets or cloches to protect seedlings from hard freezes.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Support plants in windy places. Dig in or compost roots and plants to make good use of their residual nitrogen.
plants.harvesting: Harvest before the pods become tough. Often get a second crop.
plants.companions: Carrot, Celery, Corn, Lettuce, Potatoes, Nasturtium, Lovage, Cabbage, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, Broccoli and Kale.

plants.soil: Rich, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid-spring, at about the time apple trees bloom. Sow fall crops in mid to late summer. Thin seedlings to at least 5 inches apart to grow large roots.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Rarely required.
plants.notes: Each seed is actually a multi-celled capsule, so you may need small scissors to thin plants to proper spacing. Weed carefully, and mulch between plants to deter weeds. Baby beet greens often are included in salad mixes.
plants.harvesting: Harvest young leaves for salad greens as you thin young plants. Pull roots when they become plump. To keep through winter, harvest plants, cut off the tops, and keep in a cool root cellar or refrigerator.
plants.companions: Beans, Cabbage, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, Broccoli, Kale, Garlic, Onions and Onion.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost, composted manure, or balanced organic fertilizer dug in prior to planting.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors in early spring, and set out while the soil is still cool. Sow fall broccoli indoors in summer, and set out when the plants are 3 weeks old.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mix composted manure or another high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting. When heads begin to form, feed with a liquid plant food.
plants.notes: Broccoli that matures in cool fall weather has an especially tender texture with sweet flavor to match.
plants.harvesting: Use a sharp knife to harvest the primary head when the beads are plump and well-filled. Many varieties produce numerous smaller side shoots after the primary head is cut.
plants.companions: Oregano, Cabbage, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, Broccoli, Kale and Crimson Clover.
plants.troubleshooting: Cabbageworms are small green larvae of the cabbage white butterfly. You can use row covers to keep them from eating plants.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in to provide abundant organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Where summers are cool, start indoors in early spring and set plants out when they have 5 or more leaves. In other areas, start seeds indoors in summer and set out plants 8 weeks before your first fall frost date.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, improves with frost.
plants.feeding: Mix a high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Under the coldest conditions, colonies of gray-green cabbage aphids can seriously infest plants. Control early outbreaks with insecticidal soap.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from the bottom of the plant upward, twisting off sprouts that are larger than a marble. Removing nearby leaves helps to make room for growing sprouts.
plants.companions: Beet, Buckwheat, Calendula, Carrot, Chamomile, Dill, Marigold, Mint, Nasturtium, Onion, Onions, Rosemary, Sage, Thyme, Potatoes and Agastache.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in prior to planting.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors in early spring, or set out purchased seedlings.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes. Tolerates moderate frost, but damaged by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Drench every two weeks with an organic liquid fertilizer.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf color (such as red cabbage) and type (smooth-leaf or savoy).
plants.harvesting: Cut heads when they reach the size you prefer.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Thyme, Chamomile, Nasturtium, Garlic, Tansy, Broccoli, Kale, Cauliflower, Cabbage, Sage, Oregano, Agastache and Marigold.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split. Watch for green imported cabbageworms, the larvae of the cabbage white butterfly. Exclude the adults with row covers.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in prior to planting.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in summer for harvesting in the fall.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes. Tolerates moderate frost, but damaged by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Drench every two weeks with an organic liquid fertilizer.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf color (such as red cabbage) and head shape. Late-maturing fall cabbage varieties are great for cool storage or making into kraut.
plants.harvesting: Wait until a few light frosts have passed to harvest, because cool weather enhances the sweet flavor of cabbage.
plants.companions: Marigold, Nasturtium, Tomato, Celery, Catnip, Rosemary, Sage and Mint.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split. Watch for green imported cabbageworms, the larvae of the cabbage white butterfly. Exclude the adults with row covers.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in prior to planting.
plants.sowPlant: Sow late summer to move to final positions in fall to be over-wintered and ready for spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Should tolerate moderate frost.
plants.feeding: Drench every two weeks with an organic liquid fertilizer.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf color and type. Most early-maturing cabbage varieties produce smallish heads.
plants.harvesting: Cut heads when they reach the size you prefer. Small secondary heads often grow from the base of early cabbage plants after the primary head is cut.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Rosemary, Sage, Thyme, Garlic, Onions and Agastache.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for green imported cabbageworms, the larvae of the cabbage white butterfly. Exclude the adults with row covers.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in spring while the soil is still cool. Plant again in late summer for harvesting in the fall.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed plants with a liquid plant food when they begin to form heads.
plants.notes: Water often to keep the soil constantly moist.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the heads reach the size you want. In fall, cut heads high, leaving the base of the plant intact. Small heads will often regrow from the stub.
plants.companions: Basil, Celery, Dill, Garlic, Mint, Nasturtium, Potatoes, Rosemary, Thyme, Onions, Beans and Agastache.
plants.troubleshooting: Slugs can be a problem. Trap them with beer traps, hand pick them in rainy weather, or spray them with caffeinated coffee.

plants.soil: Well drained soil rich in organic matter, but with no manure added prior to planting. Use well aged compost or vermicompost to condition compacted soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil in spring. Make a second sowing for a fall crop in mid to late summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Tops tolerate light frost; roots survive hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Soil quality is more essential that supplemental feeding.
plants.notes: Keep plants well weeded to reduce competition for nutrients are water. Mulch over the tops of mature carrots to keep their shoulders from turning green.
plants.harvesting: Can be harvested over a long period, but the longer plants are left in the ground, the more likely they are to be injured by insects or animals.
plants.companions: Chives, Potatoes, Leek, Lettuce, Peas, Radish, Rosemary, Sage, Tomato, Onion and Onions.
plants.troubleshooting: Viruses, nematodes, and soil-borne diseases can cause roots to become gnarled or misshapen. Try fast-maturing varieties to sidestep these problems.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors in early spring, and set out while the soil is still cool.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mix composted manure or another high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting. When heads begin to form, feed with a liquid plant food.
plants.notes: Cabbageworms are small green larvae of the cabbage white butterfly. You can use row covers to keep them from eating plants. Bend over a few leaves if required so that the cauliflower head is kept shaded while it is forming.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the head has fully developed, but before the curd becomes loose, with a "ricey" appearance.
plants.companions: Oregano, Tomato, Celery, Dill, Sage and Mint.
plants.troubleshooting: When plants are stressed by cold or drought, they may refuse to make heads.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in before planting.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors in early spring, and set out transplants when they are big enough to handle.
plants.frostTolerant: Light frost only, damaged by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Liquid feed every two weeks throughout the season.
plants.notes: Garden-grown celery is looser and darker green than the supermarket version, with much more intense flavor. Provide water as needed to the soil moist in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Cut individual stalks as needed in the kitchen, or pull entire plants.
plants.companions: Chives, Garlic, Nasturtium, Cauliflower, Cabbage, Tomato and Tansy.
plants.troubleshooting: Resents hot, humid weather.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 6 inches apart and one-fourth inch deep. Thin to proper spacing when the plants are about one month old.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates frost, but is injured by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Feed monthly with a liquid organic fertilizer.
plants.notes: Mulch to keep the soil cool and moist.
plants.harvesting: Young leaves can be used to season cooked dishes. Dig the roots after the weather cools in the fall.
plants.companions: Lettuce, Spinach and Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Large, stately plants are easy to grow.

plants.soil: Average, well drained.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased clump, or start seeds indoors and set out while the soil is still cool. Established clumps can be dug and divided in spring or in fall.
plants.frostTolerant: Very cold hardy. Becomes dormant in winter.
plants.feeding: If desired, drench with a liquid organic fertilizer in spring, after new growth appears, and again in late summer.
plants.notes: Established clumps produce beautiful pink flowers in late spring.
plants.harvesting: Use scissors to gather handfuls of leaves from early spring onward. Rinse, pat dry, and snip or cut into smaller pieces.
plants.companions: Carrot, Apple, Garlic, Onion, Onions and Beet.
plants.troubleshooting: Can be invasive in cold climates. Snip off flowers to prevent unwanted reseeding.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil amended with compost.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in individual containers, or sow seeds outdoors half an inch deep and 2 inches apart. Gradually thin seedlings to proper spacing, and eat your thinnings. Older seedlings are difficult to transplant successfully.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings tolerate light frost with protection. Established plants may survive winter in mild climates.
plants.feeding: Drench with a liquid organic fertilizer when plants are 4 inches tall.
plants.notes: Cilantro seeds are the spice known as coriander.
plants.harvesting: As soon as plants are 6 inches tall, pick individual leaves as you need them in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Potatoes, Basil, Mint and Tansy.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants grown in spring often rush to produce flowers; fall-grown plants are often better producers.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors in spring and set out under cloches when plants have 5 leaves. Start another planting indoors in midsummer, and set out in early fall.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required, but may be needed if plants grow slowly even though the weather is comfortably warm.
plants.notes: The flavor of collards is improved by cool temperatures, so fall is the preferred time to grow this crop.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves individually, when they are about the size of your hand.
plants.companions: Tomato, Garlic, Nasturtium, Thyme, Sage, Onions, Onion, Dill and Agastache.
plants.troubleshooting: In warm weather, cabbageworms may feed on leaves. Exclude them with floating row covers. In cool weather, watch for outbreaks of gray-green cabbage aphids in leaf crevices. Pick off and compost badly infested leaves.

plants.soil: Warm, well-drained soil enriched with composted manure or other rich compost.
plants.sowPlant: Wait until the soil is warm to sow sweet corn. Soak seeds in water overnight before planting them 1 inch deep and 6 inches apart. Thin to 12 inches apart when the plants are 6 inches tall.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Needs more nitrogen than other vegetables. Mix an organic fertilizer into the soil before planting, following label application rates. When tassels form, feed plants second time.
plants.notes: Plant in blocks of at least 15 plants, all the same variety, to insure good wind pollination. Keep well watered in dry spells.
plants.harvesting: Sweet corn is ready when the ears feel firm and full when grasped, and a test kernel pierced with a fingernail released milky juice. Harvest in the morning, and promptly refrigerate ears to help them hold their delicate sugars.
plants.companions: Beans, Dill, Marigold, Sunflower, Cucumber, Melon, Peas and Squash.
plants.troubleshooting: Corn earworms often feed in ear tips. Snap off the damaged part as you husk your sweet cork. Sweet corn germinates poorly in cold soil.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Easily grown from seeds sown directly in the ground, or start seeds indoors and set plants out when they are 3 weeks old.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Drench with a liquid organic fertilizer when plants begin to bloom heavily.
plants.notes: Use a trellis to save space, or you can let cucumbers ramble over mulched ground.
plants.harvesting: Pick cucumbers at least every other day by snipping them from the vine with pruning shears. Many varieties are extremely productive. Fruits with hard seeds inside are overripe.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Lettuce, Radish, Tomato, Dill, Tansy, Marigold, Oregano, Sunflower and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Cucumber beetles transmit an incurable disease called bacterial wilt. Exclude them with floating rowcovers.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil amended with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in individual containers, or sow seeds outdoors half an inch deep and 2 inches apart. Gradually thin seedlings to proper spacing, and eat your thinnings. Older seedlings are difficult to transplant successfully.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings may need protection from light frosts. Cannot tolerate hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Drench with a liquid organic fertilizer when plants are 4 inches tall.
plants.notes: Young dill leaves are the herb known as dill weed. Dill flowers and seeds are used in making breads and pickles.
plants.harvesting: Gather and dry leaves when plants are 10 inches tall. Use a paper bag to harvest seeds when they change from green to tan and fall freely from their umbels.
plants.companions: Cucumber, Corn, Lettuce, Zinnia, Cabbage, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, Collards, Broccoli and Tomato.
plants.troubleshooting: Large plants may be blown over by gusty storms. Stake if necessary.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds 2 inches deep and 6 inches apart in late spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm. Make additional sowings until midsummer.
plants.frostTolerant: Warm-season annuals, cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Mix an organic fertilizer into the soil before planting, using rates given on the label. Supplemental fertilizer seldom required.
plants.notes: Edamame are very easy to grow, especially in warm climates. Extra seeds make a good short-term summer cover crop.
plants.harvesting: Gather pods when they feel well filled with seeds, but are still bright green. Most varieties produce all at once.
plants.companions: Marigold, Corn, Squash, Celery, Strawberry, Cucumber and Potatoes.
plants.troubleshooting: Japanese beetles sometimes feed on leaves. Gather them in broad containers of soapy water in the cool of the morning.

plants.soil: Warm, fertile, and well drained.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors 6 weeks before last spring frost, or buy seedlings in late spring. Transplant to larger pots if needed. Plant out in late spring, when the weather is settled and warm.
plants.frostTolerant: A semi-tropical plant; cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: From midsummer onward, drench with a liquid feed every two weeks.
plants.notes: Stake plants to keep them from falling over when they become heavy with fruit. Mulch to keep soil lightly moist.
plants.harvesting: Use pruning shears to cut fruits from the stem. Perfect fruits have shiny skins and only a few immature seeds inside.
plants.companions: Catnip, Marigold, Beans, Pepper and Tarragon.
plants.troubleshooting: Use rowcovers to keep plants warm while protecting them from flea beetles. Remove covers when plants begin blooming so the starry purple flowers can be pollinated by bees.

plants.soil: Rich, well drained soil generously amended with compost. In clay soil, use raised beds.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors, or sow in shallow furrows filled with potting soil. Thin seedlings to 12 inches apart when they are 3 weeks old. Chop the pulled seedlings into salads.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings are frost tender, but mature plants tolerate light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed every 3 weeks with a liquid organic fertilizer, and use a rich, biodegradable mulch such as grass clippings.
plants.notes: When the bulb is the size of an egg, surround it with 6 inches of loose mulch to help it plump up.
plants.harvesting: Snip tender young leaves as needed in the kitchen. When the bulbs reach 3 inches in diameter, pull them and store in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Mint.
plants.troubleshooting: Grows best in cool weather. In some climates, fennel grows better in fall than in spring.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be frost tolerant, depending on species.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with rich compost in spring or fall. Additional feeding requirements varies depending on species.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies/syrphid flies) or keep away pests. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful cover crops.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Some flowers can be added to salads, make good herbal teas, or can be harvested for use in cut or dried flower arrangements.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be frost tolerant, depending on species.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with rich compost in spring or fall. Additional feeding requirements varies depending on species.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies/syrphid flies) or keep away pests. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful cover crops.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Some flowers can be added to salads, make good herbal teas, or can be harvested for use in cut or dried flower arrangements.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be frost tolerant, depending on species.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with rich compost in spring or fall. Additional feeding requirements varies depending on species.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies/syrphid flies) or keep away pests. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful cover crops.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Some flowers can be added to salads, make good herbal teas, or can be harvested for use in cut or dried flower arrangements.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be frost tolerant, depending on species.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with rich compost in spring or fall. Additional feeding requirements varies depending on species.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies/syrphid flies) or keep away pests. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful cover crops.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Some flowers can be added to salads, make good herbal teas, or can be harvested for use in cut or dried flower arrangements.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil. Match your choice of bush fruits to local climate and soil conditions.
plants.sowPlant: Purchase dormant plants and set them out in early spring. Plants grown in containers can be transplanted through early summer. Mulch after planting new fruits.
plants.frostTolerant: All are hardy deciduous plants, but cold tolerance varies widely with species. Choose regionally-adapted bush fruits, for example juneberries (saskatoons) in the far north and rabbiteye blueberries in the far south.
plants.feeding: In early spring, mulch over root zone with 1 to 2 inches of good compost. Mulch with grass clippings or straw.
plants.notes: Numerous bush fruits are descended from native plants, and they are easier to grow organically compared to other fruits. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Let experience be your teacher -- taste fruits often as they approach ripeness. Bumper crops can be frozen, dried, or made into jams and jellies.
plants.troubleshooting: Native birds often gorge themselves on native fruits. Protect ripening berries with lightweight cloth or bird netting.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil. Match your choice of tree fruits to local climate and soil conditions.
plants.sowPlant: Purchase dormant plants and set them out in early spring. Water thoroughly and mulch after planting new fruits.
plants.frostTolerant: All are winter hardy, but cold tolerance and chilling requirements vary with species. Choose regionally-adapted tree fruits, for example cherries in the north or peaches in the south.
plants.feeding: In early spring, mulch over root zone with 1 to 2 inches of good compost. Mulch with grass clippings or straw.
plants.notes: Obtain local expertise before choosing which fruits to grow. University-based breeding programs have developed many great-tasting, disease-resistant varieties. Thin out fruit four weeks after the tree has blossomed and prune the tree in late fall. You can add a variety of this tree to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Let experience be your teacher -- taste fruits often as they approach ripeness. Bumper crops can be frozen, dried, or made into jams and jellies.
plants.troubleshooting: Protect the trunks of young trees from borers and sunscald with loose tree wrapping.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Purchase dormant plants and set them out in early spring. Plants grown in containers can be transplanted through early summer. Mulch after planting new fruits.
plants.frostTolerant: Cold tolerance varies widely with species. Choose regionally-adapted trellised fruits, for example bunch grapes in cold winter areas, or muscadine grapes where winters are mild.
plants.feeding: In early spring, mulch over root zone with 1 to 2 inches of good compost. Mulch with grass clippings or straw.
plants.notes: Obtain local expertise before choosing which fruits to grow. University-based breeding programs have developed many great-tasting, disease-resistant varieties.
plants.harvesting: Let experience be your teacher -- taste fruits often as they approach ripeness. Bumper crops can be frozen, dried, or made into jams and jellies.
plants.troubleshooting: In winter, use poultry netting (chicken wire) to protect young plants from deer, voles, and rabbits.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: In fall, plant individual cloves 4 inches deep with the pointed ends up. Cover the planting with at least 3 inches of mulch.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Use hardy Rocambole types in cold climates. Where winters are mild, grow heavy-yielding artichoke types. Among the most deer-resistant of all edibles.
plants.harvesting: Dig up bulbs in summer when one third of the leaves become dry and lose their green color. Shake off soil, and cure whole plants dry in a warm, shady place for two weeks before trimming and storing the garlic bulbs.
plants.companions: Tomato, Apple, Apricot, Plum, Cherry, Pear, Peach, Raspberry, Red Currant and Gooseberry.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for winter weeds. Plants left in the ground too long often have loose bulbs that do not store well.

plants.soil: Any reasonably fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Set out tubers in spring, planting them 4 inches deep. Plants grow quite tall, and can be used to shade heat-sensitive neighbors.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes. Plants die back to the roots in winter.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Can be invasive, so use flowers indoors as cut flowers to reduce reseeding.
plants.harvesting: Harvest tubers in fall, winter, and early spring, while the soil is cold.
plants.companions: Beans, Cucumber and Rhubarb.
plants.troubleshooting: Powdery mildew often affects plants in late summer, but does not impact yields.

plants.soil: Average, well drained.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost.
plants.frostTolerant: Depends on herb.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors in spring and set out under cloches when plants have 5 leaves. Start another planting indoors in midsummer, and set out in early fall.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required, but may be needed if plants grow slowly even though the weather is comfortably warm.
plants.notes: Kale tolerates moderate freezes, but is damaged by severe cold. Try different types, including curly varieties, many of which are blushed with red. Dinosaur or Tuscan kale has long, dark green puckered leaves.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves individually, when they are about the size of your hand.
plants.companions: Buckwheat, Marigold, Nasturtium, Chinese Cabbage, Cabbage, Lavender and Dill.
plants.troubleshooting: In warm weather, cabbageworms may feed on leaves. Exclude them with floating row covers. In cool weather, watch for outbreaks of gray-green cabbage aphids in leaf crevices. Pick off and compost badly infested leaves.

plants.soil: Well drained soil amended with well rotted compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in early spring indoors, or outdoors when the weather is warm but the soil is still cool.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates light frosts.
plants.feeding: In lean soil, mix in a balanced organic fertilizer before planting.
plants.notes: Easier to grow than broccoli, especially in spring. Can be sown in late summer for a fall crops.
plants.harvesting: Pull plants when swollen stems are the size of tennis balls. Older plants have inferior texture.
plants.companions: Beans, Beet, Celery, Cucumber, Lettuce, Potatoes, Onion and Onions.
plants.troubleshooting: Cabbageworms can be damaging, but they are less attracted to kohlrabi compared to other cabbage family crops.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added. Often grown in widely spaced enriched hills, or in well-aged compost heaps that include some soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in rows, or in hills spaced 6 feet apart. After 2 weeks, thin to 2 plants per hill.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Fruit size varies with variety. Small melons mature quickly and take up less space compared to huge varieties.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when sound holow if tapped hard. Wipe clean and store indoors.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Marigold, Oregano, Corn, Pumpkin, Radish, Squash, Beans and Morning Glory.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds early and then mulch to avoid trampling the vines after fruits have set.

plants.soil: Requires rich, loamy soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors in early spring, and move to a protected cold frame if you have one. Transplant when seedlings are about the size of a pencil.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: In late summer while the weather is still warm, drench plants thoroughly with a water-soluble plant food.
plants.notes: When leeks are almost the size you prefer, blanch them for 2 to 3 weeks by putting a mound of soil, mulch, or a cardboard tube around the base of each stem. Grows best in climates where nights remain cool through summer. In mild winter climates, try leeks as a fall-to-spring crop.
plants.harvesting: Dig as needed in the kitchen. In cold winter climates, dig plants before the ground freezes in early winter.
plants.companions: Carrot, Celery and Strawberry.
plants.troubleshooting: Struggling plants may be infested with onion root maggots, which are easy to see when you dig up a plant. Promptly remove affected plants.

plants.soil: Most soil types, but best in moisture retentive soil with some compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in early spring, or simply sow fresh seeds where you want them to grow. Scatter seeds atop prepared soil, about one-half inch apart, and barely cover them before patting them into place. Sow more seeds in summer for a fall crop.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost, but needs protection from hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: As lettuce seedlings grow, thin them so that the leaves of adjoining plants do not overlap. Mulch open space between plants to retain soil moisture and prevent weeds.
plants.harvesting: You can pick individual leaves, use scissor or a knife to harvest handfuls of baby lettuce, or grow plants at proper spacing to get large, loose heads.
plants.companions: Garlic, Beet, Dill, Chives, Basil, Carrot, Strawberry, Radish, Spinach, Lettuce, Cabbage, Scallions, Onion, Onions and Poached Egg Plant.
plants.troubleshooting: Shallow lettuce roots need constant moisture. Do not allow the soil to dry out.

plants.soil: Most soil types, but best in moisture retentive soil with rich compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in early spring. Set plant out at proper spacing while soil is still cool.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a mix-with-water plant food once a month.
plants.notes: Harvest head lettuce before the plants begin to elongate, because they lose their delicate flavor as they prepare to produce flowers and seeds.
plants.harvesting: Pull up entire plants and use a sharp knife to lop off the roots. Always harvest in the morning, when the leaves are cool and full of moisture.
plants.companions: Cilantro, Marigold, Coreopsis, Zinnia, Corn, Cucumber and Poached Egg Plant.
plants.troubleshooting: Use a cloth shade cover if needed to keep plants cool during periods of hot weather.

plants.soil: Any fertile, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in late winter and set out in very early spring. Sow again in fall, and allow plants to grow through the winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates extreme cold when well rooted.
plants.feeding: Not generally required.
plants.notes: This petite green is slow yet easy to grow in cool weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in small batches as needed in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Carrot, Turnip, Leek, Chinese Cabbage and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds that threaten to overtake the small plants.

plants.soil: Average, well drained.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy only where winters are mild. In cold climates, pot up plants in fall and grow them through winter indoors. Marjoram is easy to root from 2-inch long stem tip cuttings.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Oregano, Thyme and Pepper.
plants.troubleshooting: May become lanky by midsummer. Trim back to promote the emergence of new growth.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil where mint's wandering tendencies can be kept in check.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Mint is also easy to root from stem tip cuttings stuck into moist potting soil. Some strains are propagated only from cuttings rather than seeds.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy even in cold climates. If desired, small plants can be potted up in fall and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Spearmint or peppermint are the most versatile strain for cooking.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Peas, Brussels Sprouts, Broccoli, Cauliflower, Cabbage, Persimmon, Kale, Kohlrabi, Tomato and Eggplant.
plants.troubleshooting: Often becomes invasive. If possible, grow near walkways, driveways, or other hard surfaces, or in containers buried halfway in the ground.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil amended with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Soak seeds in water overnight before planting them 1 inch deep and 6 inches apart in warm soil. Thin to proper spacing after two weeks.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required, but thrifty growth often indicates nutritional stress.
plants.notes: Requires warm weather to grow well.
plants.harvesting: Use pruning shears to gather pods less than 5 inches long. Wear gloves and a long-sleeved shirt to avoid prickles.
plants.companions: Melon, Cucumber, Pepper and Eggplant.
plants.troubleshooting: Ants sometimes damage okra blossoms.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: If you don't start your own seeds, set out sets (small dormant bulbs) or pencil-size seedlings in spring, while the soil is still cool.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertilizer into the bed or row before planting your onions, taking care to get it into the soil below the plants. Do not feed plants that are nearing maturity if you want very sweet onions.
plants.notes: Onions respond to changing day length. Grow short-day varieties in southern latitudes. Long-day varieties work best in northern areas. Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in bulb color, size and shape.
plants.harvesting: Harvest young onions as scallions. When bulbs form and the tops of the plants fall over, pull them and cure in a warm place for about 10 days before storing.
plants.companions: Beet, Chamomile, Carrot, Lettuce, Strawberry, Tomato, Garlic, Scallions and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil in an easily accessible site.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Some strains are propagated only from cuttings. Authentic Greek oregano can be grown from seeds or plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy in cold climates provided plant is well-rooted and mulched. If desired, small plants can be potted up in fall and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Some strains are grown for their pretty pink flowers. Oregano often spreads in hospitable spots. Moderately invasive.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Tomato, Pepper and Broccoli.
plants.troubleshooting: Control oregano's spread by cutting back flowering stems when their colors fade.

plants.notes: Other plants requiring up to 10cm (4in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

Other plants requiring up to 25cm (10in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

Other plants requiring up to 50cm (20in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds in early spring, and keep moist. Parsley germinates slowly. Or, start with young purchased plants. Take care not to disturb the roots when transplanting parsley.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy only to about 10 degrees F, though winter mulches or cloches can enhance cold tolerance. Where winters are mild, parsley can be sown in fall and grown through winter.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food monthly.
plants.notes: Try both curled and flat-leafed or Italian parsley, which has stronger flavour. Plants that survive winter will bloom first thing in spring.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in early summer.
plants.companions: Asparagus, Corn and Tomato.
plants.troubleshooting: Colorful parsleyworms sometimes eat parsley leaves. Root rot is common in elderly, winter-weary plants.

plants.soil: Deeply worked soil that has not had compost or manure added within 6 months.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil, and cover the seeded bed or furrow with a board to keep it moist. Germination often takes up to 2 weeks.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Thin seedlings to proper spacing when they are 4 inches tall. Mulch to deter weeds and keep soil moist.
plants.harvesting: Use a digging fork to loosen soil along outside of the planting before pulling roots. Can be left in the soil through winter in many areas.
plants.companions: Onion, Onions and Radish.

plants.otherName: Snow pea, snap pea, shell pea
plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Soak seeds in water overnight before sowing 2 inches deep and 2 inches apart. Thin plants to proper spacing after the seeds germinate.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required if the plants are mulched deeply with grass clippings, shredded leaves, or another biodegradable material.
plants.notes: Support plants with a trellis, which can be made from string, netting, or twiggy sticks pushed into the ground near each plant.
plants.harvesting: Pick snow peas when the delicate pods begin to show immature seeds inside. Gather snap peas when the pods become plump yet are still glossy and filled with sweet-tasting peas. Pick shell peas before the pods become waxy.
plants.companions: Chives, Mint, Alyssum, Carrot, Corn, Cucumber, Radish, Turnip and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Mature plants usually stop producing and die back in hot summer weather.

plants.soil: Well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Start indoors, and set out seedlings when the soil is settled and warm. Mulch to keep soil lightly moist at all times.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Mix an organic fertilizer into the planting holes as you transplant peppers. Feed every two weeks with a liquid feed after the plants begin to blossom and set fruit.
plants.notes: Tie heavy-bearing plants to a single stake to keep them from falling over.
plants.harvesting: Peppers can be harvested when they are still green, though their flavor improves as they ripen to red, yellow, or orange.
plants.companions: Basil, Marjoram, Oregano, Carrot, Tomato, Borage and Dill.
plants.troubleshooting: Hot weather can cause peppers to temporarily stop flowering. They will pick up again when nights cool down.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil that has not been amended with manure for at least 6 months.
plants.sowPlant: Grow from sprouting potatoes or seed potatoes, cut into chunks so that each piece has 2 growing "eyes," or sprouts. Let the cut pieces dry for a day before planting 3 inches deep.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required if plants are deeply mulched with straw, grass clippings, rotted leaves, or another organic mulch.
plants.notes: Try different types with red, tan or purple skins, but avoid big baking potatoes, which require a long, cool season. Keep potatoes mulched to protect shallow tubers from sun, which turns them green and bitter.
plants.harvesting: When the plants begin to bloom, feel under the mulch for little new potatoes. Harvest often as the plants begin to die back. Gather potatoes on a cloudy day, and cover them to protect them from exposure to light.
plants.companions: Basil, Beans, Eggplant, Marigold, Peas, Squash, Tansy, Horseradish, Cabbage and Catnip.
plants.troubleshooting: Yellow-and-black Colorado potato beetles lay eggs on leaf undersides, which hatch into fat red leaf- and flower-eating larvae. Use row covers to exclude them or hand pick off.

plants.latinName: Cucurbita pepo,  C. moschata, C. maxima
plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added. Often grown in widely spaced enriched hills, or in layered compost heaps that include some soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in hills spaced 6 feet apart. After 2 weeks, thin to 2 plants per hill.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Fruit size varies with variety. Small "pie" pumpkins are easy to grow and produce nutritious, flavorful flesh.
plants.harvesting: When the plant die back or before freezing weather, cut pumpkins leaving a stub of stem attached. Wipe clean and store indoors.
plants.companions: Corn, Melon, Beans, Nasturtium, Oregano, Marigold, Monarda and Lemon Balm.
plants.troubleshooting: Squash bugs, squash vine borers and cucumber beetles can be formidable pests. Cover young plants with row covers to exclude them.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors or sow them where you want plants to grow in early spring or early fall. Radicchio grows best when temperatures are cool.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates frost but is injured by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Drench with an organic liquid plant food when heads begin to form.
plants.notes: In early winter, plants can be lifted and grown indoors during winter.
plants.harvesting: Some varieties are more bolt resistant than others when grown in spring.
plants.companions: Endive, Mizuna, Tatsoi and Mustard.
plants.troubleshooting: Bitter flavor is often due to hot weather.

plants.soil: Almost any soil with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds directly in the bed or row, one-half inch deep and 1 inch apart. Thin to proper spacing when the seedlings are 1 week old.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Use radishes to mark divisions between sowings of salad greens or other spring vegetables.
plants.harvesting: Harvest round radishes when the roots are the size of a quarter. Young radishes have the best flavor, so pull them promptly.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Lettuce and Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles often make small holes in leaves, but do not merit control.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, use raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Set individual cloves in prepared ground in the fall. They will root during the winter, and multiply into a cluster in late spring or early summer.  Alternatively, plant first thing in spring, or grow from seed and set out seedlings in early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Used in place of onions for concentrated flavor.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in early summer when the tops begin to fail, and the bulbs have divided into several plump bulblets. If storing shallots, cure in a dry place for 10 days after pulling the plants.
plants.companions: Beet, Chamomile, Carrot, Strawberry, Lettuce, Chinese Cabbage and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Onion root maggots can cause plants to collapse. Remove infested plants.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil with plenty of compost dug in. In clay soil, use raised beds.
plants.sowPlant: Can be grown from seeds, but it is faster to grow from a dormant crown, or by cutting away and replanting a division taken from an established plant. Make new plantings or move old ones in spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, becomes dormant in winter.
plants.feeding: Use mulch to keep soil nutrient levels high. Mulch with rich compost in late winter, and add more mulch in summer to deter weeds and keep soil moist.
plants.notes: To make rhubarb stems longer, cover plants with bushel baskets or other large, breathable containers for one month in spring.
plants.harvesting: Use a sharp knife to cut new stems in spring as they reach 14 inches long. Discard leaves, which contain dangerously high levels of oxalic acid. Stop harvesting in early summer, and allow plants to grow freely the rest of the season.
plants.companions: Strawberry.
plants.troubleshooting: Trap slugs with beer, hand pick them in rainy weather, or spray them with caffeinated coffee first thing in the morning.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, keeping in mind that growth habit varies with variety. Trailing rosemary for walls, or dwarf varieties for containers, are propagated by rooting stem cuttings rather than from seeds. Wild Mediterranean rosemary can be grown from seeds or plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy only to about 10 degrees F, though winter protection can help. Where winters are mild, rosemary can grow into huge, shrub-like plants. In cold winter areas, small plants can be potted up in fall and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Trailing rosemary is great cascading over a wall.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying from spring to late summer.
plants.companions: Beans, Cabbage, Carrot, Sage and Lavender.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants are often short-lived, so root stem cuttings each spring to always have vigorous young plants. Treat small outbreaks of powdery mildew with a spray made from 2 Tablespoons milk in 1 cup water.

plants.soil: Any fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds half an inch deep and 4 inches apart in early summer. Thin seedlings to 8 inches apart when they are 3 weeks old.
plants.frostTolerant: Time planting so that rutabagas are reaching maturity just as the first fall frosts arrive. Cold weather improved rutabaga flavor and texture.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Needs more water than many other vegetables. Mulch to keep the soil cool and moist.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in mid to late fall, after the soil has cooled and frosts have become frequent. Trimmed roots can be stored in a cool basement, root cellar, or refrigerator.
plants.companions: Chives, Onion, Onions and Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Rutabagas left in the ground too long become woody.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors in early spring. Plants started from seed may not bloom their first year.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy only to about 15 degrees F, though winter protection can help. In cold winter areas, small plants can be potted up in fall and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: One-year-old plants nursed through winter produce beautiful blue flowers. Sage grown in containers can be kept in a cold garage through winter.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying from spring to fall.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Cucumber, Tomato and Rosemary.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants are often short-lived, so root a few stem cuttings each spring to always have vigorous young plants.

plants.soil: Rich soil that has been generously amended with fully composted manure or another high-nitrogen compost. Use raised beds in clay soil.
plants.sowPlant: Easy to grow from seeds sown in spring, one-half inch deep and 2 inches apart. Also can be started indoors and moved outside under cloches in early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, survives winter with mulch in many climates.
plants.feeding: Not needed for spring crops grown in rich soil, but older plants benefit from feeding with a liquid feed in spring, when they show vigorous new growth.
plants.notes: Keep well watered. Spinach grows tall and goes to seed when days become long and hot. Grow a second crop in the fall.
plants.harvesting: Pick individual leaves, or allow plants to grow into dense, leafy rosettes.
plants.companions: Cilantro, Celery, Cauliflower, Eggplant, Strawberry, Chinese Cabbage and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Slow growth and yellowing leaves indicate nutritional stress. Drench with a water soluble plant food.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in spring, either in rows or hills. Also may be started from seedlings started indoors or purchased at stores.
plants.frostTolerant: Cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a liquid fertilizer when they begin to blossom and set fruits.
plants.notes: Keep plantings small, to fewer than a dozen plants. Different types of summer squash help pollinate one another because they are of the same species.
plants.harvesting: Harvest summer squash when they are young and tender, before the rinds begin to harden. Use a knife to cut fruits from the plants.
plants.companions: Corn, Nasturtium, Borage, Oregano, Marigold, Cucumber, Melon, Pumpkin and Lemon Balm.
plants.troubleshooting: Squash bugs and squash vine borers can be serious pests. Exclude them from young plantings with row covers.

plants.otherName: Acorn, buttercup, butternut, sweet potato, squash
plants.soil: Well-drained soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in late spring or early summer, either in rows or hills. Also may be started from seedlings started indoors or purchased at stores.
plants.frostTolerant: Cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a liquid fertilizer when they begin to blossom and set fruits.
plants.notes: Some types grow to be large, long-vined plants, while others grow into compact bushes. Grow at the edge of your garden to save space.
plants.harvesting: Harvest winter squash when they plants begin to die back and the rinds cannot easily be pierced with your fingernail. Wipe clean, and store indoors at cool room temperatures.
plants.companions: Corn, Borage, Oregano, Marigold, Beans, Nasturtium and Lemon Balm.
plants.troubleshooting: Squash bugs and squash vine borers can be serious pests. Exclude them from young plantings with row covers. Butternuts naturally resist these pests.

plants.soil: Well-drained, moderately acidic soil amended with compost.
plants.position: Full sun in beds, partial shade in containers.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in early spring, or in fall in mild winter areas. Take care not to bury the central crown when transplanting.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardy, though plants go dormant from late fall to early spring.
plants.feeding: In fall and again in early spring, topdress established plants with rich compost or an organic fertilizer. Allow plants to rest in midsummer.
plants.notes: Can be used as a ground cover beneath grapes or blueberries, or managed as a perpetual bed. In late summer, remove weeds and withered leaves, and thin runners to no more than 3 per plant. Lift and transplant extra runners.
plants.harvesting: Gather ripe fruits in the morning, when they are cool, and refrigerate immediately. Wash in cool water just before eating.
plants.companions: Beans, Lettuce, Spinach, Thyme, Onions and Nigella.
plants.troubleshooting: Slugs can be deterred with straw mulch or traps. Use lightweight cloth or netting to protect ripening berries from birds.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best, but can adapt to any fertile, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant 'slips' that grow from sprouting tubers in late spring or early summer, after the soil is very warm.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Sweet potatoes form a dense green ground cover under hot summer conditions. Tubers are often found 12 inches or more from the plant's primary crown, so dig carefully.  Although not from the solanaceae family, sweet potatoes are often placed in that group for crop rotation purposes because they share several important pests and diseases such as wireworms and nematodes which is why we show it as solanaceae.
plants.harvesting: Dig in fall when the soil is still warm. Cure in a warm, airy place for two weeks before storing at cool room temperatures.
plants.companions: Beans, Strawberry, Parsnip, Nigella and Beet.
plants.troubleshooting: Deer are fond of sweet potato vines.

plants.soil: Rich, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the ground in mid spring, and again in late summer for a fall crop. Sow seeds 4 inches apart, and thin to proper spacing. Can be started indoors if the roots are not disturbed as seedlings are transplanted.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes. With mulch, plants are hardy to about 20°F.
plants.feeding: Not usually required is a mulch is used to keep soil moist.
plants.notes: Swiss chard is so beautiful that it should be grown where it is easily seen. A great vegetable for edible ornamental beds.
plants.harvesting: Twist leaves from the outside of the plant regularly from mid summer onwards. Plants regrow when cut back to 3 inches.
plants.companions: Chinese Cabbage, Cabbage, Beans, Onion and Onions.
plants.troubleshooting: Cutworms can girdle seedlings, so be watchful when growing chard in spots recently vacated by grass.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased plants, or start seeds indoors in early spring. Good culinary thyme can be grown from seed, but some creeping forms are propagated only from rooted cuttings or divisions.
plants.frostTolerant: Very winter hardy. Becomes dormant from fall to spring.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: Creeping forms make sturdy ground covers. Bees are attracted to pink thyme flowers.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in summer, before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Strawberry, Ageratum, Dianthus, Portulaca and Dahlia.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants are often short-lived, so root a few stem cuttings each spring to always have vigorous young plants.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost mixed in before planting.
plants.sowPlant: Start seedlings indoors or start with purchased plants. Set out after the last frost has passed, when the soil is warm and settled.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed or seaweed drench from mid summer onwards.
plants.notes: Bushy determinate plants can be tied to stakes, but long-bearing indeterminate varieties need a sturdy cage or trellis.
plants.harvesting: Pick regularly as soon as the fruits turn color but are still firm. Store at room temperature.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Asparagus, Carrot, Celery, Cucumber, Onion, Onions, Chives, Marigold, Basil, Borage, Monarda, Mint, Dill and Calendula.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for leaf-eating tomato hornworms, and pick them off. Black patches on the bottom of fruits are a nutritional disorder best prevented by growing tomatoes in well-prepared soil with constant light moisture.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid fall or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.

plants.soil: Almost any soil
plants.sowPlant: Large trees are usually already well established
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches.

plants.soil: Any reasonably fertile well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds in rows in spring, and use roots in salads. Grow a second crop in fall, and use both roots and greens in cooking.
plants.frostTolerant: Light frost improves flavor, but can be damaged by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Keep watered in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Pick individual leaves for cooking greens, or pull whole plants to harvest roots. Fall-grown turnips can be stored in a cool root cellar for several weeks.
plants.companions: Mache and Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Spring crops bolt to seed quickly, so pull them when the roots are perfect.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added. Often grown in widely spaced enriched hills, or in well-aged compost heaps that include some soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in rows, or in hills spaced 6 feet apart. After 2 weeks, thin to 2 plants per hill.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Fruit size varies with variety. Small "icebox" watermelons mature quickly and take up less space compared to huge watermelons.
plants.harvesting: Ripe watermelons sound deep and resonant when thumped, and the curled tendril opposite the melon should be brown. Wipe clean and store indoors.
plants.companions: Beans, Corn, Radish and Potatoes.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds early and then mulch to avoid trampling the vines after fruits have set.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid-fall or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Chives, Nasturtium, Lavender and Garlic.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid-fall or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Chives, Nasturtium, Parsnip, Garlic and Lavender.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. Prefers a pH of 6.
plants.sowPlant: Buy plants or use offshoots from an existing plant and cut them to 6 inches after planting.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required but if leaves start to yellow then add a liquid feed.
plants.notes: Need supporting on wires or tied against a fence. Train the briars onto wire supports from 3 feet high and above. Each fall add some compost.
plants.harvesting: Pick over a long season as ripe.
plants.companions: Pear, Cherry and Almond.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. Acidic pH of 5 to 5.5 required.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid-fall or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe.
plants.companions: Cranberry.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost, composted manure, or balanced organic fertilizer dug in prior to planting.
plants.sowPlant: Sow fall broccoli indoors in summer, and set out when the plants are 3 weeks old.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mix composted manure or another high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting. When heads begin to form, feed with a liquid plant food.
plants.harvesting: Use a sharp knife to harvest the primary head when the beads are plump and well-filled. Many varieties produce numerous smaller side shoots after the primary head is cut.
plants.companions: Oregano and Crimson Clover. Also, alfalfa.
plants.troubleshooting: Cabbageworms are small green larvae of the cabbage white butterfly. You can use row covers to keep them from eating plants.

plants.soil: Almost any soil type.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards or indoors during winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required while seedlings are still small.
plants.companions: Chives and Mint.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.position: Sun preferred but tolerant of some shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil in late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Can blanch a few plants at a time when they are grown by excluding light from them for a few days. This can make them less bitter.
plants.harvesting: Havest as required by cutting off at base. Will sometimes resprout.
plants.companions: Radicchio, Mizuna, Tatsoi and Mustard.

plants.soil: Will grow on relatively poor soil as long as it is well drained and compost is dug in. pH of 6.5 to 7 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid-fall or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well rotted compost annually.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to three buds. Vines can gradually be trained up a support system.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, thinning a few out beforehand to allow others to swell.
plants.companions: Agastache and Chives.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best but will grow in most locations.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil from early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Cut leaves as required.
plants.companions: Cranberry and Blueberry.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil from early to late summer
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: May need to protect under mesh or fleece to prevent problems with flea beetle. Keep soil moist in dry weather to prevent running to seed.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required.
plants.companions: Beans, Radicchio, Endive, Tatsoi and Mustard.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil that has not been amended with manure for at least 6 months.
plants.sowPlant: Grow from sprouting potatoes or seed potatoes, cut into chunks so that each piece has 2 growing "eyes," or sprouts. Let the cut pieces dry for a day before planting 3 inches deep.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required if plants are deeply mulched with straw, grass clippings, rotted leaves, or another organic mulch.
plants.notes: Try different types with waxy texture, good with salads. Keep potatoes mulched to protect shallow tubers from sun, which turns them green and bitter.
plants.harvesting: When the plants begin to bloom, feel under the mulch for little new potatoes. Harvest often as the plants begin to die back. Gather potatoes on a cloudy day, and cover them to protect them from exposure to light.
plants.companions: Basil, Horseradish, Cilantro, Tansy, Eggplant, Marigold, Peas, Squash, Beans and Catnip.
plants.troubleshooting: Yellow-and-black Colorado potato beetles lay eggs on leaf undersides, which hatch into fat red leaf- and flower-eating larvae. Use row covers to exclude them or hand pick off.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid-fall or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: After harvesting cut the canes down to ground level, leaving any new shoots.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe. Can protect with netting if birds are eating them but make sure that the plant doesn't grow through the netting making it difficult to remove.
plants.companions: Garlic and Rye.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in spring, either in rows or hills. Also may be started from seedlings started indoors or purchased at stores.
plants.frostTolerant: Cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a liquid fertilizer when they begin to blossom and set fruits.
plants.notes: Keep plantings small, to fewer than a dozen plants. Other types of summer squash help pollinate one another because they are of the same species.
plants.harvesting: Harvest zucchini when they are young and tender, about 6 inches long, before the rinds begin to harden. Use a knife to cut fruits from the plants.
plants.companions: Nasturtium and Zinnia.
plants.troubleshooting: Squash bugs and squash vine borers can be serious pests. Exclude them from young plantings with row covers.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil, or high quality organic potting soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, because bay stem cuttings are very difficult to root. Spring and early summer are the best times to adopt a new bay plant.  Outdoors, allow 6 feet (2 meters) between plants being grown as a hedge. When grown in containers, gradually shift plants to a container at least 12" (30 cm) in diameter. A mature plant, grown in a sunken container, will occupy a space 18" (45 cm) square.
plants.frostTolerant: Bay is a half-hardy shrub or small tree that can tolerate winter temperatures no lower than 20F (-7C). In cold climates, bay is best grown in a container that can be kept indoors in winter.
plants.feeding: Fertilize bay grown in containers with an organic water soluble fertilizer every three weeks from spring to late summer. Feeding is not generally needed for plants grown outdoors as herb garden specimen plants or hedges.
plants.notes: When growing bay as a potted plant, allow the soil to become dry as fall approaches. Through winter, allow the soil to dry between waterings. Dried bay used in bouquets supposedly brings good luck.
plants.harvesting: Stem or leaves as desired from early summer to fall. In midsummer, gather perfect small branches and dry them in small bunches. Stored dried leaves in airtight containers.
plants.companions: Beans. Use an attractively potted bay plant as a movable accent in your summer herb garden. In mild winter climates, use bay as a landscape shrub or small tree.
plants.troubleshooting: Repot containers every other spring, gradually moving to slightly larger pots. Outdoors, prune as needed if plants outgrow their space.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot where bumblebees and other large pollinators are desired.
plants.sowPlant: Plant the large seeds in your garden in late spring. A fresh crop of plants can be planted in late summer for bloom in the fall.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings will survive light frosts, but older plants are easily damaged.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Borage seedlings are only edible when very young. Large plants produce edible, starry blue flowers that attract bees in droves. The foliage can be gathered and composted.
plants.harvesting: Cut back borage plants by half their size in midsummer to encourage reblooming. Blossom clusters make beautiful but short-lived cut flowers or edible garnishes.
plants.companions: Tomato, Squash, Strawberry and Pepper. A good companion for any crop that needs strong defense from insects. Borage attracts large buzzing insects that dominate their air space.
plants.troubleshooting: Beware of sleepy bees when pruning or otherwise working with mature borage plants.

plants.soil: Rich soil that retains moisture well.
plants.position: A sunny spot that is easily accessed for cutting.
plants.sowPlant: Plant the curled seeds in your garden from early spring onward, or start them indoors and set out the sturdy seedlings. Allow some plants to produce mature seeds to scatter where you want to see calendula seedlings in subsequent seasons.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings tolerate light frosts. Established plants may rebloom in late fall if protected from damaging hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Calendula blossoms are edible and can be used to bring orange color to rice or potato dishes, or snip them onto soups or salads for extra flavor and nutrition. Use clean scissors to snip off petal tips, and compost the rest.
plants.harvesting: Cut flowers as soon as they fully open, preferably in late morning, and promptly dry them. Calendulas make marginal cut flowers because they partially close at night.  For medicinal use  harvest and dry entire calendula flowers. Infuse them in vegetable oil to make a medicinal oil with a long history of use for healing burned or abraded skin.
plants.companions: Peas, Carrot, Cucumber, Tomato and Asparagus. Spring salad vegetables.
plants.troubleshooting: Elderly plants suffer from powdery mildew and other fungal ailments. It’s best to send them to the compost pile and grow fresh replacement plants in a new place.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade
plants.sowPlant: Catnip can be started from seeds sown indoors, or from a rooted cutting or purchased plant. Set out plants at about the time of your last frost.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy in cold climates provided plant is well-rooted and mulched. If desired, small plants can be potted up in fall and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Pinching back in late spring helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Catnip flower clusters are visited by numerous small beneficial insects. If you can, grow clumps in different parts of your garden.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as desired for the pleasure of your cats. One small stem tip with four to eight leaves is plenty for one or two cats to enjoy. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Potatoes, Lavender, Rosemary, Sage, Mint, Agastache, Gaillardia and Tulip. Most other herbs that grow to more than 12 inches tall.
plants.troubleshooting: Clip off spent blossom clusters to limit reseeding in your garden.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot, for example at the end of a vegetable row or bed.
plants.sowPlant: Seeds can be started indoors or sown directly in the garden. When allowed to shed mature seeds, chamomile often becomes a welcome volunteer plant.
plants.frostTolerant: Young seedlings easily tolerate spring frosts, and may survive winters in mild climates. The easiest chamomile to grow is a cool-season annual.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Feathery chamomile foliage contrasts well with the textures of other herbs and flowers.
plants.harvesting: Cut branches when they are holding numerous open flowers, and hang in small bunches to dry. Chamomile tea is made from the blossoms only. When the stems are dry, pop off the blossoms and store them in an airtight container.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Lettuce, Spinach, Calendula, Cilantro, Feverfew and Mint. Leafy greens grown in spring, as well as spring-blooming herbs and flowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Rabbits enjoy nibbling chamomile foliage.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors or sow them where you want them to grow, or start with a purchased plant. New growth emerges in mid-spring, followed by flowers that attract pollinators in early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Extremely cold hardy perennials, comfrey plants become dormant in winter and re-emerge every spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Comfrey is a fine source of greens for composting. When the large plants are cut back in summer, old branches are quickly replaced by a fresh flush of foliage.
plants.harvesting: Roots to be used to make medicinal ointments or skin creams can be harvested at any time, but preferably in early winter. Gather greens for composting in early summer and again in the fall. For medicinal use topical preparations made from comfrey roots are traditionally used to promote healing of sprains and broken bones by increasing circulation to the affected area. Taken internally, comfrey contains compounds that may harm the liver.
plants.companions: Apple, Apricot, Peach, Pear, Plum, Persimmon and Nectarine. Comfrey is a large plant that tends to crowd out its neighbors.
plants.troubleshooting: Comfrey has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Rich soil with a near neutral Ph.
plants.position: Full sun in cool climates, partial afternoon shade where summers are very hot.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in late winter and set out seedlings, or start with purchased plants. Echinacea often does not bloom reliably until its second year in the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: Echinacea is a hardy perennial that survives very cold winters. Plants become dormant in winter and re-emerge in spring.
plants.feeding: Spread rich compost over the dormant plants each winter.
plants.notes: Echinacea is grown for its beautiful flowers and for the medicinal properties of teas and tinctures made from roots, leaves and flowers.
plants.harvesting: Dig plants in early fall to harvest the roots. Small divisions with skimpy root systems can be replanted and allowed to grow for another year.  For enhancing immunity to colds, echinacea tinctures or teas are taken every few hours for several days.
plants.companions: Monarda. Echinacea’s purple blossoms contrast well with pink, yellow or orange flowers.
plants.troubleshooting: It is not known whether or not colorful new varieties of Echinacea have medicinal properties that compare to older strains, which are preferred by butterflies.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot where fennel’s tall branches will not cause unwanted shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in early spring, or plant them outdoors while the weather is still cool.
plants.frostTolerant: A short-lived hardy perennial, fennel will survive winter temperatures to 0F/-17C.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Fennel flowers attract numerous small beneficial insects.
plants.harvesting: Gather fennel fronds as you need them in the kitchen. Fennel can reseed to the point of weediness. Gathering and using the blooms as cut flowers will prevent excessive reseeding.
plants.companions: Cosmos. Cucumber, squash, melons, pumpkin and other low, vining plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Prune back fennel plants in mid fall, before cold weather turns the plants to mush.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Plants spaced 6 inches (15 cm) apart will grow into a solid mass in 3 years.
plants.frostTolerant: Garlic chives are hardy perennials that survive winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
