plants.notes: Garlic chives produce white, lightly scented flowers in late summer. Gather them for use as cut flowers to keep garlic chives from reseeding. Like regular chives, garlic chives can become invasive.
plants.harvesting: Do not harvest in the first year.  In spring, gather handfuls of greens for use in the kitchen. The leaves become somewhat tough in summer.
plants.companions: Oregano, Thyme, Carrot, Tomato, Grape Vine and Rose. Also, other mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Deadhead garlic chives to limit reseeding.

plants.soil: Any moist, fertile soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot with room to spread. The roots often spread several feet in the course of a season.
plants.sowPlant: Set out roots any time that the ground is not frozen, preferably from early spring to early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Horseradish is a hardy perennial that will survive winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Persistent and long lived, horseradish can become invasive if you accidentally allow pieces of root to be spread around the garden.
plants.harvesting: Dig roots anytime you need them in the kitchen. Keep scrubbed roots in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Potatoes. Usually horseradish should be planted by itself.
plants.troubleshooting: Horseradish seldom has problems with insects or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Some strains are propagated only from rooted cuttings.  A mature clump of lavender will grow to 24" (60 cm) wide.
plants.frostTolerant: A hardy perennial from the Mediterranean, lavender will survive winter temperatures to 0F/-17C.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed beyond annual topdressing with rich compost in spring.
plants.notes: Try different strains, and even species, to find the right lavender for your climate. Lavender demands excellent drainage, and benefits from dry, airy conditions.
plants.harvesting: Gather spikes of lavender flowers as soon as they open, and dry in small bundles before storing in an airtight container. You can also dry lavender branches for use in recipes, sachets or potpourri.
plants.companions: Rose, Rosemary, Sage, Mint, Agastache, Apple, Cherry, Peach, Pear and Plum. Colourful petunias, nasturitums or other annual flowers that contrast with lavender’s gray-green foliage and blue flowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Wait until spring to prune back lavender plants, because the dead stems help shelter the base of the plants from harsh winter weather.

plants.soil: Rich well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or obtain a rooted piece from a friend or neighbour who has an established clump. Lemon balm can be transplanted from early spring to early summer. You also can start seeds in late winter, and set out the seedlings in spring.  Lemon balm grows into a rounded mound.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial, lemon balm can survive temperatures to -20F (-30C).
plants.feeding: Not generally required.
plants.notes: Lemon balm is very easy to grow. Locate it where leaves can be conveniently picked, crushed and sniffed.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying or steeping into tinctures in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Squash, Tomato and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Control lemon balm’s spread by cutting back flowering stems in late summer.

plants.soil: High quality organic potting soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or obtain a stem tip cutting from a friend and root it in late spring. Cuttings and divisions are best taken when plants are emerging from dormancy in late spring. Lemon verbena is typically grown as a specimen plant in a container at least 12in (30 cm) in diameter. A mature plant, grown in a sunken container, will occupy a space 18in (45 cm) square if well staked but still expect lanky growth that responds well to monthly trimming.
plants.frostTolerant: Lemon verbena is a tender perennial; its roots should not be allowed to freeze. In most climates, it is best grown in a container that can be kept in a cool (but not freezing) place through winter, the plant’s dormant season.
plants.feeding: Fertilize with an organic water soluble fertilizer every two weeks from spring to fall, when the plant is actively growing in a container. Feeding is not generally needed for plants grown in beds in semi-tropical climates.
plants.notes: Lemon verbena is the most "lemony" of all lemon foliage herbs. Locate it where leaves can be conveniently picked, crushed and sniffed.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as desired. Smelling lemon verbena is a special delight of summer best captured in teas. Dry perfect leaves in small bunches, and store them in airtight containers.  This is a fragrance herb to delight your sense of smell. Incorporate stems in flower arrangements scent the air with lemon. Put a piece in your pocket.
plants.companions: Monarda. Use this 3-foot (90 cm) tall herb as a movable accent in your summer herb garden.
plants.troubleshooting: Repot plants in spring, gradually moving to slightly larger pots. In summer, sink the pot into the ground to protect it from overheating and drying out on hot days.

plants.soil: Rich soil that retains moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun in cool climates; partial shade where summers are very hot.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Lovage will reach its mature size in about three years.    One plant is usually sufficient, but it’s a good idea to start a new plant every few years.  At maturity, lovage will need a 3-foot (90 cm) square space. It is a very large herb. Because of its 5-foot (1.5 meter) height, lovage is best located at the edge or rear of the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: Lovage is a hardy perennial that survives winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Topdress the soil around the dormant plant with rich compost each winter.
plants.notes: Tender young growth has the best flavour. In summer, consider pruning plants back to force them to push out a flush of new leaves.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen for their celery flavor. Freeze extra leaves by covering chopped lovage leaves with water in ice cube trays.
plants.companions: Potatoes, Pepper and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Remove flowers should lovage produce too many unwanted seedlings. Or, gather lovage seeds and use them in cooking as a substitute for celery seeds.

plants.soil: Rich soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Morning sun with partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased plants, set out in spring. Many selected cultivars are resistant to powdery mildew, a common problem with this species.  12" (30 cm) each way (minimum) is a good spacing for an initial planting of 3 plants. Monarda is a slight spreader, but not invasive like mint. Over time, a happy plant will form a mount 4 feet (120 cm) high and wide.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial, monarda can survive temperatures to -20F (-30C).
plants.feeding: Topdress the dormant plants with good compost in winter.
plants.notes: Pastel flower colours look especially cooling in partial shade. Leaves are excellent for tea.
plants.harvesting: Harvest stems to dry for tea in early summer, before the plants bloom. The plants will regrow after cutting, then bloom.
plants.companions: Lovage, Cosmos, Corn, Squash, Beans and Echinacea. Salad greens, other shade-tolerant plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Moving clumps every few years may help limit problems with powdery mildew.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, because stevia seeds are very reluctant to sprout. Plants are grown from rooted cuttings taken from greenhouse-grown plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Stevia is a tender perennial grown as a vegetatively propagated annual. Parent plants brought through winter indoors provide rootable stems in spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed. If needed, a water soluble fertilizer can be provided in midsummer to invigorate plants.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in midsummer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Thyme and Marjoram. Stevia is an upright plant which goes with mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Stevia thrives in warm weather, and may grow slowly under very cool conditions.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot near the back or edge of a garden bed, because tarragon is a lanky plant.
plants.sowPlant: Set out a purchased plant in late spring. The best strain, called French tarragon, is propagated exclusively by rooting cuttings. At maturity, tarragon will need a 3-foot (90 cm) square space.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial, tarragon can survive temperatures to -20F (-30C).
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Tarragon covers itself with yellow-orange blossoms in late summer.
plants.harvesting: Gather stem tips as you need them in the kitchen. Tarragon can be dried, or you can use fresh tarragon to make flavored vinegars.
plants.companions: Eggplant. Often planted with thyme and other low, mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Tarragon has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out seedlings two to four weeks before your last frost. After two years, valerian will grow into a 18" (45 cm) wide clump.
plants.frostTolerant: Extremely cold hardy, even in harsh winter climates. Plants die back to the ground in winter and re-emerge in spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Valerian produces extremely fragrant flowers in early summer. Gather them for use as cut flowers to keep valerian from reseeding and becoming invasive.
plants.harvesting: Dig roots in fall or early spring and dry outdoors, because they release an unpleasant smell as they dry. Store in airtight container. Dried valerian roots are used to make a bedtime tea that promotes sleep. They are also much loved by cats and dogs.
plants.companions: Echinacea, Catnip, Agastache and Dill. Often planted with low, mound-forming herbs and flowers. Valerian can stand 5 feet (1.5 meters) tall when it is in full bloom.
plants.troubleshooting: Control valerian's spread by cutting back flowering stems before they can shed seeds in your garden.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in late winter to early spring when growing cold-hardy bunching varieties. Or, plant large sets close together and harvest the plants when young.
plants.frostTolerant: Many varieties are cold hardy to -10F (- 33C) when well rooted in the garden.
plants.feeding: Work an organic fertilizer into the soil prior to setting out seedlings or sets.
plants.notes: Any immature onion can be eaten as a green onion, or scallion.
plants.harvesting: Pull individual plants as you need them in the kitchen. With perennial bunching varieties, lift clumps in spring or fall and replant some of the divisions.
plants.companions: Beet, Lettuce, Potatoes, Carrot, Tomato and Cabbage. Often planted with mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Slugs often chew holes in onion leaves in wet weather.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in late winter to early spring when growing cold-hardy bunching varieties. Or, plant large sets close together and harvest the plants when young.
plants.frostTolerant: Many varieties are cold hardy to -10F (- 33C) when well rooted in the garden.
plants.feeding: Work an organic fertilizer into the soil prior to setting out seedlings or sets.
plants.notes: Any immature onion can be eaten as a green onion, or scallion.
plants.harvesting: Pull individual plants as you need them in the kitchen. With perennial bunching varieties, lift clumps in spring or fall and replant some of the divisions.
plants.companions: Beet, Lettuce, Potatoes, Thyme and Chives. Often planted with mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Slugs often chew holes in onion leaves in wet weather.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased bulblets or corms, set out 10 to 6 weeks before your first fall frost, or in early fall.
plants.frostTolerant: Multiplying onions and other perennial strains are typically hardy to -26F (-15C) when given a protective winter mulch.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting a new bed.
plants.notes: Most perennial onions grow vigorously in early spring and die back in midsummer. These interesting yet variable plants resemble shallots more than other onions.
plants.harvesting: Harvest bulblets from topsetting onions and use them as pearl onions in the kitchen. When plants die back, cured roots often yield a small shallot. In spring or fall, you can cut off small divisions for use as scallions (green onions).
plants.companions: Potatoes, Lettuce, Beet, Thyme and Chives. Often grouped with garlic and shallots.
plants.troubleshooting: In fall, move perennial onions to a fresh location to avoid problems with onion root maggots, which are attracted by decomposing onion tissues.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: If you don't start your own seeds, set out sets (small dormant bulbs) or pencil-size seedlings in spring, while the soil is still cool.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertilizer into the bed or row before planting your onions, taking care to get it into the soil below the plants. Do not feed plants that are nearing maturity if you want very sweet onions.
plants.notes: Onions respond to changing day length. Grow short-day varieties in southern latitudes. Long-day varieties work best in northern areas. Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in bulb color, size and shape.
plants.harvesting: Harvest young onions as scallions. When bulbs form and the tops of the plants fall over, pull them and cure in a warm place for about 10 days before storing.
plants.companions: Beet, Carrot, Swiss Chard and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: If you don't start your own seeds, set out sets in fall when the soil is cool. Japanese bunching onions are often planted in the fall in cooler climates.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertilizer into the bed or row before planting your onions, taking care to get it into the soil below the plants. Do not feed plants that are nearing maturity if you want very sweet onions.
plants.notes: Onions respond to changing day length. Grow short-day varieties in southern latitudes. Long-day varieties work best in northern areas. Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in bulb color, size and shape.
plants.harvesting: Harvest young onions as scallions. When bulbs form and the tops of the plants fall over, pull them and cure in a warm place for about 10 days before storing.
plants.companions: Beet, Carrot, Cabbage, Chinese Cabbage and Swiss Chard.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds in late spring, after the soil has warmed. In cool climates, you can give plants a two-week head start indoors. After the first season, look for volunteer seedlings and move them to where you want them to grow.
plants.frostTolerant: Malabar spinach is a tropical plant that tolerates neither frost nor cold soil.
plants.feeding: Mix in a balanced organic fertilizer when preparing the planting site.
plants.notes: Malabar spinach is highly ornamental, and is easily trained up a trellis. Some varieties have red stems.   Malabar spinach is typically grown on a tower, fence or tepee style trellis.  Four trellised plants will occupy a space 18 inches (45 cm) square at maturity.
plants.harvesting: Clip leaves as you need them in the kitchen. When lightly steamed or stir-fried, the leaves resemble a cross between spinach and chard.
plants.companions: Asparagus. Malabar spinach is a vigorous climbing plant that needs a trellis or other support. It will quickly overtake other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: In the fall, gather up dead plants and compost them to limit reseeding in the garden. In some climates, Malabar spinach can become weedy.

plants.soil: Well-drained, reasonably good soil, though will tolerate a variety of sites.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in late spring, planting out when all risk of frost past or direct into the soil from then onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Requires very little attention.  Soak seeds in water overnight before planting to improve germination.
plants.harvesting: Pull a few leaves from the outside of the plant regularly from mid summer onwards to produce more growth.
plants.companions: Peas, Beans and Strawberry.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in prior to planting.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors in early spring, or set out purchased seedlings.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes. Tolerates moderate frost, but damaged by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Drench every two weeks with an organic liquid fertilizer.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf color (such as red cabbage) and type (smooth-leaf or savoy).
plants.harvesting: Cut heads when they reach the size you prefer.
plants.companions: Dill, Agastache, Thyme, Mint, Tansy, Chamomile, Garlic, Cabbage, Kale and Cauliflower.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split. Watch for green imported cabbageworms, the larvae of the cabbage white butterfly. Exclude the adults with row covers.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in prior to planting.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in summer for harvesting in the fall.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes. Tolerates moderate frost, but damaged by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Drench every two weeks with an organic liquid fertilizer.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf color (such as red cabbage) and head shape. Late-maturing fall cabbage varieties are great for cool storage or making into kraut.
plants.harvesting: Wait until a few light frosts have passed to harvest, because cool weather enhances the sweet flavor of cabbage.
plants.companions: Marigold, Nasturtium, Tomato and Celery.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split. Watch for green imported cabbageworms, the larvae of the cabbage white butterfly. Exclude the adults with row covers.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in prior to planting.
plants.sowPlant: Sow late summer to move to final positions in fall to be over-wintered and ready for spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Should tolerate moderate frost.
plants.feeding: Drench every two weeks with an organic liquid fertilizer.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf color and type. Most early-maturing cabbage varieties produce smallish heads.
plants.harvesting: Cut heads when they reach the size you prefer. Small secondary heads often grow from the base of early cabbage plants after the primary head is cut.
plants.companions: Dill, Agastache, Thyme, Nasturtium, Chamomile, Tomato, Celery, Mint and Tansy.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for green imported cabbageworms, the larvae of the cabbage white butterfly. Exclude the adults with row covers.

plants.notes: Other perennial plants. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
Cover crop, usually planted in fall after others have been harvested.  You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow buckwheat from late spring to late summer, whenever a bed will be unused for more than three weeks.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 4 inches (10 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Buckwheat cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: When using buckwheat to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Limit reseeding by pulling up or turning under buckwheat just after it blooms, but before it develops mature seeds.
plants.harvesting: Buckwheat can be pulled up and composted or turned under any time. It will return the most organic matter when taken down 5 to 6 weeks after seeding.
plants.companions: Brussels Sprouts and Kale. Mixes well with upright flowers, and makes an attractive backdrop for herbs. A small bed of buckwheat in bloom will attract numerous beneficial insects.
plants.troubleshooting: Buckwheat has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in summer, when the soil is warm. Crowder peas will not germinate in cold soil.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Crowder peas are semi-tropical plants that crave warm growing conditions.
plants.feeding: When using crowder peas to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Crowder peas are a good nitrogen-fixing summer cover crop for warm climates, where the vegetable seasons are sharply divided by a period of hot weather.
plants.harvesting: Pull up or turn under plants any time after they are about 4 weeks old, but before they develop pods.
plants.companions: Cosmos and Celosia. Other heat-tolerant summer-blooming annuals.
plants.troubleshooting: Rarely bothered by pests or diseases when grown in warm weather.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow fenugreek from late spring to late summer, whenever a bed will be unused for more than eight weeks.  Direct seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 6 inches (15 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Fenugreek cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: When using fenugreek to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: On warm days, fenugreek often emits a fragrance similar to that of maple syrup. It also can be grown as a medicinal herb.
plants.harvesting: Mow plants before turning them under, or pull them up and compost them if you want to use the spot for planting right away.
plants.companions: Buckwheat, Beans and Crowder Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Fenugreek rarely has problems with pests and diseases when grown in home gardens.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer to use mustard as a short-term fall cover crop. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 6 inches (15 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Mustard is cool-season annual that can tolerate light frosts but not hard freezes.
plants.feeding: None generally needed, because mustard is customarily used as a late summer/fall cover crop to take up nitrogen left in the soil by corn or other vegetables.
plants.notes: You can gather individual leaves for cooking, which taste best after the first frost has passed. Mustard residue suppresses soil-borne nematodes, so it is an excellent cover crop to grow before potatoes.
plants.harvesting: Chop down the green foliage with a hoe and turn it under just before hard freezes are expected. The mustard roots and foliage will rot during the winter months.
plants.companions: Grape Vine, Beans, Peas, Apple and Plum. Mustard does an excellent job of suppressing weeds when grown in a solid mass.
plants.troubleshooting: Irrigation is often needed to get a good stand in dry fall weather.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds from late spring to early summer. Soybeans must have warm soil to germinate and grow.  Poke holes into a cultivated bed or row to plant soybean seeds about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 6 inches (15 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Soybean is a warm-season crop to grow in summer.
plants.feeding: When using soybeans to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Soybean cover crops are used primarily to add nitrogen to poor soil.
plants.harvesting: Chop down or pull up plants just as they begin to flower. Nitrogen nodules left behind in the soil add fertility.
plants.companions: Buckwheat.
plants.troubleshooting: Soybeans are very attractive to deer and Japanese beetles.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer so that plants can become established before cold weather comes. In cold climates, crimson clover can be planted in early spring instead of fall. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. No thinning is required.
plants.frostTolerant: In the US, crimson clover is hardy to Zone 6. Established plantings made in early fall can tolerate temperatures to 0F (-18 C) or slightly colder.
plants.feeding: When using crimson clover to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results. Using inoculated seed can also help to grow a vigorous stand.
plants.notes: Crimson clover is one of the most beautiful cover crops you can grow.
plants.harvesting: Take down plants just as the red tops begin to fade, but before the plants produce mature seeds. The easiest method is to slice plants off at the soil line with a sharp hoe. They can then be turned under or composted. Nitrogen nodules left behind in the soil add fertility.
plants.companions: Cornflower and Broccoli. Often planted with hardy annual flowers including bachelor buttons and corn poppies.
plants.troubleshooting: Crimson clover plants become quite tough as they age, but they seldom regrow when cut off at the soil line.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow hairy vetch in late summer so the plants can become established before cold weather comes.   Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 3 inches (7 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. No thinning is required.
plants.frostTolerant: Many varieties are cold hardy to -20F (- 29C) when well rooted in the garden.
plants.feeding: When using hairy vetch to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Hairy vetch stays small through winter and makes vigorous growth in spring. It is highly recommended as a cover crop to grow before tomatoes.
plants.harvesting: Take down plants in spring, 3 weeks before the bed is needed for summer vegetables. The easiest method is to slice plants off at the soil line with a sharp hoe. The cut plants can be allowed to dry into a surface mulch.
plants.companions: Rye and Wheat.
plants.troubleshooting: Hairy vetch can become weedy if allowed to produce mature seeds.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer to grow a cover crop that forms its own mulch when it is winterkilled, or when using oats as a companion crop for slower-growing legumes. Oats also can be grown as a spring cover crop to increase soil organic matter.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 3 inches (7 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 8 inches (20cm) apart when growing oats with other cover crops.
plants.frostTolerant: Oats are a cool-weather crop that can tolerate light frosts but is usually killed by temperatures below 5F (-15C).
plants.feeding: None generally needed, especially when oats are grown with nitrogen-fixing cover crops such as winter peas, winter beans or hairy vetch.
plants.notes: Oats are an ideal late summer cover crop where winters are cold enough to kill it; the dead residue forms its own winter mulch, which is usually well rotted by spring.
plants.harvesting: Young oats can be turned under anytime. In mild winter climates, oats should be mowed and tilled before seedheads appear in late spring.
plants.companions: Winter Peas and Winter Field Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Rotting oat foliage has herbicidal properties, in that it inhibits germination of weed seeds. Always wait 3 weeks before sowing seeds into soil where oats have been turned under.

plants.soil: Any soil, including poorly drained sites.
plants.sowPlant: Walk over the planted site to firm the seeds into the ground, and then water to promote fast germination. Although customarily grown in fall, annual rye can be used as a fast-growing cover crop in all but the hottest summer months.   Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 1 inch (2 cm) apart and one-fourth inch (.5 cm) deep.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardiness varies with variety. Some strains are killed by temperatures around -10F (-23 C), while especially hardy varieties can tolerate more extreme cold.
plants.feeding: When using annual rye to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Mature annual rye plants can be difficult to dig out. In areas where annual rye is not killed by winter weather, mow down the plants and turn under the residue when the plants are young.
plants.harvesting: In a home garden, annual rye cover crops are easiest to manage if they are mowed every few weeks. The clippings make excellent mulch.
plants.companions: Raspberry and Garlic. Annual rye forms a very thick stand, and is normally grown alone to choke out weeds and boost organic matter, especially in new gardening sites.
plants.troubleshooting: Annual rye has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in early fall, though cereal rye will germinate in mid fall, after the soil has lost its warmth. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 3 inches (7 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 8 inches (20cm) apart when growing cereal rye with other cover crops.
plants.frostTolerant: Most varieties of cereal rye can survive temperatures to -20F (-29C) if the plants are well rooted before the ground freezes.
plants.feeding: When using cereal rye to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase organic matter and break up dense subsoil.  Can be sown later in the fall than other cover crops.
plants.harvesting: Mow down plants in spring, before they develop seeds. Or, gather the immature seed tops and dry them for arrangements, and then pull up the plants. They can be used as mulch or composted.
plants.companions: Winter Field Beans, Winter Peas and Hairy Vetch. In spring, widely spaced rye plants can serve as trellises for garden peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Deer often nibble cereal rye in winter.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer or early fall for an overwintered crop. Spring wheat can be planted while the soil is still cool.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 3 inches (7 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 8 inches (20cm) apart when growing wheat with other cover crops.
plants.frostTolerant: Many varieties are cold hardy to -10F (- 23C) when well rooted in the garden. Grow varieties described as soft spring wheat in spring, but choose hard winter wheat for fall.
plants.feeding: When using wheat to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase organic matter, break up dense subsoil and crowd out weeds. Makes a beautiful show in spring.
plants.harvesting: Mow down plants in spring, before they develop seeds. Or, gather the immature seed tops and dry them for arrangements, and then pull up the plants. They can be used as mulch or composted.
plants.companions: Winter Field Beans, Hairy Vetch and Winter Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Deer often nibble wheat grown in winter.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Poke holes in prepared seedbed and plant seeds 2 inches (5 cm) deep. Winter field beans may be planted in late summer, or in very early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: A cool-season annual, winter field beans can tolerate frost but are killed by temperatures below 10to 15F (-12 to -9C). In the US, they are rated as hardy to Zone 8.
plants.feeding: When using winter field beans to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase soil nitrogen. Easier to turn under using hand tools compared to other cover crops.  Small-seeded varieties are best for cover crop use.
plants.harvesting: For maximum nitrogen gain, chop plants down and turn them under as soon as they begin to bloom.  You also can pull up the plants and compost them.
plants.companions: Wheat, Rye and Oats.
plants.troubleshooting: Winter field beans attract numerous beneficial insects. Do not grow them just before potatoes or other root crops, because field beans can host rootknot nematodes.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Poke holes in prepared seedbed and plant seeds 1 to 2 inches (3 to 5 cm) deep. Gaps between plants can be filled with an upright grain.
plants.frostTolerant: A cool-season annual, winter field peas (Austrian peas), can tolerate heavy frost but are killed by temperatures below 0to -10F (-17 to -23C). In the US, they are rated as hardy to Zone 7.
plants.feeding: When using winter field peas to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase soil nitrogen. Highly recommended as a winter cover crop to go before sweet corn because of its vigorous nitrogen-fixing activity in early spring. Very low weedy potential compared to other cover crops.
plants.harvesting: For maximum nitrogen gain, chop plants down and turn them under as soon as they begin to bloom.  You also can pull up the plants and compost them.
plants.companions: Wheat, Rye and Oats.
plants.troubleshooting: Allow at least 3 weeks after turning under winter pea residue before direct-seeding vegetables, because the rotting vegetation can cause an increase in damping off of seedlings.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil, or high quality organic potting soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, because bay stem cuttings are very difficult to root. Spring and early summer are the best times to adopt a new bay plant. Outdoors, allow 2m (6ft) between plants being grown as a hedge. When grown in containers, gradually shift plants to a container at least 30cm (12") in diameter. A mature plant, grown in a sunken container, will occupy a space 45cm (18") square.
plants.frostTolerant: Bay is a half-hardy shrub or small tree that can tolerate winter temperatures no lower than -7C (20F). In cold climates, bay is best grown in a container that can be kept indoors in winter.
plants.feeding: Fertilise bay grown in containers with an organic water soluble fertiliser every three weeks from spring to late summer. Feeding is not generally needed for plants grown outdoors as herb garden specimen plants or hedges.
plants.notes: When growing bay as a potted plant, allow the soil to become dry as autumn approaches. Through winter, allow the soil to dry between waterings.
plants.harvesting: Stem or leaves as desired from early summer to autumn. In midsummer, gather perfect small branches and dry them in small bunches. Stored dried leaves in airtight containers.
plants.companions: Beans. Use an attractively potted bay plant as a movable accent in your summer herb garden. In mild winter climates, use bay as a landscape shrub or small tree.
plants.troubleshooting: Repot containers every other spring, gradually moving to slightly larger pots. Outdoors, prune as needed if plants outgrow their space.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot where bumblebees and other large pollinators are desired.
plants.sowPlant: Plant the large seeds in your garden in late spring. A fresh crop of plants can be planted in late summer for bloom in autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings will survive light frosts, but older plants are easily damaged.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Borage seedlings are only edible when very young. Large plants produce edible, starry blue flowers that attract bees in droves. The foliage can be gathered and composted.
plants.harvesting: Cut back borage plants by half their size in midsummer to encourage reblooming. Blossom clusters make beautiful but short-lived cut flowers or edible garnishes.
plants.companions: Tomato, Strawberry and Squash. A good companion for any crop that needs strong defense from insects. Borage attracts large buzzing insects that dominate their air space.
plants.troubleshooting: Beware of sleepy bees when pruning or otherwise working with mature borage plants.

plants.soil: Rich soil that retains moisture well.
plants.position: A sunny spot that is easily accessed for cutting.
plants.sowPlant: Plant the curled seeds in your garden from early spring onward, or start them indoors and set out the sturdy seedlings. Allow some plants to produce mature seeds to scatter where you want to see calendula seedlings in subsequent seasons.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings tolerate light frosts. Established plants may rebloom in late autumn if protected from damaging hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Calendula blossoms are edible and can be used to bring orange colour to rice or potato dishes, or snip them onto soups or salads for extra flavour and nutrition. Use clean scissors to snip off petal tips, and compost the rest.
plants.harvesting: Cut flowers as soon as they fully open, preferably in late morning, and promptly dry them. Calendulas make marginal cut flowers because they partially close at night.  For medicinal use  harvest and dry entire calendula flowers. Infuse them in vegetable oil to make a medicinal oil with a long history of use for healing burned or abraded skin.
plants.companions: Peas, Carrot, Cucumber, Asparagus, Lettuce and Tomato. Spring salad vegetables.
plants.troubleshooting: Elderly plants suffer from powdery mildew and other fungal ailments. It’s best to send them to the compost pile and grow fresh replacement plants in a new place.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade
plants.sowPlant: Catnip can be started from seeds sown indoors, or from a rooted cutting or purchased plant. Set out plants at about the time of your last frost.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy in cold climates provided the plant is well-rooted and mulched. If desired, small plants can be potted up in autumn and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Pinching back in late spring helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Catnip flower clusters are visited by numerous small beneficial insects. If you can, grow clumps in different parts of your garden.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as desired for the pleasure of your cats. One small stem tip with four to eight leaves is plenty for one or two cats to enjoy. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Sage, Cosmos, Monarda and Rose. Most other herbs that grow to more than 12 inches tall.
plants.troubleshooting: Clip off spent blossom clusters to limit reseeding in your garden.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot, for example at the end of a vegetable row or bed.
plants.sowPlant: Seeds can be started indoors or sown directly in the garden. When allowed to shed mature seeds, chamomile often becomes a welcome volunteer plant.
plants.frostTolerant: Young seedlings easily tolerate spring frosts, and may survive winters in mild climates. The easiest chamomile to grow is a cool-season annual.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Feathery chamomile foliage contrasts well with the textures of other herbs and flowers.
plants.harvesting: Cut branches when they are holding numerous open flowers, and hang in small bunches to dry. Chamomile tea is made from the blossoms only. When the stems are dry, pop off the blossoms and store them in an airtight container.
plants.companions: Calendula, Coriander, Feverfew, Cabbage, Onion, Onions and Spinach. Leafy greens grown in spring, as well as spring-blooming herbs and flowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Rabbits enjoy nibbling chamomile foliage.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors or sow them where you want them to grow, or start with a purchased plant. New growth emerges in mid-spring, followed by flowers that attract pollinators in early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Extremely cold hardy perennials, comfrey plants become dormant in winter and re-emerge every spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Comfrey is a fine source of greens for composting or for using as a mulch around nutrient-hungry plants. When the large plants are cut back in summer, old branches are quickly replaced by a fresh flush of foliage.
plants.harvesting: Roots to be used to make medicinal ointments or skin creams can be harvested at any time, but preferably in early winter. Gather greens for composting in early summer and again in autumn. For medicinal use topical preparations made from comfrey roots are traditionally used to promote healing of sprains and broken bones by increasing circulation to the affected area. However it should not be taken internally as comfrey contains compounds that may harm the liver.
plants.companions: Apple, Apricot, Peach, Pear, Plum, Persimmon and Nectarine. Comfrey is a large plant that tends to crowd out its neighbours.
plants.troubleshooting: Comfrey has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Rich soil with a near neutral Ph.
plants.position: Full sun in cool climates, partial afternoon shade where summers are very hot.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in late winter and set out seedlings, or start with purchased plants. Echinacea often does not bloom reliably until its second year in the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: Echinacea is a hardy perennial that survives very cold winters. Plants become dormant in winter and re-emerge in spring.
plants.feeding: Spread rich compost over the dormant plants each winter.
plants.notes: Echinacea is grown for its beautiful flowers and for the medicinal properties of teas and tinctures made from roots, leaves and flowers.
plants.harvesting: Dig plants up in early autumn to harvest the roots. Small divisions with skimpy root systems can be replanted and allowed to grow for another year.  For enhancing immunity to colds, echinacea tinctures or teas are taken every few hours for several days.
plants.companions: Monarda. Echinacea’s purple blossoms contrast well with pink, yellow or orange flowers.
plants.troubleshooting: It is not known whether or not colourful new varieties of Echinacea have medicinal properties that compare to the older strains, which are preferred by butterflies.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot where fennel’s tall branches will not cause unwanted shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in early spring, or plant them outdoors while the weather is still cool.
plants.frostTolerant: A short-lived hardy perennial, fennel will survive winter temperatures to -17C (0F).
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Fennel flowers attract numerous small beneficial insects.
plants.harvesting: Gather fennel fronds as you need them in the kitchen. Fennel can reseed to the point of weediness. Gathering and using the blooms as cut flowers will prevent excessive reseeding.
plants.companions: Cosmos. Cucumber, squash, melons, pumpkin and other low, vining plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Prune back fennel plants in mid autumn, before cold weather turns the plants to mush.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Plants spaced 15 cm (6in) apart will grow into a solid mass in 3 years.
plants.frostTolerant: Garlic chives are hardy perennials that survive winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Garlic chives produce white, lightly scented flowers in late summer. Gather them for use as cut flowers to keep garlic chives from reseeding. Like regular chives, garlic chives can become invasive.
plants.harvesting: Do not harvest in the first year.  In spring, gather handfuls of greens for use in the kitchen. The leaves become somewhat tough in summer.
plants.companions: Apple, Carrot, Grape Vine, Peas, Rose, Tomato, Gooseberry, Raspberry and Strawberry. Also, other mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Deadhead garlic chives to limit reseeding.

plants.soil: Any moist, fertile soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot with room to spread. The roots often spread several feet in the course of a season.
plants.sowPlant: Set out roots any time that the ground is not frozen, preferably from early spring to early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Horseradish is a hardy perennial that will survive winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Persistent and long lived, horseradish can become invasive if you accidentally allow pieces of root to be spread around the garden.
plants.harvesting: Dig roots anytime you need them in the kitchen. Keep scrubbed roots in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Potatoes. Usually horseradish should be planted by itself.
plants.troubleshooting: Horseradish seldom has problems with insects or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Some strains are propagated only from rooted cuttings.  A mature clump of lavender will grow to 60 cm (24") wide.
plants.frostTolerant: A hardy perennial from the Mediterranean, lavender will survive winter temperatures to -17C / 0F.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed beyond annual topdressing with rich compost in spring.
plants.notes: Try different strains, and even species, to find the right lavender for your climate. Lavender demands excellent drainage, and benefits from dry, airy conditions.
plants.harvesting: Gather spikes of lavender flowers as soon as they open, and dry in small bundles before storing in an airtight container. You can also dry lavender branches for use in recipes, sachets or potpourri.
plants.companions: Rose, Rosemary, Sage, Mint, Agastache, Apple, Cherry, Peach, Pear and Plum. Colourful petunias, nasturitums or other annual flowers that contrast with lavender’s gray-green foliage and blue flowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Wait until spring to prune back lavender plants, because the dead stems help shelter the base of the plants from harsh winter weather.

plants.soil: Rich well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or obtain a rooted piece from a friend or neighbour who has an established clump. Lemon balm can be transplanted from early spring to early summer. You also can start seeds in late winter, and set out the seedlings in spring.  Lemon balm grows into a rounded mound.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial, lemon balm can survive temperatures to -30C (-20F).
plants.feeding: Not generally required.
plants.notes: Lemon balm is very easy to grow. Locate it where leaves can be conveniently picked, crushed and sniffed.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying or steeping into tinctures in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Tomato and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Control lemon balm’s spread by cutting back flowering stems in late summer.

plants.soil: High quality organic potting soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or obtain a stem tip cutting from a friend and root it in late spring. Lemon verbena cuttings and divisions are best taken when plants are emerging from dormancy in late spring. Lemon verbena is typically grown as a specimen plant in a container at least 30 cm (12in) in diameter. A mature plant, grown in a sunken container, will occupy a space 45 cm (18in) square if well staked but still expect lanky growth that responds well to monthly trimming.
plants.frostTolerant: Lemon verbena is a tender perennial; its roots should not be allowed to freeze. In most climates, it is best grown in a container that can be kept in a cool (but not freezing) place through winter, the plant’s dormant season.
plants.feeding: Fertilise with an organic water soluble fertiliser every two weeks from spring to fall, when the plant is actively growing in a container. Feeding is not generally needed for plants grown in beds in semi-tropical climates.
plants.notes: Lemon verbena is the most "lemony" of all lemon foliage herbs. Locate it where leaves can be conveniently picked, crushed and sniffed.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as desired. Smelling lemon verbena is a special delight of summer best captured in teas. Dry perfect leaves in small bunches, and store them in airtight containers.  This is a fragrance herb to delight your sense of smell and can be used in flower arrangements.
plants.companions: Monarda and Salvia. Use this 3-foot (90 cm) tall herb as a movable accent in your summer herb garden.
plants.troubleshooting: Repot plants in spring, gradually moving to slightly larger pots. In summer, sink the pot into the ground to protect it from overheating and drying out on hot days.

plants.soil: Rich soil that retains moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun in cool climates; partial shade where summers are very hot.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Lovage will reach its mature size in about three years.  One plant is usually sufficient, but it’s a good idea to start a new plant every few years.  At maturity, lovage will need a 90 cm (3ft) square space. It is a very large herb. Because of its 1.5 meter (5ft) height, lovage is best located at the edge or rear of the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: Lovage is a hardy perennial that survives winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Topdress the soil around the dormant plant with rich compost each winter.
plants.notes: Tender young growth has the best flavour. In summer, consider pruning plants back to force them to push out a flush of new leaves.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen for their celery flavor. Freeze extra leaves by covering chopped lovage leaves with water in ice cube trays.
plants.companions: Potatoes, Pepper and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Remove flowers should lovage produce too many unwanted seedlings. Or, gather lovage seeds and use them in cooking as a substitute for celery seeds.

plants.soil: Rich soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Morning sun with partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased plants, set out in spring. Many selected cultivars are resistant to powdery mildew, a common problem with this species.  30 cm (12in) each way is a good spacing for an initial planting of 3 plants. Monarda is a slight spreader, but not invasive like mint. Over time, a happy plant will form a mount 120 cm (4ft) high and wide.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial which can survive temperatures to -30C (-20F).
plants.feeding: Topdress the dormant plants with good compost in winter.
plants.notes: Pastel flower colours look especially cooling in partial shade. Leaves are excellent for tea.
plants.harvesting: Harvest stems to dry for tea in early summer, before the plants bloom. The plants will regrow after cutting, then bloom.
plants.companions: Lovage, Cosmos, Squash, Beans and Echinacea. Salad greens, other shade-tolerant plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Moving clumps every few years may help limit problems with powdery mildew.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, because stevia seeds are very reluctant to sprout. Plants are grown from rooted cuttings taken from greenhouse-grown plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Stevia is a tender perennial grown as a vegetatively propagated annual. Parent plants brought through winter indoors provide rootable stems in spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed. If needed, a water soluble organic fertiliser can be provided in midsummer to invigorate plants.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in midsummer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Thyme and Marjoram. Stevia is an upright plant which goes with mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Stevia thrives in warm weather, and may grow slowly under very cool conditions.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot near the back or edge of a garden bed, because tarragon is a lanky plant.
plants.sowPlant: Set out a purchased plant in late spring. The best strain, called French tarragon, is propagated exclusively by rooting cuttings. At maturity, tarragon will need a 90 cm (3ft) square space.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial, tarragon can survive temperatures to --30C (-20F).
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Tarragon covers itself with yellow-orange blossoms in late summer.
plants.harvesting: Gather stem tips as you need them in the kitchen. Tarragon can be dried, or you can use fresh tarragon to make flavored vinegars.
plants.companions: Aubergine. Often planted with thyme and other low, mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Tarragon has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out seedlings two to four weeks before your last frost. After two years, valerian will grow into a 18" (45 cm) wide clump.
plants.frostTolerant: Extremely cold hardy, even in harsh winter climates. Plants die back to the ground in winter and re-emerge in spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Valerian produces extremely fragrant flowers in early summer. Gather them for use as cut flowers to keep valerian from reseeding and becoming invasive.
plants.harvesting: Dig roots in fall or early spring and dry outdoors, because they release an unpleasant smell as they dry. Store in airtight container. Dried valerian roots are used to make a bedtime tea that promotes sleep. They are also much loved by cats and dogs.
plants.companions: Echinacea, Catnip, Agastache and Dill. Often planted with low, mound-forming herbs and flowers. Valerian can stand 1.5 m (5ft) tall when it is in full bloom.
plants.troubleshooting: Control valerian's spread by cutting back flowering stems before they can shed seeds in your garden.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased bulblets or corms, set out 10 to 6 weeks before your first autumn frost, or in early autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Multiplying onions and other perennial strains are typically hardy to -15C (-26F) when given a protective winter mulch.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting a new bed.
plants.notes: Most perennial onions grow vigorously in early spring and die back in midsummer. These interesting yet variable plants resemble shallots more than other onions.
plants.harvesting: Harvest bulblets from topsetting onions and use them as pearl onions in the kitchen. When plants die back, cured roots often yield a small shallot. In spring or autumn, you can cut off small divisions for use as spring onions.
plants.companions: Strawberry, Potatoes, Lettuce, Thyme and Chives. Often grouped with garlic and shallots.
plants.troubleshooting: In autumn move perennial onions to a fresh location to avoid problems with onion root maggots, which are attracted by decomposing onion tissues.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Easiest to sow onion sets (tiny bulbs) which are planted direct into the soil from autumn/fall onwards. Can also be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late winter before planting out mid-late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required, though overwintered sets can be given a liquid feed in spring.
plants.notes: Japanese variety onion sets can be used to give an early harvest. Onion sets are also the better choice for heavier or wetter soils.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Cabbage, Carrot, Swiss Chard, Lettuce, Strawberry and Tomato.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Easiest to sow onion sets (tiny bulbs) which are planted direct into the soil from autumn onwards. Can also be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late winter before planting out mid-late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required, though overwintered sets can be given a liquid feed in spring.
plants.notes: Japanese variety onion sets can be used to give an early harvest. Onion sets are also the better choice for heavier or wetter soils.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Cabbage, Carrot and Swiss Chard.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in late winter to plant out in early spring. Or sow direct into ground from mid spring onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from early spring to early summer.
plants.companions: Dill, Agastache, Thyme, Nasturtium, Chamomile, Tomato, Celery, Mint and Tansy.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid-late summer and transplant to final positions in early to mid autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Wait until a few light frosts have passed to harvest, because cool weather enhances the sweet flavour of cabbage.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Onions, Onion and Garlic.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow late summer to move to final positions in autumn to be over-wintered and ready for spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf colour and type. Most early-maturing cabbage varieties produce smallish heads.
plants.harvesting: Harvest early plants or leave to mature to a firm 'heart' until early summer.  Small secondary heads often grow from the base of early cabbage plants after the primary head is cut.
plants.companions: Dill, Agastache, Thyme, Nasturtium, Chamomile, Tomato, Celery, Mint and Tansy.
plants.troubleshooting: Surround stem with a 10cm (4 inch) mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.

plants.notes: Other perennial plants. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
Cover crop, usually planted in fall after others have been harvested.  You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow buckwheat from late spring to late summer, whenever a bed will be unused for more than three weeks.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. Thin to 10 cm (4in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Buckwheat cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: When using buckwheat to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Limit reseeding by pulling up or turning under buckwheat just after it blooms, but before it develops mature seeds.
plants.harvesting: Buckwheat can be pulled up and composted or turned under any time. It will return the most organic matter when taken down 5 to 6 weeks after seeding.
plants.companions: Brussels Sprouts and Kale. Mixes well with upright flowers, and makes an attractive backdrop for herbs. A small bed of buckwheat in bloom will attract numerous beneficial insects.
plants.troubleshooting: Buckwheat has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun in very warm locations only.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in summer, when the soil is warm. Crowder peas will not germinate in cold soil.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Crowder peas are semi-tropical plants that crave warm growing conditions.
plants.feeding: When using crowder peas to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Crowder peas are a good nitrogen-fixing summer cover crop for warm climates, where the vegetable seasons are sharply divided by a period of hot weather.
plants.harvesting: Pull up or turn under plants any time after they are about 4 weeks old, but before they develop pods.
plants.companions: Cosmos and Celosia. Other heat-tolerant summer-blooming annuals.
plants.troubleshooting: Rarely bothered by pests or diseases when grown in warm weather.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow fenugreek from late spring to late summer, whenever a bed will be unused for more than eight weeks.  Direct seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. Thin to 15 cm (6in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Fenugreek cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: When using fenugreek to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: On warm days, fenugreek often emits a fragrance similar to that of maple syrup. It also can be grown as a medicinal herb.
plants.harvesting: Mow plants before turning them under, or pull them up and compost them if you want to use the spot for planting right away.
plants.companions: Buckwheat, Beans and Crowder Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Fenugreek rarely has problems with pests and diseases when grown in home gardens.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer to use mustard as a short-term autumn green manure. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2 in) deep. Thin to 15 cm (6in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Mustard is cool-season annual that can tolerate light frosts but not hard freezes.
plants.feeding: None generally needed, because mustard is customarily used as a late summer/autumn cover crop to take up nitrogen left in the soil by sweet corn or other vegetables.
plants.notes: You can gather individual leaves for cooking, which taste best after the first frost has passed. Mustard residue suppresses soil-borne nematodes, so it is an excellent green manure to grow before potatoes.
plants.harvesting: Chop down the green foliage with a hoe and turn it under just before hard freezes are expected. The mustard roots and foliage will rot during the winter months.
plants.companions: Grape Vine, Beans, Peas, Apple and Plum. Mustard does an excellent job of suppressing weeds when grown in a solid mass.
plants.troubleshooting: Irrigation is often needed to get a good stand if autumn is dry.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun in very warm locations only.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds from late spring to early summer. Soya beans must have warm soil to germinate and grow.  Poke holes into a cultivated bed or row to plant soybean seeds about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. Thin to 15 cm (6in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Soya beans are a warm-season crop to grow in summer in hot climates.
plants.feeding: When using soya beans to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Soya bean green manures are used primarily to add nitrogen to poor soil.
plants.harvesting: Chop down or pull up plants just as they begin to flower. Nitrogen nodules left behind in the soil add fertility.
plants.companions: Marigold, Sweetcorn, Squash, Celery, Strawberry and Potatoes.
plants.troubleshooting: Soya beans are very attractive to deer.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer so that plants can become established before cold weather comes. In cold climates, crimson clover can be planted in early spring instead of autumn. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required.
plants.frostTolerant: Established plantings made in early autumn can tolerate temperatures to -18 C (0F).
plants.feeding: When using crimson clover to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results. Using inoculated seed can also help to grow a vigorous stand.
plants.notes: Crimson clover is one of the most beautiful cover crops you can grow.
plants.harvesting: Take down plants just as the red tops begin to fade, but before the plants produce mature seeds. The easiest method is to slice plants off at the soil line with a sharp hoe. They can then be turned under or composted. Nitrogen nodules left behind in the soil add fertility.
plants.companions: Oats, Rye and Broccoli. Often planted with hardy annual flowers including bachelor buttons and corn poppies.
plants.troubleshooting: Crimson clover plants become quite tough as they age, but they seldom regrow when cut off at the soil line.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow hairy vetch in late summer so the plants can become established before cold weather comes.   Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required.
plants.frostTolerant: Many varieties are cold hardy to - 29C (-20F) when well rooted in the garden.
plants.feeding: When using hairy vetch to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Hairy vetch stays small through winter and makes vigorous growth in spring. It is highly recommended as a green manure to grow before tomatoes.
plants.harvesting: Take down plants in spring, 3 weeks before the bed is needed for summer vegetables. The easiest method is to slice plants off at the soil line with a sharp hoe. The cut plants can be allowed to dry into a surface mulch.
plants.companions: Rye and Wheat.
plants.troubleshooting: Hairy vetch can become weedy if allowed to produce mature seeds.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer to grow as a green manure that forms its own mulch when it is winterkilled, or when using oats as a companion crop for slower-growing legumes. Oats also can be grown as a spring green manure to increase soil organic matter.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm (8in) apart when growing oats with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Oats are a cool-weather crop that can tolerate light frosts but is usually killed by temperatures below-15C (5F).
plants.feeding: None generally needed, especially when oats are grown with nitrogen-fixing green manures such as winter peas, winter beans or hairy vetch.
plants.notes: Oats are an ideal late summer green manure if your winters are cold enough to kill it; the dead residue forms its own winter mulch, which is usually well rotted by spring.
plants.harvesting: Young oats can be turned under anytime. In mild winter climates, oats should be mowed and tilled before seedheads appear in late spring.
plants.companions: Winter Peas and Winter Field Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Rotting oat foliage has herbicidal properties, in that it inhibits germination of weed seeds. Always wait 3 weeks before sowing seeds into soil where oats have been turned under.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer or early autumn as a green manure.  Make sure seed is well covered, because phacelia seeds need darkness to germinate.
plants.frostTolerant: Phacelia will survive mild frosts to overwinter and bloom in spring.
plants.feeding: None generally required.
plants.notes: Phacelia is a wonderful plant for attracting bees and other beneficial insects, particularly useful in early spring if it has overwintered as it is an early pollen source for bees coming out of hibernation.
plants.harvesting: For maximum benefit as a green manure dig in when quite small.  Otherwise leave plants to grow up to 1m (3 ft) tall as the flowers attract beneficial insects.
plants.companions: Cucumber, Tomato, Kale and Broccoli.
plants.troubleshooting: Although native to California in the US phacelia harbours damaging lygus bugs, so it is rarely grown there.

plants.soil: Any soil, including poorly drained sites.
plants.sowPlant: Walk over the planted site to firm the seeds into the ground, and then water to promote fast germination. Although customarily grown in autumn, annual rye can be used as a fast-growing green manure in all but the hottest summer months.   Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 1 inch (2 cm) apart and one-fourth inch (.5 cm) deep.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardiness varies with variety. Some strains are killed by temperatures around -23 C (-10F), while especially hardy varieties can tolerate more extreme cold.
plants.feeding: When using annual rye to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Mature annual rye plants can be difficult to dig out. Where annual rye is not killed by winter weather, mow down the plants and turn under the residue when the plants are young.
plants.harvesting: In a home garden, annual rye cover crops are easiest to manage if they are mowed every few weeks. The clippings make excellent mulch.
plants.companions: Raspberry. Annual rye forms a very thick stand, and is normally grown alone to choke out weeds and boost organic matter, especially in new gardening sites.
plants.troubleshooting: Annual rye has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in early autumn, though cereal rye will still germinate in mid autumn, after the soil has lost its warmth. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm (8in) apart when growing cereal rye with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Most varieties of cereal rye can survive temperatures to -29C (-20F) if the plants are well rooted before the ground freezes.
plants.feeding: When using cereal rye to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase organic matter and break up dense subsoil.  Can be sown later in the autumn than other green manures.
plants.harvesting: Mow down plants in spring, before they develop seeds. Or, gather the immature seed tops and dry them for arrangements, and then pull up the plants. They can be used as mulch or composted.
plants.companions: Hairy Vetch, Winter Peas and Winter Field Beans. In spring, widely spaced rye plants can serve as trellises for garden peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Deer often nibble cereal rye in winter.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer or early autumn for an overwintered crop. Spring wheat can be planted while the soil is still cool.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm (8in) apart when growing wheat with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Many varieties are cold hardy to - 23C (-10F) when well rooted in the garden. Grow varieties described as soft spring wheat in spring, but choose hard winter wheat for autumn.
plants.feeding: When using wheat to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase organic matter, break up dense subsoil and crowd out weeds. Makes a beautiful show in spring.
plants.harvesting: Mow down plants in spring, before they develop seeds. Or, gather the immature seed tops and dry them for arrangements, and then pull up the plants. They can be used as mulch or composted.
plants.companions: Hairy Vetch, Winter Field Beans and Winter Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Deer often nibble wheat grown in winter.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Poke holes in prepared seedbed and plant seeds 5 cm (2in) deep. Winter field beans may be planted in late summer, or in very early spring.  In milder areas they can be planted quite late into autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: A cool-season annual, winter field beans can tolerate frost but are killed by temperatures below -12 to -9C (10-15F).
plants.feeding: When using winter field beans to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase soil nitrogen. Easier to turn under using hand tools compared to other green manures.  Small-seeded varieties are best for green manure use.
plants.harvesting: For maximum nitrogen gain, chop plants down and turn them under as soon as they begin to bloom.  You also can pull up the plants and compost them.
plants.companions: Wheat, Rye and Oats.
plants.troubleshooting: Winter field beans attract numerous beneficial insects. Do not grow them just before potatoes or other root crops, because field beans can host rootknot nematodes.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Poke holes in prepared seedbed and plant seeds 3 to 5 cm (1 to 2in) deep. Gaps between plants can be filled with an upright grain.
plants.frostTolerant: A cool-season annual, winter field peas (Austrian peas), can tolerate heavy frost but are killed by temperatures below -17 to -23C (0 to -10F).
plants.feeding: When using winter field peas to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
