plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase soil nitrogen. Highly recommended as a winter green manure to go before sweet corn because of its vigorous nitrogen-fixing activity in early spring. Very low weedy potential compared to other green manures.
plants.harvesting: For maximum nitrogen gain, chop plants down and turn them under as soon as they begin to bloom.  You also can pull up the plants and compost them.
plants.companions: Wheat, Rye and Oats.
plants.troubleshooting: Allow at least 3 weeks after turning under winter pea residue before direct-seeding vegetables, because the rotting vegetation can cause an increase in damping off of seedlings.

plants.soil: Average garden soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow alyssum from early spring to early summer, and in autumn where winters are mild. Alyssum grows fast and often stops blooming in hot weather.  Broadcast seeds into cultivated soil or containers about 2 inches (5cm) apart, and barely cover them with soil. When the seedlings have more than four leaves, thin to 6 inches (15 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Alyssum seedlings can tolerate light frost, but plants are often killed by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Fast growth is encouraged by mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting. Encourage reblooming with a liquid feed.
plants.notes: Can reseed if allowed to do so, but extra seedlings are easy to lift and move or pull out.
plants.harvesting: Tired alyssum plants often melt down in hot, humid conditions. As annual flowers go, they are short-lived.
plants.companions: Peas, Lettuce, Spinach, Lobelia, Heliotrope and Geranium. In white or pastel shades, alyssum in the perfect little flower to tuck into the corners of beds, or you can grow it beneath tall vegetables or among herbs. Alyssum is famous for attracting tiny wasps and other beneficial insects.

plants.soil: Any good garden soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow cornflowers from early to mid spring for early summer bloom. Also sow in fall in climates with mild winters. Plant seeds in soil or in containers about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Young cornflower seedlings can tolerate freezing temperatures, so seeds can be planted in early spring, or in the autumn where winters are mild.
plants.feeding: Fast growth is encouraged by mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Rice-size cornflower seeds are much loved by goldfinches and other small seed-eating birds.
plants.harvesting: Cornflowers make good cut flowers. Pull up the plants in mid to late summer, when they no longer look attractive.
plants.companions: Wheat, Oats and Crimson Clover. Cornflowers have an upright posture that helps them fit in tight spaces. Intersperse throughout the garden, as cornflower nectar is unusually sweet, and thus a preferred food source for many beneficial insects.
plants.troubleshooting: Cornflowers may be nibbled by rabbits, especially in early spring when other food is scarce.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow cosmos in early spring so the plants can become established before hot weather comes.  Cosmos also can be started indoors in containers and set out when the seedlings have at least five leaves, or purchased as bedding plants. Plant seeds in prepared soil about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties; allow 12 inches (30 cm) between very tall varieties.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings tolerate light frosts, but plants are killed by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Varieties vary greatly in height, colour and flower form. Choose dwarf varieties for tight spaces.  Sulphur cosmos (C. sulphureus) thrives in humid heat.
plants.harvesting: Cosmos make good cut flowers. Pull up the plants and compost them when blooms become few or freezing weather is expected.
plants.companions: Dill, Agastache and Echinacea. Tall varieties can form a colourful hedge that attracts bees and other pollinators, and mix well with tall herbs like dill and fennel.
plants.troubleshooting: In some climates, cosmos planted in spring may not come into full bloom until days become short in early autumn.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow marigolds in late spring, or set them out as bedding plants. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties; allow 12 inches (30 cm) between very tall varieties.
plants.frostTolerant: None.  Marigold cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: The 'Gem' marigolds (T. tenufolia) bear edible blossoms with a spicy, citrus flavor.
plants.harvesting: Marigolds make good short-stemmed cut flowers for small bouquets. Don't rush to pull up plants that stop blooming but look healthy, because they will probably come back into bloom.
plants.companions: Tomato, Cabbage, Squash, Melon, Cauliflower, Kale, Potatoes, Blackcurrant, Redcurrant and White currant. Dwarf types make good edging plants that may deter rabbits. Some varieties are known for their ability to starve out rootknot nematodes when planted as a mass.
plants.troubleshooting: Marigolds have few problems with pests or diseases.  Tall varieties may need staking to keep them upright.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Soaking seeds in water overnight prior to planting may speed germination, but nasturtium seeds sprout best when the soil is warm. Poke seeds into the soil about 1 inch (3 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Nasturtiums may survive very light frosts, but they are easily damaged by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Nasturtium blossoms, leaves and immature green seed pods are edible.
plants.harvesting: Gather nasturtium blossoms in the morning, when they are plumped up with moisture. Snip away the base of each blossom, which may taste bitter.
plants.companions: Apple, Beans, Cabbage, Kale, Broccoli, Potatoes, Pumpkin, Radish, Squash, Sweetcorn, Tomato and Sunflower. Nasturtiums sprawl out over the ground, so they suppress weeds and shade the soil when grown near tall plants like sweet corn, tomatoes or sunflowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Nasturtium will often reseed itself in hospitable sites.

plants.soil: Any fertile soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow poached egg plant in early spring, while the soil is cool. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 4 inches (10 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Young seedlings can tolerate light frost, but the plants are easily damaged by hard frosts.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Pull up old plants to limit reseeding. Where summers are hot, plants may expire after blooming heavily in spring.
plants.harvesting: The delicate flowers and fragrance of poached egg plant always bring cheer to the garden. Pull up and compost plants when they stop blooming heavily.
plants.companions: Lettuce, Tomato and Sweetcorn. This low-growing plant spreads into a mat of green foliage covered with flowers. Grow along pathways or edges of beds, or near tall plants like sweet corn or tomatoes.
plants.troubleshooting: Poached egg plant has few problems with pests or diseases, but may fail when subjected to extreme humid heat.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Salvia needs warm soil to grow well, so wait until the last frost has passed to set out plants. Start seeds indoors in individual containers or set out purchased plants. Space plants 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Salvia cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Pinching off the first bloom will encourage plants to grow into lush bushes bearing numerous flower spikes.
plants.harvesting: Gather stems to use in cut arrangements. Snip off old flowers every few weeks to keep plants in bloom all summer.
plants.companions: Catnip and Lavender. Mixes well with upright flowers or herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Salvia has few problems with pests or diseases.  Newer named varieties are vigorous and very heavy blooming.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow sunflowers from late spring to early summer.  Poke seeds into the soil about 1 inch (3 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties. Extremely tall sunflowers or those that grow into multi-branched bushes may require 3 feet (1 meter) between plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Sunflower seedlings often escape damage from light frost, but sunflowers are warm-natured plants with no tolerance of freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Explore different sunflower varieties, which vary in size, colour, growth habit, and the culinary quality of the seeds.
plants.harvesting: Cut sunflower heads when some of the seeds inside the edges appear ripe and fall away when rubbed, or when birds start harvesting them for you. Store in a warm, dry place.
plants.companions: Beans, Courgette, Marrow, Pumpkin and Cucumber. A rare "shelter" plant, sunflowers can be used to create shade for sun-stressed crops. Tall varieties can serve as trellises for runner beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Sunflowers will twist around to face the south or west, seeking the most abundant source of sun, which may be away from your garden.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Plant zinnias in late spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.  Start seeds indoors in individual containers, set out purchased plants, or direct-sow into warm soil. Poke seeds into the soil about one-half inch (1 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties. Zinnia varieties that grow more than 24 inches (60) cm) tall require 18 inches (45 cm) between plants.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Zinnias cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.  In midsummer, drench plants with a high-nitrogen liquid fertiliser to stimulate strong reblooming.
plants.notes: Frequent cutting of blossoms helps many varieties to rebloom constantly for many weeks. Butterflies prefer flat, single zinnia blossoms over "double" varieties that are packed with petals.
plants.harvesting: Gather zinnias for use in arrangements just as the petals open. The true flowers are the tiny yellow florets, which pump out nectar for butterflies.
plants.companions: Dill, Courgette, Beans and Swiss Chard. Also grown with fennel and other upright herbs. Tall, single-flowered varieties attract butterflies.
plants.troubleshooting: Older zinnias often become infected with powdery mildew. Pull up and compost diseased plants. Many hybrids offer some resistance to powdery mildew.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in containers in late winter, and set out seedlings in spring. You can also work with purchased seedlings, or lift and move volunteer seedlings found in the garden. Set plants at least 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions. They are easily recognized by their lacy leaves.
plants.frostTolerant: Six-month-old, well rooted plants tolerate winter temperatures to --29C (-20F).  Most individual plants die in their second or third summer, after blooming heavily.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.  When plants emerge after their first winter, mulch with rich compost or topdress with a balanced organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Frequent cutting of blossoms helps feverfew stay in bloom longer. Depending on climate, feverfew is a biennial or short-lived perennial.  When seeds are started early, it will bloom its first year.
plants.harvesting: To harvest for medicinal use, gather when the plants are in full flower but still holding an abundance of greenery. Medicinal preparations are made from a mixture of dried flowers and leaves.
plants.companions: Mint. Also grown with beds of other tea plants where insects are not wanted. Feverfew repels insects of all nature, so it is a good plant to grow near entryways.
plants.troubleshooting: Feverfew can reseed too well in hospitable spaces, so keep an eye on it for invasive tendencies.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in spring. Established plants can be dug and moved anytime as long as soil is kept packed around the roots. Start seeds indoors in individual containers, set out purchased plants, or direct-sow into warm soil.  Space plants 30cm (12 in) apart in all directions. Few gardeners need more than a few of these productive plants.
plants.frostTolerant: When established, this hardy perennial can tolerate winter temperatures to -29C (-20F).
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.  Each spring, mulch around the plant with rich compost.
plants.notes: Pinch off blossom spikes to keep plants from reseeding in the garden, and to increase productivity. Young leaves that grow in cool weather have the mildest flavor.
plants.harvesting: Gather individual leaves as needed in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Rosemary, Sage and Thyme.
plants.troubleshooting: For top productivity, replace plants every few years.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow tatsoi in spring and again in late summer for harvest in autumn. Sow in double rows, with rows spaced 10 inches (25 cm) apart. Plant seeds 2 inches (5 cm) apart and barely cover them with soil. Gradually thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Tatsoi can tolerate light frost, but exposure to cold temperatures in spring can trigger early bolting. In autumn, exposure to light frost can improve tatsoi's flavor.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: This beautiful little mustard cousin often grows better in autumn than in spring.
plants.harvesting: Gather individual leaves, or pull whole plants for use in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Chicory, Endive, Mizuna, Mustard, Kale and Pansy . Also grown with other greens found in oriental salad mixtures. In autumn, tatsoi looks beautiful with pansies and parsley.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles often chew small holes in tatsoi leaves in spring, but are less of a problem in the fall.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow bok choy in spring and again in late summer for harvest in autumn. Sow in double rows, with rows spaced 10 inches (25 cm) apart. Plant seeds 2 inches (5 cm) apart and barely cover them with soil. Gradually thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart. Miniature varieties can be grown 3 inches (8 cm) apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Bok choy can tolerate light frost, but exposure to cold temperatures in spring can trigger early bolting. In autumn, exposure to light frost can improve bok choy's flavor.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Also spelled pac choi, this lovely little mustard cousin is fast and easy to grow.
plants.harvesting: Pull whole plants for use in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Mint and Viola. Often grown with lettuce, mustard, kale, escarole, tatsoi, mizuna and other greens found in oriental salad mixtures. Miniature varieties are available for square foot gardens and containers.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles often chew small holes in bok choy leaves in spring, but are less of a problem in the fall.

plants.soil: Average garden soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow alyssum from early spring to early summer, and in autumn where winters are mild. Alyssum grows fast and often stops blooming in hot weather.  Broadcast seeds into cultivated soil or containers about 2 inches (5cm) apart, and barely cover them with soil. When the seedlings have more than four leaves, thin to 6 inches (15 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Alyssum seedlings can tolerate light frost, but plants are often killed by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Fast growth is encouraged by mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting. Encourage reblooming with a liquid feed.
plants.notes: Can reseed if allowed to do so, but extra seedlings are easy to lift and move or pull out.
plants.harvesting: Tired alyssum plants often melt down in hot, humid conditions. As annual flowers go, they are short-lived.
plants.companions: Peas, Lettuce, Spinach, Lobelia, Heliotrope and Geranium. In white or pastel shades, alyssum in the perfect little flower to tuck into the corners of beds, or you can grow it beneath tall vegetables or among herbs. Alyssum is famous for attracting tiny wasps and other beneficial insects.

plants.soil: Any good garden soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow cornflowers from early to mid spring for early summer bloom. Also sow in fall in climates with mild winters. Plant seeds in soil or in containers about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Young cornflower seedlings can tolerate freezing temperatures, so seeds can be planted in early spring, or in the fall where winters are mild.
plants.feeding: Fast growth is encouraged by mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Rice-size cornflower seeds are much loved by goldfinches and other small seed-eating birds.
plants.harvesting: Cornflowers make good cut flowers. Pull up the plants in mid to late summer, when they no longer look attractive.
plants.companions: Wheat, Oats and Crimson Clover. Cornflowers have an upright posture that helps them fit in tight spaces. Intersperse throughout the garden, as cornflower nectar is unusually sweet, and thus a preferred food source for many beneficial insects.
plants.troubleshooting: Cornflowers may be nibbled by rabbits, especially in early spring when other food is scarce.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow cosmos in early spring so the plants can become established before hot weather comes.  Cosmos also can be started indoors in containers and set out when the seedlings have at least five leaves, or purchased as bedding plants. Plant seeds in prepared soil about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties; allow 12 inches (30 cm) between very tall varieties.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings tolerate light frosts, but plants are killed by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Varieties vary greatly in height, color and flower form. Choose dwarf varieties for tight spaces.  Sulphur cosmos (C. sulphureus) thrives in humid heat.
plants.harvesting: Cosmos make good cut flowers. Pull up the plants and compost them when blooms become few or freezing weather is expected.
plants.companions: Dill, Agastache and Echinacea. Tall varieties can form a colorful hedge that attracts bees and other pollinators, and mix well with tall herbs like dill and fennel.
plants.troubleshooting: In some climates, cosmos planted in spring may not come into full bloom until days become short in early autumn.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow marigolds in late spring, or set them out as bedding plants. In climates with long, hot summers, make a second planting in summer for great autumn color.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties; allow 12 inches (30 cm) between very tall varieties.
plants.frostTolerant: None.  Marigold cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: The 'Gem' marigolds (T. tenufolia) bear edible blossoms with a spicy, citrus flavor.
plants.harvesting: Marigolds make good short-stemmed cut flowers for small bouquets. Don't rush to pull up plants that stop blooming but look healthy, because they will probably come back into bloom.
plants.companions: Tomato, Cabbage, Squash, Pumpkin, Cucumber, Melon, Cauliflower, Kale, Potatoes, Black Currant, Red Currant, White Currant, Beans, Orange, Lime and Lemon. Dwarf types make good edging plants that may deter rabbits. Some varieties are known for their ability to starve out rootknot nematodes when planted as a mass.
plants.troubleshooting: Marigolds have few problems with pests or diseases.  Tall varieties may need staking to keep them upright.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Soaking seeds in water overnight prior to planting may speed germination, but nasturtium seeds sprout best when the soil is warm. Poke seeds into the soil about 1 inch (3 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Nasturtiums may survive very light frosts, but they are easily damaged by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Nasturtium blossoms, leaves and immature green seed pods are edible.
plants.harvesting: Gather nasturtium blossoms in the morning, when they are plumped up with moisture. Snip away the base of each blossom, which may taste bitter.
plants.companions: Apple, Beans, Cabbage, Kale, Broccoli, Potatoes, Pumpkin, Radish, Squash, Corn, Tomato and Sunflower. Nasturtiums sprawl out over the ground, so they suppress weeds and shade the soil when grown near tall plants like sweet corn, tomatoes or sunflowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Nasturtium will often reseed itself in hospitable sites.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow phacelia in spring while the soil is still cool. Make sure seed is well covered, because phacelia seeds need darkness to germinate. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-fourth inch (0.5 cm) deep. Thin to 10 inches (25 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Phacelia seedlings can tolerate light frost, but the plants are easily damaged by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: When growing phacelia to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Limit reseeding by pulling up or turning under phacelia just after it blooms, but before it develops mature seeds.
plants.harvesting: Phacelia can be pulled up and composted or turned under any time. Pull up individual plants grown for flowers before they shed seeds.
plants.companions: Cucumber, Tomato, Kale, Broccoli and Cabbage. Mixes well with other cool-season flowers such as orange calendulas, or you can use phacelia as a cover crop or bee plant.
plants.troubleshooting: Phacelia has few problems with pests or diseases, but expect plant to be abuzz with bees and other beneficial insects.

plants.soil: Any fertile soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow poached egg plant in early spring, while the soil is cool. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 4 inches (10 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Young seedlings can tolerate light frost, but the plants are easily damaged by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Pull up old plants to limit reseeding. Where summers are hot, plants may expire after blooming heavily in spring.
plants.harvesting: The delicate flowers and fragrance of poached egg plant always bring cheer to the garden. Pull up and compost plants when they stop blooming heavily.
plants.companions: Lettuce, Mizuna, Tatsoi and Endive. This low-growing plant spreads into a mat of green foliage covered with flowers. Grow along pathways or edges of beds, or near tall plants like sweet corn or tomatoes.
plants.troubleshooting: Poached egg plant has few problems with pests or diseases, but may fail when subjected to extreme humid heat.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Scarlet sage needs warm soil to grow well, so wait until the last frost has passed to set out plants. Start seeds indoors in individual containers or set out purchased plants. Space plants 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Scarlet sage cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Pinching off the first bloom will encourage plants to grow into lush bushes bearing numerous flower spikes.
plants.harvesting: Gather stems to use in cut arrangements. Snip off old flowers every few weeks to keep plants in bloom all summer.
plants.companions: Catnip and Lavender. Mixes well with upright flowers or herbs, and the blossoms are much loved by hummingbirds.
plants.troubleshooting: Scarlet sage has few problems with pests or diseases.  Newer named varieties are vigorous and very heavy blooming.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow sunflowers from late spring to early summer. Where summers are long and warm, make a second sowing for autumn harvest.  Poke seeds into the soil about 1 inch (3 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties. Extremely tall sunflowers or those that grow into multi-branched bushes may require 3 feet (1 meter) between plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Sunflower seedlings often escape damage from light frost, but sunflowers are warm-natured plants with no tolerance of freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Explore different sunflower varieties, which vary in size, color, growth habit, and the culinary quality of the seeds.
plants.harvesting: Cut sunflower heads when some of the seeds inside the edges appear ripe and fall away when rubbed, or when birds start harvesting them for you. Store in a warm, dry place.
plants.companions: Beans, Squash, Pumpkin, Corn and Cucumber. A rare "shelter" plant, sunflowers can be used to create shade for sun-stressed crops. Tall varieties can serve as trellises for pole beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Sunflowers will twist around to face the south or west, seeking the most abundant source of sun, which may be away from your garden.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Plant zinnias in late spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.  Start seeds indoors in individual containers, set out purchased plants, or direct-sow into warm soil. Poke seeds into the soil about one-half inch (1 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties. Zinnia varieties that grow more than 24 inches (60) cm) tall require 18 inches (45 cm) between plants.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Zinnias cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil prior to planting.  In midsummer, drench plants with a high-nitrogen liquid fertilizer to stimulate strong reblooming.
plants.notes: Frequent cutting of blossoms helps many varieties to rebloom constantly for many weeks. Butterflies prefer flat, single zinnia blossoms over "double" varieties that are packed with petals.
plants.harvesting: Gather zinnias for use in arrangements just as the petals open. The true flowers are the tiny yellow florets, which pump out nectar for butterflies.
plants.companions: Dill, Beans, Swiss Chard, Cosmos and Zucchini. Dill, fennel and other upright herbs, bush snap beans, chard. Tall, single-flowered varieties attract butterflies.
plants.troubleshooting: Older zinnias often become infected with powdery mildew. Pull up and compost diseased plants. Many hybrids offer some resistance to powdery mildew.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in containers in late winter, and set out seedlings in spring. You can also work with purchased seedlings, or lift and move volunteer seedlings found in the garden. Set plants at least 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions. They are easily recognized by their lacy leaves.
plants.frostTolerant: Six-month-old, well rooted plants tolerate winter temperatures to -20F (-29C).  Most individual plants die in their second or third summer, after blooming heavily.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil prior to planting.  When plants emerge after their first winter, mulch with rich compost or topdress with a balanced organic fertilizer.
plants.notes: Frequent cutting of blossoms helps feverfew stay in bloom longer. Depending on climate, feverfew is a biennial or short-lived perennial.  When seeds are started early, it will bloom its first year.
plants.harvesting: To harvest for medicinal use, gather when the plants are in full flower but still holding an abundance of greenery. Medicinal preparations are made from a mixture of dried flowers and leaves.
plants.companions: Mint. Also grown with beds of other tea plants where insects are not wanted. Feverfew repels insects of all nature, so it is a good plant to grow near entryways.
plants.troubleshooting: Feverfew can reseed too well in hospitable spaces, so keep an eye on it for invasive tendencies.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in spring. Established plants can be dug and moved anytime as long as soil is kept packed around the roots. Start seeds indoors in individual containers, set out purchased plants, or direct-sow into warm soil.  Space plants 12 inches apart in all directions. Few gardeners need more than a few of these productive plants.
plants.frostTolerant: When established, this hardy perennial can tolerate winter temperatures to -20F (-29C).
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil prior to planting.  Each spring, mulch around the plant with rich compost.
plants.notes: Pinch off blossom spikes to keep plants from reseeding in the garden, and to increase productivity. Young leaves that grow in cool weather have the mildest flavor.
plants.harvesting: Gather individual leaves as needed in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Rosemary, Sage, Thyme and Pear. Rosemary, sage, and other perennial herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: For top productivity, replace plants every few years.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow tatsoi in spring and again in late summer for harvest in fall. Sow in double rows, with rows spaced 10 inches (25 cm) apart. Plant seeds 2 inches (5 cm) apart and barely cover them with soil. Gradually thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Tatsoi can tolerate light frost, but exposure to cold temperatures in spring can trigger early bolting. In fall, exposure to light frost can improve tatsoi's flavor.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: This beautiful little mustard cousin often grows better in fall than in spring.
plants.harvesting: Gather individual leaves, or pull whole plants for use in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Lettuce, Mizuna, Mustard, Endive and Johnny Jump Up. Also grown with other greens found in mesclun mixtures. In fall, tatsoi looks beautiful with pansies and parsley.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles often chew small holes in tatsoi leaves in spring, but are less of a problem in the fall.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow bok choy in spring and again in late summer for harvest in fall. Sow in double rows, with rows spaced 10 inches (25 cm) apart. Plant seeds 2 inches (5 cm) apart and barely cover them with soil. Gradually thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart. Miniature varieties can be grown 3 inches (8 cm) apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Bok choy can tolerate light frost, but exposure to cold temperatures in spring can trigger early bolting. In fall, exposure to light frost can improve bok choy's flavor.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Also spelled pac choi, this lovely little mustard cousin is fast and easy to grow.
plants.harvesting: Pull whole plants for use in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Nasturtium, Lettuce, Mustard, Kale, Tatsoi and Mizuna. Also grown with other greens found in mesclun mixtures. Miniature varieties are available for square foot gardens and containers.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles often chew small holes in bok choy leaves in spring, but are less of a problem in the fall.

plants.soil: Average garden soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in late spring and set seedlings out after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.  Set plants about 3 feet (1 m) apart. Grow at least two plants, spaced close together, to insure good pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Tomatillos are tropical plants that require warm conditions.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Tomatillos can reseed if allowed to do so, but extra seedlings are easy to lift and move or pull out.
plants.harvesting: After the outer husks of some fruit turn from green to tan, look for ripe tomatillos that have fallen to the ground. Gather and store in the refrigerator for up to two weeks.  Wash before cooking to remove sticky residue.
plants.companions: Corn and Sunflower. Depending on climate and soil, plants can grow up to 4 feet (1.3 m) tall and wide.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants sometimes wait until late in the season to bear an abundance of fruits. Slightly green (immature) tomatillos have the tart citrus flavor most people prefer.

plants.soil: Warm, fertile, and well drained.
plants.sowPlant: Frost areas: sow under cover 6 weeks before last spring frost. Plant out in late spring, when the weather is settled and warm. Frost free areas: Sow seed directly or in seed beds/seed trays in spring
plants.frostTolerant: A semi-tropical plant; cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Eggplants are heavy feeders, so enrich the soil well before transplanting. Give them regular moisture and keep their roots well mulched and weed free. When  flowers start forming, feed with slow release potassium-rich organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Plants need staking once they start bearing. Mulch to keep soil lightly moist.
plants.harvesting: Fruit will be ready about three months after transplanting. Cut the fruit off. It has a strong stem and twisting or pulling could damage the plant. Eat as soon as possible after harvesting because they don’t keep well. In hotter, frost-free areas, cut back plants after the first fruiting to encourage a second harvest.
plants.companions: Alyssum, Beans, Echinacea, Tarragon, Pepper and Lettuce. Jane recommends Marigolds, French and Runner beans
plants.troubleshooting: Cutworms love young eggplant seedlings, so protect accordingly. Adult plants could also be attacked by spider mite (look for the top leaves turning yellow) and leaf beetles, which eat the leaves, leaving them in lacy tatters. Marigolds repel beetles and scented geranium repels spider mites.

plants.soil: Rich soil.
plants.sowPlant:
Frost areas: Sow  seeds  under cover 6 weeks before last spring frost. Sow seed in modules and then transplant the seedlings into larger pots, so they can grow bigger while waiting for the weather to warm up – basil likes hot weather. Or transplant purchased seedlings in late spring
Frost free areas: Sow seed directly or in seed beds/seed trays in spring
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Once summer heats up, watch out for flowers developing, as this reduces leaf production. Snip off the flowering top  at least six leaf nodes down the stem to  encourage more leaves to grow. Perennial basil is available, although it will only survive in areas with mild winters.
plants.harvesting: Wait until the first basil stems are about 20 cm long before starting to harvest. It is better to grow a few plants and harvest leaves from each one rather than all from one plant.
plants.companions: Tomato, Lettuce and Purslane. Jane recommends peppers, Tomatoes, Marigold. Helps prevent mildew on cucurbits.

plants.soil: Good, well-drained soil.
plants.position: Most locations. Like cool and moist conditions
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly in the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Broad beans can grow over 1.5 m tall and require staking in particularly windy areas. Grow in a group of them together, as they will support each other. If they become too heavy when bearing, support them with a single or double line. Dig in roots when finished cropping as these return nitrogen to the soil.
plants.harvesting: Harvest about three to four months after sowing, before the pods become tough. Often get a second crop.
plants.companions: Marigold, Lovage, Petunia, Potatoes, Carrot and Cucumber. Jane recommends lettuce, Spinach
plants.troubleshooting: Aphid (removing growing point helps prevent them), beetles

plants.soil: Rich soil, well-drained but with plenty of organic matter to retain moisture.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly in the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Rarely required.
plants.notes: Strong supports needed for climbing varieties. Supply plenty of water to the roots from flowering through to harvest.
plants.harvesting: Pick pods young before they get stringy. To save seeds, allow selected pods to mature on the plants until papery, then pick and dry indoors
plants.companions: Marigold, Lovage, Petunia, Potatoes, Carrot and Cucumber. Jane recommends all root crops, aubergine, lettuce, cucumber
plants.troubleshooting: Leaf-eating beetles can trun the leaves into confetti overnight. Either hand pick them (they come out at night) or if there are too many, use a pyrethrum based spray

plants.soil: Rich soil, well-drained with plenty of organic matter to retain moisture.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly in the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Rarely required.
plants.notes: Strong supports needed for climbing varieties. Supply plenty of water to the roots from flowering through to harvest.
plants.harvesting: Regular picking encourages more growth
plants.companions: Marigold, Lovage, Petunia, Potatoes, Carrot, Strawberry, Swiss Chard and Beetroot. Jane recommends all root crops, cucumber.
plants.troubleshooting: Leaf-eating beetles can trun the leaves into confetti overnight. Either hand pick them (they come out at night) or if there are too many, use a pyrethrum based spray

plants.soil: Rich soil. Well-drained light but deep soil preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Unlike most other root crops, beetroot don’t mind being transplanted, provided the seedlings are small and kept moist during transplanting.  They can also be directly seeded where they are to grow. Thin seedlings to at least 10cm apart to grow large roots. They can be left to grow in a group, provided they have enough space to spread.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Rarely required.
plants.notes: Each beetroot seed is actually a small cluster of seeds, so space well and may require thinning. Be careful not to damage the beet when weeding. Young leaves are also a colourful addition to salads. Liable to bolt (run to seed) if sown too early, though some varieties are resistant to this. Keep well watered in dry weather to prevent roots splitting
plants.harvesting: Harvest young leaves for salad greens as you thin young plants. Pull roots when they become plump.
plants.companions: Beans, Onion, Onions, Lettuce, Cabbage, Swiss Chard, Kohlrabi and Kale. Jane recommends garlic, lettuce.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow early to mid summer. Sow in seedtrays or pots as they take quite a while to reach transplanting stage and during that time a quick summer crop can be grown and harvested in the garden. Firm soil well when transplanting.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mix composted manure or another high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting. Add a slow release organic fertiliser to the planting hole before transplanting. Spraying leaves with dilute seaweed spray prevents birds eating them.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. May need supportive canes during the winter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest by cutting off the large central head first before it starts to flower. Cut it at an angle to prevent water settling and rotting the stem. Smaller side shoots should then be produced for harvesting a few weeks later.
plants.companions: Rosemary, Sage, Celery, Mint, Chamomile, Beetroot, Onion, Onions and Potatoes. Jane recommends members of the allium family, nasturtium, rosemary, sage

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: In frost  areas sow early spring under cover. Plant out early summer. In frost free areas, sow directly or transplant in spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed in mid to late summer.
plants.notes: Unless using a self-blanching type, will need to be planted in trenches, then tubes wrapped round in mid summer and/or earthed up with soil. Keep moist during dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Can cut frequently if required. In any case harvest before the first frost in autumn.
plants.companions: Chives, Tomato, Beans, Cauliflower, Cabbage, Leek, Garlic, Onion and Onions.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best but will grow in most locations.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil from early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Cut leaves as required.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Basil, Sweetcorn, Lettuce, Beetroot, Turnip, Radish and Carrot.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best but will grow in most locations.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil from early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water well in dry periods.
plants.harvesting: Roots can be lifted throughout winter.
plants.companions: Beans, Cabbage, Carrot, Celeriac, Endive, Kohlrabi, Leek, Lettuce, Onion and Spinach.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow early to mid summer. Sow in seedtrays or pots as they take quite a while to reach transplanting stage and during that time a quick summer crop can be grown and harvested in the garden. Firm soil well when transplanting. Plant out when about 10 cm high
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, improves with frost.
plants.feeding: Mix composted manure or another high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting. Add a slow release organic fertiliser to the planting hole before transplanting. Spraying leaves with dilute seaweed spray prevents birds eating them.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. May need supportive canes during the winter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from the bottom of the plant upward, twisting off sprouts that are larger than a marble. Removing nearby leaves helps to make room for growing sprouts.
plants.companions: Potatoes, Mint, Agastache, Echinacea, Nasturtium and Buckwheat. Jane recommends Dill, Rosemary, Potato.
plants.troubleshooting: Brussels sprouts are a mecca for aphids. Plant tansy next to it to encourage ladybirds or spray with a garlic and soap spray

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow early to mid summer. Sow in seedtrays or pots as they take quite a while to reach transplanting stage and during that time a quick summer crop can be grown and harvested in the garden. Firm soil well when transplanting.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Spraying leaves with dilute seaweed spray prevents birds eating them
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings.
plants.harvesting: Harvest by cutting off the large central head first before it starts to flower. Cut it at an angle to prevent water settling and rotting the stem. Side shoots will appear and as long as these are continually harvested before they form flowers, they will continue producing for a couple of months
plants.companions: Rosemary, Sage, Celery, Beans, Onion, Potatoes, Mint, Chamomile and Beetroot.

plants.soil: Light, deep, well-drained soil which has not had compost or manure added recently (to avoid forked roots forming.)
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil under cloches from late winter or without protection from mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Light frost tolerant.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Slugs love young carrot seedlings so protect early started plants. Thin out when the seedlings are large enough to handle if they are too close (best done in damp evenings to prevent carrot fly). Cover with mesh or fleece to deter carrot fly. Weed carefully during early stages.
plants.harvesting: Can be harvested over a long period, although if left in ground over winter they may split attracting slugs.
plants.companions: Sage, Onion, Onions, Lettuce, Peas, Leek, Chives and Tomato. Jane recommends Leek, Onion, Tomato, Sage.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow early to mid summer. Sow in seedtrays or pots as they take quite a while to reach transplanting stage and during that time a quick summer crop can be grown and harvested in the garden. Firm soil well when transplanting.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mix composted manure or another high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting. Add a slow release organic fertiliser to the planting hole before transplanting. Spraying leaves with dilute seaweed spray prevents birds eating them.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. Bend over a few leaves if required so that the cauliflower head is kept shaded while it is forming.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the head has fully developed, but before the curd becomes loose, with a "ricey" appearance.
plants.companions: Sage and Celery.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: In frost areas, sow under cover in seed trays in early spring. Plant out after last frosts. In frost free areas sow directly into the soil in early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Feed with a slow release organic fertiliser when flowers begin forming. Fortnightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: One or two plants is plenty - they will produce lots of courgettes over a season.
plants.harvesting: Harvest before the courgettes get too big and turn into marrows. This encourages more courgettes to grow.
plants.companions: Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: In frost areas, sow under cover in seed trays in early spring. Plant out after last frosts. In frost free areas sow directly into the soil in early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: When  flowers start forming, feed with slow release potassium-rich organic fertiliser. Fortnightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: Support plants well so they can climb upwards, even when the cucumbers get large. This also protects the cucumbers from slugs. Occasionally a plant can produce very bitter cucumbers so always test a bit before serving to others!
plants.harvesting: Cut the cucumbers off the plant when they are still quite young, otherwise the skin becomes hard and will need peeling. More cucumbers will then be produced.
plants.companions: Beans, Sweetcorn, Peas, Radish and Sunflower. Jane recommends Beans, Lettuce, Radish, Tomato.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be, depending on flower.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests e.g. marigold, nasturtium, cornflowers, Californian poppies and calendula etc. Many will self-seed and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Not usually applicable, although some flowers (eg nasturtium) can be added to salads and others (eg chamomile) make good herbal teas.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: Best grown from cloves, planted direct into holes, pointed end up in late autumn or late winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Many varieties require a cooler period with temperatures under 10 degrees celcius for the first one or two months.
plants.harvesting: Dig up bulbs in summer when leaves start to turn yellow. Clean them and let them dry out over a few days before storing.
plants.companions: Raspberry, Rose, Apple, Plum, Pear, Cherry and Gooseberry.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for winter weeds. Plants left in the ground too long often have loose bulbs that do not store well.

plants.soil: Most herbs can be grown in otherwise poor soil but it should be well drained and free of weeds.
plants.position: Sunny to shady, dependent on herb.
plants.sowPlant: Usually sow direct into soil in late spring. Perennial herbs need lifting and dividing in autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Some types are partially frost tolerant but others are not.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Just a small area will usually provide more than enough, unless growing for decorative reasons or using them to attract beneficial insects to the garden. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required, a few leaves at a time. Cut back busy perennials in Spring. Can be dried by hanging a bunch in a dry place although some flavour is lost when dried.

plants.soil: Good soil, firm, preferably with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: In frost  areas sow early spring under cover. Plant out early summer. In frost free areas, sow directly or transplant in spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. May need supportive canes during the winter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves gradually from the centre of each plant while they are still tender. New leaves will grow and harvesting can extend into the following spring.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Celery, Cucumber, Marigold, Nasturtium, Rhubarb, Dill, Mint, Thyme, Chamomile, Catnip, Tansy and Buckwheat.

plants.soil: Requires rich, loamy soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: In frost  areas sow early spring under cover. Plant out in late spring. In frost free areas, sow directly or transplant into weed-free ground in late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: In late summer while the weather is still warm, drench plants thoroughly with a water-soluble plant food.
plants.notes: When leeks are almost the size you prefer, blanch them for 2 to 3 weeks by putting a mound of soil, mulch, or a cardboard tube around the base of each stem. Grows best in climates where nights remain cool through summer.
plants.harvesting: Can be left in the ground until required and harvested right through autumn, winter and early spring.
plants.companions: Onion, Onions, Celery and Carrot. Jane recommends Carrot, Celery.

plants.soil: Most soil types but best if it's moisture retentive with some dug in compost.
plants.position: In summer, semi-shade, a cool sunny spot or inter-planted between other crops. In winter, full sun
plants.sowPlant: Start sowing in early spring and continue every few weeks for a continuous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Early sowings are easily attacked by slugs and snails, so may be best in containers. Thin out to give plenty of room for each plant to grow. In hot summer conditions lettuce can bolt (produce flower heads) and becomes tough and a little bitter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves as required over a number of weeks.
plants.companions: Sweetcorn, Poached Egg Plant, Cucumber, Carrot, Radish, Onion and Onions. Jane recommends Carrot, Radish, Strawberry.
plants.troubleshooting: Shallow lettuce roots need constant moisture. Do not allow the soil to dry out.

plants.soil: Most soil types but best if it's moisture retentive with some dug in compost.
plants.position: In summer, semi-shade, a cool sunny spot or inter-planted between other crops. In winter, full sun
plants.sowPlant: Start sowing in early spring and continue every few weeks for a continuous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Early sowings are easily attacked by slugs and snails, so may be best in containers. Thin out to give plenty of room for each plant to grow. In hot summer conditions lettuce can bolt (produce flower heads) and becomes tough and a little bitter.
plants.harvesting: When the heart of the lettuce feels firm pull the whole plant up and cut off the roots. Harvest in the morning when the leaves are cool and full of moisture.
plants.companions: Sweetcorn, Cucumber, Carrot, Rocket, Radish, Onion, Onions, Spring Onion and Poached Egg Plant. Jane recommends Carrot, Radish, Strawberry.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of added compost.
plants.sowPlant: Frost areas: sow under cover 6 weeks before last spring frost. Plant out in late spring, when the weather is settled and warm. Frost free areas: Sow seed directly or in seed beds/seed trays in spring
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: When flowering starts, spray weekly with foliar seaweed spray and side dress with a slow release high potassium organic fertiliser
plants.notes: Tie upright types to canes with string to support the weight of the fruit. Remove side shoots which grow in the angle between the leaf stems and the main stem of the plant.
plants.harvesting: Pick regularly as soon as the fruits are ripe. This encourages production of more tomatoes.
plants.companions: Asparagus, Parsley, Marigold, Basil, Chives, Dill, Calendula and Borage.
plants.troubleshooting: Blossom end rot patches on the bottom of fruits are a nutritional disorder best prevented by growing tomatoes in well-prepared soil with constant, light moisture. Yellow leaves indicate lack of magnesium, so apply liquid feed.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds in early autumn to plant out in late autumn
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required, though can be given a liquid feed in spring.
plants.notes: Onions will only start bulbing when the days become long enough to expose them to enough light
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Tomato, Lettuce, Chamomile and Flax. Jane recommends Beetroot, Lettuce, Cabbage, Strawberry.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong.

plants.notes: Other plants requiring up to 10cm (4in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

Other plants requiring up to 25cm (10in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

Other plants requiring up to 50cm (20in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

plants.soil: Light, deep, well-drained soil which has not had compost or manure added recently (to avoid forked roots forming.)
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil when it has warmed up from mid spring onwards. Takes a couple of weeks to germinate.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Thin out when the seedlings are large enough to handle if they are too close. Weed carefully during early stages. Cover with mesh or fleece if carrot fly has been a problem in the past, although parsnips are less susceptible to this.
plants.harvesting: Use a garden fork to loosen soil along outside of the planting before pulling roots. Can be left in the soil through winter.
plants.companions: Swiss Chard, Pepper, Peas, Potatoes, Beans, Radish and Garlic.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into the soil from mid spring onwards. Some varieties can be planted year round. Sow in batches for a continuous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required, although a mulch of compost, grass clippings or other organic matter can help on poor soils.
plants.notes: Support plants with a strong row or wigwam structure over which netting can be tied for them to climb up. Alternatively, use twiggy sticks pushed into the ground near each plant.
plants.harvesting: Best picked just before eating, often sweet enough to enjoy raw.
plants.companions: Carrot, Turnip, Lettuce, Coriander and Sweetcorn. Jane recommends Carrot, Radish, Corn, Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Mature plants usually stop producing and die back in hot summer weather.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.position: Sheltered sunny position or under cover.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in early spring. Transfer to bigger pots as required. If planting out then do so from mid spring when soil has warmed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed once the plant is a reasonable size.
plants.notes: Sometimes require supports if the peppers are large.
plants.harvesting: Harvest peppers green when they have grown to a good size or wait for them to ripen to yellow or red if preferred.
plants.companions: Lovage, Borage, Basil, Marjoram, Oregano and Petunia.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil with plenty of compost dug in is best but will grow in most positions.
plants.sowPlant: Grow from seed potatoes. Chit them by leaving on cardboard or eggboxes in a light position until they have produced short green sprouts. Plant out in early to mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: As shoots appear, draw soil over them if there is still a possibility of frost. Once the shoots are hand height, earth them up by drawing more soil around them leaving the top of the shoots still showing to keep the actual potatoes covered. If any potatoes get exposed to light and turn green they should not be eaten. Make sure potatoes are kept watered in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: The earliest potatoes can be harvested when the plants begin to flower. Once the foliage has wilted harvest the main crop within a couple of weeks, digging in from the side to avoid damaging the tubers.
plants.companions: Catnip, Alyssum, Marigold, Coriander, Horseradish, Aubergine and Beans. Jane recommends Beans, Corn, Cabbage, Marigold.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil with plenty of compost dug in is best but will grow in most positions.
plants.sowPlant: Grow from seed potatoes. Plant out in early to mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: As shoots appear, draw soil over them if there is still a possibility of frost. Once the shoots are hand height, earth them up by drawing more soil around them leaving the top of the shoots still showing to keep the actual potatoes covered. If any potatoes get exposed to light and turn green they should not be eaten. Make sure potatoes are kept watered in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Once the foliage has wilted harvest the main crop within a couple of weeks, digging in from the side to avoid damaging the tubers.
plants.companions: Beans, Alyssum, Coriander, Marigold, Horseradish, Aubergine and Catnip. Jane recommends Beans, Corn, Cabbage, Marigold.

plants.soil: Almost any soil with good drainage.
plants.position: Sunny for spring and autumn sowings, light-shade for summer sowings.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the ground.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: A really good crop for growing in between others, especially as it grows to maturity so quickly.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as the root has developed to a usable size, while taste and texture are still good.
plants.companions: Lettuce, Catnip, Nasturtium, Cucumber, Spinach and Beans. Jane recommends Pea, Nasturtium, Lettuce.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Grown from a crown (root) which can be split from a healthy plant and planted out, usually in mid winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but leaves and shoots die back.
plants.feeding: Mulch with extra compost each year after the leaves have died down.
plants.notes: Early sweet stems can be produced by forcing and blanching the rhubarb: in mid winter to early spring add dry material such as leaves or straw and cover with a deep container or bucket to exclude light for about one month.
plants.harvesting: Do not harvest during the first year of growth. After this, pull a few of the thicker sticks when long enough. Stop harvesting in early summer and allow plants to grow freely for the rest of the season.
plants.companions: Strawberry.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Sun or partial shade. A cooler, shady position in summer.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards. Can also sow in early autumn for a winter crop.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop that doubles as a cooked green. Flower buds are also edible. Hot weather causes leaves to become very strongly flavoured. Self seeds.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in small batches as required. Once it flowers the leaves become tougher and hotter in taste.
plants.companions: Beans, Nasturtium, Thyme and Lettuce.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles sometimes make small holes in leaves.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture retentive soil which has had compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in late winter, planting out in early spring. Direct sow from early spring until it becomes too hot. Sow again in late autumn for a winter crop
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, survives winter with mulch.
plants.feeding: If growth is slow or leaves are pale green, feed with liquid seaweed
plants.notes: Keep well watered. Hot or dry conditions can make it bolt (run to seed) which reduces production of usable leaves considerably.
plants.harvesting: Pick a few leaves at a time to allow the plant to continue producing more.
plants.companions: Strawberry and Sweetcorn.

plants.latinName: Cucurbita pepo,  C. moschata, C. maxima
plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: In frost areas, sow under cover in seed trays in early spring. Plant out after last frosts. In frost free areas sow directly into the soil in early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Feed with a slow release organic fertiliser when flowers begin forming. Fortnightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: Towards the end of the summer raise the squash off the ground by putting a piece of wood or similar under them to prevent rotting. Water roots generously in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: When the plant starts to die cut off the squash leaving part of the stalk attached. Allow the skin to harden in the sun for a few days if wanting to store them
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Beans, Sweetcorn and Lemon Balm.

plants.soil: Well-drained rich soil with compost dug in, slightly acidic preferred.
plants.position: Sunny for best ripening, although will grow in partial shade.
plants.sowPlant: Can be raised from seed easier from seedlings or  runners from existing plants. Usually need to be planted by autumn for a crop the following year, although good bought-in plants can be planted in spring and still produce a crop.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardy. Plants go dormant in cold areas from late fall to early spring.
plants.feeding: In autumn and again in early spring, topdress established plants with rich compost or an organic fertiliser. Allow plants to rest in midsummer.
plants.notes: Can be used as a ground cover beneath vegetables and fruit trees, or managed as a perpetual bed. In late summer, remove weeds and withered leaves, and thin runners to no more than 3 per plant. Lift and transplant extra runners.
plants.harvesting: Gather ripe fruits in the morning, when they are cool, and refrigerate immediately. Wash in cool water just before eating.
plants.companions: Beans, Spinach, Borage, Rhubarb, Nigella and Lettuce.
plants.troubleshooting: Slugs can be deterred with straw mulch or traps. Use jamjars or netting to protect ripening berries from birds.

plants.soil: Will grow in most good soils.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil in late spring or early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Cold weather can improve flavour and texture.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water well in dry periods.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in autumn when the rutabaga is well developed. Can be left in the ground until mid winter
plants.companions: Onion, Onions, Peas, Chives and Beans.

plants.soil: Rich soil best but will grow in most places.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the ground from mid spring onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Keep well watered in dry weather
plants.harvesting: Cut a few leaves from the outside of the plant regularly from late spring onwards.
plants.companions: Onion, Onions, Beetroot and Cabbage.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of added compost.
plants.sowPlant: Frost areas: sow under cover 6 weeks before last spring frost. Plant out in late spring, when the weather is settled and warm. Frost free areas: Sow seed directly or in seed beds/seed trays in spring
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: When flowering starts, spray weekly with foliar seaweed spray and side dress with a slow release high potassium organic fertiliser
plants.notes: Tie upright types to canes with string to support the weight of the fruit. Remove side shoots which grow in the angle between the leaf stems and the main stem of the plant.
plants.harvesting: Pick regularly as soon as the fruits are ripe. This encourages production of more tomatoes.
plants.companions: Marigold, Mint, Parsley, Dill, Calendula and Borage. Jane recommends Basil.
plants.troubleshooting: Blossom end rot patches on the bottom of fruits are a nutritional disorder best prevented by growing tomatoes in well-prepared soil with constant light moisture. Yellow leaves indicate lack of magnesium, so apply liquid feed.

plants.soil: Any reasonably fertile well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Frost areas: sow under cover in late winter and plant out in early spring. Frost free areas: sow direct into soil from early spring to mid summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, survives mild frosts, can protect with straw.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Keep watered in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Can be harvested from mid summer onwards. Lift main crop in mid autumn and store to prevent them becoming woody in texture.
plants.companions: Peas and Nasturtium.
plants.troubleshooting: Spring crops bolt to seed quickly, so pull them when the roots are perfect.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: In areas with cooler summers, cabbage can be sown almost all year round, except for the coldest mid winter months. In areas with hot summers, avoid sowing in the hot mid summer months.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when it has formed a good sized head. Don't leave in the ground for too long otherwise it will split.
plants.companions: Mint, Rosemary, Sage, Celery and Agastache.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid-late summer and transplant to final positions in early to mid autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Wait until a few light frosts have passed to harvest, because cool weather enhances the sweet flavour of cabbage.
plants.companions: Mint, Rosemary, Sage, Celery and Agastache.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: In frost areas, sow under cover in seed trays in early spring. Plant out after last frosts. In frost free areas sow directly into the soil in early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Feed with a slow release organic fertiliser when flowers begin forming. Fortnightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: Basically the same as courgettes but left longer to produce fewer larger fruit. Seeds are removed before eating.
plants.companions: Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into the soil from mid spring onwards. Some varieties can be planted year round. Sow in batches for a continuous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required, although a mulch of compost, grass clippings or other organic matter can help on poor soils.
plants.notes: Support plants with a strong row or wigwam structure over which netting can be tied for them to climb up. Alternatively, use twiggy sticks pushed into the ground near each plant.
plants.harvesting: Best picked just before eating, often sweet enough to enjoy raw.
plants.companions: Catnip, Turnip and Beans. Jane recommends Carrot, Radish, Corn, Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Mature plants usually stop producing and die back in hot summer weather.

plants.latinName: Cucurbita pepo,  C. moschata, C. maxima
plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: In frost areas, sow under cover in seed trays in early spring. Plant out after last frosts. In frost free areas sow directly into the soil in early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Feed with a slow release organic fertiliser when flowers begin forming. Fortnightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: Towards the end of the summer raise the squash off the ground by putting a piece of wood or similar under them to prevent rotting. Water roots generously in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: When the plant starts to die cut off the squash leaving part of the stalk attached. Allow the skin to harden in the sun for a few days if wanting to store them
plants.companions: Sweetcorn, Beans and Lemon Balm.

plants.soil: Warmed, well-drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Frost areas: sow under cover 6 weeks before last spring frost. Plant out in late spring, when the weather is settled and warm. Frost free areas: Sow seed directly or in seed beds/seed trays in late spring
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Plant in blocks of at least 9 plants, all the same variety, to encourage pollination by the wind. Often planted with squash as they like similar conditions. Keep well watered in dry spells.
plants.harvesting: Harvest just before eating to get the sweetest taste, when the tassels at the top of the cobs turn brown to black. You can peel back the leaves and check the corn: if they ooze milky sap when pressed with a fingernail then they are ready.
plants.companions: Pumpkin, Beans and Lettuce.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, use raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Easiest to sow as sets (tiny bulbs) which are planted direct into the soil from early winter onwards. Can also be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late winter before planting out mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Used instead of onions for an earlier crop and concentrated flavour.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from mid summer as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Lettuce, Strawberry, Chamomile, Carrot and Mint. Jane also recommends Cabbage.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Lavender and Chives.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Lavender, Parsnip, Chives and Mint.

plants.soil: Rich, well drained, with plenty of compost added.
plants.position: Full sun or partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Best raised from buying or splitting off shoots which arise from the roots of mature plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, survives mild frosts, can protect with straw or fleece.
plants.feeding: Can apply weekly liquid feed in summer if necessary.
plants.notes: Need plenty of water so they benefit from having a layer of mulch such as well rotted compost around them to retain moisture.
plants.harvesting: Use a sharp knife to cut the heads (flower buds) with 2 inches of stem attached while they are still closed or justly slightly opening.
plants.companions: Peas and Hairy Vetch.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained, and free of persistent weeds.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Transplant seedlings in late winter or early spring. A few varieties can be grown from seed.
plants.frostTolerant: Long-lived hardy perennial. Beds can produce for decades.
plants.feeding: Mulch with 5cm (2 in) of rich compost or rotted manure every winter.
plants.notes: After the stems die back in early winter, cut them off at ground level and compost them. Remove weeds, apply compost and mulch, and your yearly maintenance is done.
