plants.harvesting: Begin gathering spears the third year after transplanting, cutting all spears that appear for a month in early spring. In subsequent years, harvest for 6 weeks each spring.
plants.companions: Tomato, Petunia, Parsley, Basil and Calendula.
plants.troubleshooting: Cutting new shoots just below the surface often helps control problems with asparagus beetles, which often lay their eggs on tender shoots near the soil line.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. Prefers a pH of 6.
plants.sowPlant: Buy plants or use offshoots from an existing plant and cut them to 15cm (6 in) after planting.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required but if leaves start to yellow then add a liquid feed.
plants.notes: Need supporting on wires or tied against a fence. Train the briars onto wire supports from 1m (3ft) high and above. Each autumn add some compost.
plants.harvesting: Pick over a long season as ripe.
plants.companions: Pear, Cherry and Almond.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests e.g. marigold, nasturtium, cornflowers, Californian poppies and calendula etc. Many will self-seed and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Not usually applicable, although some flowers (eg nasturtium) can be added to salads and others (eg chamomile) make good herbal teas.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests e.g. marigold, nasturtium, cornflowers, Californian poppies and calendula etc. Many will self-seed and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Not usually applicable, although some flowers (eg nasturtium) can be added to salads and others (eg chamomile) make good herbal teas.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in modules for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests e.g. marigold, nasturtium, cornflowers, Californian poppies and calendula etc. Many will self-seed and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Not usually applicable, although some flowers (eg nasturtium) can be added to salads and others (eg chamomile) make good herbal teas.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: In spring mulch around the root area with compost and then grass clippings or other organic mulch.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. You can add a variety of this tree to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges. In spring mulch around the root area with compost and then grass clippings or other organic mulch.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe.
plants.troubleshooting: May need to protect fruit from birds with netting, or just allow for losing some fruit.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: After harvesting cut the canes down to ground level, leaving any new shoots.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe. Can protect with netting if birds are eating them but make sure that the plant doesn't grow through the netting making it difficult to remove.
plants.companions: Garlic.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Direct sow from early spring through to mid autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water in dry conditions and keep weed free. Will self seed if left to flower.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required when they reach a usable size.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Lettuce, Strawberry and Chamomile. Jane also recommends Cabbage.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Large trees are usually already well established.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches.

plants.soil: Any reasonably fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Set out tubers in spring, planting them 10cm deep. Plants grow quite tall, and can be used to shade heat-sensitive neighbours.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes. Plants die back to the roots in winter.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Can be invasive, so use flowers indoors as cut flowers to reduce reseeding.
plants.harvesting: Harvest tubers from late autumn as required. Make sure all tubers are removed from soil by end of season.
plants.companions: Beans, Cucumber and Rhubarb.
plants.troubleshooting: Powdery mildew often affects plants in late summer, but does not impact yields.

plants.soil: Average, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds 5cm (2 in) deep and 8cm (3 in) apart in spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm. Make additional sowings until midsummer.
plants.frostTolerant: Warm-season annuals, cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Can mix compost or an organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: The pods of many dry beans can be eaten as runner beans when very young.
plants.harvesting: Gather pods when they dry to speckled tan. Allow the harvested beans to dry indoors for one to two weeks before storing in a cool, dry place. Most varieties produce all at once.
plants.companions: Celery, Sweetcorn, Potatoes and Rosemary. Jane recommends Marigold, Sweetcorn, Squash.
plants.troubleshooting: Pods that come into contact with soil are prone to rot. Mulch to prevent this problem.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow late summer to move to final positions in autumn to be over-wintered and ready for spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf colour and type. Most early-maturing cabbage varieties produce smallish heads.
plants.harvesting: Harvest early plants or leave to mature to a firm 'heart' until early summer.  Small secondary heads often grow from the base of early cabbage plants after the primary head is cut.
plants.companions: Mint, Rosemary, Zinnia, Nasturtium, Sage, Celery and Agastache.
plants.troubleshooting: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid-late summer and transplant to final positions in early to mid autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed plants with a liquid plant food when they begin to form heads.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Keep soil moist in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from early spring to early summer.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Agastache, Nasturtium, Sage, Lettuce, Mustard, Kale, Endive, Tat soi and Mizuna.
plants.troubleshooting: Slugs can be a problem.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Frost areas: sow under cover 6 weeks before last spring frost. Plant out in late spring, when the weather is settled and warm. Frost free areas: Sow seed directly or in seed beds/seed trays in spring
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed monthly with a liquid organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Keep moist during dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from late autumn through to spring - can be left in the soil over winter if required.
plants.companions: Chives, Beans, Leek and Tomato.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil in early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Flowers, leaves and roots are all edible
plants.harvesting: Harvest roots in autumn.
plants.companions: Endive, Mizuna, Tat soi and Mustard.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.position: Sun or partial shade. A cooler, shady position in summer.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards. In frost areas sow under cover for an earlier sowing in mid-late winter. Can also sow in early autumn for a winter crop.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in small batches as required.
plants.companions: Carrot, Turnip, Leek, Cabbage and Viola.

plants.soil: Almost any soil type.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards or indoors during winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required while seedlings are still small.
plants.companions: Chives and Mint.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.position: Sun preferred but tolerant of some shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil in late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Can blanch a few plants at a time when they are grown by excluding light from them for a few days. This can make them less bitter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required by cutting off at base. Will sometimes resprout.
plants.companions: Chicory, Mizuna, Tat soi and Mustard.

plants.soil: Rich, well draining, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in shallow furrows filled with potting soil. Thin seedlings to 30cm apart when they are 3 weeks old. Chop the pulled seedlings into salads.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings are frost tender, but mature plants tolerate light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed every 3 weeks with a liquid organic fertiliser, and use a rich, biodegradable mulch such as grass clippings.
plants.notes: When the bulb is the size of an egg, surround it with 6 inches of loose mulch to help it plump up and slightly blanch it.
plants.harvesting: Snip tender young leaves as needed in the kitchen. When the bulbs reach 8cm in diameter, pull them and store in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Mint and Agastache.

plants.soil: Rich soil, light textured with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in early spring either direct into soil or in pots to plant out later.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil but can still benefit from organic compost mixing in before planting.
plants.notes: Not as affected by cabbage root fly as other members of the brassica family. May require fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves but usually matures quickly enough for this not to be a problem.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from mid summer onwards when roots are up to tennis ball size to prevent the texture becoming 'woody'.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Swiss Chard, Leek, Chives, Onion and Onions.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards or under cover for an earlier sowing in mid-late winter. Can also sow in early autumn/fall for a winter crop.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates extreme cold when well rooted.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in small batches as required.
plants.companions: Carrot, Turnip, Leek and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds that threaten to overtake the small plants.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Frost areas: sow under cover 6 weeks before last spring frost. Plant out in late spring, when the weather is settled and warm. Frost free areas: Sow seed directly or in seed beds/seed trays in spring
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: When they start flowering, feed with a slow release, potassium rich organic fertiliser. After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Keep moist by watering regularly. Pinch out the growing tip once the plant has made three leaves and do the same to side shoots as they appear.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit as soon as it feels slightly soft when the ends are pressed.
plants.companions: Radish, Mint, Sweetcorn and Marigold.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds early and then mulch to avoid trampling the vines after fruits have set.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: In areas with cooler summers, mizuna can be sown almost all year round, except for the coldest mid winter months. In areas with hot summers, avoid sowing in the hot mid summer months.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Keep soil moist in dry weather to prevent bolting (running to seed.)
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Nasturtium, Sage, Lettuce, Mustard, Kale, Endive and Tat soi.

plants.soil: Rich, well draining, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Soak seeds in water overnight before planting them 2cm deep and 15cm apart in warm soil after last frosts. Thin to proper spacing after two weeks.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Requires warm temperatures to give a good yield. Wear gloves if handling the plants when wet gives you an allergic reaction.
plants.harvesting: Pick pods young while they are still small.
plants.companions: Sunflower, Melon, Cucumber, Pepper and Aubergine.
plants.troubleshooting: Ants sometimes damage okra blossoms.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: In areas with cooler summers, bok choy can be sown almost all year round, except for the coldest mid winter months. In areas with hot summers, avoid sowing in the hot mid summer months.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Keep soil moist in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when mature. Leaves can be picked form a number of plants instead of harvesting whole plant. Its buds and flowers are edible
plants.companions: Marigold, Nasturtium, Rhubarb, Sage, Dill, Chamomile, Coriander and Lettuce.

plants.soil: Well-drained, reasonably good soil, though will tolerate a variety of sites.
plants.sowPlant: Frost areas: sow under cover 6 weeks before last spring frost. Plant out in late spring, when the weather is settled and warm. Frost free areas: Sow seed directly or in seed beds/seed trays in spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Requires very little attention. Soak seeds in water overnight before planting to improve germination.
plants.harvesting: Pull a few leaves from the outside of the plant regularly from mid summer onwards to produce more growth.
plants.companions: Strawberry, Coriander, Beans, Peas and Mangetout.

plants.soil: Rich soil best but will grow in most places.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the ground from early spring onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Keep well watered in dry seasons.
plants.harvesting: Pull a few leaves from the outside of the plant regularly from mid summer onwards.
plants.companions: Strawberry and Coriander.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: In frost areas, sow under cover in seed trays in early spring. Plant out after last frosts. In frost free areas sow directly into the soil in early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Feed with a slow release organic fertiliser when flowers begin forming. Fortnightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: One or two plants is plenty - they will produce lots of courgettes over a season.
plants.harvesting: Harvest before the courgettes get too big and turn into marrows. This encourages more courgettes to grow.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Sweetcorn and Lemon Balm.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best, but can adapt to any fertile, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant 'slips' that grow from sprouting tubers in mid to late spring after the soil has warmed up
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Mix a good organic compost into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Sweet potatoes form a dense green ground cover, thriving in hot summer conditions. Tubers are often found 12 inches or more from the plant's primary crown, so dig carefully.  Although not from the solanaceae family, sweet potatoes are often placed in that group for crop rotation purposes because they share several important pests and diseases such as wireworms and nematodes which is why we show it as solanaceae.
plants.harvesting: Dig in autumn when the soil is still warm. Cure in a warm, airy place for two weeks before storing at cool room temperatures.
plants.companions: Beans, Strawberry, Parsnip and Beetroot.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. Acidic pH of 5 to 5.5 required.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potassium added, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe.

plants.soil: Will grow on relatively poor soil as long as it is well drained and compost is dug in. pH of 6.5 to 7 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well rotted compost annually.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to three buds. Vines can gradually be trained up a support system.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, thinning a few out beforehand to allow others to swell.
plants.companions: Tansy, Chives, Sage and Agastache.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in to retain moisture. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potassium added, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, or a little before if heavy crop produced.
plants.companions: Marigold, Tomato and Tansy.

plants.soil: Moist soil preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Usually sow direct into soil in mid spring. Alternatively, divide plants in autumn or early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Lift the clumps every three years and divide them.
plants.harvesting: Cut back as required - this encourages new growth.
plants.companions: Tomato, Carrot, Sunflower and Apple.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil amended with compost.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in individual containers, or sow seeds outdoors 1cm deep and 5cm apart. Gradually thin seedlings to proper spacing, and eat your thinnings. Older seedlings are difficult to transplant successfully.
plants.frostTolerant: Can tolerate mild frost.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.harvesting: Can harvest leaves, or leave to flower and produce seeds which can be ground.
plants.companions: Spinach, Celery and Lavender.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil amended with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in individual containers, or sow seeds outdoors 1cm deep and 5cm apart. Gradually thin seedlings to proper spacing, and eat your thinnings. Older seedlings are difficult to transplant successfully.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings may need protection from light frosts.
plants.feeding: Drench with a liquid organic fertiliser when plants are 10cm tall.
plants.notes: Dill flowers and seeds are used in making breads and pickles.
plants.harvesting: Gather and dry leaves when plants are 25cm tall. Use a paper bag to harvest seeds when they change from green to tan and fall freely from their umbels.
plants.companions: Tomato, Aubergine, Pepper, Coriander, Kale, Cauliflower, Broccoli and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Large plants may be blown over by gusty storms. Stake if necessary.

plants.soil: Well-drained but moist soil preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Usually sow direct into soil in mid spring or raise in pots to plant out.
plants.frostTolerant: Some types are partially frost tolerant but most are not.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Pick leaves as required from late spring
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required, a few leaves at a time. Can be dried by hanging a bunch in a dry place although some flavour is lost when dried.
plants.companions: Oregano, Lavender, Rosemary and Kiwi.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil where mint's wandering tendencies can be kept in check.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant or sow seeds. Frost areas: start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Frost free areas, sow seeds in seed trays. Mint is easy to root from stem tip cuttings stuck into moist potting soil. Some strains are propagated only from cuttings rather than seeds.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy even in cold climates. If desired, small plants can be potted up in autumn and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Spearmint or peppermint are the most versatile strain for cooking.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Tomato, Kale, Cauliflower, Broccoli and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Often becomes invasive. If possible, grow near paths, driveways, or other hard surfaces, or in containers buried halfway in the ground.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, Frost areas: start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Frost free areas, sow seeds in seed trays. Some strains are propagated only from cuttings. Authentic Greek oregano can be grown from seeds or plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy in cold climates provided plant is well-rooted and mulched. If desired, small plants can be potted up in autumn and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Some strains are grown for their pretty pink flowers. Oregano often spreads in hospitable spots. Moderately invasive.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Strawberry, Pepper, Aubergine, Squash, Cauliflower, Broccoli, Brussels Sprouts, Kohlrabi, Turnip and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Control oregano's spread by cutting back flowering stems when their colours fade.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds in early spring, and keep moist. Parsley germinates slowly. Or, start with young purchased plants. Take care not to disturb the roots when transplanting parsley.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food monthly.
plants.harvesting: Try both curled and flat-leafed or Italian parsley, which has stronger flavour. Second year plants will flower in spring.
plants.companions: Tomato, Asparagus, Carrot, Chives and Sweetcorn.

plants.soil: Well drained soil with compost dug in.
plants.position: Sun preferred but will grow in most positions.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, keeping in mind that growth habit varies with variety. Trailing rosemary for walls, or dwarf varieties for containers, are propagated by rooting stem cuttings rather than from seeds. Wild Mediterranean rosemary can be grown from seeds or plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Where winters are mild, rosemary can grow into huge, shrub-like plants.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Trailing rosemary is great cascading over a wall.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying from spring to late summer.
plants.companions: Beans, Cabbage, Carrot, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower and Kale.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant or sow seeds. Frost areas start seeds indoors in early spring. Frost free, sow in seed trays or seed beds in early spring. Plants started from seed may not bloom their first year.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy through mild frosts. In colder areas, small plants can be potted up in fall and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: After the first year, sage plants produce beautiful blue flowers. Cut older plants back in spring if they become woody or straggly
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying from spring to autumn.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Carrot, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, Kale, Beans and Lettuce.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants are often short-lived, so root a few stem cuttings each spring to always have vigorous young plants.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant or sow seeds. Frost areas start seeds indoors in early spring. Frost free, sow in seed trays or seed beds in early spring. Good culinary thyme can be grown from seed, but some creeping forms are propagated only from rooted cuttings or divisions.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardy.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: Creeping forms make sturdy ground covers. Bees are attracted to pink thyme flowers.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in summer, before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Carrot, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, Kale, Broccoli, Turnip, Strawberry and Kohlrabi.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants are often short-lived, so root a few stem cuttings each spring to always have vigorous young plants.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil, or high quality organic potting soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, because bay stem cuttings are very difficult to root. Spring and early summer are the best times to adopt a new bay plant. Outdoors, allow 2m between plants being grown as a hedge. When grown in containers, gradually shift plants to a container at least 30cm in diameter.
plants.frostTolerant: Bay is a half-hardy shrub or small tree that can tolerate winter temperatures no lower than -7C.
plants.feeding: Fertilise bay grown in containers with an organic water soluble fertiliser every three weeks from spring to late summer. Feeding is not generally needed for plants grown outdoors.
plants.notes: When growing bay as a potted plant, allow the soil to become dry as autumn approaches. Through winter, allow the soil to dry between waterings.
plants.harvesting: Stem or leaves as desired when needed. In midsummer, gather perfect small branches and dry them in small bunches. Stored dried leaves in airtight containers.
plants.companions: Beans. Use an attractively potted bay plant as a movable accent in your summer herb garden. In mild winter climates, use bay as a landscape shrub or small tree.
plants.troubleshooting: Repot containers every other spring, gradually moving to slightly larger pots. Outdoors, prune as needed if plants outgrow their space.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot where bumblebees and other large pollinators are desired.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds in late spring. A fresh crop of plants can be planted in late summer for bloom in autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings will survive light frosts, but older plants are easily damaged.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Borage seedlings are only edible when very young. Large plants produce edible, starry blue flowers that attract bees in droves. The foliage can be gathered and composted. Will self seed.
plants.harvesting: Cut back borage plants by half their size in midsummer to encourage reblooming. Blossom clusters make beautiful but short-lived cut flowers or edible garnishes.
plants.companions: Tomato and Strawberry. A good companion for any crop that needs strong defense from insects. Borage attracts large buzzing insects that dominate their air space.
plants.troubleshooting: Beware of sleepy bees when pruning or otherwise working with mature borage plants.

plants.soil: Rich soil that retains moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Plant the curled seeds in your garden from early spring onward. Allow some plants to produce mature seeds to scatter where you want to see calendula seedlings in subsequent seasons.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings tolerate light frosts. Established plants may rebloom in late autumn in mild climates
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Calendula blossoms are edible and can be used to bring orange colour to rice or potato dishes, or snip them onto soups or salads for extra flavour and nutrition. Use clean scissors to snip off petal tips, and compost the rest.
plants.harvesting: Cut flowers as soon as they fully open, preferably in late morning, and promptly dry them. For medicinal use  harvest and dry entire calendula flowers. Infuse them in vegetable oil to make a medicinal oil with a long history of use for healing burned or abraded skin.
plants.companions: Kale and Tomato. Spring salad vegetables.
plants.troubleshooting: Elderly plants suffer from powdery mildew and other fungal ailments. It’s best to send them to the compost pile and grow fresh replacement plants in a new place.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade
plants.sowPlant: Catnip can be started from seeds or from a rooted cutting or purchased plant. Set out plants at about the time of your last frost.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy in cold climates provided the plant is well-rooted and mulched. If desired, small plants can be potted up in autumn and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Pinching back in late spring helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Catnip flower clusters are visited by numerous small beneficial insects. If you can, grow clumps in different parts of your garden.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as desired for the pleasure of your cats. One small stem tip with four to eight leaves is plenty for one or two cats to enjoy. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Lavender and Potatoes. Most other herbs that grow to more than 12 inches tall.
plants.troubleshooting: Clip off spent blossom clusters to limit reseeding in your garden.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot, for example at the end of a vegetable row or bed.
plants.sowPlant: Frost areas: start seeds indoors in early spring. Frost free areas: sow in seed trays or seed beds in early spring.  When allowed to shed mature seeds, chamomile often becomes a welcome volunteer plant.
plants.frostTolerant: Young seedlings easily tolerate mild frosts, and survive winters in mild climates. The easiest chamomile to grow is a cool-season annual.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Feathery chamomile foliage contrasts well with the textures of other herbs and flowers.
plants.harvesting: Cut branches when they are holding numerous open flowers, and hang in small bunches to dry. Chamomile tea is made from the blossoms only. When the stems are dry, pop off the blossoms and store them in an airtight container.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Cauliflower, Brussels Sprouts, Broccoli, Onion, Onions, Leek and Chives. Leafy greens grown in spring, as well as spring-blooming herbs and flowers.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant. New growth emerges in mid-spring, followed by flowers that attract pollinators in early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Extremely cold hardy perennials, comfrey plants become dormant in winter and re-emerge every spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Comfrey is a fine source of greens for composting or for using as a mulch around nutrient-hungry plants. When the large plants are cut back in summer, old branches are quickly replaced by a fresh flush of foliage.
plants.harvesting: Roots to be used to make medicinal ointments or skin creams can be harvested at any time, but preferably in early winter. Gather greens for composting in early summer and again in autumn. For medicinal use topical preparations made from comfrey roots are traditionally used to promote healing of sprains and broken bones by increasing circulation to the affected area. However it should not be taken internally as comfrey contains compounds that may harm the liver.
plants.companions: Apple, Apricot, Peach, Pear, Plum, Persimmon and Nectarine. Comfrey is a large plant that tends to crowd out its neighbours.
plants.troubleshooting: Comfrey has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Rich soil with a near neutral Ph.
plants.position: Full sun in cool climates, partial afternoon shade where summers are very hot.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased plants or sow directly in the garden from early spring onwards. Echinacea often does not bloom reliably until its second year in the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: Echinacea is a hardy perennial that survives very cold winters. Plants become dormant in winter and re-emerge in spring.
plants.feeding: Spread rich compost over the dormant plants each winter.
plants.notes: Echinacea is grown for its beautiful flowers and for the medicinal properties of teas and tinctures made from roots, leaves and flowers.
plants.harvesting: Dig plants up in early autumn to harvest the roots. Small divisions with skimpy root systems can be replanted and allowed to grow for another year.  For enhancing immunity to colds, echinacea tinctures or teas are taken every few hours for several days.
plants.companions: Broccoli, Cauliflower, Cabbage, Catnip, Agastache, Coreopsis, Larkspur and Gaillardia. Echinacea’s purple blossoms contrast well with pink, yellow or orange flowers.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot where fennel’s tall branches will not cause unwanted shade.
plants.sowPlant: Frost areas: start seeds indoors in early spring. Frost free areas: sow in seed trays or seed beds in early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: A short-lived hardy perennial, fennel will survive winter temperatures to -17C .
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Fennel flowers attract numerous small beneficial insects.
plants.harvesting: Gather fennel fronds as you need them in the kitchen. Fennel can reseed to the point of weediness. Gathering and using the blooms as cut flowers will prevent excessive reseeding.
plants.companions: Cosmos. Cucumber, squash, melons, pumpkin and other low, vining plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Prune back fennel plants in mid autumn, before cold weather turns the plants to mush.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant. Plants spaced 15 cm apart will grow into a solid mass in 3 years.
plants.frostTolerant: Garlic chives are hardy perennials that survive winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Garlic chives produce white, lightly scented flowers in late summer. Gather them for use as cut flowers to keep garlic chives from reseeding. Like regular chives, garlic chives can become invasive.
plants.harvesting: Do not harvest in the first year.  In spring, gather handfuls of greens for use in the kitchen. The leaves become somewhat tough in summer.
plants.companions: Apple, Carrot, Grape Vine, Peas, Rose, Tomato, Gooseberry, Raspberry and Strawberry. Also, other mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Deadhead garlic chives to limit reseeding.

plants.soil: Any moist, fertile soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot with room to spread. The roots often spread several feet in the course of a season.
plants.sowPlant: Set out roots from early spring to early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Horseradish is a hardy perennial that will survive winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Persistent and long lived, horseradish can become invasive if you accidentally allow pieces of root to be spread around the garden.
plants.harvesting: Dig roots anytime you need them in the kitchen. Keep scrubbed roots in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Potatoes. Usually horseradish should be planted by itself.
plants.troubleshooting: Horseradish seldom has problems with insects or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant or sow seeds. Frost areas: start seeds indoors in early spring. Frost free areas: sow in seed trays or seed beds in early spring. Some strains are propagated only from rooted cuttings.  A mature clump of lavender will grow to 60 cm wide.
plants.frostTolerant: A hardy perennial from the Mediterranean, lavender will survive severe winters
plants.feeding: Not generally needed beyond annual topdressing with rich compost in spring.
plants.notes: Try different strains, and even species, to find the right lavender for your climate. Lavender demands excellent drainage, and benefits from dry, airy conditions.
plants.harvesting: Gather spikes of lavender flowers as soon as they open, and dry in small bundles before storing in an airtight container. You can also dry lavender branches for use in recipes, sachets or potpourri.
plants.companions: Rose, Rosemary, Sage, Mint, Agastache, Apple, Cherry, Peach, Pear and Plum. Colourful petunias, nasturitums or other annual flowers that contrast with lavender’s gray-green foliage and blue flowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Wait until spring to prune back lavender plants, because the dead stems help shelter the base of the plants from winter weather.

plants.soil: Rich well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or obtain a rooted piece from a friend or neighbour who has an established clump. Frost areas: start seeds indoors in early spring. Frost free areas: sow in seed trays or seed beds in early spring. Lemon balm can be transplanted from early spring to early summer. Lemon balm grows into a rounded mound.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial, lemon balm can survive temperatures to -30C.
plants.feeding: Not generally required.
plants.notes: Lemon balm is very easy to grow. Locate it where leaves can be conveniently picked, crushed and sniffed.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying or steeping into tinctures in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Beans, Tomato, Cosmos and Catnip.
plants.troubleshooting: Control lemon balm’s spread by cutting back flowering stems in late summer.

plants.soil: Rich well-drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or obtain a stem tip cutting from a friend and root it in late spring. Lemon verbena cuttings and divisions are best taken when plants are emerging from dormancy in late spring. It responds well to regular trimming.
plants.frostTolerant: Lemon verbena is a tender perennial. It will die back in winter and resurface in spring. Mulch it well and don't let its roots freeze otherwise it will die.
plants.feeding: Feeding is not generally needed.
plants.notes: Lemon verbena is the most "lemony" of all lemon foliage herbs. Locate it where leaves can be conveniently picked, crushed and sniffed.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as desired. Smelling lemon verbena is a special delight of summer best captured in teas. Dry perfect leaves in small bunches, and store them in airtight containers.  This is a fragrant herb to delight your sense of smell and can be used in flower arrangements.
plants.companions: Lavender. Use this 3-foot (90 cm) tall herb as a movable accent in your summer herb garden.

plants.soil: Rich soil that retains moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun in cool climates; partial shade where summers are very hot.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant or sow from seed. Frost areas: start seeds indoors in early spring. Frost free areas: sow in seed trays or seed beds in early spring. Lovage will reach its mature size in about three years.  One plant is usually sufficient, but it’s a good idea to start a new plant every few years.  At maturity, lovage will need a 90 cm square space. It is a very large herb. Because of its 1.5 meter height, lovage is best located at the edge or rear of the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: Lovage is a hardy perennial that survives winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Topdress the soil around the dormant plant with rich compost each winter.
plants.notes: Tender young growth has the best flavour. In summer, consider pruning plants back to force them to push out a flush of new leaves.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen for their celery flavour. Freeze extra leaves by covering chopped lovage leaves with water in ice cube trays.
plants.companions: Potatoes, Pepper and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Remove flowers should lovage produce too many unwanted seedlings. Or, gather lovage seeds and use them in cooking as a substitute for celery seeds.

plants.soil: Rich soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Morning sun with partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased plants, set out in spring. 30 cm each way is a good spacing for an initial planting of 3 plants. Bergamot is a slight spreader, but not invasive like mint. Over time, a happy plant will form a mound 120 cm  high and wide.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial which can survive temperatures to -20F
plants.feeding: Topdress the dormant plants with good compost in winter.
plants.notes: Attracts bees. Leaves are excellent for tea.
plants.harvesting: Harvest stems to dry for tea in early summer, before the plants bloom. The plants will regrow after cutting, then bloom.
plants.companions: Cosmos and Lovage. Salad greens, other shade-tolerant plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Moving clumps every few years may help limit problems with powdery mildew.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, because stevia seeds are very reluctant to sprout.
plants.frostTolerant: Stevia is a tender perennial. Parent plants brought through winter indoors provide rootable stems in spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed. If needed, a water soluble organic fertiliser can be provided in midsummer to invigorate plants.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in midsummer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Thyme and Marjoram. Stevia is an upright plant which goes with mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Stevia thrives in warm weather, and may grow slowly under very cool conditions.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot near the back or edge of a garden bed, because tarragon is a lanky plant.
plants.sowPlant: Set out a purchased plant in late spring. The best strain, called French tarragon, is propagated exclusively by rooting cuttings. At maturity, tarragon will need a 90 cm square space.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial, tarragon can survive temperatures to -30C .
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Tarragon covers itself with yellow-orange blossoms in late summer.
plants.harvesting: Gather stem tips as you need them in the kitchen. Tarragon can be dried, or you can use fresh tarragon to make flavoured vinegars.
plants.companions: Aubergine. Often planted with thyme and other low, mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Tarragon has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant. After two years, valerian will grow into a 45 cm wide clump.
plants.frostTolerant: Extremely cold hardy, even in harsh winter climates. Plants die back to the ground in winter and re-emerge in spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Valerian produces extremely fragrant flowers in early summer. Gather them for use as cut flowers to keep valerian from reseeding and becoming invasive.
plants.harvesting: Dig roots in fall or early spring and dry outdoors, because they release an unpleasant smell as they dry. Store in airtight container. Dried valerian roots are used to make a bedtime tea that promotes sleep. They are also much loved by cats and dogs.
plants.companions: Echinacea, Catnip, Agastache and Dill. Often planted with low, mound-forming herbs and flowers. Valerian can stand 1.5 m (5ft) tall when it is in full bloom.
plants.troubleshooting: Control valerian's spread by cutting back flowering stems before they can shed seeds in your garden.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seed in pots (under cover in frost areas) in late winter before planting out mid-late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required, though overwintered plants can be given a liquid feed in spring.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Carrot, Swiss Chard and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seed in pots (under cover in frost areas) in late winter before planting out mid-late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required, though overwintered plants can be given a liquid feed in spring.
plants.notes: Japanese variety onion sets can be used to give an early harvest. Onion sets are also the better choice for heavier or wetter soils.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Carrot, Swiss Chard, Cabbage and Lettuce.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: In areas with cooler summers, cabbage can be sown almost all year round, except for the coldest mid winter months. In areas with hot summers, avoid sowing in the hot mid summer months.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when it has formed a good sized head. Don't leave in the ground for too long otherwise it will split.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid-late summer and transplant to final positions in early to mid autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Wait until a few light frosts have passed to harvest, because cool weather enhances the sweet flavour of cabbage.
plants.companions: Agastache, Nasturtium, Tansy, Mint, Coriander, Beetroot, Onion, Garlic and Dill.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow late summer to move to final positions in autumn to be over-wintered and ready for spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf colour and type. Most early-maturing cabbage varieties produce smallish heads.
plants.harvesting: Harvest early plants or leave to mature to a firm 'heart' until early summer.  Small secondary heads often grow from the base of early cabbage plants after the primary head is cut.
plants.companions: Dill, Agastache, Nasturtium, Tansy, Mint, Coriander, Beetroot, Onion, Onions, Garlic, Thyme, Chamomile, Sage, Tomato and Celery.
plants.troubleshooting: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.

plants.notes: Other perennial plants. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
Cover crop, usually planted in fall after others have been harvested.  You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow buckwheat from late spring to late summer, whenever a bed will be unused for more than three weeks.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm apart and 1 cm deep. Thin to 10 cm apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Buckwheat cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: When using buckwheat to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Limit reseeding by pulling up or turning under buckwheat just after it blooms, but before it develops mature seeds.
plants.harvesting: Buckwheat can be pulled up and composted or turned under any time. It will return the most organic matter when taken down 5 to 6 weeks after seeding.
plants.companions: Brussels Sprouts, Kale and Soya beans. Mixes well with upright flowers, and makes an attractive backdrop for herbs. A small bed of buckwheat in bloom will attract numerous beneficial insects.
plants.troubleshooting: Buckwheat has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun in warm locations only.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in summer, when the soil is warm. Cowpeas will not germinate in cold soil.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Cowpeas are semi-tropical plants that crave warm growing conditions.
plants.feeding: When using cowpeas to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Cowpeas are a good nitrogen-fixing summer cover crop for warm climates, where the vegetable seasons are sharply divided by a period of hot weather.
plants.harvesting: Pull up or turn under plants any time after they are about 4 weeks old, but before they develop pods.
plants.companions: Cosmos, Coreopsis and Fenugreek. Other heat-tolerant summer-blooming annuals.
plants.troubleshooting: Rarely bothered by pests or diseases when grown in warm weather.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow fenugreek from late spring to late summer, whenever a bed will be unused for more than eight weeks.  Direct seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm apart and 1 cm deep. Thin to 15 cm apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Fenugreek cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: When using fenugreek to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: On warm days, fenugreek often emits a fragrance similar to that of maple syrup. It also can be grown as a medicinal herb.
plants.harvesting: Mow plants before turning them under, or pull them up and compost them if you want to use the spot for planting right away.
plants.companions: Buckwheat, Beans and Cowpeas.
plants.troubleshooting: Fenugreek rarely has problems with pests and diseases when grown in home gardens.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: In areas with cooler summers, mustard can be sown almost all year round, except for the coldest mid winter months. In areas with hot summers, avoid sowing in the hot mid summer months. Sow in late summer to use mustard as a short-term autumn green manure. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm apart and 1 cm deep. Thin to 15 cm apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Mustard is cool-season annual
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.notes: Use young leaves in salads and older ones for cooking. Mustard residue suppresses soil-borne nematodes, so it is an excellent green manure to grow before potatoes.
plants.harvesting: Chop down the green foliage with a hoe and turn it under before it starts to flower.
plants.companions: Grape Vine, Beans, Peas, Apple and Plum. Mustard does an excellent job of suppressing weeds when grown in a solid mass.
plants.troubleshooting: Irrigation is often needed to get a good stand if autumn is dry.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun in very warm locations only.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds from late spring to early summer. Soya beans must have warm soil to germinate and grow.  Poke holes into a cultivated bed or row to plant soybean seeds about 5 cm apart and 1 cm deep. Thin to 15 cm apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Soya beans are a warm-season crop to grow in summer in hot climates.
plants.feeding: When using soya beans to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Soya bean green manures are used primarily to add nitrogen to poor soil.
plants.harvesting: Chop down or pull up plants just as they begin to flower. Nitrogen nodules left behind in the soil add fertility.
plants.companions: Marigold, Sweetcorn, Squash, Celery, Strawberry and Potatoes.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer so that plants can become established before cold weather comes. In cold climates, crimson clover can be planted in early spring instead of autumn. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm apart and 1 cm deep. No thinning is required.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: When using crimson clover to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results. Using inoculated seed can also help to grow a vigorous stand.
plants.notes: Crimson clover is one of the most beautiful cover crops you can grow.
plants.harvesting: Take down plants just as the red tops begin to fade, but before the plants produce mature seeds. The easiest method is to slice plants off at the soil line with a sharp hoe. They can then be turned under or composted. Nitrogen nodules left behind in the soil add fertility.
plants.companions: Cornflower. Often planted with hardy annual flowers including bachelor buttons and corn poppies.
plants.troubleshooting: Crimson clover plants become quite tough as they age, but they seldom regrow when cut off at the soil line.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow hairy vetch in late summer so the plants can become established before cold weather comes.   Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm apart and 1 cm deep. No thinning is required.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy.
plants.feeding: When using hairy vetch to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Hairy vetch stays small through winter and makes vigorous growth in spring. It is highly recommended as a green manure to grow before tomatoes.
plants.harvesting: Take down plants in spring, 3 weeks before the bed is needed for summer vegetables. The easiest method is to slice plants off at the soil line with a sharp hoe. The cut plants can be allowed to dry into a surface mulch.
plants.companions: Oats, Rye and Cornflower.
plants.troubleshooting: Hairy vetch can become weedy if allowed to produce mature seeds.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer to grow as a green manure that forms its own mulch when it is winterkilled, or when using oats as a companion crop for slower-growing legumes. Oats also can be grown as a spring green manure to increase soil organic matter.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm apart and 1 cm deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm apart when growing oats with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Oats are a cool-weather crop that can tolerate frosts
plants.feeding: None generally needed, especially when oats are grown with nitrogen-fixing green manures such as winter peas, winter beans or hairy vetch.
plants.notes: Oats are an ideal late summer green manure. Cut it down and leave the dead residue to form a winter mulch, which is usually well rotted by spring.
plants.harvesting: Young oats can be turned under anytime. In mild winter climates, oats should be mowed and tilled before seedheads appear in late spring.
plants.companions: Rye.
plants.troubleshooting: Rotting oat foliage has herbicidal properties, in that it inhibits germination of weed seeds. Always wait 3 weeks before sowing seeds into soil where oats have been turned under.

plants.soil: Any soil, including poorly drained sites.
plants.sowPlant: Although customarily grown in autumn, annual rye can be used as a fast-growing green manure in all but the hottest summer months.   Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 cm apart and 0.5 cm deep. Firm the seeds into the ground, and then water to promote fast germination.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: When using annual rye to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Mature annual rye plants can be difficult to dig out, so mow down the plants and turn under the residue when the plants are young.
plants.harvesting: In a home garden, annual rye cover crops are easiest to manage if they are mowed every few weeks. The clippings make excellent mulch.
plants.companions: Raspberry. In spring, widely spaced rye plants can serve as trellises for garden peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Annual rye has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in early autumn, though cereal rye will still germinate in mid autumn, after the soil has lost its warmth. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm apart and 1 cm deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm apart when growing cereal rye with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: When using cereal rye to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase organic matter and break up dense subsoil.  Can be sown later in the autumn than other green manures.
plants.harvesting: Mow down plants in spring, before they develop seeds.  The residue can be used as mulch or composted.
plants.companions: Hairy Vetch.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer or early autumn for an overwintered crop. Spring wheat can be planted while the soil is still cool.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm apart and 1 cm deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm apart when growing wheat with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: When using wheat to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase organic matter, break up dense subsoil and crowd out weeds. Makes a beautiful show in spring.
plants.harvesting: Mow down plants in spring, before they develop seeds. The residue can be used as mulch or composted.
plants.companions: Hairy Vetch.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: In areas with cooler summers, Tat soi can be sown almost all year round, except for the coldest mid winter months. In areas with hot summers, avoid sowing in the hot mid summer months.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Surround stem with a 10cm mat with a slit cut into it for the stem to prevent cabbage root fly from destroying the roots. Use fine mesh or fleece over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Keep soil moist in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when mature. Leaves can be picked from a number of plants instead of harvesting whole plant. Its buds and flowers are edible
plants.companions: Marjoram, Beetroot, Cabbage, Carrot, Cucumber, Peas, Strawberry and Viola. Also grown with other greens found in oriental salad mixtures. In autumn, tatsoi looks beautiful with pansies and parsley.

plants.soil: Well drained fertile soil
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant and transplant it from early spring to mid summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Repels harmful insects, beetles and caterpillars. Use trimmings as mulch and to confuse birds on newly seeded areas
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves as and when needed, Cut back in spring.

plants.soil: Will do OK in poor soil, prefers well drained loam
plants.sowPlant: Direct sow from early spring through to summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.notes: Repels harmful insects, beetles and caterpillars. Flowers attract beneficial insects. Use trimmings as mulch and to confuse birds on newly seeded areas. Will self seed to point of weediness if allowed to.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves as and when needed, Cut back in spring.
plants.companions: Mint. Also grown with beds of other tea plants where insects are not wanted. Feverfew repels insects of all nature, so it is a good plant to grow near entryways.

plants.soil: Well drained fertile soil
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant. It will spread if not cut back. If allowed to it will self seed.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.notes: Repels harmful insects. Yellow button flowers attract beneficial insects, especially ladybirds. Use trimmings as mulch and to confuse birds on newly seeded areas.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves as and when needed, Cut back in spring.
plants.companions: Rose, Raspberry, Apple, Peach, Pear, Nectarine, Plum, Cherry, Almond, Cabbage, Cauliflower, Brussels Sprouts, Kohlrabi and Turnip.

plants.soil: Will do OK in poor soil, prefers well drained loam
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds year round
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.harvesting: Harvest ripe seeds just before they shatter. Flowers and leaves are edible. Flowers attract beneficial insects
plants.companions: Potatoes. Potatoes and carrots

plants.soil: Deep, enriched, sandy loam
plants.sowPlant: Plant a fresh root from early to late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Tender, Does best in warm, humid climates.
plants.feeding: None generally needed
plants.notes: Can be invasive if left unharvested
plants.harvesting: As soon as you see new shoots coming up to the side of the main plant, start harvesting young rhizomes. In autumn, dig up the whole pant, harvest the bulk of the rhizomes and save a few for replanting.
plants.companions: Carrot, Onion, Onions and Leek.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant and transplant it from early spring to mid summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Roots semi hardy, leaves tender. Dies back in cold winter areas.
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.notes: Lemon grass loves being cut back and this will encourage more growth. Mulch well in cold winter areas.
plants.harvesting: Leave the plant to develop some thick stems before starting to harvest.
plants.companions: Coriander, Basil, Thyme, Mint, Lemon Verbena, Echinacea and Marigold.

plants.soil: Will do OK in poor soil, prefers well drained loam
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant and transplant it from early spring to mid summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.notes: Will self seed if allowed to. Cut back flowering heads to prevent this. If plant becomes too bushy, cut it back and add leaves to compost. It is a nutrient accumulator.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves as soon as plant is big enough. Use young leaves in salads and cook older ones.
plants.companions: Rosemary, Sage, Lovage and Pear.

plants.soil: Well drained fertile soil
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds directly in spring
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.notes: Dwarf varieties are suitable for smaller gardens. Plant larger varieties to the back of the garden to prevent them casting shade. Keep well watered in dry weather
plants.harvesting: Harvest once seeds start drying. Spent stalks and heads good addition to compost (make sure all the seeds are out).
plants.companions: Cucumber and Beans.

plants.soil: Will grow in any soil
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant and transplant it from early spring to mid summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.notes: It is a nutrient accumulator and has a beneficial effect on most plants near it.
plants.harvesting: Pick leaves as and when needed for medicinal use. Cut flowers for arrangements.
plants.companions: Lavender, Rosemary, Marjoram and Oregano.

plants.soil: Average garden soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow alyssum from early spring to early summer, and in autumn where winters are mild. Alyssum grows fast and often stops blooming in hot weather.  Broadcast seeds into cultivated soil or containers about 5cm apart, and barely cover them with soil. When the seedlings have more than four leaves, thin to 15 cm apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Alyssum seedlings can tolerate light frost, but plants are often killed by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Fast growth is encouraged by mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting. Encourage reblooming with a liquid feed.
plants.notes: Can reseed if allowed to do so, but extra seedlings are easy to lift and move or pull out.
plants.harvesting: Tired alyssum plants often melt down in hot, humid conditions. As annual flowers go, they are short-lived.
plants.companions: Peas, Lettuce, Spinach, Lobelia, Heliotrope, Geranium and Aubergine. In white or pastel shades, alyssum in the perfect little flower to tuck into the corners of beds, or you can grow it beneath tall vegetables or among herbs. Alyssum is famous for attracting tiny wasps and other beneficial insects.

plants.soil: Any good garden soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow cornflowers from early to mid spring for early summer bloom. Also sow in autumn in climates with mild winters. Plant seeds in soil or in containers about 5 cm apart and 1 cm deep. Thin to 20 cm apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Young cornflower seedlings can tolerate freezing temperatures, so seeds can be planted in early spring, or in autumn where winters are mild.
plants.feeding: Fast growth is encouraged by mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Flowers are edible. Rice-size cornflower seeds are much loved by goldfinches and other small seed-eating birds.
plants.harvesting: Cornflowers make good cut flowers. Pull up the plants in mid to late summer, when they no longer look attractive.
plants.companions: Wheat, Oats and Crimson Clover. Cornflowers have an upright posture that helps them fit in tight spaces. Intersperse throughout the garden, as cornflower nectar is unusually sweet, and thus a preferred food source for many beneficial insects.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow cosmos in early spring so the plants can become established before hot weather comes.  Cosmos also can be started indoors in containers and set out when the seedlings have at least five leaves, or purchased as bedding plants. Plant seeds in prepared soil about 5 cm apart and 1 cm deep. Thin to 20 cm apart in all directions for dwarf varieties; allow 30 cmbetween very tall varieties.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings tolerate light frosts, but plants are killed by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Varieties vary greatly in height, colour and flower form. Choose dwarf varieties for tight spaces.  Sulphur cosmos (C. sulphureus) thrives in humid heat.
plants.harvesting: Cosmos make good cut flowers. Pull up the plants and compost them when blooms become few or freezing weather is expected.
plants.companions: Bergamot, Agastache, Catnip and Echinacea. Tall varieties can form a colourful hedge that attracts bees and other pollinators, and mix well with tall herbs like dill and fennel.
plants.troubleshooting: In some climates, cosmos planted in spring may not come into full bloom until days become short in early autumn.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow marigolds in late spring, or set them out as bedding plants. In climates with long, hot summers, make a second planting in summer for great autumn colour.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm apart and 1 cm deep. Thin to 20 cm apart in all directions for dwarf varieties; allow 30 cm between very tall varieties.
plants.frostTolerant: None.  Marigold cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: The 'Gem' marigolds (T. tenufolia) bear edible blossoms with a spicy, citrus flavor.
plants.harvesting: Marigolds make good short-stemmed cut flowers for small bouquets. Don't rush to pull up plants that stop blooming but look healthy, because they will probably come back into bloom.
plants.companions: Tomato, Cabbage, Squash, Pumpkin, Cucumber, Melon, Cauliflower, Kale, Potatoes, Blackcurrant, Redcurrant, White currant, Beans, Orange, Lime and Lemon. Dwarf types make good edging plants that may deter rabbits. Some varieties are known for their ability to starve out rootknot nematodes when planted as a mass.
plants.troubleshooting: Marigolds have few problems with pests or diseases.  Tall varieties may need staking to keep them upright.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Soaking seeds in water overnight prior to planting may speed germination, but nasturtium seeds sprout best when the soil is warm. Poke seeds into the soil about 3 cm deep and 8 cm apart. Thin to 30 cm apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Nasturtiums may survive very light frosts, but they are easily damaged by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Nasturtium blossoms, leaves and immature green seed pods are edible.
plants.harvesting: Gather nasturtium blossoms in the morning, when they are plumped up with moisture. Snip away the base of each blossom, which may taste bitter.
plants.companions: Apple, Beans, Cabbage, Kale, Broccoli, Pumpkin, Radish, Squash, Sweetcorn, Tomato, Sunflower, Kohlrabi, Turnip, Cucumber and Melon. Nasturtiums sprawl out over the ground, so they suppress weeds and shade the soil when grown near tall plants like sweet corn, tomatoes or sunflowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Nasturtium will often reseed itself in hospitable sites.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow phacelia in spring while the soil is still cool. Make sure seed is well covered, because phacelia seeds need darkness to germinate. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm apart and 0.5 cm deep. Thin to 125 cm apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Phacelia seedlings can tolerate light frost, but the plants are easily damaged by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: When growing phacelia to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Limit reseeding by pulling up or turning under phacelia just after it blooms, but before it develops mature seeds.
plants.harvesting: Phacelia can be pulled up and composted or turned under any time. Pull up individual plants grown for flowers before they shed seeds.
plants.companions: Cucumber, Tomato, Kale, Broccoli and Cabbage. Mixes well with other cool-season flowers such as orange calendulas, or you can use phacelia as a cover crop or bee plant.
plants.troubleshooting: Phacelia has few problems with pests or diseases, but expect plant to be abuzz with bees and other beneficial insects.

plants.soil: Any fertile soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow poached egg plant in early spring, while the soil is cool. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about  5 cm apart and 1 cm deep. Thin to 10 cm apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Young seedlings can tolerate light frost, but the plants are easily damaged by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Pull up old plants to limit reseeding. Where summers are hot, plants may expire after blooming heavily in spring.
plants.harvesting: The delicate flowers and fragrance of poached egg plant always bring cheer to the garden. Pull up and compost plants when they stop blooming heavily.
