plants.companions: Lettuce, Mizuna, Tat soi and Endive. This low-growing plant spreads into a mat of green foliage covered with flowers. Grow along pathways or edges of beds, or near tall plants like sweet corn or tomatoes.
plants.troubleshooting: Poached egg plant has few problems with pests or diseases, but may fail when subjected to extreme humid heat.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Scarlet sage needs warm soil to grow well, so wait until the last frost has passed to set out plants. Start seeds indoors in individual containers or set out purchased plants. Space plants 30 cm apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Scarlet sage cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Pinching off the first bloom will encourage plants to grow into lush bushes bearing numerous flower spikes.
plants.harvesting: Gather stems to use in cut arrangements. Snip off old flowers every few weeks to keep plants in bloom all summer.
plants.companions: Lavender and Catnip. Mixes well with upright flowers or herbs, and the blossoms are much loved by hummingbirds.
plants.troubleshooting: Scarlet sage has few problems with pests or diseases.  Newer named varieties are vigorous and very heavy blooming.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Plant zinnias in late spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.  Start seeds indoors in individual containers, set out purchased plants, or direct-sow into warm soil. Poke seeds into the soil about 1 cm deep and 8 cm apart. Thin to 30 cm apart in all directions for dwarf varieties. Zinnia varieties that grow more than  60 cm tall require 45 cm between plants.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Zinnias cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.  In midsummer, drench plants with a high-nitrogen liquid fertiliser to stimulate strong reblooming.
plants.notes: Frequent cutting of blossoms helps many varieties to rebloom constantly for many weeks. Butterflies prefer flat, single zinnia blossoms over "double" varieties that are packed with petals.
plants.harvesting: Gather zinnias for use in arrangements just as the petals open. The true flowers are the tiny yellow florets, which pump out nectar for butterflies.
plants.companions: Alyssum, Dill, Beans and Swiss Chard. Dill, fennel and other upright herbs, bush snap beans, chard. Tall, single-flowered varieties attract butterflies.
plants.troubleshooting: Older zinnias often become infected with powdery mildew. Pull up and compost diseased plants. Many hybrids offer some resistance to powdery mildew.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in late spring or early summer, either in rows or hills. Also may be started from seedlings started indoors or purchased at stores.
plants.frostTolerant: Cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a liquid fertilizer when they begin to blossom and set fruits.
plants.notes: Most gourds grow into large, long-vined plants. Growing long gourds on a trellis helps them keep their shape. Grow at the edge of your garden to save space.
plants.harvesting: Harvest gourds as late as possible, because gourds will not cure and store unless they are totally ripe. Cut gourds with a bit of stem attached, and move to a dry place to cure through winter.
plants.companions: Radish, Catnip, Broccoli, Tansy, Dill and Marigold.
plants.troubleshooting: Squash bugs and squash vine borers can be serious pests. Exclude them from young plantings with row covers. Some gourds such as luffas rarely fruit well in northern latitudes.

plants.soil: Rich soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly when the soil is warm. In cooler climates start seed indoors and transplant out after the last frost, being careful not to disturb the roots. Water very well before planting.
plants.frostTolerant: Cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertilizer into the soil before planting cotton. In midsummer when flowering begins, topdress with more fertilizer or drench with a liquid plant food.
plants.notes: Cotton thrives on heat, but does not respond well to overwatering. In cool climates, grow individual cotton plants in large, dark-colored containers to increase root warmth.
plants.harvesting: Harvest after bolls split open, during a period of dry weather. Cut cotton on long stems and dry in bunches, like herbs.
plants.companions: Basil, Garlic, Cilantro, Mint, Sage, Dill, Onion, Onions and Sunflower.
plants.troubleshooting: Night-flying beetles often chew holes in cotton leaves, but this problem is mostly cosmetic.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil enriched with plenty of compost to lower pH.
plants.sowPlant: Start indoors and transplant outdoors into a hill or mound after the soil has warmed in early summer. In climates with warm summers direct-sow peanuts in early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Rarely necessary. Peanuts are a nitrogen-fixing legume.
plants.notes: Peanuts require at least 120 days of hot weather and ample rainfall to crop well. Regular shallow hoeing is needed to keep the soil around the plants loose and free of weeds, because the stems of peanut flowers bend over and "plant" themselves in the soil.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the leaves turn yellow and die back, or immediately after the first frost. Shake off soil, gently rinsing if necessary, and dry the whole plants in a warm, well-ventilated area for one to two weeks. Remove the peanuts, and continue drying them in a single layer until the shells are crisp. Moldy nuts should be disposed of immediately as they can be toxic.
plants.companions: Beet, Cabbage, Carrot, Celeriac, Celery, Corn, Cucumber, Eggplant, Lettuce, Marigold, Peas, Rosemary, Radish, Strawberry and Tansy.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots in mid spring then plant out once all danger of frosts is past.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Keep moist by watering regularly. Pinch out the growing tip once the plant has made three leaves and do the same to side shoots as they appear.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit as soon as it feels slightly soft when the ends are pressed.
plants.companions: Tansy and Nasturtium.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds early and then mulch to avoid trampling the vines after fruits have set.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.position: Sheltered sunny position or under cover.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in early spring. Transfer to bigger pots as required. If planting out then do so from mid spring when soil has warmed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed once the plant is a reasonable size.
plants.notes: Sometimes require supports.
plants.harvesting: Harvest peppers green when they have grown to a good size or wait for them to ripen to yellow or red if preferred. Chilli peppers will get hotter when left and can be dried out in the sun before storing.
plants.companions: Carrot, Onion, Onions, Leek and Tomato.
plants.troubleshooting: Hot weather increases hot compounds in chillis, so those grown in cool climates may lack heat.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Cold tolerance varies widely with species.
plants.feeding: In early spring, mulch over root zone with 1 to 2 inches of good compost. Mulch with grass clippings or straw.
plants.notes: Obtain local expertise before choosing which fruits to grow.
plants.harvesting: Let experience be your teacher -- taste fruits often as they approach ripeness. Bumper crops can be frozen, dried, or made into jams and jellies.
plants.troubleshooting: In winter, use chicken wire (poultry netting) to protect young plants from rabbits, deer etc.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added. Often grown in widely spaced enriched hills, or in well-aged compost heaps that include some soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in rows, or in hills spaced 6 feet apart. After 2 weeks, thin to 2 plants per hill. To prevent insect problems and encourage early growth, cover seedlings with row cover (fleece) tunnels until they begin to bloom.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Fruit size, flesh color and texture varies with variety and type of melon. Fast-growing muskmelons often do best where summers are cool and rainy, while warm, dry climates favor smooth-skinned honeydews. Small melons mature quickly and take up less space compared to varieties that produce huge fruits.
plants.harvesting: Many muskmelons and cantaloupes separate naturally from the stem when the melons are ripe, so they come away from the vine with only a gentle tug. Melons that do not “slip” often sound hollow when tapped, and the skin color takes on a yellowish cast. Wipe harvested melons clean and store indoors in a cool place, or in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Tansy, Nasturtium and Catnip.
plants.troubleshooting: Use a paper or other roll-out mulch to prevent weeds. Do not weed after the fruits have set. In the US, melons are at high risk for damage from squash bugs, squash vine borers, cucumber beetles and bacterial wilt, so using row cover is a wise preventive strategy.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added. Often grown in widely spaced enriched hills, or in well-aged compost heaps that include some soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in rows, or in hills spaced 6 feet apart. After 2 weeks, thin to 2 plants per hill. To prevent insect problems and encourage early growth, cover seedlings with row cover (fleece) tunnels until they begin to bloom.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Fruit size, flesh color and texture varies with variety and type of melon. Fast-growing muskmelons often do best where summers are cool and rainy, while warm, dry climates favor smooth-skinned honeydews. Small melons mature quickly and take up less space compared to varieties that produce huge fruits.
plants.harvesting: Many muskmelons and cantaloupes separate naturally from the stem when the melons are ripe, so they come away from the vine with only a gentle tug. Melons that do not “slip” often sound hollow when tapped, and the skin color takes on a yellowish cast. Wipe harvested melons clean and store indoors in a cool place, or in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Corn, Radish, Mint, Marigold and Nasturtium.
plants.troubleshooting: Use a paper or other roll-out mulch to prevent weeds. Do not weed after the fruits have set. In the US, melons are at high risk for damage from squash bugs, squash vine borers, cucumber beetles and bacterial wilt, so using row cover is a wise preventive strategy.

plants.soil: Well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Start indoors, and set out seedlings when the soil is settled and warm. Mulch to keep soil lightly moist at all times.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Mix an organic fertilizer into the planting holes as you transplant peppers. Feed every two weeks with a liquid feed after the plants begin to blossom and set fruit.
plants.notes: Tie heavy-bearing plants to a single stake to keep them from falling over. Ornamental varieties with variegated foliage and colorful fruits are easy to grow in containers.
plants.harvesting: Chili peppers can be harvested when they are immature, but pungency increases with ripeness. Wear protective gloves when handling hot chilis, which can be dried or frozen for future use.
plants.companions: Carrot, Onion, Onions, Leek and Tomato.
plants.troubleshooting: Hot weather increases hot compounds in chilis, so those grown in cool climates may lack heat. Some chilis do not bear heavily until days become shorter in late summer.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost mixed in before planting.
plants.sowPlant: Start seedlings indoors or start with purchased plants. Set out after the last frost has passed, when the soil is warm and settled.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed or seaweed drench from mid summer onwards.
plants.notes: Bushy determinate plants can be tied to stakes, but long-bearing indeterminate varieties need a sturdy cage or trellis.
plants.harvesting: Pick regularly as soon as the fruits turn color but are still firm. Store at room temperature.
plants.companions: Marigold, Broccoli, Chives, Mint, Borage, Parsley, Basil, Pepper, Asparagus, Monarda, Lettuce, Garlic, Dill and Calendula.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for leaf-eating tomato hornworms, and pick them off. Black patches on the bottom of fruits are a nutritional disorder best prevented by growing tomatoes in well-prepared soil with constant light moisture.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Best direct sown once soil has warmed and there is no longer a risk of frost. If your growing season is short they can be started inside in pots to get a head start.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble, organic plant food.
plants.notes: Keep moist by watering regularly. If space is limited, pinch out the growing tip once the plant has made three leaves and do the same to side shoots as they appear.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when it slips from the stem.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds early and then mulch to avoid trampling the vines after fruits have set.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in early spring. Transfer to bigger pots as required. Plant out from mid spring when soil has warmed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid organic feed once the plant is a reasonable size.
plants.notes: Sometimes require supports if the peppers are large.
plants.harvesting: Harvest peppers green when they have grown to a good size or wait for them to ripen to yellow or red if preferred.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Chives, Lavender and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Chives, Lavender and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Benefits from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring, topped by a deep mulch of wood chips or sawdust year round.
plants.notes: Prune in winter to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. Most varieties need at  least one other pear tree in the neighbourhood to get good  pollination. Healthy pear trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Harvest pears before they fully ripen, and ripen under cool indoor temperatures.
plants.companions: Mint, Borage, Calendula and Spring Onion. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Very cool or hot weather can affect ripening, and leaving fruits on the tree for too long can cause them to rot from the inside out. Scab and other fungal diseases can cause problems for pears. Prune to  improve airflow and avoid feeding with too much nitrogen.Fire blight can be controlled by trimming off and destroying affected areas as soon as possible. This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.  For a large spread, pears can be grown at 10m apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.

plants.companions: Oats, Rye and Buckwheat. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Very cool or hot weather can affect ripening, and leaving fruits on the tree for too long can cause them to rot from the inside out. Scab and other fungal diseases can cause problems for pears. Prune to  improve airflow and avoid feeding with too much nitrogen.Fire blight can be controlled by trimming off and destroying affected areas as soon as possible. This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive clay or loam.
plants.position: Sunny spot, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young plum trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Feed with a mulch of high nitrogen fertiliser in spring. Keep plum trees mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Some varieties are self-fertile; otherwise at least one other plum flowering at the same time will be required for pollination. Prune in late winter, before buds begin to swell.  Healthy plum trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit feels soft when gently squeezed. As fruit ripens, some fruits will fall from the tree, and others can easily be shaken onto cloths spread on the ground.
plants.companions: Marjoram, Catnip, Coriander, Rosemary, Parsley, Dill, Marigold, Garlic and Lovage. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Plums can be affected by silverleaf disease – prune in dry weather in summer to help avoid infection. In humid climates, plums often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality plums.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive clay or loam.
plants.position: Sunny spot, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. plants.troubleshooting: Plums can be affected by silverleaf disease – prune in dry weather in summer to help avoid infection. In humid climates, plums often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality plums.

plants.soil: Fertile, moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.
plants.position: Sunny spot with excellent air circulation. You will need two trees for good fruit set with sweet cherries. Standard tart cherries are often self fertile, and make nice landscape trees.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young cherry trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Cherries benefit from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter and a feed with a balanced organic  fertiliser in spring
plants.notes: Many sweet cherries need to be grown with at least one other flowering at a similar time for pollination, but many tart  cherries are self-fertile. Prune in late winter to shape trees and removed damaged branches. Healthy cherry trees will bear for twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick cherries carefully so as not to damage the delicate fruit.
plants.companions: Marigold, Garlic, Onion, Onions, Tansy and Nasturtium. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Use netting to prevent bird damage. In humid climates, cherries often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. However, because cherries ripen early, they have fewer disease problems compared to many other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Sheltered south or south-west facing wall or fence, or under glass in cooler climates. Elsewhere peaches need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young peach trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring, along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under peaches mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Peaches may need to be hand-pollinated when grown in sheltered spots. Prune peaches hard in late winter. Healthy peach trees will bear for fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick peaches when the colour has fully developed and the flesh gives slightly when squeezed. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Garlic. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping peach trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl. In humid climates, peaches often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality peaches.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Sheltered south or south-west facing wall or fence, or under glass in cooler climates. Elsewhere nectarines need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young nectarine  trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring , along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under nectarines mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Nectarines are self-fertile, but produce better when more than one tree is grown.  Prune nectarines hard in winter. Healthy nectarine trees will bear for twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick when the colour has fully developed and the flesh feels soft near the stalk. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Garlic and Marigold. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keep plant dry under cover to avoid peach leaf curl. In humid climates, nectarines often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality nectarines.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Sheltered south or south-west facing wall or fence, or under glass in cooler climates. Elsewhere nectarines need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young nectarine  trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring , along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under nectarines mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Nectarines are self-fertile, but produce better when more than one tree is grown.  Prune nectarines hard in winter. Healthy nectarine trees will bear for twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick when the colour has fully developed and the flesh feels soft near the stalk. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Garlic and Marigold. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keep plant dry under cover to avoid peach leaf curl. In humid climates, nectarines often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality nectarines.

plants.soil: Deep, moisture-retentive but well-drained, slightly alkaline soil.
plants.position: Best grown against a sheltered south-facing wall in the cooler climates. Elsewhere apricots need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young apricot trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes. Cold damage to apricot blossoms is a major limiting factor in where they can be successfully grown.
plants.feeding: Feed with balanced organic  fertiliser in early spring. Keep the area beneath apricots mulched with wood chips, straw, or another mulch that helps maintain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or mid to late summer in cooler climates. Elsewhere prune apricots in late winter. Healthy apricot trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit is soft and can be pulled easily from the tree. Ripe apricots fall to the ground.
plants.companions: Basil, Tansy and Garlic. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Dieback and oozing resin can often be remedied by improving growing conditions. Mulching, watering, feeding, weeding and hard pruning can all help. In humid climates, apricots often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality apricots.

plants.soil: Deep, moisture-retentive but well-drained, slightly alkaline soil.
plants.position: Best grown against a sheltered south-facing wall in the cooler climates. Elsewhere apricots need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young apricot trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes. Cold damage to apricot blossoms is a major limiting factor in where they can be successfully grown.
plants.feeding: Feed with balanced organic  fertiliser in early spring. Keep the area beneath apricots mulched with wood chips, straw, or another mulch that helps maintain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or mid to late summer in cooler climates. Elsewhere prune apricots in late winter. Healthy apricot trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit is soft and can be pulled easily from the tree. Ripe apricots fall to the ground.
plants.companions: Basil, Tansy and Garlic. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Dieback and oozing resin can often be remedied by improving growing conditions. Mulching, watering, feeding, weeding and hard pruning can all help. In humid climates, apricots often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality apricots.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.position: Best grown trained against a sunny, sheltered south or west facing wall, or under cover in cooler climates. In warmer climates, kiwis  thrive in full sun provided their roots receive midday shade.
plants.sowPlant: Add plenty of well-rotted organic matter when planting. Plant next to a strong trellis for support.
plants.frostTolerant: Young shoots are vulnerable to frost damage in spring; may require protection.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in late winter, and apply a balanced organic  fertiliser in early spring, just as new growth emerges.
plants.notes: Most kiwi varieties require both male and female plants for successful pollination. One male plant can pollinate up to eight nearby females. Hardy kiwis produce smaller fruits, but are usually self fertile. Healthy kiwi vines trees will bear for ten years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick before the first frosts and then ripen indoors if the fruit is not completely ripe.
plants.companions: Marjoram, Lemon Balm and Marigold. Kiwi vines are so vigorous that they dominate their space and require a sturdy trellis.
plants.troubleshooting: Will only crop if they are planted in a warm enough position, and may suffer from dieback in cold winters.

plants.soil: Deep, fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Stake trees for the first 3-4 years. Healthy medlar trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Can harvest in autumn before the fruits are fully ripe or else leave until they ripen if there is no danger of frost. Fruit must first be ‘bletted’ before eating raw.  To do this, leave them in a cool place until they turn dark red-brown and become soft.
plants.troubleshooting: Medlars are naturally astringent, like persimmons.

plants.soil: Moist, boggy, acid soil. Ideally, a mixture of sand and acidic organic matter.
plants.position: Grow in prepared beds that can be kept very moist or flooded. Bushes can be grown along the pond’s edge in  sun or partial shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in a water-retentive spot by a pond or stream, above the water line, or in a bog-like bed in a low area.
plants.frostTolerant: Plant in a water-retentive spot by a pond or stream, above the water line, or in a bog-like bed in a low area.
plants.feeding: Mulch with acidic  compost to keep soil constantly moist. For the first three years after planting, top-dress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser in spring.
plants.notes: Water only with rainwater. Cranberries will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Begin harvesting three years after planting. Harvest when fruits are red and ripe, but before they have been damaged by hard freezes.
plants.companions: Blueberry. Rhododendrons and azaleas.
plants.troubleshooting: Grows best in acid soil with a pH of 4.0 to 5.5.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter.
plants.position: Full sun to partial shade. Like currants and gooseberries, jostaberries make good bushes for garden boundaries. Unlike gooseberries, they have no thorns.
plants.sowPlant: Plant from late autumn to mid spring while dormant. Incorporate plenty of well-rotted organic matter into the planting hole.
plants.frostTolerant: Developed in Germany, jostaberries are extremely cold hardy.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with well-rotted organic matter in spring along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the root zone mulched to retain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Each winter, remove the oldest canes from established plants, and clip of damaged or drooping branches. Healthy jostaberries will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when fruits turn blue-black and are firm. Freezes well.
plants.companions: Gooseberry. Jostaberries grow best when planted together in small groups.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a sturdy frame of wires against a wall or on posts. Plant with the crown 8cm (3") below soil level and apply a thick mulch. Cut the stems to a strong bud
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: After harvesting, cut 2 year old branches to ground level. Healthy loganberries will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick when ripe. Loganberries do not ripen all at once, and should be picked weekly through the second half of summer.
plants.companions: Leek, Garlic, Chives and Onions. It is best to keep the area around a mound of loganberries mowed to make picking easier.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage. Plant a thornless variety to take the pain out of harvesting.

plants.soil: Rich, well-drained soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter added.
plants.position: Grow in full sun up a pole support system or on a strong trellis against a long fence or wall. Hops are sensitive to day length, and produce best between 35 and 55 degree latitudes.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in hills in spring after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.
plants.frostTolerant: Hops are hardy perennials that require a period of winter chilling and a growing season of at least 120 days.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Hops need support and plenty of room to sprawl. They will quickly run to the top of a 20-foot vertical trellis. Some root trimming may be required to stop the rhizomes spreading too far. Hops will bear for several years before they should be replaced by younger, more vigorous vines.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when cones feel papery and dry, and leave a yellow powder on your fingers when touched. Dry in a warm spot away from sunlight.
plants.companions: Garlic. Clover or other green manures are usually grown between rows of trellised hops.
plants.troubleshooting: Hops may develop mildew if they have inadequate air circulation. Prune vines to improve airflow.

plants.soil: Rich, light soil with plenty of organic matter added.
plants.sowPlant: Incorporate plenty of well-rotted organic matter when planting. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes. Cold damage to spring blossoms is a major limiting factor in where almonds can be successfully grown.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with  a generous mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring along with a balanced organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Almonds are best hand-pollinated when only one or two plants are grown. Healthy almond trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Knock nuts down when they start to drop, then peel and dry them.
plants.companions: Tansy. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping almond trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl and rotting fruits.

plants.soil: Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil.
plants.position: Sheltered spot in full sun or partial shade. Can be grown as a hedge.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, healthy hazel trees will bear twenty years or more.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Self-fertile but pollination is improved by growing in groups with two or more cultivars present. Begins to bear after five years. Healthy hazel trees will bear twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the husks begin to turn yellow in early autumn.
plants.companions: Crimson Clover. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: The nuts are much-loved by squirrels, birds and rodents.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but flowers can be damaged by late frosts.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Healthy walnut trees will bear for many decades.
plants.harvesting: Knock down nuts when ripe, remove the peel and dry. If pickling, harvest while it is still possible to pierce the nuts with a skewer.
plants.companions: Persimmon. Can restrict growth in other plants nearby, because many plants (including tomatoes) are sensitive to juglone, a substance present in walnut roots, leaves and wood. Walnuts should be grown in an orchard of their own, far from the vegetable garden.

plants.soil: Light, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.   For a large spread, chestnuts can be grown at 20m apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Some varieties are not self-fertile, so more than one will need to be planted for successful pollination. Healthy sweet chestnut trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: When ripe nuts fall from the trees, remove the husks (wearing gloves) and dry.
plants.companions: These are large, spreading trees that cast dense shade. The area beneath sweet chestnuts makes a good summer sitting area.
plants.troubleshooting: Squirrels, rodents and birds will steal the nuts.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring, summer and autumn feed with a high nitrogen organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Peas, Dill, Thyme, Marigold, Borage, Cosmos and Calendula. Lemons and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators and to avoid most pests. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring, summer and autumn feed with a high nitrogen organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Thyme, Marigold, Borage and Calendula. Lemons and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators and to avoid most pests. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Dill, Thyme, Marigold, Borage, Cosmos and Calendula. Limes and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators  and to avoid most pests.  Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Thyme, Marigold, Borage and Calendula. Limes and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators  and to avoid most pests.  Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. Oranges grafted onto a dwarfing rootstock may be grown in containers.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring, summer and autumn feed with a high nitrogen fertiliser. Yellowing leaves indicate a need for more nitrogen.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Lavender and Garlic. Oranges and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators and to avoid most pests. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. Oranges grafted onto a dwarfing rootstock may be grown in containers.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun; grow in a frost-free spot under cover from autumn to early summer in cooler areas.
plants.sowPlant: Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring, summer and autumn feed with a high nitrogen fertiliser. Yellowing leaves indicate a need for more nitrogen.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Lavender and Garlic. Oranges and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators and to avoid most pests. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.  Figs grow well in large containers.
plants.position: A sheltered site in full sun. In colder areas grow against a south-facing wall or under cover. Figs grown as pillars or espaliered plants can be planted closer - 45cm (18in) apart, and gradually thinned to the best specimens.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in containers or in a hole lined with solid material that the roots cannot penetrate to encourage fruiting.
plants.frostTolerant: Reasonably tolerant, but the tips of branches carrying fruit can be damaged in cold weather so protect branches with horticultural fleece in winter in cooler regions. Cold also can kill plants back to their roots, from which new plants often re-grow.
plants.feeding: Top-dress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser each spring, and mulch with well-rotted organic matter year round. When growing figs in containers, apply liquid tomato feed every 2-3 weeks once fruits appear.
plants.notes: Figs produce fruitlets which flower the following year and produce fruit.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin feels soft and starts to split when gently squeezed. Figs can be dried or made into fig preserves but otherwise do not store well.
plants.companions: Strawberry and Marigold. None. Figs have large leaves that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: May suffer from red spider mite when grown under cover. Can be controlled using soft soap or by increasing humidity. Net figs to protect from birds, squirrels and wasps. Even with netting, ants sometimes invade the open centers of figs.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.  Figs grow well in large containers.
plants.position: A sheltered site in full sun. In colder areas grow against a south-facing wall or under cover. Figs grown as pillars or espaliered plants can be planted closer - 45cm (18in) apart, and gradually thinned to the best specimens.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in containers or in a hole lined with solid material that the roots cannot penetrate to encourage fruiting.
plants.frostTolerant: Reasonably tolerant, but the tips of branches carrying fruit can be damaged in cold weather so protect branches with horticultural fleece in winter in cooler regions. Cold also can kill plants back to their roots, from which new plants often re-grow.
plants.feeding: Top-dress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser each spring, and mulch with well-rotted organic matter year round. When growing figs in containers, apply liquid tomato feed every 2-3 weeks once fruits appear.
plants.notes: Figs produce fruitlets which flower the following year and produce fruit.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin feels soft and starts to split when gently squeezed. Figs can be dried or made into fig preserves but otherwise do not store well.
plants.companions: Strawberry and Marigold. None. Figs have large leaves that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: May suffer from red spider mite when grown under cover. Can be controlled using soft soap or by increasing humidity. Net figs to protect from birds, squirrels and wasps. Even with netting, ants sometimes invade the open centers of figs.

plants.soil: Well-drained alkaline soil.
plants.position: Sunny, sheltered spot. In cooler climates grow under cover to ensure fruiting. Requires lots of heat to ripen fruits. Pomegranates are self-fertile, so single plants fruit well.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants grown from rooted cuttings in late winter or early spring. Named cultivars produce better than pomegranates grown from seeds.
plants.frostTolerant: Pomegranates tolerate cold to -12°C (10°F)
plants.feeding: Fertilise with a balanced organic fertiliser in November and March.
plants.notes: Prune outdoor plants in spring, and indoor plants in early winter. Remove dead, broken or crossing branches as well as any suckers that have appeared at the base of the plants.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when ripe. The fruit stores well in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Lavender, Cosmos, Zinnia, Sunflower, Nasturtium and Coreopsis. Pomegranates grow into tall, dense shrubs that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Pomegranates often do not start bearing until they are five years old.

plants.soil: Warm, fertile, well-drained soil with a slightly acidic pH.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in late winter or early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but most grow and crop more reliably under cover in cooler climates.
plants.feeding: Persimmons usually need no fertiliser when grown in lawns. Too much nitrogen can cause fruit to drop.
plants.notes: Persimmons do not need to go through a frost to be palatable, but they do need plenty of time to finish ripening after they have been picked. Persimmons may take seven years to start bearing, and then produce for decades.
plants.harvesting: Cut fruits from the tree before they are ripe, retaining the short pedicel. Store in a cool, dry place for up to four months.
plants.companions: Mint.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for aphids and other small sucking insects, which can often be brought under control with insecticidal soap.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid-fall or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Chives and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid-fall or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Chives and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: In cool climates, grow dwarf varieties against a wall, as an espalier. Semi-dwarf and standard pears make excellent landscape trees in large yards.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Benefits from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring, topped by a deep mulch of wood chips or sawdust year round.
plants.notes: Prune in winter to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. Most varieties need at  least one other pear tree in the neighborhood to get good  pollination. Healthy pear trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Harvest pears before they fully ripen, and ripen under cool indoor temperatures.
plants.companions: Dill, Lovage and Tansy. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Very cool or hot weather can affect ripening, and leaving fruits on the tree for too long can cause them to rot from the inside out. Scab and other fungal diseases can cause problems for pears. Prune to  improve airflow and avoid feeding with too much nitrogen. Fire blight can be controlled by trimming off and destroying affected areas as soon as possible. This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: In cool climates, grow dwarf varieties against a wall, as an espalier. Semi-dwarf and standard pears make excellent landscape trees in large yards.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.   For a large spread, pears can be grown at 30ft (10m) apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Benefits from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring, topped by a deep mulch of wood chips or sawdust year round.
plants.notes: Prune in winter to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. Most varieties need at  least one other pear tree in the neighborhood to get good  pollination. Healthy pear trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Harvest pears before they fully ripen, and ripen under cool indoor temperatures.
plants.companions: Oats, Rye and Buckwheat. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Very cool or hot weather can affect ripening, and leaving fruits on the tree for too long can cause them to rot from the inside out. Scab and other fungal diseases can cause problems for pears. Prune to  improve airflow and avoid feeding with too much nitrogen. Fire blight can be controlled by trimming off and destroying affected areas as soon as possible. This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive clay or loam.
plants.position: Sunny spot, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young plum trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Feed with a mulch of high nitrogen fertilizer in spring. Keep plum trees mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Some varieties are self-fertile; otherwise at least one other plum flowering at the same time will be required for pollination. Prune in late winter, before buds begin to swell. Healthy plum trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit feels soft when gently squeezed. As fruit ripens, some fruits will fall from the tree, and others can easily be shaken onto cloths spread on the ground.
plants.companions: Garlic, Marjoram, Catnip, Cilantro, Rosemary, Parsley, Dill, Marigold and Lovage. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Plums can be affected by silverleaf disease in temperate climates – prune in dry weather in summer to help avoid infection. Plum curculios feed on buds, flowers and unripe fruits. Control by allowing hens to feed around trees, or shake branches to dislodge the insects onto a sheet then plunge into very hot water. Remove any fallen fruits as soon as possible. In humid climates, plums often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality plums.

plants.soil: Fertile, moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.
plants.position: Sunny spot with excellent air circulation. You will need two trees for good fruit set with sweet cherries. Standard tart cherries are often self fertile, and make nice landscape trees.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young cherry trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Cherries benefit from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter and a feed with a balanced organic  fertilizer in spring.
plants.notes: Many sweet cherries need to be grown with at least one other flowering at a similar time for pollination, but many tart  cherries are self-fertile. Prune in late winter to shape trees and removed damaged branches. Healthy cherry trees will bear for twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick cherries carefully so as not to damage the delicate fruit.
plants.companions: Marigold, Garlic, Onion, Onions, Tansy and Nasturtium. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Use netting to prevent bird damage. In humid climates, cherries often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. However, because cherries ripen early, they have fewer disease problems compared to many other tree fruits. If there are holes in the trunk which leak a gummy substance or sawdust-like frass, the culprit is probably a borer or beetle – to kill this pest, poke a needle into the hole. Tent caterpillars build gauzy nests in early spring, and devour leaves. Control by swirling a broom head in the nest, then use a stick to scrape the tent off and stomp on it.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Sheltered south or south-west facing wall or fence, or under glass in cool climates. Elsewhere peaches need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young peach trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Topdress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring, along with a balanced organic fertilizer. Keep the area under peaches mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Peaches may need to be hand-pollinated when grown in sheltered spots. Prune peaches hard in late winter. Healthy peach trees will bear for fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick peaches when the color has fully developed and the flesh gives slightly when squeezed. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Garlic, Peas and Beans. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping peach trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl. In humid climates, peaches often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality peaches. Plum curculios feed on buds, flowers and unripe fruits. Control by allowing hens to feed around trees, or shake branches to dislodge the insects onto a sheet then plunge into very hot water. Remove any fallen fruits as soon as possible. Peach borers can be identified by holes in the bark with a sawdustlike frass. Poke a needle into the hole to kill the borer.

plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young nectarine  trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Topdress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring , along with a balanced organic fertilizer. Keep the area under nectarines mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Nectarines are self-fertile, but produce better when more than one tree is grown. Prune nectarines hard in winter. Healthy nectarine trees will bear for twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick when the color has fully developed and the flesh feels soft near the stalk. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Garlic, Tansy, Dill, Chives, Cilantro and Nasturtium. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keep plant dry under cover to avoid peach leaf curl. In humid climates, nectarines often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality nectarines. Plum curculios feed on buds, flowers and unripe fruits. Control by allowing hens to feed around trees, or shake branches to dislodge the insects onto a sheet then plunge into very hot water. Remove any fallen fruits as soon as possible. Peach borers can be identified by holes in the bark with a sawdustlike frass. Poke a needle into the hole to kill the borer.

plants.soil: Deep, moisture-retentive but well-drained, slightly alkaline soil.
plants.position: Best grown against a sheltered south-facing wall in cool climates. Elsewhere apricots need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young apricot trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes. Cold damage to apricot blossoms is a major limiting factor in where they can be successfully grown.
plants.feeding: Feed with balanced organic  fertilizer in early spring. Keep the area beneath apricots mulched with wood chips, straw, or another mulch that helps maintain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or mid to late summer in the cool climates. Elsewhere prune apricots in late winter. Healthy apricot trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit is soft and can be pulled easily from the tree. Ripe apricots fall to the ground.
plants.companions: Basil, Tansy and Garlic. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Dieback and oozing resin can often be remedied by improving growing conditions. Mulching, watering, feeding, weeding and hard pruning can all help. In humid climates, apricots often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality apricots. Plum curculios feed on buds, flowers and unripe fruits. Control by allowing hens to feed around trees, or shake branches to dislodge the insects onto a sheet then plunge into very hot water. Remove any fallen fruits as soon as possible.

plants.companions: Basil, Tansy and Garlic. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
