Remove any fallen fruits as soon as possible.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.position: Best grown trained against a sunny, sheltered south or west facing wall, or under cover in cool climates. In warmer climates, kiwis thrive in full sun provided their roots receive midday shade.
plants.sowPlant: Add plenty of well-rotted organic matter when planting. Plant next to a strong trellis for support.
plants.frostTolerant: Young shoots are vulnerable to frost damage in spring; may require protection.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in late winter, and apply a balanced organic  fertilizer in early spring, just as new growth emerges.
plants.notes: Most kiwi varieties require both male and female plants for successful pollination. One male plant can pollinate up to eight nearby females. Hardy kiwis produce smaller fruits, but are usually self fertile. Healthy kiwi vines trees will bear for ten years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick before the first frosts and then ripen indoors if the fruit is not completely ripe.
plants.companions: Marjoram, Lemon Balm and Marigold. Kiwi vines are so vigorous that they dominate their space and require a sturdy trellis.
plants.troubleshooting: Will only crop if they are planted in a warm enough position, and may suffer from dieback in cold winters. Japanese beetles can collected by placing sheets beneath plants, shaking the plant and then destroying any fallen beetles in a hot bucket of soapy water.

plants.soil: Deep, fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Stake trees for the first 3-4 years. Healthy medlar trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Can harvest in fall before the fruits are fully ripe or else leave until they ripen if there is no danger of frost. Fruit must first be ‘bletted’ before eating raw.  To do this, leave them in a cool place until they turn dark red-brown and become soft.
plants.troubleshooting: Medlars are naturally astringent, like persimmons.

plants.soil: Moist, boggy, acid soil. Ideally, a mixture of sand and acidic organic matter.
plants.position: Grow in prepared beds that can be kept very moist or flooded. Bushes can be grown along the pond’s edge in  sun or partial shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in a water-retentive spot by a pond or stream, above the water line, or in a bog-like bed in a low area.
plants.frostTolerant: Cranberries tolerate extreme cold, but blossoms are subject to cold damage in spring.
plants.feeding: Mulch with acidic compost to keep soil constantly moist. For the first three years after planting, topdress the root zone with a balanced organic fertilizer in spring.
plants.notes: Water only with rainwater. Cranberries will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Begin harvesting three years after planting. Harvest when fruits are red and ripe, but before they have been damaged by hard freezes.
plants.companions: Blueberry. Rhododendrons and azaleas.
plants.troubleshooting: Grows best in acid soil with a pH of 4.0 to 5.5.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter.
plants.position: Full sun to partial shade. Like currants and gooseberries, jostaberries make good bushes for garden boundaries. Unlike gooseberries, they have no thorns.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid spring while dormant. Incorporate plenty of well-rotted organic matter into the planting hole.
plants.frostTolerant: Developed in Germany, jostaberries are extremely cold hardy.
plants.feeding: Topdress with well-rotted organic matter in spring along with a balanced organic fertilizer. Keep the root zone mulched to retain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Each winter, remove the oldest canes from established plants, and clip of damaged or drooping branches. Healthy jostaberries will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when fruits turn blue-black and are firm. Freezes well.
plants.companions: Gooseberry. Jostaberries grow best when planted together in small groups.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a sturdy frame of wires against a wall or on posts. Plant with the crown 8cm below soil level and apply a thick mulch. Cut the stems to a strong bud.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: After harvesting, cut 2 year old branches to ground level. Healthy loganberries will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick when ripe. Loganberries do not ripen all at once, and should be picked weekly through the second half of summer.
plants.companions: Leek, Garlic, Onions and Chives. It is best to keep the area around a mound of loganberries mowed to make picking easier.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage. Plant a thornless variety to take the pain out of harvesting.

plants.soil: Rich, well-drained soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter added.
plants.position: Grow in full sun up a pole support system or on a strong trellis against a long fence or wall. Hops are sensitive to day length, and produce best between 35 and 55 degree latitudes.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in hills in spring after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.
plants.frostTolerant: Hops are hardy perennials that require a period of winter chilling and a growing season of at least 120 days.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Hops need support and plenty of room to sprawl. They will quickly run to the top of a 20-foot vertical trellis. Some root trimming may be required to stop the rhizomes spreading too far. Hops will bear for several years before they should be replaced by younger, more vigorous vines.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when cones feel papery and dry, and leave a yellow powder on your fingers when touched. Dry in a warm spot away from sunlight.
plants.companions: Crimson Clover. Clover or other cover crops are usually grown between rows of trellised hops.
plants.troubleshooting: Hops may develop mildew if they have inadequate air circulation. Prune vines to improve airflow.

plants.soil: Rich, light soil with plenty of organic matter added.
plants.sowPlant: Incorporate plenty of well-rotted organic matter when planting. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes. Cold damage to spring blossoms is a major limiting factor in where almonds can be successfully grown.
plants.feeding: Topdress with  a generous mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring along with a balanced organic fertilizer.
plants.notes: Healthy almond trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Knock nuts down when they start to drop, then peel and dry them.
plants.companions: Tansy. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping almond trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl and rotting fruits. Poor growth and dieback can sometimes be treated with hard pruning and heavy applications of well-rotted organic matter.

plants.soil: Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil.
plants.position: Sheltered spot in full sun or partial shade. Can be grown as a hedge.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Self-fertile but pollination is improved by growing in groups with two or more cultivars present. Begins to bear after five years. Healthy hazel trees will bear twenty years or more. Hazelnuts grow best in climate such as the Pacific Northwest, where winters are chilly yet mild.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the husks begin to turn yellow in early fall.
plants.companions: Crimson Clover. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: The nuts are much-loved by squirrels, birds and rodents.

plants.soil: Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil.
plants.position: Sheltered spot in full sun or partial shade. Can be grown as a hedge.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Self-fertile but pollination is improved by growing in groups with two or more cultivars present. Begins to bear after five years. Healthy filbert trees will bear twenty years or more. Filberts grow best in climate such as the Pacific Northwest, where winters are chilly yet mild.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the husks begin to turn yellow in early fall.
plants.companions: Hops, Apple, Cherry, Gooseberry, Red Currant, White Currant, Black Currant and Crimson Clover. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: The nuts are much-loved by squirrels, birds and rodents.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but flowers can be damaged by late frosts.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Healthy walnut trees will bear for many decades.
plants.harvesting: Knock down nuts when ripe, remove the peel and dry. If pickling, harvest while it is still possible to pierce the nuts with a skewer.
plants.companions: Persimmon. Can restrict growth in other plants nearby, because many plants (including tomatoes) are sensitive to juglone, a substance present in walnut roots, leaves and wood. Walnuts should be grown in an orchard of their own, far from the vegetable garden.
plants.troubleshooting: Native black walnuts are often easier to grow in the US compared to English or Persian walnuts.

plants.soil: Light, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.   For a large spread, chestnuts can be grown at 65ft (20m) apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Some varieties are not self-fertile, so more than one will need to be planted for successful pollination. Healthy sweet chestnut trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: When ripe nuts fall from the trees, remove the husks (wearing gloves) and dry.
plants.companions: Strawberry and Garlic. These are large, spreading trees that cast dense shade. The area beneath sweet chestnuts makes a good summer sitting area.
plants.troubleshooting: Squirrels, rodents and birds will steal the nuts.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained sandy loam is ideal.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but cultivars should be chosen that fit the climate. Some pecans are much more cold tolerant than others.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Pecans are outstanding nut-producing landscape trees in much of the Southeast USA. Pecan trees will bear for decades. It takes 20 years for a pecan tree to grow to maturity.
plants.harvesting: Gather nuts as they fall to the ground. Allow them to dry in a place that is protected from rain.
plants.companions: Pecans are large, spreading trees that make good shade trees in large landscapes.
plants.troubleshooting: Pecans grow best in warm, humid climates. In cool climate pecans may not produce nuts, and may suffer from coral spot.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. When growing dwarf lemons in containers, avoid potting soils that contain wetting agents.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun spring to fall. In winter, plants may be moved into a greenhouse, sunroom, or heated garage
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F). ‘Meyer’ lemons can survive modest freezes.
plants.feeding: In spring and summer,  feed with a high nitrogen organic fertilizer. Fertilize more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. The 'Meyer' lemon is easier to grow than other types.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly colored and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Dill, Thyme, Marigold, Borage, Cosmos, Calendula and Peas. Lemons and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. When growing dwarf lemons in containers, avoid potting soils that contain wetting agents.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun spring to fall. In winter, plants may be moved into a greenhouse, sunroom, or heated garage
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 12" (30cm) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F). ‘Meyer’ lemons can survive modest freezes.
plants.feeding: In spring and summer,  feed with a high nitrogen organic fertilizer. Fertilize more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. The 'Meyer' lemon is easier to grow than other types.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly colored and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Thyme, Marigold, Borage and Calendula. Lemons and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. When growing dwarf limes in containers, avoid potting soils that contain wetting agents.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun spring to fall. In winter, plants may be moved into a greenhouse, sunroom, or heated garage.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F). The ‘Bearss’ lime often grown in containers should be brought indoors when temperatures go below 5°C (40°F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer feed with a balanced organic fertilizer. Fertilize more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. The 'Bearss' lime is easier to grow in containers than other types.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly colored and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Dill, Thyme, Marigold, Borage, Cosmos and Calendula. Limes and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. When growing dwarf limes in containers, avoid potting soils that contain wetting agents.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun spring to fall. In winter, plants may be moved into a greenhouse, sunroom, or heated garage.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 12" (30cm) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F). The ‘Bearss’ lime often grown in containers should be brought indoors when temperatures go below 5°C (40°F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer feed with a balanced organic fertilizer. Fertilize more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. The 'Bearss' lime is easier to grow in containers than other types.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly colored and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Thyme, Marigold, Borage and Calendula. Limes and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. Oranges grafted onto a dwarfing rootstock may be grown in containers.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun spring to fall. In winter, plants may be moved into a greenhouse, sunroom, or heated garage.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer,  feed with a balanced organic fertilizer. Yellowing leaves indicate a need for more nitrogen.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. Very sweet oranges need a long season of warm weather, but kumquats, calamondin oranges and satsumas fruit well in marginal areas or when grown in containers.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly colored and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Lavender and Garlic. Oranges and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. Oranges grafted onto a dwarfing rootstock may be grown in containers.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun spring to fall. In winter, plants may be moved into a greenhouse, sunroom, or heated garage.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 12" (30cm) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer,  feed with a balanced organic fertilizer. Yellowing leaves indicate a need for more nitrogen.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. Very sweet oranges need a long season of warm weather, but kumquats, calamondin oranges and satsumas fruit well in marginal areas or when grown in containers.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly colored and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Lavender and Garlic. Oranges and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.  Figs grow well in large containers.
plants.position: A sheltered site in full sun. In colder areas grow against a south-facing wall with a frame that makes it possible to install a plastic cover in winter. Figs grown as pillars or espaliered plants can be planted closer - 18in (45cm) apart, and gradually thinned to the best specimens.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in early spring, just as they are emerging from winter dormancy. Where winters are cold, try growing figs in containers that are brought into an cool place in winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Figs easily tolerate periodic frosts, but hard freezes (temperatures below 25°F/-4°C) can lead to death of branches and dormant buds. Cold also can kill plants back to their roots, from which new plants often re-grow.
plants.feeding: Topdress the root zone with a balanced organic fertilizer each spring, and mulch with  well-rotted organic matter year round. When growing figs in containers, apply liquid tomato feed every 2-3 weeks once fruits appear.
plants.notes: Figs produce fruitlets which flower the following year and produce fruit.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin feels soft and starts to split when gently squeezed. Figs can be dried or made into fig preserves.
plants.companions: Strawberry and Marigold. Figs have large leaves that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: May suffer from red spider mites when grown under cover. Can be controlled using soft soap or by increasing humidity. Net figs to protect from birds, squirrels and wasps. Even with netting, ants sometimes invade the open centers of figs.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.  Figs grow well in large containers.
plants.position: A sheltered site in full sun. In colder areas grow against a south-facing wall with a frame that makes it possible to install a plastic cover in winter. Figs grown as pillars or espaliered plants can be planted closer - 18in (45cm) apart, and gradually thinned to the best specimens.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in early spring, just as they are emerging from winter dormancy. Where winters are cold, try growing figs in containers that are brought into an cool place in winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Figs easily tolerate periodic frosts, but hard freezes (temperatures below 25°F/-4°C) can lead to death of branches and dormant buds. Cold also can kill plants back to their roots, from which new plants often re-grow.
plants.feeding: Topdress the root zone with a balanced organic fertilizer each spring, and mulch with  well-rotted organic matter year round. When growing figs in containers, apply liquid tomato feed every 2-3 weeks once fruits appear.
plants.notes: Figs produce fruitlets which flower the following year and produce fruit.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin feels soft and starts to split when gently squeezed. Figs can be dried or made into fig preserves.
plants.companions: Strawberry and Marigold. Figs have large leaves that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: May suffer from red spider mites when grown under cover. Can be controlled using soft soap or by increasing humidity. Net figs to protect from birds, squirrels and wasps. Even with netting, ants sometimes invade the open centers of figs.

plants.soil: Well-drained alkaline soil.
plants.position: Sunny, sheltered spot. In cooler climates grow under cover to ensure fruiting. Requires lots of heat to ripen fruits. Pomegranates are self-fertile, so single plants fruit well.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants grown from rooted cuttings in late winter or early spring. Named cultivars such as ‘Wonderful’ produce better than pomegranates grown from seeds.
plants.frostTolerant: Pomegranates tolerate cold to 10°F (-12°C).
plants.feeding: Fertilize with a balanced organic fertilizer in November and March.
plants.notes: Prune outdoor plants in spring, and indoor plants in early winter. Remove dead, broken or crossing branches as well as any suckers that have appeared at the base of the plants.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when ripe, which is usually in early fall. The fruit stores well in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Coreopsis, Lavender, Cosmos, Zinnia, Sunflower and Nasturtium. Pomegranates grow into tall, dense shrubs that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Pomegranates often do not start bearing until they are five years old.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil with a slightly acidic pH.
plants.position: Choose full sun for Oriental persimmons. American persimmon trees tolerate partial shade from high pines or other typical neighbors.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in late winter or early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Oriental persimmons tolerate cold to 10°F (-12°C). American persimmons tolerate much colder conditions, often surviving to -25F (-32C).
plants.feeding: Persimmons usually need no fertilizer when grown in lawns. Too much nitrogen can cause fruit to drop.
plants.notes: Persimmons do not need to go through a frost to be palatable, but they do need plenty of time to finish ripening after they have been picked. Persimmons may take seven years to start bearing, and then produce for decades.
plants.harvesting: Cut fruits from the tree before they are ripe, retaining the short pedicel. Store in a cool, dry place for up to four months.
plants.companions: Mint. To get good fruit set, male and female trees are required of American persimmons. Oriental persimmons are self fertile, but fruit better when multiple trees are grown.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for aphids and other small sucking insects, which can often be brought under control with insecticidal soap.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter while they are dormant. This gives them a chance to settle and develop their roots before putting their energy into spring growth. Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: A cordon requires regular trimming throughout summer to maintain its shape. In midwinter, trim back all the lateral shoots on the main arm so three buds remain
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Chives, nasturtiums, stinging nettles and tansy.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter while they are dormant. This gives them a chance to settle and develop their roots before putting their energy into spring growth. Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: An espalier requires regular trimming throughout summer to maintain its shape. Remove any vigorous shoots that don’t fit into your design, especially those growing off the main central stem.In midwinter, trim back all the lateral shoots on the main arm so three buds remain
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Chives, nasturtiums, stinging nettles and tansy.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: In cool climates, grow dwarf varieties against a wall, as an espalier. Semi-dwarf and standard pears make excellent landscape trees in large gardens.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter while they are dormant. This gives them a chance to settle and develop their roots before putting their energy into spring growth. Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes in cold areas.
plants.feeding: Benefits from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring, topped by a deep mulch of wood chips or sawdust year round.
plants.notes: Prune in winter to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.  Most varieties need at  least one other pear tree in the neighborhood to get good pollination.
plants.harvesting: Harvest pears before they fully ripen, and ripen under cool indoor temperatures.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Very cool or hot weather can affect ripening, and leaving fruits on the tree for too long can cause them to rot from the inside out. Scab and other fungal diseases can cause problems for pears. Prune to  improve airflow and avoid feeding with too much nitrogen. Fire blight can be controlled by trimming off and destroying affected areas as soon as possible. This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: In cool climates, grow dwarf varieties against a wall, as an espalier. Semi-dwarf and standard pears make excellent landscape trees in large gardens.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter while they are dormant. This gives them a chance to settle and develop their roots before putting their energy into spring growth. Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.

plants.feeding: Benefits from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring, topped by a deep mulch of wood chips or sawdust year round.
plants.notes: Prune in winter to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. Most varieties need at  least one other pear tree in the neighborhood to get good  pollination.
plants.harvesting: Harvest pears before they fully ripen, and ripen under cool indoor temperatures.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.

Scab and other fungal diseases can cause problems for pears. Prune to  improve airflow and avoid feeding with too much nitrogen. Fire blight can be controlled by trimming off and destroying affected areas as soon as possible. This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: In cool climates, grow dwarf varieties against a wall, as an espalier. Semi-dwarf and standard pears make excellent landscape trees in large gardens.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter while they are dormant. This gives them a chance to settle and develop their roots before putting their energy into spring growth. Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes in cold areas.
plants.feeding: Benefits from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring, topped by a deep mulch of wood chips or sawdust year round.
plants.notes: Prune in winter to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. Most varieties need at  least one other pear tree in the neighborhood to get good  pollination.
plants.harvesting: Harvest pears before they fully ripen, and ripen under cool indoor temperatures.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Very cool or hot weather can affect ripening, and leaving fruits on the tree for too long can cause them to rot from the inside out. Scab and other fungal diseases can cause problems for pears. Prune to  improve airflow and avoid feeding with too much nitrogen. Fire blight can be controlled by trimming off and destroying affected areas as soon as possible. This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive clay or loam.
plants.position: Sunny spot, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter while they are dormant. This gives them a chance to settle and develop their roots before putting their energy into spring growth. Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young plum trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes in cold areas.
plants.feeding: Feed with a mulch of high nitrogen fertiliser  in spring. Keep plum trees mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Some varieties are self-fertile; otherwise at least one other plum flowering at the same time will be required for pollination. Prune in late winter, before buds begin to swell.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit feels soft when gently squeezed. As fruit ripens, some fruits will fall from the tree, and others can easily be shaken onto cloths spread on the ground.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Plums can be affected by silverleaf disease– prune in dry weather in summer to help avoid infection. Plum curculios feed on buds, flowers and unripe fruits. Control by allowing hens to feed around trees, or shake branches to dislodge the insects onto a sheet then plunge into very hot water. Remove any fallen fruits as soon as possible. In humid climates, plums often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality plums.

plants.soil: Fertile, moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.
plants.position: Sunny spot with excellent air circulation. Cherry trees will only produce fruit in areas with very cold winters. You will need two trees for good fruit set with sweet cherries. Standard tart cherries are often self fertile, and make nice landscape trees.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter while they are dormant. This gives them a chance to settle and develop their roots before putting their energy into spring growth. Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young cherry trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes in cold areas.
plants.feeding: Cherries benefit from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter and a feed with a balanced organic  fertiliser  in spring.
plants.notes: Many sweet cherries need to be grown with at least one other flowering at a similar time for pollination, but many tart  cherries are self-fertile. Prune in late winter to shape trees and removed damaged branches.
plants.harvesting: Pick cherries carefully so as not to damage the delicate fruit.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Use netting to prevent bird damage. In humid climates, cherries often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. However, because cherries ripen early, they have fewer disease problems compared to many other tree fruits. If there are holes in the trunk which leak a gummy substance or sawdust-like frass, the culprit is probably a borer or beetle – to kill this pest, poke a needle into the hole. Tent caterpillars build gauzy nests in early spring, and devour leaves. Control by swirling a broom head in the nest, then use a stick to scrape the tent off and stomp on it.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Peaches need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter while they are dormant. This gives them a chance to settle and develop their roots before putting their energy into spring growth. Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young peach trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes in cold areas.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring, along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under peaches mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Peaches may need to be hand-pollinated when grown in sheltered spots. Prune peaches hard in late winter.
plants.harvesting: Pick peaches when the colour has fully developed and the flesh gives slightly when squeezed. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping peach trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl. In humid climates, peaches often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality peaches. Plum curculios feed on buds, flowers and unripe fruits. Control by allowing hens to feed around trees, or shake branches to dislodge the insects onto a sheet then plunge into very hot water. Remove any fallen fruits as soon as possible. Peach borers can be identified by holes in the bark with a sawdustlike frass. Poke a needle into the hole to kill the borer.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Nectarines need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter while they are dormant. This gives them a chance to settle and develop their roots before putting their energy into spring growth. Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes in cold areas.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring , along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under nectarines mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Nectarines are self-fertile, but produce better when more than one tree is grown. Prune nectarines hard in winter.
plants.harvesting: Pick when the colour has fully developed and the flesh feels soft near the stalk. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keep plant dry under cover to avoid peach leaf curl. In humid climates, nectarines often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality nectarines. Plum curculios feed on buds, flowers and unripe fruits. Control by allowing hens to feed around trees, or shake branches to dislodge the insects onto a sheet then plunge into very hot water. Remove any fallen fruits as soon as possible. Peach borers can be identified by holes in the bark with a sawdustlike frass. Poke a needle into the hole to kill the borer.

plants.soil: Deep, moisture-retentive but well-drained, slightly alkaline soil.
plants.position: Apricots need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter while they are dormant. This gives them a chance to settle and develop their roots before putting their energy into spring growth. Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young apricot trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes in cold areas.
plants.feeding: Feed with balanced organic  fertiliser in early spring. Keep the area beneath apricots mulched with wood chips, straw, or another mulch that helps maintain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Prune apricots in late winter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit is soft and can be pulled easily from the tree. Ripe apricots fall to the ground.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Dieback and oozing resin can often be remedied by improving growing conditions. Mulching, watering, feeding, weeding and hard pruning can all help. In humid climates, apricots often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality apricots. Plum curculios feed on buds, flowers and unripe fruits. Control by allowing hens to feed around trees, or shake branches to dislodge the insects onto a sheet then plunge into very hot water. Remove any fallen fruits as soon as possible.

Remove any fallen fruits as soon as possible.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.position: Kiwis thrive in full sun provided their roots receive midday shade. It is a deciduous climber that prefers a temperate climate.It will survive mild frosts but won’t do well in hot summers.
plants.sowPlant: Add plenty of well-rotted organic matter when planting. Plant next to a strong trellis for support.
plants.frostTolerant: Young shoots are vulnerable to frost damage in spring; may require protection.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in late winter, and apply a balanced organic  fertiliser  in early spring, just as new growth emerges.
plants.notes: Most kiwi varieties require both male and female plants for successful pollination. One male plant can pollinate up to eight nearby females. Hardy kiwis produce smaller fruits, but are usually self fertile.
plants.harvesting: Pick before the first frosts and then ripen indoors if the fruit is not completely ripe.
plants.companions: Kiwi vines are so vigorous that they dominate their space and require a sturdy trellis.
plants.troubleshooting: Will only crop if they are planted in a warm enough position, and may suffer from dieback in cold winters.

plants.soil: Moist, boggy, acid soil. Ideally, a mixture of sand and acidic organic matter.
plants.position: Grow in prepared beds that can be kept very moist or flooded. Bushes can be grown along the pond’s edge in  sun or partial shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in a water-retentive spot by a pond or stream, above the water line, or in a bog-like bed in a low area.
plants.frostTolerant: Cranberries tolerate extreme cold, but blossoms are subject to cold damage in spring.
plants.feeding: Mulch with acidic compost to keep soil constantly moist. For the first three years after planting, top-dress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser in spring.
plants.notes: Water only with rainwater.
plants.harvesting: Begin harvesting three years after planting. Harvest when fruits are red and ripe, but before they have been damaged by hard freezes.
plants.companions: Rhododendrons and azaleas.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter.
plants.position: Full sun to partial shade. Like currants and gooseberries, jostaberries make good bushes for garden boundaries. Unlike gooseberries, they have no thorns.
plants.sowPlant: Plant from late autumn to mid spring while dormant. Incorporate plenty of well-rotted organic matter into the planting hole.
plants.frostTolerant: Developed in Germany, jostaberries are extremely cold hardy.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with well-rotted organic matter in spring along with a balanced organic fertiliser . Keep the root zone mulched to retain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Each winter, remove the oldest canes from established plants, and clip of damaged or drooping branches.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when fruits turn blue-black and are firm. Freezes well.
plants.companions: Jostaberries grow best when planted together in small groups.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a sturdy frame of wires against a wall or on posts. Plant with the crown 8cm below soil level and apply a thick mulch. Cut the stems to a strong bud.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: After harvesting, cut 2 year old branches to ground level.
plants.harvesting: Pick when ripe. Loganberries do not ripen all at once, and should be picked weekly through the second half of summer.
plants.companions: It is best to keep the area around a mound of loganberries mowed to make picking easier.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage. Plant a thornless variety to take the pain out of harvesting.

plants.soil: Rich, well-drained soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter added.
plants.position: Grow in full sun up a pole support system or on a strong trellis against a long fence or wall. Hops are sensitive to day length, and produce best between 35 and 55 degree latitudes.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in hills in spring after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.
plants.frostTolerant: Hops are hardy perennials that require a period of winter chilling and a growing season of at least 120 days.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Hops need support and plenty of room to sprawl. They will quickly run to the top of a 20-foot vertical trellis. Some root trimming may be required to stop the rhizomes spreading too far.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when cones feel papery and dry, and leave a yellow powder on your fingers when touched. Dry in a warm spot away from sunlight.
plants.companions: Clover or other green manures are usually grown between rows of trellised hops.
plants.troubleshooting: Hops may develop mildew if they have inadequate air circulation. Prune vines to improve airflow.

plants.soil: Rich, light soil with plenty of organic matter added.
plants.sowPlant: Incorporate plenty of well-rotted organic matter when planting. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes in cold areas.
plants.feeding: Topdress with  a generous mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring along with a balanced organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Almonds are best hand-pollinated when only one or two plants are grown.
plants.harvesting: Knock nuts down when they start to drop, then peel and dry them.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping almond trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl and rotting fruits. Poor growth and dieback can sometimes be treated with hard pruning and heavy applications of well-rotted organic matter.

plants.soil: Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil.
plants.position: Sheltered spot in full sun or partial shade. Can be grown as a hedge.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, healthy hazel trees will bear twenty years or more.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Self-fertile but pollination is improved by growing in groups with two or more cultivars present. Begins to bear after five years.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the husks begin to turn yellow in early autumn.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: The nuts are much-loved by squirrels, birds and rodents.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but flowers can be damaged by late frosts.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.harvesting: Knock down nuts when ripe, remove the peel and dry. If pickling, harvest while it is still possible to pierce the nuts with a skewer.
plants.companions: Can restrict growth in other plants nearby, because many plants (including tomatoes) are sensitive to juglone, a substance present in walnut roots, leaves and wood.  Walnuts should be grown in an orchard of their own, far from the vegetable garden.

plants.soil: Light, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.  For a large spread, chestnuts can be grown at 20m apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Some varieties are not self-fertile, so more than one will need to be planted for successful pollination.
plants.harvesting: When ripe nuts fall from the trees, remove the husks (wearing gloves) and dry.
plants.companions: These are large, spreading trees that cast dense shade. The area beneath sweet chestnuts makes a good summer sitting area.
plants.troubleshooting: Squirrels, rodents and birds will steal the nuts.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained sandy loam is ideal.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but cultivars should be chosen that fit the climate. Some pecans are much more cold tolerant than others.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Pecans are outstanding nut-producing landscape trees.
plants.harvesting: Gather nuts as they fall to the ground. Allow them to dry in a place that is protected from rain.
plants.companions: Pecans are large, spreading trees that make good shade trees in large landscapes.
plants.troubleshooting: Pecans grow best in warm, humid climates. In cool climate pecans may not produce nuts, and may suffer from coral spot.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. When growing dwarf lemons in containers, avoid potting soils that contain wetting agents.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun. In gardens where the temperatures drop below –5 °C grow them in containers that can be moved into a warm, sheltered area during winter.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: Lemons are best suited for sub-tropical gardens, but will survive moderate frosts (-3 to -5°C) if protected when young. In colder areas, don’t worry too much if citrus leaves go yellowish in winter – it is just a sign of them not enjoying the cold. Position them in a warm microclimate such as a north or west facing wall
plants.feeding: In spring and summer,  feed with a high nitrogen organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. The 'Meyer' lemon is easier to grow than other types.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Lemons and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. When growing dwarf lemons in containers, avoid potting soils that contain wetting agents.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun. In gardens where the temperatures drop below –5 °C grow them in containers that can be moved into a warm, sheltered area during winter.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: Lemons are best suited for sub-tropical gardens, but will survive moderate frosts (-3 to -5°C) if protected when young. In colder areas, don’t worry too much if citrus leaves go yellowish in winter – it is just a sign of them not enjoying the cold. Position them in a warm microclimate such as a north or west facing wall
plants.feeding: In spring and summer,  feed with a high nitrogen organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. The 'Meyer' lemon is easier to grow than other types.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Lemons and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. When growing dwarf limes in containers, avoid potting soils that contain wetting agents.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun. In gardens where the temperatures drop below -2 °C grow them in containers that can be moved into a warm, sheltered area during winter.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: Lime are best suited for sub-tropical gardens,  will survive mild frosts (-1°C to -2°C) if protected when young. In colder areas, don’t worry too much if citrus leaves go yellowish in winter – it is just a sign of them not enjoying the cold. Position them in a warm microclimate such as a north or west facing wall
plants.feeding: In spring and summer feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. The 'Bearss' lime is easier to grow in containers than other types.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Limes and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. When growing dwarf limes in containers, avoid potting soils that contain wetting agents.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun. In gardens where the temperatures drop below -2 °C grow them in containers that can be moved into a warm, sheltered area during winter.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: Lime are best suited for sub-tropical gardens,  will survive mild frosts (-1°C to -2°C) if protected when young. In colder areas, don’t worry too much if citrus leaves go yellowish in winter – it is just a sign of them not enjoying the cold. Position them in a warm microclimate such as a north or west facing wall
plants.feeding: In spring and summer feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Fertilise more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. The 'Bearss' lime is easier to grow in containers than other types.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Limes and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. Oranges grafted onto a dwarfing rootstock may be grown in containers.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun. In gardens where the temperatures drop below 0 °C grow them in containers that can be moved into a warm, sheltered area during winter.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Certain Valencia orange varieties will survive mild frosts (-1°C to -2°C) if protected when young.
plants.feeding: In spring and summer, feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Yellowing leaves indicate a need for more nitrogen.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. Very sweet oranges need a long season of warm weather, but kumquats, calamondin oranges and satsumas fruit well in marginal areas or when grown in containers.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Oranges and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. Oranges grafted onto a dwarfing rootstock may be grown in containers.
plants.position: A sheltered spot in full sun. In gardens where the temperatures drop below 0 °C grow them in containers that can be moved into a warm, sheltered area during winter.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in late winter or early spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to bring plants indoors for the winter. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Certain Valencia orange varieties will survive mild frosts (-1°C to -2°C) if protected when young.
plants.feeding: In spring and summer, feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Yellowing leaves indicate a need for more nitrogen.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. Very sweet oranges need a long season of warm weather, but kumquats, calamondin oranges and satsumas fruit well in marginal areas or when grown in containers.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Oranges and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Grow outdoors in the warmer months to expose plants to heat and pollinators. Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.  Figs grow well in large containers or as an espalier.
plants.position: A sheltered site in full sun. In colder areas grow against a north-facing wall with a frame that makes it possible to install a plastic cover in areas with very cold winters.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in early spring, just as they are emerging from winter dormancy. Where winters are cold, try growing figs in containers that are brought into an cool place in winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Figs easily tolerate periodic frosts, but hard freezes (temperatures below 25°F/-4°C) can lead to death of branches and dormant buds. Cold also can kill plants back to their roots, from which new plants often regrow.
plants.feeding: Top-dress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser each spring, and mulch with well-rotted organic matter year round. When growing figs in containers, apply liquid tomato feed every 2-3 weeks once fruits appear.
plants.notes: Figs produce fruitlets which flower the following year and produce fruit.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin feels soft and starts to split when gently squeezed. Figs can be dried or made into fig preserves.
plants.companions: None. Figs have large leaves that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: May suffer from red spider mites when grown under cover. Can be controlled using soft soap or by increasing humidity. Net figs to protect from birds, squirrels and wasps. Even with netting, ants sometimes invade the open centers of figs.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.  Figs grow well in large containers or as an espalier.
plants.position: A sheltered site in full sun. In colder areas grow against a north-facing wall with a frame that makes it possible to install a plastic cover in areas with very cold winters.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in early spring, just as they are emerging from winter dormancy. Where winters are cold, try growing figs in containers that are brought into an cool place in winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Figs easily tolerate periodic frosts, but hard freezes (temperatures below 25°F/-4°C) can lead to death of branches and dormant buds. Cold also can kill plants back to their roots, from which new plants often regrow.
plants.feeding: Top-dress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser each spring, and mulch with well-rotted organic matter year round. When growing figs in containers, apply liquid tomato feed every 2-3 weeks once fruits appear.
plants.notes: Figs produce fruitlets which flower the following year and produce fruit.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin feels soft and starts to split when gently squeezed. Figs can be dried or made into fig preserves.
plants.companions: None. Figs have large leaves that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: May suffer from red spider mites when grown under cover. Can be controlled using soft soap or by increasing humidity. Net figs to protect from birds, squirrels and wasps. Even with netting, ants sometimes invade the open centers of figs.

plants.soil: Well-drained alkaline soil.
plants.position: Sunny, sheltered spot. Requires lots of heat to ripen fruits.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants grown from rooted cuttings in late winter or early spring. Named cultivars such as ‘Wonderful’ produce better than pomegranates grown from seeds.
plants.frostTolerant: Pomegranates tolerate cold to 10°F (-12°C).
plants.feeding: Fertilise with a balanced organic fertiliser in November and March.
plants.notes: Prune in spring. Remove dead, broken or crossing branches as well as any suckers that have appeared at the base of the plants.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when ripe, which is usually in early autumn. The fruit stores well in the refrigerator and the 'jewels' can be frozen.
plants.companions: None. Pomegranates grow into tall, dense shrubs that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Pomegranates often do not start bearing until they are five years old.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil with a slightly acidic pH.
plants.position: Choose full sun for Oriental persimmons. American persimmon trees tolerate partial shade from high pines or other typical neighbors.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in late winter or early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Oriental persimmons tolerate cold to 10°F (-12°C). American persimmons tolerate much colder conditions, often surviving to -25F (-32C).
plants.feeding: Persimmons usually need no fertiliser when grown in lawns. Too much nitrogen can cause fruit to drop.
plants.notes: Persimmons do not need to go through a frost to be palatable, but they do need plenty of time to finish ripening after they have been picked.
plants.harvesting: Cut fruits from the tree before they are ripe, retaining the short pedicel. Store in a cool, dry place for up to four months.
plants.companions: None. To get good fruit set, male and female trees are required of American persimmons. Oriental persimmons are self fertile, but fruit better when multiple trees are grown.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for aphids and other small sucking insects, which can often be brought under control with insecticidal soap.

plants.soil: Rich, light soil with plenty of organic matter added.
plants.sowPlant: Incorporate plenty of well-rotted organic matter when planting. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes. Cold damage to spring blossoms is a major limiting factor in where almonds can be successfully grown.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with  a generous mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring along with a balanced organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Almonds are best hand-pollinated when only one or two plants are grown. Healthy almond trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Knock nuts down when they start to drop, then peel and dry them.
plants.companions: Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping almond trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl and rotting fruits.

plants.soil: Average garden soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow alyssum from early spring to early summer, and in autumn where winters are mild. Alyssum grows fast and often stops blooming in hot weather.  Broadcast seeds into cultivated soil or containers about 2 inches (5cm) apart, and barely cover them with soil. When the seedlings have more than four leaves, thin to 6 inches (15 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Alyssum seedlings can tolerate light frost, but plants are often killed by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Fast growth is encouraged by mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting. Encourage reblooming with a liquid feed.
plants.notes: Can reseed if allowed to do so, but extra seedlings are easy to lift and move or pull out.
plants.harvesting: Tired alyssum plants often melt down in hot, humid conditions. As annual flowers go, they are short-lived.
plants.companions: Peas, Lettuce, Spinach, Lobelia and Geranium. In white or pastel shades, alyssum in the perfect little flower to tuck into the corners of beds, or you can grow it beneath tall vegetables or among herbs. Alyssum is famous for attracting tiny wasps and other beneficial insects.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter when dormant to help them establish better. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Garlic, Tansy and Lavender.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter when dormant to help them establish better. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Garlic and Lavender.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter when dormant to help them establish better. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Chives and Garlic.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter when dormant to help them establish better. Should be planted with at least one other apple tree which flowers at a similar time to aid pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when apples are ripe.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Chives, Garlic, Tansy, Lavender and Parsnip.

plants.soil: Deep, moisture-retentive but well-drained, slightly alkaline soil.
plants.position: Apricots need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young apricot trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes. Cold damage to apricot blossoms is a major limiting factor in where they can be successfully grown.
plants.feeding: Feed with balanced organic  fertiliser in early spring. Keep the area beneath apricots mulched with wood chips, straw, or another mulch that helps maintain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Prune apricots in late winter or early spring. Healthy apricot trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit is soft and can be pulled easily from the tree. Ripe apricots fall to the ground.
plants.companions: Basil, Tansy, Garlic and Asparagus. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Dieback and oozing resin can often be remedied by improving growing conditions. Mulching, watering, feeding, weeding and hard pruning can all help. In humid climates, apricots often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality apricots.

plants.soil: Deep, moisture-retentive but well-drained, slightly alkaline soil.
plants.position: Apricots need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young apricot trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.

plants.feeding: Feed with balanced organic  fertiliser in early spring. Keep the area beneath apricots mulched with wood chips, straw, or another mulch that helps maintain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Prune apricots in late winter or early spring. Healthy apricot trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit is soft and can be pulled easily from the tree. Ripe apricots fall to the ground.
plants.companions: Basil, Tansy, Garlic and Asparagus. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
