In humid climates, apricots often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality apricots.

plants.soil: Rich, well drained, with plenty of compost added.
plants.position: Full sun or partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Best raised from buying or splitting off shoots which arise from the roots of mature plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, survives mild frosts, can protect with straw or frost protection cloth.
plants.feeding: Can apply weekly liquid feed in summer if necessary.
plants.notes: Need plenty of water so they benefit from having a layer of mulch such as well rotted compost around them to retain moisture.
plants.harvesting: Use a sharp knife to cut the heads (flower buds) with 2 inches of stem attached while they are still closed or justly slightly opening.
plants.companions: Cucumber.

plants.soil: Any reasonably fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Set out tubers in late winter and early spring, planting them 10cm (4 in) deep. Plants grow quite tall, and can be used to shade heat-sensitive neighbors.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes. Plants die back to the roots in winter.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Can be invasive, so use flowers indoors as cut flowers to reduce reseeding.
plants.harvesting: Harvest tubers from late autumn as required. Make sure all tubers are removed from soil by end of season.
plants.companions: Beans and Cucumber.
plants.troubleshooting: Powdery mildew often affects plants in late summer, but does not impact yields.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained, and free of persistent weeds.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Set out dormant 1-year old roots, called crowns, in winter. A few varieties can be grown from seed.
plants.frostTolerant: Long-lived hardy perennial. Beds can produce for decades.
plants.feeding: Mulch with 5cm (2 in) of rich compost or rotted manure every winter.
plants.notes: After the stems die back in early winter, cut them off at ground level and compost them. Remove weeds, apply compost and mulch, and your yearly maintenance is done.
plants.harvesting: Begin gathering spears the second year after planting, cutting all spears that appear for a month in early spring. In subsequent years, harvest for 6 weeks each spring.
plants.companions: Apricot, Basil, Comfrey, Lovage, Marjoram, Parsley, Tomato, Calendula and Petunia.

plants.soil: Warm, fertile, and well drained.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors 6-8 weeks before last spring frost. Transplant to larger pots if needed. Plant out in spring, when the weather is settled and warm.
plants.frostTolerant: A semi-tropical plant; cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: From midsummer onward, drench with a liquid feed every two weeks.
plants.notes: Stake plants to keep them from falling over when they become heavy with fruit. Mulch to keep soil lightly moist.
plants.harvesting: Use pruning shears to cut fruits from the stem. Perfect fruits have shiny skins and only a few immature seeds inside.
plants.companions: Beans, Spinach and Tarragon.

plants.soil: Rich soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil in early summer or under cover in pots.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Plants raised in a greenhouse or under cover will have softer leaves. Pinch off flower buds as they appear to keep the plant productive.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves a few at a time to keep the plant cropping.
plants.companions: Tomato, Capsicum and Apricot.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil, or high quality organic potting soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, because bay stem cuttings are very difficult to root. Spring and early summer are the best times to adopt a new bay plant. Outdoors, allow 2m (6ft) between plants being grown as a hedge. When grown in containers, gradually shift plants to a container at least 30cm (12") in diameter. A mature plant, grown in a sunken container, will occupy a space 45cm (18") square.
plants.frostTolerant: Bay is a half-hardy shrub or small tree that can tolerate winter temperatures no lower than -7C (20F). In cold climates, bay is best grown in a container that can be kept indoors in winter.
plants.feeding: Fertilise bay grown in containers with an organic water soluble fertiliser every three weeks from spring to late summer. Feeding is not generally needed for plants grown outdoors as herb garden specimen plants or hedges.
plants.notes: When growing bay as a potted plant, allow the soil to become dry as autumn approaches. Through winter, allow the soil to dry between waterings.
plants.harvesting: Stem or leaves as desired from early summer to autumn. In midsummer, gather perfect small branches and dry them in small bunches. Stored dried leaves in airtight containers.
plants.companions: Beans. Use an attractively potted bay plant as a movable accent in your summer herb garden. In mild winter climates, use bay as a landscape shrub or small tree.
plants.troubleshooting: Repot containers every other spring, gradually moving to slightly larger pots. Outdoors, prune as needed if plants outgrow their space.

plants.soil: Average, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds 5cm (2 in) deep and 8cm (3 in) apart in spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm. Make additional sowings until midsummer.
plants.frostTolerant: Warm-season annuals, cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Can mix compost or an organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: The pods of many dry beans can be eaten as runner beans when very young.
plants.harvesting: Gather pods when they dry to tan. Allow the harvested beans to dry indoors for one to two weeks before storing in a cool, dry place. Most varieties produce all at once.
plants.companions: Celery, Sweetcorn, Potatoes and Rosemary.
plants.troubleshooting: Pods that come into contact with soil are prone to rot. Mulch to prevent this problem.

plants.soil: Good, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil in rows. Early sowings should be protected by frost cloth or raised under cover in containers.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Support plants in windy places. Dig in roots when finished cropping as these return nitrogen to the soil.
plants.harvesting: Harvest before the pods become tough. Often get a second crop.
plants.companions: Kale, Lettuce, Carrot, Sweetcorn, Celery, Lovage, Petunia and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Rich soil, well-drained with plenty of organic matter to retain moisture.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil once the risk of frost has passed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Rarely required.
plants.notes: Supply plenty of water to the roots from flowering through to harvest.
plants.harvesting: Pick young beans regularly and the plants will continue to crop.
plants.companions: Marigold, Lovage, Petunia, Potatoes, Strawberry, Silver Beet and Beetroot.

plants.soil: Rich soil, well-drained but with plenty of organic matter to retain moisture.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into ground from spring after the risk of frost has passed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Rarely required.
plants.notes: Strong supports needed for climbing varieties. Supply plenty of water to the roots from flowering through to harvest.
plants.harvesting: Pick pods young before they get stringy.
plants.companions: Sweetcorn, Lovage, Marjoram, Parsley, Pumpkin, Squash and Sunflower.
plants.troubleshooting: Scarlet runner beans prefer cooler temperatures than regular beans, high temperatures can result in low pod set.

plants.soil: Rich soil. Well-drained light but deep soil preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Best direct sown in final position . Thin seedlings to at least 10cm (4 in) apart to grow large roots.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Rarely required.
plants.notes: Each seed is actually a small cluster of seeds, so space well and may require thinning. Be careful not to damage the beet when weeding. Young leaves are also a colourful addition to salads. Liable to bolt (run to seed) if sown too early, though some varieties are resistant to this.
plants.harvesting: Harvest young leaves for salad greens as you thin young plants. Pull roots when they become plump. To keep through winter, harvest plants, cut off the tops, and keep in a cool cellar or refrigerator.
plants.companions: Beans, Broccoli, Brussels Sprouts, Cabbage, Cauliflower, Kohlrabi, Lettuce, Lovage, Marjoram, Peas, Potatoes, Spinach, Silver Beet, Onion and Onions.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. Prefers a pH of 6.
plants.sowPlant: Buy plants or use offshoots from an existing plant and cut them to 15cm (6 in) after planting.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required but if leaves start to yellow then add a liquid feed.
plants.notes: Need supporting on wires or tied against a fence. Train the canes onto wire supports from 1m (3ft) high and above. Each autumn add some compost.  Plants can be invasive make sure to keep them incheck.
plants.harvesting: Pick over a long season as ripe.
plants.companions: Raspberry and Marigold.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage. Plant a thornless variety to take the pain out of harvesting.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.position: Sunny position preferred, tolerant of some shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter when dormant to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, will freeze well.
plants.companions: Marigold.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. Acidic pH of 5 to 5.5 required.
plants.sowPlant: Can be planted anytime but should be protected from heat if planted in summer until established.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in double rows, with rows spaced 10 inches (25 cm) apart. Plant seeds 2 inches (5 cm) apart and barely cover them with soil. Gradually thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart. Miniature varieties can be grown 3 inches (8 cm) apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Bok choy can tolerate light frost, but exposure to cold temperatures in spring can trigger early bolting. In autumn, exposure to light frost can improve bok choy's flavor.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: This lovely little mustard cousin is fast and easy to grow.
plants.harvesting: Pull whole plants for use in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Mint. Often planted with lettuce, mustard, kale, escarole, tatsoi, mizuna and other greens found in oriental salad mixtures. Miniature varieties are available for square foot gardens and containers.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles often chew small holes in bok choy leaves in spring, but are less of a problem in the fall.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot where bees and other large pollinators are desired.
plants.sowPlant: Plant the large seeds direct into the garden or in containers. A fresh crop of plants can be planted in late summer for bloom in autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings will survive light frosts, but older plants are easily damaged.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Borage seedlings are only edible when very young. Large plants produce edible, starry blue flowers that attract bees in droves. The foliage can be gathered and composted.
plants.harvesting: Cut back borage plants by half their size in midsummer to encourage reblooming. Blossom clusters make beautiful but short-lived cut flowers or edible garnishes.
plants.companions: Pumpkin, Squash, Tomato, Strawberry and Zucchini. Any crop that needs strong defense from insects. Borage attracts large buzzing insects that dominate their air space.
plants.troubleshooting: Beware of sleepy bees when pruning or otherwise working with mature borage plants.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Either direct into soil or in pots to plant out later if clubroot disease is a problem in your soil. Firm down well when planting out. For green summer broccoli, see 'Broccoli (Green)'.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. May need supportive stakes during the winter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest by cutting off the large central head first before it starts to flower. Smaller side shoots should then be produced for harvesting a few weeks later.
plants.companions: Oregano.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow late summer to autumn in most areas. Plant out when thumb height.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, improves with frost.
plants.feeding: Mix a high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. May need supportive stakes during the winter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from the bottom of the plant upward, twisting off sprouts that are larger than a marble. Removing nearby leaves helps to make room for growing sprouts.
plants.companions: Buckwheat, Mint, Agastache, Echinacea, Mustard and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow buckwheat from late spring to late summer, whenever a bed will be unused for more than three weeks.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. Thin to 10 cm (4in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Buckwheat cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: When using buckwheat to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Limit reseeding by pulling up or turning under buckwheat just after it blooms, but before it develops mature seeds.
plants.harvesting: Buckwheat can be pulled up and composted or turned under any time. It will return the most organic matter when taken down 5 to 6 weeks after seeding.
plants.companions: Brussels Sprouts and Kale. Mixes well with upright flowers, and makes an attractive backdrop for herbs. A small bed of buckwheat in bloom will attract numerous beneficial insects.
plants.troubleshooting: Buckwheat has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in summer and plant out in autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Wait until a few light frosts have passed to harvest, because cool weather enhances the sweet flavour of cabbage.
plants.companions: Dill, Beetroot, Carrot, Chamomile, Coriander, Cucumber, Beans, Lettuce, Lovage, Marjoram, Marigold, Mint, Nasturtium, Peas, Rosemary, Sage, Tansy, Thyme, Tomato and Zinnia.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in summer and plant out in autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.
plants.harvesting: Wait until a few light frosts have passed to harvest, because cool weather enhances the sweet flavour of cabbage.
plants.companions: Dill, Beetroot, Carrot, Chamomile, Coriander, Cucumber, Beans, Lettuce, Lovage, Marjoram, Marigold, Mint, Nasturtium, Peas, Rosemary, Sage, Tansy, Thyme, Tomato and Zinnia.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in mid-late summer and transplant to final positions in early to mid autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed plants with a liquid plant food when they begin to form heads.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Keep soil moist in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when plants reach a suitable size.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Agastache, Nasturtium, Sage, Lettuce, Mustard, Kale, Endive, Tatsoi and Mizuna.
plants.troubleshooting: Slugs can be a problem.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow late summer to move to final positions in autumn to be over-wintered and ready for spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf colour and type. Long maturity cabbages are best suited to cooler areas.
plants.harvesting: Harvest early plants or leave to mature to a firm 'heart' until early summer.  Small secondary heads often grow from the base of early cabbage plants after the primary head is cut.
plants.companions: Dill, Beetroot, Carrot, Chamomile, Coriander, Cucumber, Beans, Lettuce, Lovage, Marjoram, Marigold, Mint, Nasturtium, Peas, Rosemary, Sage, Tansy, Thyme, Tomato and Zinnia.
plants.troubleshooting: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over spring to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow late summer to move to final positions in autumn to be over-wintered and ready for spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Try growing different varieties from seed to explore differences in leaf colour and type. Long maturity cabbages are best suited to cooler areas.
plants.harvesting: Harvest early plants or leave to mature to a firm 'heart' until early summer.  Small secondary heads often grow from the base of early cabbage plants after the primary head is cut.
plants.companions: Dill, Beetroot, Carrot, Chamomile, Coriander, Cucumber, Beans, Lettuce, Lovage, Marjoram, Marigold, Mint, Nasturtium, Peas, Rosemary, Sage, Tansy, Thyme, Tomato and Zinnia.
plants.troubleshooting: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over spring to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow spring to autumn in most areas.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Short maturity cabbages are the most suitable types for sowing during the warmer months.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when heads have reached a decent size and are firm.
plants.companions: Dill, Beetroot, Carrot, Chamomile, Coriander, Cucumber, Beans, Lettuce, Lovage, Marjoram, Marigold, Mint, Nasturtium, Peas, Rosemary, Sage, Tansy, Thyme, Tomato and Zinnia.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow spring to autumn in most areas.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Short maturity cabbages are the most suitable types for sowing during the warmer months.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when heads have reached a decent size and are firm.
plants.companions: Dill, Beetroot, Carrot, Chamomile, Coriander, Cucumber, Beans, Lettuce, Lovage, Marjoram, Marigold, Mint, Nasturtium, Peas, Rosemary, Sage, Tansy, Thyme, Tomato and Zinnia.
plants.troubleshooting: Heavy summer rains following dry weather can cause heads to split.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either direct into soil or in pots to plant out later if clubroot disease is a problem in your soil.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: When heads begin to form, feed with a liquid plant food.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings.
plants.harvesting: Harvest by cutting off the large central head first before it starts to flower. Smaller side shoots should then be produced for harvesting a few weeks later.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Dill, Sage, Zinnia, Mint and Oregano.

plants.soil: Rich soil that retains moisture well.
plants.position: A sunny spot that is easily accessed for cutting.
plants.sowPlant: Plant the curled seeds in your garden from early spring onward, or start them indoors and set out the sturdy seedlings. Allow some plants to produce mature seeds to scatter where you want to see calendula seedlings in subsequent seasons.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings tolerate light frosts. Established plants may rebloom in late autumn if protected from damaging hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Calendula blossoms are edible and can be used to bring orange colour to rice or potato dishes, or snip them onto soups or salads for extra flavour and nutrition. Use clean scissors to snip off petal tips, and compost the rest.
plants.harvesting: Cut flowers as soon as they fully open, preferably in late morning, and promptly dry them. Calendulas make marginal cut flowers because they partially close at night.  For medicinal use  harvest and dry entire calendula flowers. Infuse them in vegetable oil to make a medicinal oil with a long history of use for healing burned or abraded skin.
plants.companions: Tomato and Asparagus. Often planted with spring salad vegetables, peas, carrots, cucumbers.
plants.troubleshooting: Elderly plants suffer from powdery mildew and other fungal ailments. It’s best to send them to the compost pile and grow fresh replacement plants in a new place.

plants.soil: Light, deep, well-drained soil which has not had compost or manure added recently (to avoid forked roots forming.)
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil. Best not sown during heavy frost.
plants.frostTolerant: Light frost tolerant.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Slugs love young carrot seedlings so protect early started plants. Thin out when the seedlings are large enough to handle if they are too close. Weed carefully during early stages.
plants.harvesting: Can be harvested over a long period, although if left in ground over winter they may split attracting slugs.
plants.companions: Chives, Lettuce, Leek, Onion, Onions, Rosemary, Peas, Sage and Tomato.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade
plants.sowPlant: Catnip can be started from seeds sown indoors, or from a rooted cutting or purchased plant. Set out plants at about the time of your last frost.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy in cold climates provided the plant is well-rooted and mulched. If desired, small plants can be potted up in autumn and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Pinching back in late spring helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Catnip flower clusters are visited by numerous small beneficial insects. If you can, grow clumps in different parts of your garden.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as desired for the pleasure of your cats. One small stem tip with four to eight leaves is plenty for one or two cats to enjoy. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Mint, Agastache, Echinacea and Potatoes. Most other herbs that grow to more than 12 inches tall.
plants.troubleshooting: Clip off spent blossom clusters to limit reseeding in your garden.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either direct into soil or in pots to plant out later if clubroot disease is a problem in your soil. Firm down well when planting out.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mix composted manure or another high-nitrogen compost into the soil before planting. When heads begin to form, feed with a liquid plant food.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. Bend over a few leaves if required so that the cauliflower head is kept shaded while it is forming.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the head has fully developed, but before the curd becomes loose, with a "ricey" appearance.
plants.companions: Dill, Nasturtium, Sage, Zinnia and Mint.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow spring to summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed monthly with a liquid organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Keep moist during dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from late autumn through to spring - can be left in the soil over winter if required.
plants.companions: Lettuce, Spinach and Peas.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow spring to summer.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed in mid to late summer.
plants.notes: Unless using a self-blanching type, will need to be planted in trenches, then tubes wrapped round in mid summer and/or earthed up with soil. Keep moist during dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Can cut frequently if required. In any case harvest before the first frost in autumn.
plants.companions: Chives, Dill, Beans, Leek, Lovage, Marjoram, Onion, Onions, Sage, Spinach, Tomato and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot, for example at the end of a vegetable row or bed.
plants.sowPlant: Seeds can be started indoors or sown directly in the garden. When allowed to shed mature seeds, chamomile often becomes a welcome volunteer plant.
plants.frostTolerant: Young seedlings easily tolerate spring frosts, and may survive winters in mild climates. The easiest chamomile to grow is a cool-season annual.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Feathery chamomile foliage contrasts well with the textures of other herbs and flowers.
plants.harvesting: Cut branches when they are holding numerous open flowers, and hang in small bunches to dry. Chamomile tea is made from the blossoms only. When the stems are dry, pop off the blossoms and store them in an airtight container.
plants.companions: Onion, Onions, Spring Onion, Chives, Leek, Cabbage, Kohlrabi, Broccoli and Cauliflower. Often planted with other leafy greens grown in spring, as well as calendula, coriander, and other spring-blooming herbs and flowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Rabbits enjoy nibbling chamomile foliage.

plants.soil: Fertile, moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.
plants.position: Sunny spot with excellent air circulation. You will need two trees for good fruit set with sweet cherries. Standard tart cherries are often self fertile, and make nice landscape trees.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young cherry trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Cherries benefit from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter and a feed with a balanced organic  fertiliser in spring
plants.notes: Many sweet cherries need to be grown with at least one other flowering at a similar time for pollination, but many tart  cherries are self-fertile. Prune in late winter to shape trees and removed damaged branches. Healthy cherry trees will bear for twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick cherries carefully so as not to damage the delicate fruit.
plants.companions: Marigold, Garlic, Lavender, Tansy, Chives, Nasturtium and Onions. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Use netting to prevent bird damage. In humid climates, cherries often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. However, because cherries ripen early, they have fewer disease problems compared to many other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Fertile, moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.
plants.position: Sunny spot with excellent air circulation. You will need two trees for good fruit set with sweet cherries. Standard tart cherries are often self fertile, and make nice landscape trees.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young cherry trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Cherries benefit from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter and a feed with a balanced organic  fertiliser in spring
plants.notes: Many sweet cherries need to be grown with at least one other flowering at a similar time for pollination, but many tart  cherries are self-fertile. Prune in late winter to shape trees and removed damaged branches. Healthy cherry trees will bear for twenty years or more.

plants.troubleshooting: Use netting to prevent bird damage. In humid climates, cherries often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. However, because cherries ripen early, they have fewer disease problems compared to many other tree fruits.

Young cherry trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.

plants.feeding: Cherries benefit from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter and a feed with a balanced organic  fertiliser in spring
plants.notes: Many sweet cherries need to be grown with at least one other flowering at a similar time for pollination, but many tart  cherries are self-fertile. Prune in late winter to shape trees and removed damaged branches. Healthy cherry trees will bear for twenty years or more.

plants.troubleshooting: Use netting to prevent bird damage. In humid climates, cherries often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. However, because cherries ripen early, they have fewer disease problems compared to many other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Light, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Some varieties are not self-fertile, so more than one will need to be planted for successful pollination. Healthy sweet chestnut trees will bear for decades. Spacing for chestnut trees will depend on chosen variety and pruning method.
plants.harvesting: When ripe nuts fall from the trees, remove the husks (wearing gloves) and dry.
plants.companions: Strawberry and Garlic. These are large, spreading trees that cast dense shade. The area beneath sweet chestnuts makes a good summer sitting area.
plants.troubleshooting: Squirrels, rodents and birds will steal the nuts.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil in final growing position
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Can be forced and blanched by replanting in a deep soil-filled box in a warm place during winter.
plants.harvesting: Can run to seed if sown too early.
plants.companions: Endive, Mizuna, Tatsoi and Mustard.

plants.soil: Moist soil preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Usually sow direct into soil, can also be started in containers if prefered. Alternatively, divide plants in autumn or early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Lift the clumps every three years and divide them.
plants.harvesting: Cut back as required - this encourages new growth.
plants.companions: Apple, Carrot, Apricot and Cherry.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Plants spaced 15 cm (6in) apart will grow into a solid mass in 3 years.
plants.frostTolerant: Garlic chives are hardy perennials that survive winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Garlic chives produce white, lightly scented flowers in late summer. Gather them for use as cut flowers to keep garlic chives from reseeding. Like regular chives, garlic chives can become invasive.
plants.harvesting: Do not harvest in the first year.  In spring, gather handfuls of greens for use in the kitchen. The leaves become somewhat tough in summer.
plants.companions: Carrot, Grape Vine, Rose and Tomato. Often planted with oregano, thyme, and other mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Deadhead garlic chives to limit reseeding.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors or sow them where you want them to grow, or start with a purchased plant. New growth emerges in spring, followed by flowers that attract pollinators in early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Extremely cold hardy perennials, comfrey plants become dormant in winter and re-emerge every spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Comfrey is a fine source of greens for composting or for using as a mulch around nutrient-hungry plants. When the large plants are cut back in summer, old branches are quickly replaced by a fresh flush of foliage.
plants.harvesting: Roots to be used to make medicinal ointments or skin creams can be harvested at any time, but preferably in early winter. Gather greens for composting in early summer and again in autumn. For medicinal use topical preparations made from comfrey roots are traditionally used to promote healing of sprains and broken bones by increasing circulation to the affected area. However it should not be taken internally as comfrey contains compounds that may harm the liver.
plants.companions: Apple, Apricot, Peach, Pear, Plum, Persimmon, Nectarine and Asparagus. Comfrey is a large plant that tends to crowd out its neighbors.
plants.troubleshooting: Comfrey has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil amended with compost.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in individual containers, or sow seeds outdoors 1cm (half an inch) deep and 5cm (2 in) apart. Gradually thin seedlings to proper spacing, and eat your thinnings. Older seedlings are difficult to transplant successfully.
plants.frostTolerant: Can tolerate mild frost.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.harvesting: Can harvest leaves, or leave to flower and produce seeds which can be ground.
plants.companions: Potatoes, Basil, Mint, Yarrow and Tansy.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.position: Sun or partial shade. A cooler, shady position in summer.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil also under cover for an earlier sowing in mid-late winter. Generally best grown during the cooler months in areas with a hot summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in small batches as required.
plants.companions: Carrot, Turnip, Leek, Cabbage and Viola.

plants.soil: Any good garden soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in fall to winter in climates with mild winters. Plant seeds in soil or in containers about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Young cornflower seedlings can tolerate freezing temperatures, so seeds can be planted in the autumn where winters are mild.
plants.feeding: Fast growth is encouraged by mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Rice-size cornflower seeds are much loved by goldfinches and other small seed-eating birds.
plants.harvesting: Cornflowers make good cut flowers. Pull up the plants in mid to late summer, when they no longer look attractive.
plants.companions: Wheat, Oats and Crimson Clover. Cornflowers have an upright posture that helps them fit in tight spaces. Intersperse throughout the garden, as cornflower nectar is unusually sweet, and thus a preferred food source for many beneficial insects.
plants.troubleshooting: Cornflowers may be nibbled by rabbits, especially in early spring when other food is scarce.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow cosmos in early spring so the plants can become established before hot weather comes.  Cosmos also can be started indoors in containers and set out when the seedlings have at least five leaves, or purchased as bedding plants. Plant seeds in prepared soil about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties; allow 12 inches (30 cm) between very tall varieties.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings tolerate light frosts, but plants are killed by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Varieties vary greatly in height, colour and flower form. Choose dwarf varieties for tight spaces.  Sulphur cosmos (C. sulphureus) thrives in humid heat.
plants.harvesting: Cosmos make good cut flowers. Pull up the plants and compost them when blooms become few or freezing weather is expected.
plants.companions: Monarda, Cowpeas and Dill. Tall varieties can form a colourful hedge that attracts bees and other pollinators, and mix well with tall herbs like dill and fennel.
plants.troubleshooting: In some climates, cosmos planted in spring may not come into full bloom until days become short in early autumn.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots or sow direct once soil has warmed. Plant out after last frosts.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fornightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: Plants will produce lots of Zucchini over a season.
plants.harvesting: Harvest before the Zucchini get too big. This encourages more Zucchini to grow.
plants.companions: Lovage, Marjoram, Nasturtium and Coriander.

plants.soil: Moist, boggy, acid soil. Ideally, a mixture of sand and acidic organic matter.
plants.position: Grow in prepared beds that can be kept very moist or flooded. Bushes can be grown along the pond’s edge in  sun or partial shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in a water-retentive spot by a pond or stream, above the water line, or in a bog-like bed in a low area.
plants.frostTolerant: Plant in a water-retentive spot by a pond or stream, above the water line, or in a bog-like bed in a low area.
plants.feeding: Mulch with acidic compost to keep soil constantly moist. For the first three years after planting, top-dress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser in spring.
plants.notes: Water only with rainwater. Cranberries will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Begin harvesting three years after planting. Harvest when fruits are red and ripe, but before they have been damaged by hard freezes.
plants.companions: Blueberry. Rhododendrons and azaleas.
plants.troubleshooting: Grows best in acid soil with a pH of 4.0 to 5.5.

plants.soil: Almost any soil type.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards or indoors during winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required while seedlings are still small.
plants.companions: Chives and Mint.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in autumn so that plants can become established before cold weather comes. In cold climates, crimson clover can be planted in early spring instead of autumn. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required.
plants.frostTolerant: Established plantings made in early autumn can tolerate temperatures to -18 C (0F).
plants.feeding: When using crimson clover to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results. Using inoculated seed can also help to grow a vigorous stand.
plants.notes: Crimson clover is one of the most beautiful cover crops you can grow.
plants.harvesting: Take down plants just as the red tops begin to fade, but before the plants produce mature seeds. The easiest method is to slice plants off at the soil line with a sharp hoe. They can then be turned under or composted. Nitrogen nodules left behind in the soil add fertility.
plants.companions: Cornflower. Often planted with other hardy annual flowers including field poppies.
plants.troubleshooting: Crimson clover plants become quite tough as they age, but they seldom regrow when cut off at the soil line.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun in very warm locations only.
plants.sowPlant: Sow when the soil is warm. Cowpeas will not germinate in cold soil.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Cowpeas are semi-tropical plants that crave warm growing conditions.
plants.feeding: When using cowpeas to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Cowpeas are a good nitrogen-fixing summer cover crop for warm climates, where the vegetable seasons are sharply divided by a period of hot weather.
plants.harvesting: Pull up or turn under plants any time after they are about 4 weeks old, but before they develop pods.
plants.companions: Cosmos and Celosia. Often planted with other heat-tolerant summer- blooming annuals.
plants.troubleshooting: Rarely bothered by pests or diseases when grown in warm weather.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots or direct when soil has warmed. Plant out after last frosts.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fornightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: Support plants well so they can climb upwards, even when the cucumbers get large. This also protects the cucumbers from slugs. Occasionally a plant can produce very bitter cucumbers so always test a bit before serving to others!
plants.harvesting: Cut the cucumbers off the plant when they are still quite young, otherwise the skin becomes hard and will need peeling. More cucumbers will then be produced.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Dill, Radish, Marigold, Oregano, Sunflower, Borage, Lettuce, Turnip and Tansy.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil amended with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in individual containers, or sow seeds outdoors 1cm (half an inch) deep and 5cm (2 in) apart. Gradually thin seedlings to proper spacing, and eat your thinnings. Older seedlings are difficult to transplant successfully.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings may need protection from light frosts.
plants.feeding: Drench with a liquid organic fertiliser when plants are 10cm (4 in) tall.
plants.notes: Dill flowers and seeds are used in making breads and pickles.
plants.harvesting: Gather and dry leaves when plants are 25cm (10 in) tall. Use a paper bag to harvest seeds when they change from green to tan and fall freely from their umbels.
plants.companions: Cucumber, Coriander, Cabbage, Cauliflower, Broccoli, Kohlrabi and Tomato.
plants.troubleshooting: Large plants may be blown over by gusty storms. Stake if necessary.

plants.soil: Rich soil with a near neutral Ph.
plants.position: Full sun in cool climates, partial afternoon shade where summers are very hot.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in late winter and set out seedlings, or start with purchased plants. Echinacea often does not bloom reliably until its second year in the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: Echinacea is a hardy perennial that survives very cold winters. Plants become dormant in winter and re-emerge in spring.
plants.feeding: Spread rich compost over the dormant plants each winter.
plants.notes: Echinacea is grown for its beautiful flowers and for the medicinal properties of teas and tinctures made from roots, leaves and flowers.
plants.harvesting: Dig plants up in early autumn to harvest the roots. Small divisions with skimpy root systems can be replanted and allowed to grow for another year.  For enhancing immunity to colds, echinacea tinctures or teas are taken every few hours for several days.
plants.companions: Monarda, Brussels Sprouts, Broccoli and Cauliflower. Echinacea’s purple blossoms contrast well with pink, yellow or orange flowers.
plants.troubleshooting: It is not known whether or not colourful new varieties of Echinacea have medicinal properties that compare to the older strains, which are preferred by butterflies.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.position: Sun preferred but tolerant of some shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil, early plantings can be started undercover in containers.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Can blanch a few plants at a time when they are grown by excluding light from them for a few days. This can make them less bitter.
plants.harvesting: Havest as required by cutting off at base. Will sometimes resprout.
plants.companions: Chicory, Mizuna, Tatsoi and Mustard.

plants.soil: Rich, well draining, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors, or sow in shallow furrows filled with potting soil. Thin seedlings to 30cm (12 in) apart when they are 3 weeks old. Chop the pulled seedlings into salads.
plants.frostTolerant: Seedlings are frost tender, but mature plants tolerate light frost.
plants.feeding: Feed every 3 weeks with a liquid organic fertiliser, and use a rich, biodegradable mulch such as grass clippings.
plants.notes: When the bulb is the size of an egg, surround it with 6 inches of loose mulch to help it plump up and slightly blanch it.
plants.harvesting: Snip tender young leaves as needed in the kitchen. When the bulbs reach 8cm (3 in) in diameter, pull them and store in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Mint.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot where fennel’s tall branches will not cause unwanted shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in late winter and early spring, or plant them outdoors while the weather is still cool.
plants.frostTolerant: A short-lived hardy perennial, fennel will survive winter temperatures to -17C (0F).
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Fennel flowers attract numerous small beneficial insects.
plants.harvesting: Gather fennel fronds as you need them in the kitchen. Fennel can reseed to the point of weediness. Gathering and using the blooms as cut flowers will prevent excessive reseeding.
plants.companions: Cosmos. Cucumber, squash, melons, pumpkin and other low, vine-like plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Prune back fennel plants in mid autumn, before cold weather turns the plants to mush.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow fenugreek from late summer to autumn, whenever a bed will be unused for more than eight weeks.  Direct seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. Thin to 15 cm (6in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Fenugreek cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: When using fenugreek to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: On warm days, fenugreek often emits a fragrance similar to that of maple syrup. It also can be grown as a medicinal herb.
plants.harvesting: Mow plants before turning them under, or pull them up and compost them if you want to use the spot for planting right away.
plants.companions: Buckwheat, Beans and Cowpeas.
plants.troubleshooting: Fenugreek rarely has problems with pests and diseases when grown in home gardens.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in containers in late winter, and set out seedlings in spring. You can also work with purchased seedlings, or lift and move volunteer seedlings found in the garden. Set plants at least 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions. They are easily recognized by their lacy leaves.
plants.frostTolerant: Six-month-old, well rooted plants tolerate winter temperatures to --29C (-20F).  Most individual plants die in their second or third summer, after blooming heavily.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.  When plants emerge after their first winter, mulch with rich compost or topdress with a balanced organic fertiliser.
plants.notes: Frequent cutting of blossoms helps feverfew stay in bloom longer. Depending on climate, feverfew is a biennial or short-lived perennial.  When seeds are started early, it will bloom its first year.
plants.harvesting: To harvest for medicinal use, gather when the plants are in full flower but still holding an abundance of greenery. Medicinal preparations are made from a mixture of dried flowers and leaves.
plants.companions: Mint. Often planted with other tea plants where insects are not wanted. Feverfew repels insects of all nature, so it is a good plant to grow near entryways.
plants.troubleshooting: Feverfew can reseed too well in hospitable spaces, so keep an eye on it for invasive tendencies.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.
plants.position: A sheltered site in full sun. In colder areas grow against a north-facing wall with a frame that makes it possible to install a plastic cover in winter. Figs grown as pillars or espaliered plants can be planted closer - 18in (45cm) apart, and gradually thinned to the best specimens.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in winter when dormant. Where winters are cold, try growing figs in containers that are brought into an cool place in winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Figs easily tolerate periodic frosts, but hard freezes (temperatures below 25°F/-4°C) can lead to death of branches and dormant buds. Cold also can kill plants back to their roots, from which new plants often re-grow.
plants.feeding: Topdress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser each spring, and mulch with  well-rotted organic matter year round. When growing figs in containers, apply liquid tomato feed every 2-3 weeks once fruits appear.
plants.notes: Figs produce fruitlets which flower the following year and produce fruit.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin feels soft and starts to split when gently squeezed. Figs can be dried or made into fig preserves.
plants.companions: Strawberry and Marigold. Figs have large leaves that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: May suffer from red spider mites when grown under cover. Can be controlled using soft soap or by increasing humidity. Net figs to protect from birds. Even with netting, ants sometimes invade the open centers of figs.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.  Figs grow well in large containers.
plants.position: A sheltered site in full sun. In colder areas grow against a north-facing wall with a frame that makes it possible to install a plastic cover in winter. Figs grown as pillars or espaliered plants can be planted closer - 18in (45cm) apart, and gradually thinned to the best specimens.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in winter when dormant. Where winters are cold, try growing figs in containers that are brought into an cool place in winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Figs easily tolerate periodic frosts, but hard freezes (temperatures below 25°F/-4°C) can lead to death of branches and dormant buds. Cold also can kill plants back to their roots, from which new plants often re-grow.
plants.feeding: Topdress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser each spring, and mulch with  well-rotted organic matter year round. When growing figs in containers, apply liquid tomato feed every 2-3 weeks once fruits appear.
plants.notes: Figs produce fruitlets which flower the following year and produce fruit.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin feels soft and starts to split when gently squeezed. Figs can be dried or made into fig preserves.
plants.companions: Strawberry and Marigold. Figs have large leaves that shade out other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: May suffer from red spider mites when grown under cover. Can be controlled using soft soap or by increasing humidity. Net figs to protect from birds. Even with netting, ants sometimes invade the open centers of figs.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in containers for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be, depedning on flower.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests e.g. marigold, calendular etc. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Not usually applicable, although some flowers (eg nasturtium) can be added to salads and others (eg chamomile) make good herbal teas.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in containers for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests e.g. marigold, calendular etc. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Not usually applicable, although some flowers (eg nasturtium) can be added to salads and others (eg chamomile) make good herbal teas.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in containers for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests e.g. marigold, calendular etc. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Not usually applicable, although some flowers (eg nasturtium) can be added to salads and others (eg chamomile) make good herbal teas.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow either in containers for planting out later or direct into the soil depending on type.
plants.frostTolerant: Can be.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Choose flowers that attract beneficial insects (such as hoverflies) or keep away pests e.g. marigold, calendular etc. Many will self-seed next year and some form useful green manures.  You can add a variety of this flower to specify the type and also any specific spacing or planting requirements.
plants.harvesting: Not usually applicable, although some flowers (eg nasturtium) can be added to salads and others (eg chamomile) make good herbal teas.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potasium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges. In spring mulch around the root area with compost and then grass clippings or other organic mulch.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe.
plants.troubleshooting: May need to protect fruit from birds with netting, or just allow for losing some fruit.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: In spring mulch around the root area with compost and then grass clippings or other organic mulch.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. You can add a variety of this tree to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: Best grown from cloves, planted direct into holes, pointed end up in autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Many varieties require a cooler period with temperatures under 10 degrees celcius for the first one or two months.
plants.harvesting: Dig up bulbs when leaves start to turn yellow. Clean them and let them dry out over a few days before storing.
plants.companions: Apricot, Cherry, Parsnip, Peas, Raspberry, Rosemary, Rose, Pear and Peach.
plants.troubleshooting: Watch for winter weeds. Plants left in the ground too long often have loose bulbs that do not store well.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in to retain moisture. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter when dormant to help them establish better.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, or a little before if heavy crop produced.
plants.companions: Marigold, Tomato and Tansy.

plants.soil: Will grow on relatively poor soil as long as it is well drained and compost is dug in. pH of 6.5 to 7 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter when dormant to help them establish better.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well rotted compost annually.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to three buds. Vines can gradually be trained up a support system.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, thinning a few out beforehand to allow others to swell.
plants.companions: Nasturtium, Chives, Garlic and Agastache.

plants.notes: Cover crop, usually planted in fall after others have been harvested.  You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow hairy vetch in autumn so the plants can become established before cold weather comes.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required.
plants.frostTolerant: Many varieties are cold hardy to - 29C (-20F) when well rooted in the garden.
plants.feeding: When using hairy vetch to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Hairy vetch stays small through winter and makes vigorous growth in spring. It is highly recommended as a green manure to grow before tomatoes.
plants.harvesting: Take down plants in spring, 3 weeks before the bed is needed for summer vegetables. The easiest method is to slice plants off at the soil line with a sharp hoe. The cut plants can be allowed to dry into a surface mulch.
plants.companions: Crimson Clover, Faba Bean, Buckwheat and Field Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Hairy vetch can become weedy if allowed to produce mature seeds.

plants.soil: Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil.
plants.position: Sheltered spot in full sun or partial shade. Can be grown as a hedge.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, healthy hazelnut trees will bear twenty years or more.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Self-fertile but pollination is improved by growing in groups with two or more cultivars present. Begins to bear after five years. Healthy hazelnut trees will bear twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the husks begin to turn yellow in early autumn.
plants.companions: Crimson Clover. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: The nuts are much-loved by birds and rodents.

plants.soil: Most herbs can be grown in otherwise poor soil but it should be well drained and free of weeds.
plants.position: Sunny to shady, dependent on herb.
plants.sowPlant: Usually sow direct into soil in late spring. Perennial herbs need lifting and dividing in autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Some types are partially frost tollerant but most are not.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Just a small area will usually provide more than enough, unless growing for decorative reasons or using them to attract beneficial insects to the garden. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required, a few leaves at a time. Can be dried by hanging a bunch in a dry place although some flavour is lost when dried.

plants.soil: Rich, well-drained soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter added.
plants.position: Grow in full sun up a pole support system or on a strong trellis against a long fence or wall. Hops are sensitive to day length, and produce best between 35 and 55 degree latitudes.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in hills in spring after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.
plants.frostTolerant: Hops are hardy perennials that require a period of winter chilling and a growing season of at least 120 days.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Hops need support and plenty of room to sprawl. They will quickly run to the top of a 20-foot vertical trellis. Some root trimming may be required to stop the rhizomes spreading too far. Hops will bear for several years before they should be replaced by younger, more vigorous vines.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when cones feel papery and dry, and leave a yellow powder on your fingers when touched. Dry in a warm spot away from sunlight.
plants.companions: Crimson Clover and Garlic. Clover or other green manures are usually grown between rows of trellised hops.
plants.troubleshooting: Hops may develop mildew if they have inadequate air circulation. Prune vines to improve airflow.

plants.soil: Any moist, fertile soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot with room to spread. The roots often spread several feet in the course of a season.
plants.sowPlant: Set out roots any time that the ground is not frozen, preferably from early spring to early summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Horseradish is a hardy perennial that will survive winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Persistent and long lived, horseradish can become invasive if you accidentally allow pieces of root to be spread around the garden.
plants.harvesting: Dig roots anytime you need them in the kitchen. Keep scrubbed roots in the refrigerator.
plants.companions: Potatoes. Horseradish is usually planted by itself.
plants.troubleshooting: Horseradish seldom has problems with insects or diseases.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter.
plants.position: Full sun to partial shade. Like currants and gooseberries, jostaberries make good bushes for garden boundaries. Unlike gooseberries, they have no thorns.
plants.sowPlant: Plantin winter dormant as this will help the plants establish better. Incorporate plenty of well-rotted organic matter into the planting hole.
plants.frostTolerant: Developed in Germany, jostaberries are extremely cold hardy.
plants.feeding: Top-dress with well-rotted organic matter in spring along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the root zone mulched to retain soil moisture.
plants.notes: Each winter, remove the oldest canes from established plants, and clip of damaged or drooping branches. Healthy jostaberries will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when fruits turn blue-black and are firm. Freezes well.
plants.companions: Gooseberry. Jostaberries grow best when planted together in small groups.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage.

plants.soil: Good soil, firm, preferably with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover for early sowings or during cold weather. Plant out when thumb sized. Can be direct sown as well.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Protect against birds which can damage the young seedlings and overwintering crops. May need supportive stakes during the winter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves gradually from the centre of each plant while they are still tender. New leaves will grow and harvesting can extend from late autumn/fall right through to the next spring.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Thyme, Chamomile, Catnip, Tansy, Buckwheat, Marigold and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.position: Best grown trained against a sunny, sheltered north or west facing wall, or under cover in cooler climates. In warmer climates, kiwis  thrive in full sun provided their roots receive midday shade.
plants.sowPlant: Add plenty of well-rotted organic matter when planting. Plant next to a strong trellis for support.
plants.frostTolerant: Young shoots are vulnerable to frost damage in spring; may require protection.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in late winter, and apply a balanced organic  fertiliser in early spring, just as new growth emerges.
plants.notes: Most kiwi varieties require both male and female plants for successful pollination. One male plant can pollinate up to eight nearby females. Hardy kiwis produce smaller fruits, but are usually self fertile. Healthy kiwi vines will bear for ten years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick before the first frosts and then ripen indoors if the fruit is not completely ripe.
plants.companions: Marjoram, Lemon Balm and Marigold. Kiwi vines are so vigorous that they dominate their space and require a sturdy trellis.
plants.troubleshooting: Will only crop if they are planted in a warm enough position, and may suffer from dieback in cold winters.

plants.soil: Rich soil, light textured with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in early spring either direct into soil or in pots to plant out later.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil but can still benefit from organic compost mixing in before planting.
plants.notes: May require fine mesh or exclusion netting over the warmer months to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves but usually matures quickly enough for this not to be a problem.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from mid summer onwards when roots are up to tennis ball size to prevent the texture becoming 'woody'.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Onion and Onions.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Some strains are propagated only from rooted cuttings.  A mature clump of lavender will grow to 60 cm (24") wide.
plants.frostTolerant: A hardy perennial from the Mediterranean, lavender will survive winter temperatures to -17C / 0F.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed beyond annual topdressing with rich compost in spring.
plants.notes: Try different strains, and even species, to find the right lavender for your climate. Lavender demands excellent drainage, and benefits from dry, airy conditions.
plants.harvesting: Gather spikes of lavender flowers as soon as they open, and dry in small bundles before storing in an airtight container. You can also dry lavender branches for use in recipes, sachets or potpourri.
plants.companions: Rose, Rosemary, Sage, Mint, Agastache, Apple, Cherry, Peach, Pear, Plum and Salsify. Colourful petunias, nasturitums or other annual flowers that contrast with lavender’s gray-green foliage and blue flowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Wait until spring to prune back lavender plants, because the dead stems help shelter the base of the plants from harsh winter weather.

plants.soil: Requires rich, loamy soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in cool weather. Plant out when the soil is warm. Alternatively, sow directly into weed-free ground when the soil is warm.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: In late summer while the weather is still warm, drench plants thoroughly with a water-soluble plant food.
plants.notes: When leeks are almost the size you prefer, blanch them for 2 to 3 weeks by putting a mound of soil, mulch, or a cardboard tube around the base of each stem. Grows best in climates where nights remain cool through summer.
plants.harvesting: Can be left in the ground until required and harvested right through autumn, winter and early spring.
plants.companions: Carrot, Celery, Lovage, Marjoram, Parsnip, Strawberry, Onion and Onions.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. When growing dwarf lemons in containers, avoid potting soils that contain wetting agents.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in spring. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F). ‘Meyer’ lemons can survive modest freezes.
plants.feeding: In spring and summer,  feed with a high nitrogen organic fertiliser. Fertilize more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. The ‘Meyer’ lemon is easier to grow than other types.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Peas, Dill, Yarrow, Thyme, Marigold, Borage and Calendula. Lemons and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. When growing dwarf lemons in containers, avoid potting soils that contain wetting agents.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to move plants when needed. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F). ‘Meyer’ lemons can survive modest freezes.
plants.feeding: In spring and summer,  feed with a high nitrogen organic fertiliser. Fertilize more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. The ‘Meyer’ lemon is easier to grow than other types.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Yarrow, Thyme, Marigold, Borage and Calendula. Lemons and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects and mealybugs.

plants.soil: Rich well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or obtain a rooted piece from a friend or neighbour who has an established clump. Lemon balm can be transplanted from early spring to early summer. You also can start seeds in late winter, and set out the seedlings in spring.  Lemon balm grows into a rounded mound.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial, lemon balm can survive temperatures to -30C (-20F).
plants.feeding: Not generally required.
plants.notes: Lemon balm is very easy to grow. Locate it where leaves can be conveniently picked, crushed and sniffed.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying or steeping into tinctures in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Cosmos, Lettuce, Tomato, Beans, Cabbage, Pumpkin and Squash.
plants.troubleshooting: Control lemon balm’s spread by cutting back flowering stems in late summer.

plants.soil: High quality organic potting soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or obtain a stem tip cutting from a friend and root it in late spring. Lemon verbena cuttings and divisions are best taken when plants are emerging from dormancy in late spring. Lemon verbena is typically grown as a specimen plant in a container at least 30 cm (12in) in diameter. A mature plant, grown in a sunken container, will occupy a space 45 cm (18in) square if well staked but still expect lanky growth that responds well to monthly trimming.
plants.frostTolerant: Lemon verbena is a tender perennial; its roots should not be allowed to freeze. In most climates, it is best grown in a container that can be kept in a cool (but not freezing) place through winter, the plant’s dormant season.
plants.feeding: Fertilise with an organic water soluble fertiliser every two weeks from spring to fall, when the plant is actively growing in a container. Feeding is not generally needed for plants grown in beds in semi-tropical climates.
plants.notes: Lemon verbena is the most "lemony" of all lemon foliage herbs. Locate it where leaves can be conveniently picked, crushed and sniffed.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as desired. Smelling lemon verbena is a special delight of summer best captured in teas. Dry perfect leaves in small bunches, and store them in airtight containers.  This is a fragrance herb to delight your sense of smell and can be used in flower arrangements.
plants.companions: Lemon grass, Lavender and Stevia. Use this 90 cm (3ft) tall herb as a movable accent in your summer herb garden.
plants.troubleshooting: Repot plants in spring, gradually moving to slightly larger pots. In summer, sink the pot into the ground to protect it from overheating and drying out on hot days.

plants.soil: Most soil types but best if it's moisture retentive with some dug in compost.
plants.position: Semi-shade, a cool sunny spot or inter-planted between other crops.
plants.sowPlant: Early planting can be done under cover in containers. Continue sowing outside every few weeks for a continous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Early sowings are easily attacked by slugs and snails, so may be best in containers. Thin out to give plenty of room for each plant to grow. In hot summer conditions lettuce can bolt (produce flower heads) and becomes tough and a little bitter.
plants.harvesting: When the heart of the lettuce feels firm pull the whole plant up and cut off the roots. Harvest in the morning when the leaves are cool and full of moisture.
plants.companions: Yarrow, Beans, Carrot, Coreopsis, Cucumber, Lovage, Marjoram, Marigold, Onion, Onions, Parsnip, Peas, Radish, Strawberry, Zinnia, Mint, Agastache, Lemon Balm and Poached Egg Plant.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil also under cover for an earlier sowing in mid-late winter. Generally best grown during the cooler months in areas with a hot summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates extreme cold when well rooted.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in small batches as required.
