plants.companions: Carrot, Turnip, Leek, Cabbage and Viola.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds that threaten to overtake the small plants.

plants.soil: Most soil types but best if it's moisture retentive with some dug in compost.
plants.position: Semi-shade, a cool sunny spot or inter-planted between other crops.
plants.sowPlant: Early planting can be done under cover in containers. Continue sowing outside every few weeks for a continous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates light frost.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Early sowings are easily attacked by slugs and snails, so may be best in containers. Thin out to give plenty of room for each plant to grow. In hot summer conditions lettuce can bolt (produce flower heads) and becomes tough and a little bitter.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves as required over a number of weeks.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Dill, Chives, Carrot, Cabbage, Onion, Onions, Spring Onion, Strawberry, Radish and Spinach.
plants.troubleshooting: Shallow lettuce roots need constant moisture. Do not allow the soil to dry out.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best but will grow in most locations.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil from autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop to grow and will often fit between other plants while they are still small.
plants.harvesting: Cut leaves as required.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter.
plants.position: Full sun. In winter, plants may need to be protected or taken indoors in cold climates.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in spring. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Fertilize more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Dill, Yarrow, Thyme, Marigold, Borage, Cosmos and Calendula. Limes and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter.
plants.position: Full sun. In winter, plants may need to be protected or taken indoors in cold climates.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to move plants when needed. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Fertilize more if you see yellowing leaves.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Yarrow, Thyme, Marigold, Borage and Calendula. Limes and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a sturdy frame of wires against a wall or on posts. Plant with the crown 8cm (3") below soil level and apply a thick mulch. Cut the stems to a strong bud
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: After harvesting, cut 2 year old branches to ground level. Healthy loganberries will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick when ripe. Loganberries do not ripen all at once, and should be picked weekly through the harvest season.
plants.companions: Leek, Garlic, Onions and Chives. It is best to keep the area around a mound of loganberries mowed to make picking easier.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage. Plant a thornless variety to take the pain out of harvesting.

plants.soil: Rich soil that retains moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun in cool climates; partial shade where summers are very hot.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Lovage will reach its mature size in about three years.  One plant is usually sufficient, but it’s a good idea to start a new plant every few years.  At maturity, lovage will need a 90 cm (3ft) square space. It is a very large herb. Because of its 1.5 meter (5ft) height, lovage is best located at the edge or rear of the garden.
plants.frostTolerant: Lovage is a hardy perennial that survives winter even in very cold climates.
plants.feeding: Topdress the soil around the dormant plant with rich compost each winter.
plants.notes: Tender young growth has the best flavour. In summer, consider pruning plants back to force them to push out a flush of new leaves.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen for their celery flavor. Freeze extra leaves by covering chopped lovage leaves with water in ice cube trays.
plants.companions: Peas, Pumpkin, Squash, Monarda, Potatoes, Capsicum and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Remove flowers should lovage produce too many unwanted seedlings. Or, gather lovage seeds and use them in cooking as a substitute for celery seeds.

plants.soil: Most soil types.
plants.sowPlant: Start snow peas off under cover in a length of old guttering as this makes it easy to tip them into their final planting site. Or sow directly into the soil. Sow in batches for a continuous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Support plants with a strong row or wigwam structure over which netting can be tied for them to climb up. Alternatively, use twiggy sticks pushed into the ground near each plant.
plants.harvesting: Pick whole pods regularly while still young and not stringy.
plants.companions: Chives, Mint, Alyssum, Carrot, Cucumber, Radish and Turnip.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow marigolds in spring, or set them out as bedding plants. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties; allow 12 inches (30 cm) between very tall varieties.
plants.frostTolerant: None.  Marigold cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: The 'Gem' marigolds (T. tenufolia) bear edible blossoms with a spicy, citrus flavor.
plants.harvesting: Marigolds make good short-stemmed cut flowers for small bouquets. Don't rush to pull up plants that stop blooming but look healthy, because they will probably come back into bloom.
plants.companions: Tomato, Cabbage, Pumpkin, Squash, Honeydew, Cauliflower, Kale, Potatoes, Blackcurrant, Redcurrant and White currant. Dwarf types make good edging plants that may deter rabbits. Some varieties are known for their ability to starve out rootknot nematodes when planted as a mass.
plants.troubleshooting: Marigolds have few problems with pests or diseases.  Tall varieties may need staking to keep them upright.

plants.soil: Well-drained but moist soil preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Usually sow direct into soil in mid spring or raise in pots to plant out.
plants.frostTolerant: Some types are partially frost tolerant but most are not.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Pick leaves as required.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required, a few leaves at a time. Can be dried by hanging a bunch in a dry place although some flavour is lost when dried.
plants.companions: Oregano, Thyme, Peas, Kiwi, Pumpkin, Squash, Tatsoi, Plum, Zucchini and Lettuce.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots or sow directly when the soil has warmed. Plant out after last frosts.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fornightly liquid feed from mid summer.
plants.notes: Basically the same as Zucchini but left longer to produce fewer larger fruit. Seeds are removed before eating.
plants.harvesting: Harvest before the fruit get too big. This encourages more fruit to grow.
plants.companions: Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Deep, fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Stake trees for the first 3-4 years. Healthy medlar trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Can harvest in autumn before the fruits are fully ripe or else leave until they ripen if there is no danger of frost. Fruit must first be ‘bletted’ before eating raw.  To do this, leave them in a cool place until they turn dark red-brown and become soft.
plants.troubleshooting: Medlars are naturally astringent, like persimmons.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Best direct sown once soil has warmed and there is no longer a risk of frost. If your growing season is short they can be started inside in pots to get a head start.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Keep moist by watering regularly. Pinch out the growing tip once the plant has made three leaves and do the same to side shoots as they appear.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when cracks form around the blossom and stem ends of the fruit
plants.companions: Marigold, Sweetcorn, Nasturtium and Oregano.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds early and then mulch to avoid trampling the vines after fruits have set.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil where mint's wandering tendencies can be kept in check.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Mint is also easy to root from stem tip cuttings stuck into moist potting soil. Some strains are propagated only from cuttings rather than seeds.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy even in cold climates. If desired, small plants can be potted up in autumn and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Spearmint or peppermint are the most versatile strain for cooking.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Broccoli, Kohlrabi, Cauliflower and Persimmon.
plants.troubleshooting: Often becomes invasive. If possible, grow near paths, driveways, or other hard surfaces, or in containers buried halfway in the ground.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly into soil. Can
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: May need to protect under mesh or exclusion netting to prevent problems with flea beetle and caterpillars. Keep soil moist in dry weather to prevent bolting (running to seed.)
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Mustard, Kale, Endive, Tatsoi, Dill, Mint and Nasturtium.

plants.soil: Rich soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Morning sun with partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased plants, set out in spring. Many selected cultivars are resistant to powdery mildew, a common problem with this species.  30 cm (12in) each way is a good spacing for an initial planting of 3 plants. Monarda is a slight spreader, but not invasive like mint. Over time, a happy plant will form a mount 120 cm (4ft) high and wide.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial which can survive temperatures to -20F (-30C).
plants.feeding: Topdress the dormant plants with good compost in winter.
plants.notes: Pastel flower colours look especially cooling in partial shade. Leaves are excellent for tea.
plants.harvesting: Harvest stems to dry for tea in early summer, before the plants bloom. The plants will regrow after cutting, then bloom.
plants.companions: Cosmos, Lovage, Sweetcorn, Pumpkin, Squash, Endive, Tatsoi, Mizuna and Lettuce. Often planted with salad greens and other shade-tolerant plants.
plants.troubleshooting: Moving clumps every few years may help limit problems with powdery mildew.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in autumn to use mustard as a short-term autumn green manure. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2 in) deep. Thin to 15 cm (6in) apart in all directions. Can be sown all year round to be used as sprouts.
plants.frostTolerant: Mustard is cool-season annual that can tolerate light frosts but not hard freezes.
plants.feeding: None generally needed, because mustard is customarily used as a late summer/autumn cover crop to take up nitrogen left in the soil by sweet corn or other vegetables.
plants.notes: You can gather individual leaves for cooking, which taste best after the first frost has passed. Mustard residue suppresses soil-borne nematodes, so it is an excellent green manure to grow before potatoes. Mustard can also be grown for sprouts all year indoors and during the warmer months outdoors.
plants.harvesting: Chop down the green foliage with a hoe and turn it under just before hard freezes are expected. The mustard roots and foliage will rot during the winter months.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Cauliflower, Radish, Brussels Sprouts and Turnip. Mustard does an excellent job of suppressing weeds when grown in a solid mass.
plants.troubleshooting: Irrigation is often needed to get a good stand if autumn is dry.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Soaking seeds in water overnight prior to planting may speed germination, but nasturtium seeds sprout best when the soil is warm. Poke seeds into the soil about 1 inch (3 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Nasturtiums may survive very light frosts, but they are easily damaged by freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Nasturtium blossoms, leaves and immature green seed pods are edible.
plants.harvesting: Gather nasturtium blossoms in the morning, when they are plumped up with moisture. Snip away the base of each blossom, which may taste bitter.
plants.companions: Cucumber, Honeydew, Gourd, Beans, Tomato, Apple, Radish, Broccoli and Cabbage. Nasturtiums sprawl out over the ground, so they suppress weeds and shade the soil when grown near tall plants like sweet corn, tomatoes or sunflowers.
plants.troubleshooting: Nasturtium will often reseed itself in hospitable sites.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Nectarines need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young nectarine  trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring , along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under nectarines mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Nectarines are self-fertile, but produce better when more than one tree is grown.  Prune nectarines hard in winter. Healthy nectarine trees will bear for twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick when the colour has fully developed and the flesh feels soft near the stalk. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Garlic and Tansy. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keep plant dry under cover to avoid peach leaf curl. In humid climates, nectarines often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality nectarines.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Nectarines need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young nectarine  trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring , along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under nectarines mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Nectarines are self-fertile, but produce better when more than one tree is grown.  Prune nectarines hard in winter. Healthy nectarine trees will bear for twenty years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick when the colour has fully developed and the flesh feels soft near the stalk. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Garlic and Tansy. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keep plant dry under cover to avoid peach leaf curl. In humid climates, nectarines often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality nectarines.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer to grow as a green manure that forms its own mulch when it is winterkilled, or when using oats as a companion crop for slower-growing legumes. Oats also can be grown as a spring green manure to increase soil organic matter.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm (8in) apart when growing oats with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Oats are a cool-weather crop that can tolerate light frosts but is usually killed by temperatures below-15C (5F).
plants.feeding: None generally needed, especially when oats are grown with nitrogen-fixing green manures such as winter peas, winter beans or hairy vetch.
plants.notes: Oats are an ideal late summer green manure if your winters are cold enough to kill it; the dead residue forms its own winter mulch, which is usually well rotted by spring.
plants.harvesting: Young oats can be turned under anytime. In mild winter climates, oats should be mowed and tilled before seedheads appear in late spring.
plants.companions: Cornflower, Field Peas and Wheat.
plants.troubleshooting: Rotting oat foliage has herbicidal properties, in that it inhibits germination of weed seeds. Always wait 3 weeks before sowing seeds into soil where oats have been turned under.

plants.soil: Rich, well draining, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Soak seeds in water overnight before planting them 2cm (1 in) deep and 15cm (6 in) apart in warm soil after last frosts. Thin to proper spacing after two weeks.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Requires warm temperatures to give a good yield. Wear gloves if handling the plants when wet gives you an allergic reaction.
plants.harvesting: Pick pods young while they are still small.
plants.companions: Honeydew, Cucumber, Capsicum and Eggplant.
plants.troubleshooting: Ants sometimes damage okra blossoms.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Onions can be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late winter before planting out in spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Japanese variety onion sets can be used to give an early harvest.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days. Not recommended in the tropics.
plants.companions: Tomato, Carrot, Beetroot, Chamomile, Cauliflower, Broccoli and Cabbage.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Onions can be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late summer before planting out autumn to winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Japanese variety onion sets can be used to give an early harvest. Onion sets are also the better choice for heavier or wetter soils.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days. Not recommended in the tropics.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Cabbage, Carrot and Silver Beet.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased bulblets, plant out in autumn or winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Multiplying onions and other perennial strains are typically hardy to -15C (-26F) when given a protective winter mulch.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting a new bed.
plants.notes: Most perennial onions grow vigorously in early spring and die back in midsummer. These interesting yet variable plants resemble shallots more than other onions.
plants.harvesting: Harvest bulblets from topsetting onions and use them as pearl onions in the kitchen. When plants die back, cured roots often yield a small shallot. In spring or autumn, you can cut off small divisions for use as spring onions. Not recommended in the tropics.
plants.companions: Potatoes, Strawberry, Tomato, Carrot, Lettuce and Thyme. Often planted with Garlic and shallots.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, grow in raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Onions can be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late summer before planting out autumn to winter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required, though overwintered sets can be given a liquid feed in spring.
plants.notes: Japanese variety onion sets can be used to give an early harvest.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days. Not recommended in the tropics.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Cabbage, Carrot and Silver Beet.
plants.troubleshooting: Weed early and often to keep onions growing strong. Seedlings are less likely to bolt (produce flowers) compared to bulb onions grown from sets.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. Oranges grafted onto a dwarfing rootstock may be grown in containers.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in spring. Good drainage is essential.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer,  feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Yellowing leaves indicate a need for more nitrogen.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. Very sweet oranges need a long season of warm weather, but kumquats, calamondin oranges and satsumas fruit well in marginal areas or when grown in containers.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Lavender and Garlic. Oranges and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Warm, moist soil, well-enriched with organic matter. Oranges grafted onto a dwarfing rootstock may be grown in containers.
plants.sowPlant: Set out new plants in spring. Grow in containers of rich compost to keep plants compact and to make it easy to move plants. Good drainage is essential. Start small plants in containers at least 30cm (1ft) wide and pot them up a size yearly until they reach mature size.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Grow at temperatures above 7°C (45°F).
plants.feeding: In spring and summer,  feed with a balanced organic fertiliser. Yellowing leaves indicate a need for more nitrogen.
plants.notes: Prune in spring or summer to shape plants, and watch for thorns. Very sweet oranges need a long season of warm weather, but kumquats, calamondin oranges and satsumas fruit well in marginal areas or when grown in containers.
plants.harvesting: Pick when richly coloured and fully ripe. Picking can continue for several weeks as fruits do not ripen all at once.
plants.companions: Lavender and Garlic. Oranges and other citrus are heavy feeders that resent close company.
plants.troubleshooting: Soft soap sprays can help against scale insects.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil in an easily accessible site.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out at about the time of your last frost. Some strains are propagated only from cuttings. Authentic Greek oregano can be grown from seeds or plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy in cold climates provided plant is well-rooted and mulched. If desired, small plants can be potted up in autumn and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Some strains are grown for their pretty pink flowers. Oregano often spreads in hospitable spots. Moderately invasive.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in early summer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Strawberry, Capsicum, Tomato, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, Kohlrabi, Turnip, Cabbage and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Control oregano's spread by cutting back flowering stems when their colours fade.

plants.notes: Other plants requiring up to 50cm (20in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

Other plants requiring up to 25cm (10in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.
Other perennial plants. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

Other plants requiring up to 10cm (4in) spacing. Use this category for plants that aren't available in the main list. You can add a variety of this plant to label what it is and specify spacing or planting times.

plants.soil: Rich, moist soil, firm with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into final growing position. Pak Choi can also be started in containers.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required if good soil.
plants.notes: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants. Keep soil moist in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when plants reach a suitable size.
plants.companions: Marigold, Nasturtium, Rhubarb, Sage, Dill, Chamomile, Coriander and Lettuce.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds direct or in containers and keep moist. Parsley germinates slowly. Or, start with young purchased plants. Take care not to disturb the roots when transplanting parsley.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food monthly.
plants.notes: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food monthly.
plants.harvesting: Try both curled and flat-leafed or Italian parsley, which has stronger flavour. Plants that survive winter will bloom first thing in spring.
plants.companions: Asparagus, Sweetcorn and Tomato.

plants.soil: Light, deep, well-drained soil which has not had compost or manure added recently (to avoid forked roots forming.)
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil when it has warmed up from mid spring onwards. Takes a couple of weeks to germinate.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Thin out when the seedlings are large enough to handle if they are too close. Weed carefully during early stages.
plants.harvesting: Use a garden fork to loosen soil along outside of the planting before pulling roots. Can be left in the soil through winter in many areas.
plants.companions: Peas, Potatoes, Radish, Garlic, Onion, Onions and Beans.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Peaches need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young peach trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring, along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under peaches mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Peaches may need to be hand-pollinated when grown in sheltered spots. Prune peaches hard in late winter. Healthy peach trees will bear for fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick peaches when the colour has fully developed and the flesh gives slightly when squeezed. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Garlic. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping peach trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl. In humid climates, peaches often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality peaches.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive but well-drained. Avoid planting in heavy soils.
plants.position: Peaches need full sun to limit disease and produce high quality fruit.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young peach trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Top-dress generously with well-rotted organic matter in spring, along with a balanced organic fertiliser. Keep the area under peaches mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Peaches may need to be hand-pollinated when grown in sheltered spots. Prune peaches hard in late winter. Healthy peach trees will bear for fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Pick peaches when the colour has fully developed and the flesh gives slightly when squeezed. The fruit should pull away easily from the tree.
plants.companions: Tansy. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Keeping peach trees dry under cover or under plastic sheeting can help prevent peach leaf curl. In humid climates, peaches often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality peaches.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Benefits from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring, topped by a deep mulch of wood chips or sawdust year round.
plants.notes: Prune in winter to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. Most varieties need at  least one other pear tree in the neighbourhood to get good  pollination. Healthy pear trees will bear for decades.
plants.harvesting: Harvest pears before they fully ripen, and ripen under cool indoor temperatures.
plants.companions: Garlic and Tansy. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Very cool or hot weather can affect ripening, and leaving fruits on the tree for too long can cause them to rot from the inside out. Scab and other fungal diseases can cause problems for pears. Prune to  improve airflow and avoid feeding with too much nitrogen.Fire blight can be controlled by trimming off and destroying affected areas as soon as possible. This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
