This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.position: Moist, well-drained soil with a near-neutral pH.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Benefits from a mulch of well-rotted organic matter in spring, topped by a deep mulch of wood chips or sawdust year round.
plants.notes: Prune in winter to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required. Most varieties need at  least one other pear tree in the neighbourhood to get good  pollination. Healthy pear trees will bear for decades. Large pears can require up to 10m spacing.  This can be less depending on variety and pruning method.
plants.harvesting: Harvest pears before they fully ripen, and ripen under cool indoor temperatures.
plants.companions: Garlic and Tansy. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Very cool or hot weather can affect ripening, and leaving fruits on the tree for too long can cause them to rot from the inside out. Scab and other fungal diseases can cause problems for pears. Prune to  improve airflow and avoid feeding with too much nitrogen.Fire blight can be controlled by trimming off and destroying affected areas as soon as possible. This bacterial disease strikes suddenly in cool, damp weather, and causes branches to look like they have been burned by fire. Codling moths can destroy crops of young fruits; trichogramma wasps can be used to control them, but insects are generally less of a problem with pears than with other tree fruits.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start peas off under cover in a length of old guttering as this makes it easy to tip them into their final planting site. Or sow directly into the soil. Sow in batches for a continuous supply.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required, although a mulch of compost, grass clippings or other organic matter can help on poor soils.
plants.notes: Support plants with a strong row or wigwam structure over which netting can be tied for them to climb up. Alternatively, use twiggy sticks pushed into the ground near each plant.
plants.harvesting: Best picked just before eating, often sweet enough to enjoy raw.
plants.companions: Beans, Beetroot, Brussels Sprouts, Carrot, Cauliflower, Celery, Cucumber, Lettuce, Lovage, Marjoram, Parsnip, Potatoes, Sage, Pumpkin, Squash and Sweetcorn.
plants.troubleshooting: Mature plants usually stop producing and die back in hot summer weather.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.position: Sheltered sunny position or under cover.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in later winter or early spring. Transfer to bigger pots as required. If planting out then do so when soil has warmed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed once the plant is a reasonable size.
plants.notes: Sometimes require supports if the capsicums are large.
plants.harvesting: Harvest capsicum green when they have grown to a good size or wait for them to ripen to yellow, orange or red if preferred.
plants.companions: Carrot, Onion, Onions, Tomato and Oregano.

plants.soil: Deep, fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Stake trees for the first 3-4 years.
plants.harvesting: Harvesting depends on variety, non astringent persimmons can be eaten while still firm but astringent varieties need to be alowed to ripen until soft.
plants.companions: Mint.
plants.troubleshooting: Cover trees with netting to prevent birds from destroying the fruit.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in spring onwards as a green manure.  Make sure seed is well covered, because phacelia seeds need darkness to germinate.
plants.frostTolerant: Phacelia will survive mild frosts to overwinter and bloom in spring.
plants.feeding: None generally required.
plants.notes: Phacelia is a wonderful plant for attracting bees and other beneficial insects, particularly useful in early spring if it has overwintered as it is an early pollen source for bees coming out of hibernation.
plants.harvesting: For maximum benefit as a green manure dig in when quite small.  Otherwise leave plants to grow up to 1m (3 ft) tall as the flowers attract beneficial insects.
plants.companions: Cucumber, Tomato, Kale and Broccoli.
plants.troubleshooting: Although native to California in the US phacelia harbours damaging lygus bugs, so it is rarely grown there.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive clay or loam.
plants.position: Sunny spot, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young plum trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Feed with a mulch of high nitrogen fertiliser in spring. Keep plum trees mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Some varieties are self-fertile; otherwise at least one other plum flowering at the same time will be required for pollination. Prune in late winter, before buds begin to swell.  Healthy plum trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit feels soft when gently squeezed. As fruit ripens, some fruits will fall from the tree, and others can easily be shaken onto cloths spread on the ground.
plants.companions: Garlic, Tansy, Marjoram, Lovage and Dill. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Plums can be affected by silverleaf disease – prune in dry weather in summer to help avoid infection. In humid climates, plums often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality plums.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive clay or loam.
plants.position: Sunny spot, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young plum trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Feed with a mulch of high nitrogen fertiliser in spring. Keep plum trees mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Some varieties are self-fertile; otherwise at least one other plum flowering at the same time will be required for pollination. Prune in late winter, before buds begin to swell.  Healthy plum trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit feels soft when gently squeezed. As fruit ripens, some fruits will fall from the tree, and others can easily be shaken onto cloths spread on the ground.
plants.companions: Garlic, Tansy, Marjoram, Lovage and Dill. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Plums can be affected by silverleaf disease – prune in dry weather in summer to help avoid infection. In humid climates, plums often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality plums.

plants.soil: Moisture-retentive clay or loam.
plants.position: Sunny spot, with excellent air circulation.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests. Young plum trees are at high risk for damage from insects that bore into the main trunk.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but it is important to choose  varieties known to grow well in your area to reduce risk of losing blooms to spring freezes.
plants.feeding: Feed with a mulch of high nitrogen fertiliser in spring. Keep plum trees mulched with wood chips or sawdust.
plants.notes: Some varieties are self-fertile; otherwise at least one other plum flowering at the same time will be required for pollination. Prune in late winter, before buds begin to swell.  Healthy plum trees will bear for ten to fifteen years or more.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the fruit feels soft when gently squeezed. As fruit ripens, some fruits will fall from the tree, and others can easily be shaken onto cloths spread on the ground.
plants.companions: Garlic, Tansy, Marjoram, Lovage and Dill. Corridors within the orchard that are planted with clovers and other legumes contribute to soil fertility and attract pollinators.
plants.troubleshooting: Plums can be affected by silverleaf disease – prune in dry weather in summer to help avoid infection. In humid climates, plums often develop problems with fungal diseases such as brown rot. Preventive sprays with organic fungicides are often needed to grow good quality plums.

plants.soil: Any fertile soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Sow poached egg plant in early spring, while the soil is cool. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 2 inches (5 cm) apart and one-half inch (1 cm) deep. Thin to 4 inches (10 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: Young seedlings can tolerate light frost, but the plants are easily damaged by hard frosts.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Pull up old plants to limit reseeding. Where summers are hot, plants may expire after blooming heavily in spring.
plants.harvesting: The delicate flowers and fragrance of poached egg plant always bring cheer to the garden. Pull up and compost plants when they stop blooming heavily.
plants.companions: Tomato, Lettuce and Sweetcorn. This low-growing plant spreads into a mat of green foliage covered with flowers. Grow along pathways or edges of beds, or near tall plants like sweet corn or tomatoes.
plants.troubleshooting: Poached egg plant has few problems with pests or diseases, but may fail when subjected to extreme humid heat.

plants.soil: Any reasonable moisture-retentive but well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Set out plants in winter when dormant.
plants.frostTolerant: Pomegranates easily tolerate periodic frosts.
plants.feeding: Topdress the root zone with a balanced organic fertiliser each spring, and mulch with  well-rotted organic matter year round.
plants.notes: Pomegranate fruit split when ripe so pay close attention to them in wet weather and pick them to prevent them spoiling.
plants.harvesting: Fruits are ripe when the skin becomes dull, ripe fruits also have a habit of splitting open.
plants.companions: Coreopsis, Lavender, Cosmos, Zinnia and Nasturtium.
plants.troubleshooting: Net to prevent bird damage.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil with plenty of compost dug in is best but will grow in most positions.
plants.sowPlant: Grow from seed potatoes. Start them by leaving on cardboard or eggboxes in a light position until they have produced short green sprouts. Plant out in early to mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: As shoots appear, draw soil over them if there is still a possibility of frost. Once the shoots are hand height, earth them up by drawing more soil around them leaving the top of the shoots still showing to keep the actual potatoes covered. If any potatoes get exposed to light and turn green they should not be eaten. Make sure potatoes are kept watered in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: The earliest potatoes can be harvested when the plants begin to flower. Once the foliage has wilted harvest the main crop within a couple of weeks, digging in from the side to avoid damaging the tubers.
plants.companions: Horseradish, Beans, Alyssum, Marigold, Eggplant and Cabbage.

plants.soil: Rich, deep soil with plenty of compost dug in is best but will grow in most positions.
plants.sowPlant: Grow from seed potatoes. Plant out in early to mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: As shoots appear, draw soil over them if there is still a possibility of frost. Once the shoots are hand height, earth them up by drawing more soil around them leaving the top of the shoots still showing to keep the actual potatoes covered. If any potatoes get exposed to light and turn green they should not be eaten. Make sure potatoes are kept watered in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Once the foliage has wilted harvest the main crop within a couple of weeks, digging in from the side to avoid damaging the tubers.
plants.companions: Horseradish, Beans, Alyssum, Marigold, Eggplant, Cabbage and Catnip.

plants.latinName: Cucurbita pepo,  C. moschata, C. maxima
plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots. Transfer to larger pots if necessary. Plant out when no danger of frost.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fortnightly liquid feed from mid summer onwards.
plants.notes: Towards the end of the summer raise the pumpkins off the ground by putting a piece of wood or similar under them to prevent rotting. Water roots generously in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: When the plant starts to die cut off the pumpkins leaving part of the stalk attached. Allow the skin to harden in the sun for a few days if wanting to store them in a frost-free place.
plants.companions: Beans, Cabbage, Cauliflower, Kohlrabi, Broccoli, Eggplant, Horseradish, Marigold, Peas, Nasturtium, Parsnip, Radish and Lemon Balm.

plants.soil: Almost any soil with good drainage.
plants.position: Sunny for spring and autumn sowings, light-shade for summer sowings.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the ground
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: A really good crop for growing inbetween others, especially as it grows to maturity so quickly.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as soon as the root has developped to a usable size, while taste and texture are still good.
plants.companions: Spinach, Pumpkin and Collards. Often planted with peas, nasturtium or lettuce.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: After harvesting cut the canes down to ground level, leaving any new shoots.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe. Can protect with netting if birds are eating them but make sure that the plant doesn't grow through the netting making it difficult to remove.
plants.companions: Blackberry, Garlic and Rye.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in to retain moisture. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, will freeze well.
plants.companions: Marigold.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Grown from a crown (root) which can be split from a healthy plant and planted out, usually in winter. Can also be purchased as seedlings during warmer months.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but leaves and shoots die back.
plants.feeding: Mulch with extra compost each year after the leaves have died down.
plants.notes: Early sweet stems can be produced by forcing and blanching the rhubarb: in mid winter to early spring add dry material such as leaves or straw and cover with a deep container or bucket to exlude light for about one month.
plants.harvesting: Do not harvest during the first year of growth. After this, pull a few of the thicker sticks when long enough. Stop harvesting in early summer and allow plants to grow freely for the rest of the season.
plants.companions: Strawberry.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.position: Sun or partial shade. A cooler, shady position in summer.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the soil from early spring onwards or under cover for an earlier sowing in mid-late winter. Can also sow in early autumn for a winter crop.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, tolerates mild frosts.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: An easy salad crop that doubles as a cooked green. Flower buds are also edible. Hot weather causes leaves to become very strongly flavored.
plants.harvesting: Harvest in small batches as required. Once it flowers the leaves become tougher and hotter in taste.
plants.companions: Beans, Dill, Mint, Nasturtium and Thyme.
plants.troubleshooting: Flea beetles sometimes make small holes in leaves.

plants.soil: Well drained soil with compost dug in.
plants.position: Sun preferred but will grow in most positions.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, keeping in mind that growth habit varies with variety. Trailing rosemary for walls, or dwarf varieties for containers, are propagated by rooting stem cuttings rather than from seeds. Wild Mediterranean rosemary can be grown from seeds or plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Where winters are mild, rosemary can grow into huge, shrub-like plants.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering. Trailing rosemary is great cascading over a wall.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying from spring to late summer.
plants.companions: Sage, Tarragon and Lavender.

plants.soil: Any soil, including poorly drained sites.
plants.sowPlant: Walk over the planted site to firm the seeds into the ground, and then water to promote fast germination. Although customarily grown in autumn, annual rye can be used as a fast-growing green manure in all but the hottest summer months.   Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 1 inch (2 cm) apart and one-fourth inch (.5 cm) deep.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardiness varies with variety. Some strains are killed by temperatures around -23 C (-10F), while especially hardy varieties can tolerate more extreme cold.
plants.feeding: When using annual rye to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Mature annual rye plants can be difficult to dig out. Where annual rye is not killed by winter weather, mow down the plants and turn under the residue when the plants are young.
plants.harvesting: In a home garden, annual rye cover crops are easiest to manage if they are mowed every few weeks. The clippings make excellent mulch.
plants.companions: Raspberry. Annual rye forms a very thick stand, and is normally grown alone to choke out weeds and boost organic matter, especially in new gardening sites.
plants.troubleshooting: Annual rye has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in early autumn, though cereal rye will still germinate in mid autumn, after the soil has lost its warmth. Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm (8in) apart when growing cereal rye with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Most varieties of cereal rye can survive temperatures to -29C (-20F) if the plants are well rooted before the ground freezes.
plants.feeding: When using cereal rye to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase organic matter and break up dense subsoil.  Can be sown later in the autumn than other green manures.
plants.harvesting: Mow down plants in spring, before they develop seeds. Or, gather the immature seed tops and dry them for arrangements, and then pull up the plants. They can be used as mulch or composted.
plants.companions: Hairy vetch, winter peas, winter beans. In spring, widely spaced rye plants can serve as trellises for garden peas.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors in later winter to early spring. Plants started from seed may not bloom their first year.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy through mild frosts. In colder areas, small plants can be potted up in fall and grown through winter indoors.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: One-year-old plants nursed through winter produce beautiful blue flowers. Sage grown in containers can be kept in a cold garage through winter.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying from spring to autumn.
plants.companions: Tomato, Broccoli, Cabbage, Kohlrabi, Cauliflower, Carrot, Rosemary and Lavender.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants are often short-lived, so root a few stem cuttings each spring to always have vigorous young plants.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best but will grow in most locations.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil from early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water well in dry periods.
plants.harvesting: Roots can be lifted throughout winter.
plants.companions: Scorzonera.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Salvia needs warm soil to grow well, so wait until the last frost has passed to set out plants. Start seeds indoors in individual containers or set out purchased plants. Space plants 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Salvia cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Pinching off the first bloom will encourage plants to grow into lush bushes bearing numerous flower spikes.
plants.harvesting: Gather stems to use in cut arrangements. Snip off old flowers every few weeks to keep plants in bloom all summer.
plants.companions: Lavender and Catnip. Mixes well with upright flowers or herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Salvia has few problems with pests or diseases.  Newer named varieties are vigorous and very heavy blooming.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best but will grow in most locations.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil from early spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water well in dry periods.
plants.harvesting: Roots can be lifted throughout winter.
plants.companions: Salsify.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil with compost dug in. In clay soil, use raised beds or rows.
plants.sowPlant: Easiest to sow as sets (tiny bulbs) which are planted direct into the soil from early winter onwards. Can also be grown from seed in which case start in pots under cover in late winter before planting out mid spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not normally required.
plants.notes: Used instead of onions for an earlier crop and concentrated flavour. Not recommended for growing in the tropics.
plants.harvesting: Harvest from mid summer as soon as they reach a reasonable size. If storing them, wait until the tops start to die down and dry for about 10 days.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Chamomile, Cabbage, Carrot, Silver Beet, Strawberry and Tomato.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in spring. Established plants can be dug and moved anytime as long as soil is kept packed around the roots. Start seeds indoors in individual containers, set out purchased plants, or direct-sow into warm soil.  Space plants 30cm (12 in) apart in all directions. Few gardeners need more than a few of these productive plants.
plants.frostTolerant: When established, this hardy perennial can tolerate winter temperatures to -29C (-20F).
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.  Each spring, mulch around the plant with rich compost.
plants.notes: Pinch off blossom spikes to keep plants from reseeding in the garden, and to increase productivity. Young leaves that grow in cool weather have the mildest flavor.
plants.harvesting: Gather individual leaves as needed in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Rosemary, Sage, Thyme and Lovage. Also planted with other perennial herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: For top productivity, replace plants every few years.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun in very warm locations only.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds from spring to early summer. Soya beans must have warm soil to germinate and grow.  Poke holes into a cultivated bed or row to plant soybean seeds about 5 cm (2in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. Thin to 15 cm (6in) apart in all directions.
plants.frostTolerant: No. Soya beans are a warm-season crop to grow in summer in hot climates.
plants.feeding: When using soya beans to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Soya bean green manures are used primarily to add nitrogen to poor soil.
plants.harvesting: Chop down or pull up plants just as they begin to flower if you wish to use as green manure. Nitrogen nodules left behind in the soil add fertility.  Soya Beans for consumption should be harvested when pods have filled but are still green.
plants.companions: Marigold, Sweetcorn, Celery, Strawberry and Potatoes. Buckwheat

plants.soil: Rich, moisture retentive soil which has had compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Best sown during the cooler months. Can be sown in containers during cold weather or sown direct if not too cold.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, survives winter with mulch in milder areas.
plants.feeding: Not needed for spring crops grown in rich soil, but older plants benefit from feeding with a liquid feed during the growing season, when they show vigorous new growth.
plants.notes: Keep well watered. Hot or dry conditions can make it bolt (run to seed) which reduces production of usable leaves considerably. Sow another crop in late summer/early autumn.
plants.harvesting: Pick a few leaves at a time to allow the plant to continue producing more.
plants.companions: Celery, Eggplant, Strawberry and Radish.
plants.troubleshooting: Slow growth and yellowing leaves indicate nutritional stress. Drench with a water soluble plant food.

plants.soil: Well-drained, reasonably good soil, though will tolerate a variety of sites.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in winter or early spring, planting out when all risk of frost past or direct into the soil from then onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Requires very little attention. Soak seeds in water overnight before planting to improve germination.
plants.harvesting: Pull a few leaves from the outside of the plant regularly from mid summer onwards to produce more growth.
plants.companions: Peas, Beans, Strawberry and Coriander.

plants.soil: Rich soil best but will grow in most places.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the ground in spring onwards.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Keep well watered in dry seasons.
plants.harvesting: Pull a few leaves from the outside of the plant regularly from summer onwards.
plants.companions: Strawberry, Coriander and Asparagus.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Can be started off early under cover in containers which are then planted out but usually sown direct into position.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water in dry conditions and keep weed free.
plants.harvesting: Harvest as required when they reach a usable size.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Cabbage, Silver Beet, Lettuce, Strawberry and Tomato.

plants.soil: Soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots in late winter or early spring. Plant out after last frosts.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fortnightly liquid feed from summer.
plants.notes: One or two plants is plenty - they will usually produce several squash over a season.
plants.harvesting: Harvest regularly when the squash are not too large; this encourages more to grow.
plants.companions: Borage, Lovage, Marjoram, Nasturtium, Peas, Beans, Sunflower, Sweetcorn, Tansy and Lemon Balm.

plants.latinName: Cucurbita pepo,  C. moschata, C. maxima
plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.sowPlant: Sow under cover in pots in late winter or early spring. Transfer to larger pots if necessary. Plant out in spring when no danger of frost.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Fortnightly liquid feed from mid summer onwards.
plants.notes: Towards the end of the summer raise the pumpkin off the ground by putting a piece of wood or similar under them to prevent rotting. Water roots generously in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: When the plant starts to die cut off the pumpkin leaving part of the stalk attached. Allow the skin to harden in the sun for a few days if wanting to store them in a frost-free place.
plants.companions: Borage, Lovage, Marjoram, Nasturtium, Peas, Beans, Sunflower, Sweetcorn, Tansy and Lemon Balm.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, because stevia seeds are very reluctant to sprout. Plants are grown from rooted cuttings taken from greenhouse-grown plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Stevia is a tender perennial grown as a vegetatively propagated annual. Parent plants brought through winter indoors provide rootable stems in spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed. If needed, a water soluble organic fertiliser can be provided in midsummer to invigorate plants.
plants.notes: Frequent pinching back helps to keep plants bushy and full, and it delays flowering.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in midsummer, just before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Marjoram, Thyme and Salvia. Often paired with mound-forming herbs; stevia is an upright plant.
plants.troubleshooting: Stevia thrives in warm weather, and may grow slowly under very cool conditions.

plants.soil: Well-drained rich soil with compost dug in, slightly acidic preferred.
plants.position: Sunny for best ripening, although will grow in partial shade.
plants.sowPlant: Strawberries can be grown from seed, usually during spring or autumn or crowns can be purchased ready to plant. Planting in autumn to gives them more time to establish their root system.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardy, though plants go dormant from late autumn to early spring.
plants.feeding: In autumn and again in early spring, topdress established plants with rich compost or an organic fertiliser. Allow plants to rest in midsummer.
plants.notes: Can be used as a ground cover beneath grapes or apple trees, or managed as a perpetual bed. In late summer, remove weeds and withered leaves, and thin runners to no more than 3 per plant. Lift and transplant extra runners.
plants.harvesting: Gather ripe fruits in the morning, when they are cool, and refrigerate immediately. Wash in cool water just before eating.
plants.companions: Beans, Borage, Chives, Leek, Nigella, Lettuce, Marigold, Onions, Sage, Spinach and Spring Onion.
plants.troubleshooting: Slugs can be deterred with straw mulch or traps. Use jamjars or netting to protect ripening berries from birds.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow sunflowers from spring to summer.  Poke seeds into the soil about 1 inch (3 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties. Extremely tall sunflowers or those that grow into multi-branched bushes may require 3 feet (1 meter) between plants.
plants.frostTolerant: Sunflower seedlings often escape damage from light frost, but larger plants have no tolerance of freezing temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: Explore different sunflower varieties, which vary in size, colour, growth habit, and the culinary quality of the seeds.
plants.harvesting: Cut sunflower heads when some of the seeds inside the edges appear ripe and fall away when rubbed, or when birds start harvesting them for you. Store in a warm, dry place.
plants.companions: Apricot, Cucumber, Pumpkin, Squash and Sweetcorn. A rare "shelter" plant, sunflowers can be used to create shade for sun-stressed crops. Tall varieties can serve as trellises for pole beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Sunflowers will twist around to face the most abundant source of sun, which may be away from your garden.

plants.soil: Will grow in most good soils.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into soil late summer to autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: Cold weather can improve flavour and texture.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Water well in dry periods.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the swede is well developed. In milder areas can be left in the ground, otherwise lift and store them in boxes of sand.
plants.companions: Onion, Onions, Peas and Chives.

plants.soil: Light, sandy soil best, but can adapt to any fertile, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant 'slips' that grow from sprouting tubers in late spring or early summer, after the soil is very warm.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Mix a good organic compost into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Sweet potatoes form a dense green ground cover, thriving in hot summer conditions. Tubers are often found 12 inches or more from the plant's primary crown, so dig carefully.
plants.harvesting: Dig in autumn when the soil is still warm. Cure in a warm, airy place for two weeks before storing at cool room temperatures.
plants.companions: Beans, Parsnip, Strawberry and Beetroot.

plants.soil: Warmed, well-drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Direct sow when soil has warmed and there is no longer a risk of frost.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Plant in blocks of at least 9 plants, all the same variety, to encourage pollination by the wind. Often planted with pumpkins and squash as they like similar conditions. Keep well watered in dry spells.
plants.harvesting: Harvest just before eating to get the sweetest taste, when the tassles at the top of the cobs turn brown to black. You can peel back the leaves and check the corn: if they ooze milky sap when pressed with a fingernail then they are ready.
plants.companions: Beans, Pumpkin, Squash and Sunflower.

plants.soil: Rich soil best but will grow in most places.
plants.sowPlant: Sow direct into the ground. Can be sown in containers and planted out when the soil is too cool to direct sow.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Keep well watered in dry seasons.
plants.harvesting: Pull a few leaves from the outside of the plant regularly once the plants have reached a decent size.
plants.companions: Onion, Onions, Beetroot, Cabbage, Broccoli, Brussels Sprouts, Cauliflower, Kohlrabi, Strawberry and Turnip.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil.
plants.position: A sunny spot near the back or edge of a garden bed, because tarragon is a lanky plant.
plants.sowPlant: Set out a purchased plant in spring. The best strain, called French tarragon, is propagated exclusively by rooting cuttings. At maturity, tarragon will need a 90 cm (3ft) square space.
plants.frostTolerant: A cold-hardy perennial, tarragon can survive temperatures to --30C (-20F).
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Tarragon covers itself with yellow-orange blossoms in late summer.
plants.harvesting: Gather stem tips as you need them in the kitchen. Tarragon can be dried, or you can use fresh tarragon to make flavored vinegars.
plants.companions: Eggplant. Often plantd with thyme and other low, mound-forming herbs.
plants.troubleshooting: Tarragon has few problems with pests or diseases.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in double rows, with rows spaced 10 inches (25 cm) apart. Plant seeds 2 inches (5 cm) apart and barely cover them with soil. Gradually thin to 8 inches (20 cm) apart.
plants.frostTolerant: Tatsoi can tolerate light frost, but exposure to cold temperatures in spring can trigger early bolting. In autumn, exposure to light frost can improve tatsoi's flavor.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.
plants.notes: This beautiful little mustard cousin often grows better in autumn than in spring.
plants.harvesting: Gather individual leaves, or pull whole plants for use in the kitchen.
plants.companions: Dill, Mint, Nasturtium, Sage, Lettuce, Mustard, Kale, Endive and Mizuna.
plants.troubleshooting: Use fine mesh or exclusion netting over the summer to prevent butterflies laying eggs on the underside of leaves - caterpillars can destroy these plants.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil enriched with compost.
plants.sowPlant: Start with purchased plants, or start seeds indoors in late winter to early spring. Thyme can be grown from seed, but some creeping forms are propagated only from rooted cuttings or divisions.
plants.frostTolerant: Winter hardy. Becomes dormant from autumn to spring.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a water soluble organic plant food one month after setting them out.
plants.notes: Creeping forms make sturdy ground covers. Bees are attracted to pink thyme flowers.
plants.harvesting: Gather sprigs as needed in the kitchen. Gather stems for drying in summer, before the plants bloom.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Broccoli, Strawberry, Dahlia and Dianthus.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants are often short-lived, so root a few stem cuttings each spring to always have vigorous young plants.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of added compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in winter to early spring and plant out when the risk of frost has passed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed from spring onwards.
plants.notes: Tie upright types to stakes with string to support the weight of the fruit. Remove side shoots which grow in the angle between the leaf stems and the main stem of the plant.
plants.harvesting: Pick regularly as soon as the fruits are ripe. This encourages production of more tomatoes.
plants.companions: Dill, Calendula, Marigold, Nasturtium, Borage, Basil, Mint, Monarda, Chives and Asparagus.
plants.troubleshooting: Blossom end rot patches on the bottom of fruits are a nutritional disorder best prevented by growing tomatoes in well-prepared soil with constant light moisture and the addition of a small amount of garden lime prior to planting out. Yellow leaves indicate lack of magnesium, so apply liquid feed.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of added compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in winter to early spring and plant out when the risk of frost has passed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed from spring onwards.
plants.notes: Tie upright types to stakes with string to support the weight of the fruit. Remove side shoots which grow in the angle between the leaf stems and the main stem of the plant.
plants.harvesting: Pick regularly as soon as the fruits are ripe. This encourages production of more tomatoes.
plants.companions: Marigold, Borage, Basil, Mint, Parsley, Asparagus, Chives, Monarda, Dill and Calendula.
plants.troubleshooting: Blossom end rot patches on the bottom of fruits are a nutritional disorder best prevented by growing tomatoes in well-prepared soil with constant light moisture and the addition of a small amount of garden lime prior to planting out. Yellow leaves indicate lack of magnesium, so apply liquid feed.

plants.soil: Almost any soil.
plants.sowPlant: Large trees are usually already well established.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches.

plants.soil: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of compost or other organic matter.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in mid autumn or early winter when it's not too cold for a little root growth to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not required, unless closely spaced or just planted.
plants.notes: Prune towards the end of the season to remove any dead or overcrowded branches and to shape if required.

plants.soil: Any reasonably fertile well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Best sown direct. Can be sown in all but the hottest and coldest months.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, survives mild frosts, can protect with straw.
plants.feeding: Not usually required.
plants.notes: Keep watered in dry weather.
plants.harvesting: Can be harvested once roots have attained sufficient size. Turnips left in the ground for too long will become woody.
plants.companions: Cucumber, Lettuce, Nasturtium, Peas and Corn salad.
plants.troubleshooting: Spring crops bolt to seed quickly, so pull them when the roots are perfect.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant, or start seeds indoors and set out seedlings two to four weeks before your last frost. After two years, valerian will grow into a 18" (45 cm) wide clump.
plants.frostTolerant: Extremely cold hardy, even in harsh winter climates. Plants die back to the ground in winter and re-emerge in spring.
plants.feeding: Not generally needed.
plants.notes: Valerian produces extremely fragrant flowers in early summer. Gather them for use as cut flowers to keep valerian from reseeding and becoming invasive.
plants.harvesting: Dig roots in fall or early spring and dry outdoors, because they release an unpleasant smell as they dry. Store in airtight container. Dried valerian roots are used to make a bedtime tea that promotes sleep. They are also much loved by cats and dogs.
plants.companions: Cosmos, Agastache and Catnip. Often paired with low, mound-forming herbs and flowers. Valerian can stand 1.5 meters (5ft) tall when it is in full bloom.
plants.troubleshooting: Control valerian's spread by cutting back flowering stems before they can shed seeds in your garden.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but flowers can be damaged by late frosts.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Healthy walnut trees will bear for many decades.
plants.harvesting: Knock down nuts when ripe, remove the peel and dry. If pickling, harvest while it is still possible to pierce the nuts with a skewer.
plants.companions: Persimmon. Can restrict growth in other plants nearby, because many plants (including tomatoes) are sensitive to juglone, a substance present in walnut roots, leaves and wood. Walnuts should be grown in an orchard of their own, far from the vegetable garden.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in late summer or early autumn for an overwintered crop. Spring wheat can be planted while the soil is still cool.  Broadcast seed into cultivated soil so that the seeds are about 7 cm (3in) apart and 1 cm (1/2in) deep. No thinning is required. Increase spacing to 20cm (8in) apart when growing wheat with other green manures.
plants.frostTolerant: Many varieties are cold hardy to - 23C (-10F) when well rooted in the garden. Grow varieties described as soft spring wheat in spring, but choose hard winter wheat for autumn.
plants.feeding: When using wheat to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase organic matter, break up dense subsoil and crowd out weeds. Makes a beautiful show in spring.
plants.harvesting: Mow down plants in spring, before they develop seeds. Or, gather the immature seed tops and dry them for arrangements, and then pull up the plants. They can be used as mulch or composted.
plants.companions: Hairy Vetch, Faba Bean, Oats, Cornflower and Field Peas.
plants.troubleshooting: Deer often nibble wheat grown in winter.

plants.soil: Rich soil with compost dug in. pH of 6 to 6.5 preferred.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in winter to help them establish.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes but cover if a severe frost is forecast.
plants.feeding: May need potash (potassium) adding, particularly if the leaves start to brown at the edges.
plants.notes: After harvesting prune the bush back to five leaves on each side shoot and remove any dead or overcrowded branches to 'open up' the plant.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when ripe, will freeze well.
plants.companions: Marigold.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Poke holes in prepared seedbed and plant seeds 5 cm (2in) deep. Faba beans may be planted in late summer, or in very early spring.  In milder areas they can be planted quite late into autumn.
plants.frostTolerant: A cool-season annual, Faba beans can tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: When using Faba beans to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase soil nitrogen. Easier to turn under using hand tools compared to other green manures.  Small-seeded varieties are best for green manure use.
plants.harvesting: For maximum nitrogen gain, chop plants down and turn them under as soon as they begin to bloom.  You also can pull up the plants and compost them.
plants.companions: Cabbage, Carrot, Celery, Sweetcorn, Potatoes, Nasturtium and Lovage. Sometimes planted with wheat, cereal rye, oats
plants.troubleshooting: Faba beans attract numerous beneficial insects. Do not grow them just before potatoes or other root crops, because Faba beans can host rootknot nematodes.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Poke holes in prepared seedbed and plant seeds 3 to 5 cm (1 to 2in) deep. Gaps between plants can be filled with an upright grain.
plants.frostTolerant: A cool-season annual, field peas (Austrian peas), can tolerate heavy frost but are killed by temperatures below -17 to -23C (0 to -10F).
plants.feeding: When using field peas to improve very poor soil, mixing a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting will give better results.
plants.notes: Primarily grown to increase soil nitrogen. Highly recommended as a winter green manure to go before sweet corn because of its vigorous nitrogen-fixing activity in early spring. Very low weedy potential compared to other green manures.
plants.harvesting: For maximum nitrogen gain, chop plants down and turn them under as soon as they begin to bloom.  You also can pull up the plants and compost them.
plants.companions: Turnip, Faba Bean, Oats and Wheat. Sometimes planted with wheat, cereal rye, oats.
plants.troubleshooting: Allow at least 3 weeks after turning under field pea residue before direct-seeding vegetables, because the rotting vegetation can cause an increase in damping off of seedlings.

plants.soil: Any sunny site with good drainage.
plants.sowPlant: Plant zinnias in spring, after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.  Start seeds indoors in individual containers, set out purchased plants, or direct-sow into warm soil. Poke seeds into the soil about one-half inch (1 cm) deep and 3 inches (8 cm) apart. Thin to 12 inches (30 cm) apart in all directions for dwarf varieties. Zinnia varieties that grow more than 24 inches (60) cm) tall require 18 inches (45 cm) between plants.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Zinnias cannot tolerate cold temperatures.
plants.feeding: Mix a light application of a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil prior to planting.  In midsummer, drench plants with a high-nitrogen liquid fertiliser to stimulate strong reblooming.
plants.notes: Frequent cutting of blossoms helps many varieties to rebloom constantly for many weeks. Butterflies prefer flat, single zinnia blossoms over "double" varieties that are packed with petals.
plants.harvesting: Gather zinnias for use in arrangements just as the petals open. The true flowers are the tiny yellow florets, which pump out nectar for butterflies.
plants.companions: Tomato, Capsicum and Beans. Sometimes planted with dill, fennel and other upright herbs, bush snap beans, chard. Tall, single-flowered varieties attract butterflies.
plants.troubleshooting: Older zinnias often become infected with powdery mildew. Pull up and compost diseased plants. Many hybrids offer some resistance to powdery mildew.

plants.soil: Average, well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds 2 inches deep and 4 inches apart two weeks or more after the last frost has passed. Grow pole varieties in warm climates, but stick with faster-maturing bush varieties where summers are short.
plants.frostTolerant: Warm-season annuals, cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Mix an organic fertiliser into the soil before planting, using rates given on the label. Supplemental fertiliser seldom required.
plants.notes: Lima beans need plenty of hot weather. They are most productive in warm climates.
plants.harvesting: For fresh eating, gather pods when they feel well-filled with seeds, and are slightly leathery. Limas for dry storage can be left on the plants until they change from green to tan.
plants.companions: Sweetcorn. Sometimes planted with Marigold and Squash.
plants.troubleshooting: Slow growth due to cool temperatures is common, but pest problems are rare. Lima beans are easy to grow in warm climates.

plants.soil: Fertile, well-drained soil with plenty of well rotted compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Sow indoors in spring and set out when plants have 5 leaves. Start another planting indoors in midsummer, and set out in early fall.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes.
plants.feeding: Not usually required, but may be needed if plants grow slowly even though the weather is comfortably warm.
plants.notes: The flavor of collards is improved by cool temperatures, so fall is the preferred time to grow this crop.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves individually, when they are about the size of your hand.
plants.companions: Tomato, Sage, Garlic, Onion, Onions, Chives, Rosemary, Mint and Nasturtium.
plants.troubleshooting: In warm weather, caterpillars may feed on leaves. Exclude them with floating row covers. In cool weather, watch for outbreaks of gray-green cabbage aphids in leaf crevices. Pick off and compost badly infested leaves.

plants.soil: Rich soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow directly when the soil is warm. In cooler climates start seed indoors and transplant out after the last frost, being careful not to disturb the roots. Water very well before planting.
plants.frostTolerant: Cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting cotton. In midsummer when flowering begins, topdress with more fertiliser or drench with a liquid plant food.
plants.notes: Cotton thrives on heat, but does not respond well to overwatering. In cool climates, grow individual cotton plants in large, dark-coloured containers to increase root warmth.
plants.harvesting: Harvest after bolls split open, during a period of dry weather. Cut cotton on long stems and dry in bunches, like herbs.
plants.companions: Basil, Garlic, Coriander, Mint, Sage, Dill, Onion, Onions and Sunflower.
plants.troubleshooting: Night-flying beetles often chew holes in cotton leaves, but this problem is mostly cosmetic.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained soil that holds moisture well.
plants.sowPlant: Purchase dormant plants and set them out in early spring. Plants grown in containers can be transplanted through early summer. Mulch after planting new fruits.
plants.frostTolerant: Cold tolerance varies widely with species. Choose regionally-adapted trellised fruits, for example bunch grapes in cold winter areas, or muscadine grapes where winters are mild.
plants.feeding: In early spring, mulch over root zone with 1 to 2 inches of good compost. Mulch with grass clippings or straw.
plants.notes: Obtain local expertise before choosing which fruits to grow. University-based breeding programs have developed many great-tasting, disease-resistant varieties.
plants.harvesting: Let experience be your teacher -- taste fruits often as they approach ripeness. Bumper crops can be frozen, dried, or made into jams and jellies.
plants.companions: Strawberries, thyme.
plants.troubleshooting: In winter, use poultry netting (chicken wire) to protect young plants from deer, voles, and rabbits.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil enriched with plenty of compost.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in late spring or early summer, either in rows or hills. Also may be started from seedlings started indoors or purchased at stores.
plants.frostTolerant: Cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Drench plants with a liquid fertiliser when they begin to blossom and set fruits.
plants.notes: Most gourds grow into large, long-vined plants. Growing long gourds on a trellis helps them keep their shape. Grow at the edge of your garden to save space.
plants.harvesting: Harvest gourds as late as possible, because gourds will not cure and store unless they are totally ripe. Cut gourds with a bit of stem attached, and move to a dry place to cure through winter.
plants.companions: Radish, Catnip, Broccoli, Tansy, Dill and Marigold.

plants.soil: Deep, enriched, sandy loam
plants.sowPlant: Plant a fresh root from early to late spring.
plants.frostTolerant: Tender, Does best in warm, humid climates.
plants.feeding: None generally needed
plants.notes: Can be invasive if left unharvested
plants.harvesting: As soon as you see new shoots coming up to the side of the main plant, start harvesting young rhizomes. In autumn, dig up the whole pant, harvest the bulk of the rhizomes and save a few for replanting.
plants.companions: Crimson Clover, Peas, Coriander, Beans, Lemon grass and Chilli.

plants.soil: Any well drained soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant and transplant it from early spring to mid summer. Seed can also be started in containers preferably during spring and summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Roots semi hardy, leaves tender. Dies back in cold winter areas.
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.notes: Lemon grass loves being cut back and this will encourage more growth. Mulch well in cold winter areas.
plants.harvesting: Leave the plant to develop some thick stems before starting to harvest.
plants.companions: Coriander, Basil, Thyme, Mint, Lemon Verbena, Echinacea and Marigold.

plants.soil: Well-drained soil enriched with plenty of compost to lower pH.
plants.sowPlant: Start indoors and transplant outdoors into a hill or mound after the soil has warmed. In warm climates peanuts can be direct sown in spring and summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Cannot tolerate frost.
plants.feeding: Rarely necessary. Peanuts are a nitrogen-fixing legume.
plants.notes: Peanuts require at least 120 days of hot weather and ample rainfall to crop well. Regular shallow hoeing is needed to keep the soil around the plants loose and free of weeds, because the stems of peanut flowers bend over and "plant" themselves in the soil.
plants.harvesting: Harvest when the leaves turn yellow and die back, or immediately after the first frost. Shake off soil, gently rinsing if necessary, and dry the whole plants in a warm, well-ventilated area for one to two weeks. Remove the peanuts, and continue drying them in a single layer until the shells are crisp. Moldy nuts should be disposed of immediately as they can be toxic.
plants.companions: Beetroot, Carrot, Celeriac, Celery, Sweetcorn, Cucumber, Eggplant, Lettuce, Marigold, Peas, Potatoes, Radish, Rosemary, Strawberry and Tansy.

plants.soil: Fertile, well drained sandy loam is ideal.
plants.sowPlant: Prepare a large hole by breaking up the soil and adding plenty of well-rotted organic matter. A wide hole is better than a very deep one. Mulch after planting, and encircle the trunk with a wire cage or protective pipe to protect the young tree from animal and insect pests.
plants.frostTolerant: Yes, but cultivars should be chosen that fit the climate. Some pecans are much more cold tolerant than others.
plants.feeding: Mulch with well-rotted organic matter in spring.
plants.notes: Pecans are outstanding nut-producing landscape trees in much of the Southeast USA. Pecan trees will bear for decades. It takes 20 years for a pecan tree to grow to maturity.
plants.harvesting: Gather nuts as they fall to the ground. Allow them to dry in a place that is protected from rain.
plants.companions: Pecans are large, spreading trees that make good shade trees in large landscapes.
plants.troubleshooting: Pecans grow best in warm, humid climates. In cool climate pecans may not produce nuts, and may suffer from coral spot.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors or sow them where you want plants to grow. Radicchio grows best when temperatures are cool.
plants.frostTolerant: Tolerates frost but is injured by hard freezes.
plants.feeding: Drench with an organic liquid plant food when heads begin to form.
plants.notes: In early winter, plants can be lifted and grown indoors during winter.
plants.harvesting: Some varieties are more bolt resistant than others when grown in spring.
plants.companions: Endive, Mizuna, Tatsoi and Mustard.
plants.troubleshooting: Bitter flavor is often due to hot weather.

plants.soil: Any average, well drained soil.
plants.position: Full sun to partial afternoon shade.
plants.sowPlant: Plant seeds in spring, after the soil has warmed. In cool climates, you can give plants a two-week head start indoors. After the first season, look for volunteer seedlings and move them to where you want them to grow.
plants.frostTolerant: Climbing spinach is a tropical plant that tolerates neither frost nor cold soil.
plants.feeding: Mix in a balanced organic fertiliser when preparing the planting site.
plants.notes: Climbing spinach is highly ornamental, and is easily trained up a trellis. Some varieties have red stems.   Climbing spinach is typically grown on a tower, fence or tepee style trellis.  Four trellised plants will occupy a space 18 inches (45 cm) square at maturity.
plants.harvesting: Clip leaves as you need them in the kitchen. When lightly steamed or stir-fried, the leaves resemble a cross between spinach and chard.
plants.companions: Peas. Climbing spinach is a vigorous climbing plant that needs a trellis or other support. It will quickly overtake other plants.
plants.troubleshooting: In the fall, gather up dead plants and compost them to limit reseeding in the garden. In some climates, climbing spinach can become weedy.

plants.soil: Well drained fertile soil
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant. It will spread if not cut back. If allowed to it will self seed.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.notes: Repels harmful insects. Yellow button flowers attract beneficial insects, especially ladybirds. Use trimmings as mulch and to confuse birds on newly seeded areas.
plants.harvesting: Harvest leaves as and when needed, Cut back in spring.
plants.companions: Cabbage.

plants.soil: Average garden soil.
plants.sowPlant: Start seeds indoors in late winter to spring and set seedlings out after the last frost has passed and the soil is warm.  Set plants about 3 feet (1 m) apart. Grow at least two plants, spaced close together, to insure good pollination.
plants.frostTolerant: None. Tomatillos are tropical plants that require warm conditions.
plants.feeding: Mix a balanced organic fertiliser into the soil before planting.
plants.notes: Tomatillos can reseed if allowed to do so, but extra seedlings are easy to lift and move or pull out.
plants.harvesting: After the outer husks of some fruit turn from green to tan, look for ripe tomatillos that have fallen to the ground. Gather and store in the refrigerator for up to two weeks.  Wash before cooking to remove sticky residue.
plants.companions: Sunflower. Also grown with sweet corn. Depending on climate and soil, plants can grow up to 4 feet (1.3 m) tall and wide.
plants.troubleshooting: Plants sometimes wait until late in the season to bear an abundance of fruits. Slightly green (immature) tomatillos have the tart citrus flavor most people prefer.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added. Often grown in widely spaced enriched hills, or in well-aged compost heaps that include some soil.
plants.sowPlant: Sow seeds 1 inch deep in rows, or in hills spaced 6 feet apart. After 2 weeks, thin to 2 plants per hill.  If your growing season is short they can be started indoors in pots to get a head start.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Fruit size varies with variety. Small watermelons mature quickly and take up less space compared to huge watermelons.
plants.harvesting: Ripe watermelons sound deep and resonant when tapped, and the curled tendril opposite the melon should be brown. Wipe clean and store indoors.
plants.companions: Potatoes, Sweetcorn, Radish and Beans.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds early and then mulch to avoid trampling the vines after fruits have set.

plants.soil: Will grow in any soil
plants.sowPlant: Start with a purchased plant and transplant it from early spring to mid summer.
plants.frostTolerant: Hardy
plants.feeding: None generally needed.
plants.notes: It is a nutrient accumulator and has a beneficial effect on most plants near it.
plants.harvesting: Pick leaves as and when needed for medicinal use. Cut flowers for arrangements.
plants.companions: Lavender, Rosemary, Marjoram, Oregano, Lemon and Stock.

plants.soil: Rich, moisture-retentive soil with plenty of compost dug in.
plants.sowPlant: Best direct sown once soil has warmed and there is no longer a risk of frost. If your growing season is short they can be started inside in pots to get a head start.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: After plants set fruit, feed twice, at two week intervals, with a water soluble plant food.
plants.notes: Keep moist by watering regularly. Pinch out the growing tip once the plant has made three leaves and do the same to side shoots as they appear.
plants.harvesting: Harvest fruit when it slips from the stem.
plants.companions: Beans and Sweetcorn.
plants.troubleshooting: Control weeds early and then mulch to avoid trampling the vines after fruits have set.

plants.soil: Rich soil with plenty of compost added.
plants.position: Sheltered sunny position or under cover.
plants.sowPlant: Sow in pots under cover in late winter to early spring. Transfer to bigger pots as required. If planting out then do so when soil has warmed and risk of frost has passed.
plants.frostTolerant: No.
plants.feeding: Weekly liquid feed once the plant is a reasonable size.
plants.notes: Sometimes require supports if the chillies are large.
plants.harvesting: Harvest chillies green when they have grown to a good size or wait for them to ripen to yellow, orange or red if preferred.
plants.companions: Carrot, Onion, Onions, Leek, Tomato and Ginger.

plants.soil: Rijke, lichte grond waaraan veel organisch materiaal is toegevoegd.
plants.sowPlant: Voeg veel goed verteerd organisch materiaal toe bij het planten. Een wijd gat is beter dan een heel diep gat. Bedek de bodem na het planten en plaats een draadkooi of een plastic buis rond de stam om de jonge boom tegen ongedierte- en insectenplagen te beschermen.
plants.frostTolerant: Ja, maar het is belangrijk om de rassen te kiezen waarvan bekend is dat ze goed groeien in uw omgeving om het risico op bevriezing in de lente en daardoor kapotte bloemen te verkleinen. Kouschade bij lente bloesems is een belangrijke factor in het bepalen waar amandelen succesvol geteeld kunnen worden.
plants.feeding: Bedek de bodem in de lente met een flinke laag bodembeddeking van goed verteerd organisch materiaal in combinatie met een gebalanceerde organische bemesting.
plants.notes: Amandelen kunnen het beste met de hand bestoven worden wanneer er maar één of twee planten geteeld worden. Gezonde amandelbomen kunnen tien tot vijftien jaar of meer dragen.
plants.harvesting: Sla de noten naar beneden wanneer ze beginnen te vallen, daarna kunnen ze worden gepeld en gedroogd.
plants.companions: Rijen in de boomgaard die beplant zijn met klaver en andere peulvruchten dragen bij aan de vruchtbaarheid van de grond en trekken bestuivers aan.
plants.troubleshooting: Het kan helpen om de amandelbomen droog te houden onder een dak of plastic plaat in het tegengaan van de perzikkrulziekte en rottend fruit.

plants.soil: Doorsnee tuingrond.
plants.sowPlant: Zaai schildzaad van de vroege lente tot de vroege zomer en bij milde winters in de herfst. Schildzaad groeit snel en houdt vaak op met bloeien in heet weer. Zaai breedwerpig in voorbewerkte grond of bakken, op ongeveer 5 cm afstand van elkaar en bedek ze met een dun laagje grond. Wanneer de zaailingen meer dan vier bladeren hebben, kunt u ze uitdunnen tot een afstand van 15 cm in alle richtingen.
plants.frostTolerant: Schildzaad zaailingen kunnen tegen lichte vorst, maar de planten gaan wel dood van temperaturen onder het vriespunt.
plants.feeding: Snelle groei wordt gestimuleerd door voor het planten een gebalanceerde organische bemesting aan de grond toe te voegen. Stimuleer herbloeien met vloeibare voeding.
plants.notes: Kan uitzaaien als ze de kans krijgt, maar extra zaailingen kunnen makkelijk verwijderd of verplaatst worden.
plants.harvesting: Vermoeide schildzaad planten vergaan meestal in hete, vochtige omstandigheden. Als de plant eenjarige bloemen heeft, bloeien die meestal kort.
plants.companions: Erwten, Sla en Spinazie. De witte en pastel gekleurde schildzaadbloemen staan mooi in de hoekjes van uw plantenbedden, of u kunt ze onder hoge groenteplanten of tussen kruiden laten groeien. Schildzaad staat erom bekend dat ze kleine wespen en andere nuttige insecten aantrekt.

plants.soil: Maak een groot gat door de grond los te woelen en voeg veel compost of ander organisch materiaal toe.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in midden herfst of vroege winter als het niet te koud is voor de wortels om zich goed te ontwikkelen. Moet met in elk geval één andere appelboom geplant worden die op hetzelfde moment bloeit om bestuiving te stimuleren.
plants.frostTolerant: Ja
plants.feeding: Niet nodig, tenzij ze dichtbij andere planten staan of net zijn geplant.
plants.notes: Snoei aan het einde van het seizoen om dode of overtollige takken te verwijderen of eventueel naar gewenste vorm.
plants.harvesting: Oogsten als de appels rijp zijn.
plants.companions: Bieslook, Oost-Indische Kers, Lavendel en Knoflook.

plants.soil: Maak een groot gat door de grond los te woelen en voeg veel compost of ander organisch materiaal toe.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in midden herfst of vroege winter als het niet te koud is voor de wortels om zich goed te ontwikkelen. Moet met in elk geval één andere appelboom geplant worden die op hetzelfde moment bloeit om bestuiving te stimuleren.
plants.frostTolerant: Ja
plants.feeding: Normaalgesproken niet nodig.
plants.notes: Snoei aan het einde van het seizoen om dode of overtollige takken te verwijderen of eventueel naar gewenste vorm.
plants.harvesting: Oogsten als de appels rijp zijn.
plants.companions: Bieslook, Oost-Indische Kers, Lavendel en Knoflook.

plants.soil: Maak een groot gat door de grond los te woelen en voeg veel compost of ander organisch materiaal toe.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in midden herfst of vroege winter als het niet te koud is voor de wortels om zich goed te ontwikkelen. Moet met in elk geval één andere appelboom geplant worden die op hetzelfde moment bloeit om bestuiving te stimuleren.
plants.frostTolerant: Ja
plants.feeding: Niet nodig, tenzij ze dichtbij andere planten staan of net zijn geplant.
plants.notes: Snoei aan het einde van het seizoen om dode of overtollige takken te verwijderen of eventueel naar gewenste vorm.
plants.harvesting: Oogsten als de appels rijp zijn.
plants.companions: Bieslook, Oost-Indische Kers, Lavendel en Knoflook.

plants.soil: Maak een groot gat door de grond los te woelen en voeg veel compost of ander organisch materiaal toe.
plants.sowPlant: Plant in midden herfst of vroege winter als het niet te koud is voor de wortels  om zich goed te ontwikkelen. Moet met in elk geval één andere appelboom geplant worden die op hetzelfde moment bloeit om bestuiving te stimuleren.
plants.frostTolerant: Ja
plants.feeding: Normaalgesproken niet nodig.
plants.notes: Snoei aan het einde van het seizoen om dode of overtollige takken te verwijderen of eventueel naar gewenste vorm.
plants.harvesting: Oogsten als de appels rijp zijn.
plants.companions: Bieslook, Oost-Indische Kers, Lavendel en Knoflook.

plants.soil: Diepe, vochtvasthoudende maar goed afgewaterde, licht alkalische grond.
plants.position: Groeien het beste tegen een zuidelijk gelegen muur in koelere klimaten. Op andere plekken hebben abrikozen veel zon nodig om ziekten tegen te gaan en om fruit van hoge kwaliteit te produceren.
plants.sowPlant: Maak een groot gat door de grond los te woelen en voeg veel compost of ander organisch materiaal toe. Een wijd gat is beter dan een heel diep gat. Bedek de bodem na het planten en doe een draadkooi of een plastic buis rond de stam om de jonge boom tegen ongedierte- en insectenplagen te beschermen. Jonge abrikozenbomen zijn zeer vatbaar voor schade van insecten die gaten in de stam boren.
plants.frostTolerant: Ja, maar het is belangrijk om de soorten te kiezen waarvan bekend is dat ze goed groeien in uw omgeving om het risico op bevriezing in de lente en daardoor kapotte bloemen te verkleinen Kouschade bij lente bloesems is een belangrijke factor in het bepalen waar abrikozen succesvol geteeld kunnen worden.
plants.feeding: Voed met organische mest in de vroege lente. Hou het gebied rond de abrikozen goed bedekt met houtsnippers, stro of een andere bodembedekking die helpt om de grond vochtig te houden.
plants.notes: Snoei in de lente of late zomer in koelere klimaten. Op andere plekken kunnen abrikozen in de late winter gesnoeid worden. Gezonde abrikozen kunnen van tien tot vijftien jaar of langer dragen.
plants.harvesting: Oogsten wanneer het fruit zacht is en makkelijk van de boom geplukt kan worden. Rijpe abrikozen zullen op de grond vallen.
plants.companions: Basilicum en Knoflook. Rijen in de boomgaard die beplant zijn met klaver en andere peulvruchten dragen bij aan de vruchtbaarheid van de grond en trekken bestuivers aan.
plants.troubleshooting: Bossterfte en gomziekte kunnen vaak verholpen worden door de teeltomstandigheden te verbeteren. Bodembedekking, bewateren, voeden, wieden en goed snoeien kan helpen. In vochtige klimaten ontwikkelen abrikozen vaak problemen met schimmelziektes zoals bruinrot. Preventieve sprays met biologische schimmeldodende middelen zijn vaak nodig om goede kwaliteit abrikozen te kweken.

plants.soil: Diepe, vochtvasthoudende maar goed afgewaterde, licht alkalische grond.
plants.position: Groeien het beste tegen een zuidelijk gelegen muur in koelere klimaten. Op andere plekken hebben abrikozen veel zon nodig om ziekten tegen te gaan en om fruit van hoge kwaliteit te produceren.

Bedek de bodem na het planten en doe een draadkooi of een plastic buis rond de stam om de jonge boom tegen ongedierte- en insectenplagen te beschermen. Jonge abrikozenbomen zijn zeer vatbaar voor schade van insecten die gaten in de stam boren.

plants.notes: Snoei in de lente of late zomer in koelere klimaten. Op andere plekken kunnen abrikozen in de late winter gesnoeid worden. Gezonde abrikozen kunnen van tien tot vijftien jaar of langer dragen.
plants.harvesting: Oogsten wanneer het fruit zacht is en makkelijk van de boom geplukt kan worden. Rijpe abrikozen zullen op de grond vallen.
